I am in the middle of the body, idle and inactive,
Always putting away the meat, without ever supporting
Like working with the rest, where the other instruments
I saw and heard, conceived, instructed, walked, felt,
And, mutually participating, the minister
To common appetite and affection
Of the whole body. The belly replied:

First citizen:
Well, sir, what response did the stomach make?

MENNIUS:
Sir, I will tell you. With a kind of smile,
Which never came from the lungs, but still...
Cause, look at you, I can make your belly smile
In addition to speaking - he responded in a mocking tone
To the discontented, to the mutineers
This envied his receipt; Still, it’s very appropriate.
While you slander our senators for this
They are not like you.

First citizen:
Your stomach's response? What!
The royally crowned head, the vigilant eye,
The heart advises, the arm our soldier,
Our horse is the leg, the tongue is our trumpet.
With other ammunition and small aids
In our fabric, if that's the case, they...

MENNIUS:
So what ?
“For me, this guy speaks!” So what ? so what ?

First citizen:
If the cormorant's belly were to be restrained,
Who is the sink of the body, -

MENNIUS:
Well, so what?

First citizen:
The former agents, if they complained,
What could the stomach say?

MENNIUS:
I am going to tell you
If you give a little of what you have little,
Be patient a little, you will hear the response from your stomach.

First citizen:
You've been talking about it for a long time.

MENNIUS:
Note this to me, good friend;
Your most serious stomach was deliberate,
Not reckless like his accusers, and he replied thus:
“It is true, my incorporated friends,” he said,
'Let me first receive the general food,
On which you live; and he is in good shape,
Because I am the store and the boutique
Of the whole body: but, if you remember,
I send it through the rivers of your blood,
Even at court, in the heart, in the seat of the brain;
And, through the cranks and desks of man,
The strongest nerves and small inferior veins
From me receive this natural skill
What they live by: and although suddenly,
You, my good friends, said the belly, notice me,

First citizen:
Yes sir ; well well.

MENNIUS:
"Even if suddenly I can't
See what I deliver to everyone,
However, I can invent my audit, that's all
Receive from me the flour of all,
And only leaves me the sound. What do you say ?

First citizen:
It was an answer: how do you apply this?

MENNIUS:
The senators of Rome are this good belly,
And you, the mutinous members; for exam
Their advice and care digest things well
By touching the wealth of the common, you will find
No public benefits you receive
But it proceeds or comes from them to you
And no way on your part. What do you think,
You, the big toe of this assembly?

First citizen:
Me big toe! why the big toe?

MENNIUS:
For this, being one of the lowest, lowest, poorest,
Of this wisest rebellion, you are the first:
You rascal, who is the worst blood to run,
Lead first to gain an advantage.
But prepare your snowshoes and your stiff clubs:
Rome and its rats are about to fight;
One side must have a ball.
Hail, noble Marcius!

MARCIUS:
THANKS. What is it, dissident rascals,
This, rubbing the poor itch of your opinion,
Do you make crusts?

First citizen:
We always have your good word.

MARCIUS:
He who gives you good words will flatter
Below abhorrent. What would you like, bastards,
Doesn’t that sound like peace or war? the one who scares you,
The other makes you proud. The one who trusts you,
Where he should find you lions, he finds you hares;
Where are the foxes, the geese: you are no more sure, no,
Than the burning coal on the ice,
Or hail in the sun. Your virtue is
To dignify him whose offense subjects him
And cursed that justice did it.
Who deserves greatness
Deserves your hatred; and your affections are
The appetite of a sick man, who desires this most
Which would increase his pain. Him, it depends
On your favors swim with fins of lead
And he cuts down the oaks with rushes. Hang in there! Do you trust?
Every minute you change your mind,
And call him noble, which was now your hatred,
Him vile was your garland. What is the problem,
That in these different places of the city
You cry out against the noble Senate, which,
Under the gods, keeps you in awe, what else
Would they feed on each other? What are they looking for?

MENNIUS:
For corn at their own rates; of what, they say,
The city is well stocked.

MARCIUS:
Hang them! They say!
They'll sit by the fire and pretend to know
What happened at the Capitol? who likes to get up,
Who prospers and who declines? secondary factions
and give
Conjectural marriages; make parties strong
And the weak who are not to their liking
Under their cobbled shoes. They say there is
enough cereal!
Would the nobility put aside its cruelty,
And let me use my sword, I'll make a career
With thousands of these quartered slaves, so high
How I could choose my spear.

MENNIUS:
Moreover, they are almost completely convinced;
For although they are abundantly lacking in discretion,
Yet they pass cowardly. But I beg you,
What does the other troop say?

MARCIUS:
They are dissolved: hang them!
They said they were hungry; sighed proverbs,
This hunger has broken down the stone walls, which dogs must eat,
This meat was made for mouths, which the gods did not send
Corn reserved for rich men: with these shreds
They expressed their complaints; to which being answered,
And a petition was granted to them, a strange petition...
To break the heart of generosity,
And make the bold power pale - they have thrown away their caps
As they would hang them on the horns of the moon,
Shouting their emulation.

MENNIUS:
What is granted to them?

MARCIUS:
Five tribunes to defend their vulgar wisdom,
Of their choice: their Junius Brutus,
Sicinius Velutus, and I don't know... "Dead!"
The populace should have first opened the roof of the city,
Before it prevailed over me: it will in time
Gain Power and Launch Bigger Themes
We argue about the insurrection.

MENNIUS:
This is strange.

MARCIUS:
Come on, go home, fragments!

Messenger:
Where is Caius Marcius?

MARCIUS:
Here: what is there?

Messenger:
The news, sir, is that the Volscians are in arms.

MARCIUS:
I'm happy with that: then we'll have ways to let off steam
Our moldy superfluity. See, our best elders.

First senator:
Marcius, it is true that you told us this recently;
The Volscians are in arms.

MARCIUS:
They have a leader,
Tullus Aufidius, this will encourage you.
I sin by envying his nobility,
And if I were something other than what I am,
I would only wish for him.

COMINIUS:
You fought together.

MARCIUS:
Were half or half the world by the ears and him.
At my party, I would rebel to do
Only my wars with him: he's a lion
That I am proud to hunt.

First senator:
Then, worthy Marcius,
Witness Cominius in these wars.

COMINIUS:
This is your old promise.

MARCIUS:
Sir, it is true;
And I am consistent. Titus Lartius, you
I will see myself once again punching Tullus in the face.
What, are you stiff? do you stand out?

TITUS:
No, Caius Marcius;
I will lean on one crutch and fight with the other,
We will stand behind this matter.

MENNIUS:
O true blood!

First senator:
Your company at the Capitol; where, I know,
Our greatest friends assist us.

TITUS:

COMINIUS:
Noble Marcius!

First senator:

MARCIUS:
No, let them follow:
The Volscians have a lot of wheat; take those rats there
To gnaw their attics. Venerable mutineers,
Your value manifests: pray, follow.

SICINIUS:
Was man ever as proud as Marcius?

BRUTUS:
He has no equal.

SICINIUS:
When we were elected tribunes of the people,

BRUTUS:
Have you marked his lips and eyes?

SICINIUS:
No. but his taunts.

BRUTUS:
Moved, he will not spare to gird the gods.

SICINIUS:
Make fun of the modest moon.

BRUTUS:
The current wars devour him: he has grown
Too proud to be so valiant.

SICINIUS:
Such nature,
Tickled by success, disdains the shadow
On which he walks at noon: but I wonder
His insolence can be commanded
Under Cominius.

BRUTUS:
The fame, at which he aims,
In whom he is already well pardoned, he cannot
Better to be detained nor more affected than by
A place below the first: what causes a miscarriage
It will be the general's fault, even if he executes
To the maximum of one man, and dizzying censorship
Then go shout out Marcius 'O if he
I had put up with it! »

SICINIUS:
Additionally, if all goes well,
The opinion which sticks so closely to Marcius must
Deprive Cominius of his demerits.

BRUTUS:
Come:
Half of all Cominius honors go to Marcius.
Although Marcius did not deserve them, and all his faults
Marcius will be honored, even if indeed
He deserves nothing in any way.

SICINIUS:
Let's go and listen
How shipping is carried out and in what manner,
More than its singularity, it will
On this present action.

BRUTUS:
Let's go.

First senator:
So your opinion is, Aufidius,
That they from Rome are registered in our councils
And know how we do it.

AUFIDIUS:
It's not yours?
Whatever anyone ever thought in this state,
This could be brought to a bodily act before Rome
Was there a workaround? It hasn't been four days
Since I heard about it; here are the words: I think
I have the letter here; Yes it's here.
“They put pressure on a power, but we don’t know it
Whether in the East or in the West: the scarcity is great;
The people mutiny; and it's the rumor,
Cominius, Marcius your old enemy,
Who is more hated from Rome than from you,
And Titus Lartius, a very valiant Roman,
These three lead this preparation
Where is it leaning: This is probably for you:
Think about it.

First senator:
Our army is on the ground
We never doubted yet but Rome was ready
To answer us.

AUFIDIUS:
You didn't think it was crazy either
To keep your grand pretensions veiled until when
Their needs must be manifested; which
upon hatching,
It seemed, seemed in Rome. Through discovery.
We will be shortened in our goal, which was
To visit in many cities before almost Rome
I should have known we were on foot.

Second senator:
Noble Aufidius,
Take your commission; Hello to your groups:
Let's leave ourselves alone to guard Corioli:
If they have filed before, for withdrawal
Bring your army; but I think you will find
They didn't prepare for us.

AUFIDIUS:
Oh, doubt it not;
I'm talking about certainties. No, even more,
Some bits of their power have already gone out,
And only so far. I leave your honors.
If we and Caius Marcius are lucky enough to meet,
It is sworn between us that we will strike one day
Until we can't take it anymore.

All:
The gods help you!

AUFIDIUS:
And protect your honors!

First senator:
Farewell.

Second senator:
Farewell.

All:
Farewell.

VOLUMNIA:
I pray you, my daughter, sing; or express yourself in a way
more comfortable type: if my son were my husband, I
should more freely rejoice in this absence where he
earned honor only in the embraces of his bed where
he would show the most love. When, however, he was only one
with the tender body and the only son of my womb, when
the young people with their snatched beauty all look towards him, when
for a day of kings' supplications, a mother should not
sell it within an hour of his sight, me, considering
how honor would become such a person. that was
no better than a painting to hang on the wall, if
fame did not make him move, pleased to let him search
danger where he hoped to find glory. To a cruel
the war I sent to him; where he came back from, his eyebrows
bound with oak. I tell you, girl, I didn't jump
more joy in learning for the first time that he was a man-child
that now, seeing for the first time, it had revealed itself a
man.

VIRGILIA:
But if he had died in the affair, madam; How then?

VOLUMNIA:
Then his good report should have been my son; I
in there would have found a problem. Listen to me profess
sincerely: had I a dozen sons, each in my love
the same and no less expensive than yours and my property
Marcius, I would have preferred that eleven had died nobly for their
country that we voluptuously satiate ourselves out of combat.

Lady :
Madam, Lady Valeria has come to visit you.

VIRGILIA:
Please grant me permission to withdraw.

VOLUMNIA:
Indeed, you won't.
It seems to me that I hear your husband's drum here,
See him snatch Aufidius by the hair,
As children of a bear, the Volscians avoid it:
It seems to me that I see him stamping like this and calling like this:
“Come on, cowards! you were scared,
Even if you were born in Rome: his bloody forehead
With his hand meshed then wiping, he goes,
Like a harvester charged with mowing
Or everything or lose your job.

VIRGILIA:
His bloody forehead! O Jupiter, no blood!

VOLUMNIA:
Go away, you idiot! he becomes more of a man
Than to gild her trophy: the breasts of Hecuba,
When she breastfed Hector, she didn't look any better
Than Hector's forehead when he spits blood
With the Greek sword, contemptuous. Tell Valeria,
We are able to welcome him.

VIRGILIA:
Heaven bless my fallen lord Aufidius!

VOLUMNIA:
He will strike Aufidius' head under his knee
And step on his neck.

VALériE:
Ladies, have a good day to you both.

VOLUMNIA:
Sweet lady.

VIRGILIA:
I am happy to see Your Lady.

VALériE:
How are you both? you are true guardians of the house.
What are you sewing here? A beautiful place, in good
faith. How is your grandson?

VIRGILIA:
I thank your Lady; well, good lady.

VOLUMNIA:
He preferred to see swords and hear a drum rather than
look at his schoolmaster.

VALériE:
O my word, the father's son: I will swear that he is a
very pretty boy. O' my faith, I looked at it o'
Wednesday half an hour together: to such
confirmed face. I saw him chasing a walleye
butterfly: and when he caught it, he let it go
Again; and after again; and again and again he
comes, and again; I caught it again; or if its
the fall made him angry, or how it was, he did
teeth and tear it; O, I guarantee it, how he mammured himself
he!

VOLUMNIA:
One about the father's mood.

VALériE:
Indeed, he is a noble child.

VIRGILIA:
A crack, ma'am.

VALériE:
Come, drop off your embroidery; I have to make you play
the maid idle with me this afternoon.

VIRGILIA:
No, good madam; I won't go out.

VALériE:
Not outside!

VOLUMNIA:
She will, she will.

VIRGILIA:
Indeed, no, by your patience; I won't end it
threshold until my lord returns from the wars.

VALériE:
Well, you lock yourself in unreasonably: come,
you must go and visit the good lady who lives there.

VIRGILIA:
I will wish him speedy strength and visit him with
my prayers; but I can't go.

VOLUMNIA:
Why, please?

VIRGILIA:
It is not to save work, nor to love.

VALériE:
You would be another Penelope: yet, they say, everything
the thread she spun in Ulysses' absence only filled
Ithaca full of moths. Come; I would like your cambric
were sensible as your finger, so you could leave
sting him out of pity. Come, you will come with us.

VIRGILIA:
No, good madam, forgive me; in fact, I won't go out.

VALériE:
Truly, come with me; and I will tell you
great news from your husband.

VIRGILIA:
O, good lady, there cannot be any more.

VALériE:
In truth, I am not joking with you; news arrived from
him last night.

VIRGILIA:
Indeed, madam?

VALériE:
Seriously, it's true; I heard a senator say it.
So it is: the Volscians have an army in front; against
from which general Cominius left, with part of
our Roman power: your lord and Titus Lartius are ready
in front of their town Corioli; they have no doubt
predominant and to make brief wars. It's true,
on my honor; and therefore, I pray, come with us.

VIRGILIA:
Excuse me, good lady; I will obey you in everything
thing afterwards.

VOLUMNIA:
Leave her alone, madame: as she is now, she will only
illness is our best joy.

VALériE:
In truth, I think she would. Then good luck.
Come, my good and sweet lady. Please, Virgilia, turn your
solemnity outside. and come with us.

VIRGILIA:
No, in one word, madam; in fact, I don't have to do it. I wish
you are very cheerful.

VALériE:
Well, goodbye.

MARCIUS:
The news comes there. A bet that they succeeded.

LARTIUS:
My horse to yours, no.

MARCIUS:
It's done.

LARTIUS:
Agreed.

MARCIUS:
Say, has our general encountered the enemy?

Messenger:
They are visible; but I haven't spoken yet.

LARTIUS:
So the right horse is mine.

MARCIUS:
I'll buy it from you.

LARTIUS:
No, I will not sell it or give it away: I will lend it to you
For half a century. Summon the city.

MARCIUS:
How far away are these armies?

Messenger:
In this kilometer and a half.

MARCIUS:
Then we will hear their 'larum, and they ours.
Now, Mars, please make us quick in work,
So that we can leave here with smoking swords,
To help our friends on the ground! Come, blow your breath.
Tutus Aufidius, is he within your walls?

First senator:
No, nor a man who fears you less than him,
It's less than a little.
Listen ! our drums
Let us give birth to our youth. We will break down our walls,
Rather than shelling us: our doors,
Which nevertheless seem closed, we have only been pinned by rushes;
They will open on their own.
Listen to yourself. far away!
There is Aufidius; list, what work he does
Among your divided army.

MARCIUS:
Oh, there they are!

LARTIUS:
Their noise be our instruction. Ladders, ho!

MARCIUS:
They do not fear us, but they are taking out their city.
Now put your shields before your heart and fight
With hearts more proof than shields. Advance,
brave Titus:
They despise us far beyond our thoughts,
Which makes me sweat with anger. Come on, my friends:
Whoever retires, I will take him for a Volsce,
And he will feel my sharpness.

MARCIUS:
All the contagion of the south falls on you,
Shame of Rome! your herd of... Boils and sores
Coat yourself, that you may be abhorred
Further than what we see and one infects the other
Against the wind a mile! You, souls of geese,
Who wear the form of men, how did you run
Slaves that monkeys would beat! Pluto and hell!
Everyone was injured behind; the back is red and the face is pale
With flight and aggravated fear! Repair and charge at home,
Or, by the fires of heaven, I will leave the enemy
And wage my wars against you: be careful: go;
If you hold on, we'll beat them down to their women,
As they followed us towards our trenches.
So, now the doors are open: now prove the correct seconds:
It is for the followers that fortune enlarges them,
Not for flyers: tag me and do the same.

First soldier:
Imprudence; not me.

Second soldier:
Nor me.

First soldier:
You see, they locked him up.

All:
In the pot, I guarantee it.

LARTIUS:
What happened to Marcius?

All:
Killed, sir, without a doubt.

First soldier:
Following the leaflets on the heels,
With them he enters; who, suddenly,
Applauded at their doors: he himself is alone,
To meet the whole city.

LARTIUS:
O noble man!
Who reasonably surpasses his senseless sword,
And when he bows, he rises. You are left, Marcius:
A whole carbuncle, as big as you,
Were not such a rich gem. You were a soldier
Even to Cato's wish, not fierce and terrible
Only by strokes; but, with your sinister looks and
The thunderous percussion of your sounds,
You make your enemies tremble, as if the world
They were feverish and shaking.

First soldier:
Listen, sir.

LARTIUS:
Oh, it's Marcius!
Let's go get it, or let's keep it the same.

First Roman:
This is what I will wear in Rome.

Second Roman:
And me that.

Third Roman:
A murrain, not! I took it for money.

MARCIUS:
See here these movers who value their hours
To a cracked drachma! Cushions, lead spoons,
Fetters of a must, doublets that the executioners would make
Bury with those who carried them, these vile slaves,
Before the fight is over, pack your bags: down with them!
And listen, what a noise the general is making! To him!
This is the man my soul hates, Aufidius,
Piercing our Romans: then, valiant Titus, take
Practical numbers to do good for the city;
While I, with those who are in spirit, will hasten
To help Cominius.

LARTIUS:
Worthy sir, you are bleeding;
Your exercise was too violent for
A second combat lesson.

MARCIUS:
Sir, don't praise me;
My work hasn't warmed me up yet: good luck:
The blood I shed is rather physical
Than dangerous for me: for Aufidius thus
I will appear and fight.

LARTIUS:
Now the fair goddess, Fortune,
Fall deeply in love with you; and its great charms
Stun your opponents' swords! Mister bold,
Prosperity be your page!

MARCIUS:
Your friend and more
Only those she places highest! So good bye.

LARTIUS:
You, the most worthy Marcius!
Go and sound the trumpet in the market place;
Call there all the officers of the city,
Where they will know our spirit: far away!

COMINIUS:
Breathe, my friends: well fought;
we left
Like the Romans, neither foolish in our positions,
Nor a coward in retirement: believe me, gentlemen,
We will be accused again. While we knocked,
By actings and transmission of bursts we heard
The accusations of our friends. Roman gods!
Direct their successes as we wish ours,
That our two powers, smiling
foreheads meeting,
Can offer you a grateful sacrifice.
Your news ?

Messenger:
The citizens of Corioli issued,
And gave to Lartius and Marcius the battle:
I saw our group heading towards their trenches,
And then I left.

COMINIUS:
Even if you tell the truth,
It seems to me that you don't speak well.
How long has it been?

Messenger:
More than an hour, my lord.

COMINIUS:
It's not a mile; briefly we heard their drums:
How could you, in one kilometer, confuse an hour,
And you bring your news so late?

Messenger:
Spies of the Volscians
Kept me on the hunt, and I was forced to ride
About three or four miles, otherwise I would have, sir,
Half an hour has passed since my report.

COMINIUS:
Who is there,
Does it look like he was skinned? O gods
It bears the seal of Marcius; and I have
Before, I saw it like that.

MARCIUS:

COMINIUS:
The shepherd does not know the thunder of a tabor
More than I know the sound of Marcius' tongue
Of every bad man.

MARCIUS:
Am I coming too late?

COMINIUS:
Yes, if you don't come with the blood of others,
But wrapped in yours.

MARCIUS:
O, let me cut you
In arms as healthy as when I courted, in the heart
As joyful as when our wedding day was over,
And candles burned all the way to bed!

COMINIUS:
Flower of warriors,
How are things going with Titus Lartius?

MARCIUS:
As for a man busy with decrees:
Sentencing some to death and others to exile;
Ransom him, or have pity, threaten the other;
Holding Corioli in the name of Rome,
Even like a flattering greyhound on a leash,
To let it slide at will.

COMINIUS:
Where is this slave
Who told me they beat you down to your trenches?
Where is he? call it here.

MARCIUS:
Leave him alone;
He spoke the truth: but for our gentlemen,
The common file, a scourge! stands for them!
The mouse never avoided the cat because it moved
Rascals worse than them.

COMINIUS:
But how did you succeed?

MARCIUS:
Will time tell? I do not think so.
Where is the enemy? are you the lords of the land?
Otherwise, why stop until you are?

COMINIUS:
Marcius,
We were at a disadvantage and fought
Retire to achieve our goal.

MARCIUS:
How does their fight take place? do you know which side
Did they place their trusted men?

COMINIUS:
As I suppose, Marcius,
Their bands in the vaward are the Antiates,
Of their best confidence; on them Aufidius,
Their very heart of hope.

MARCIUS:
I beg you,
Through all the battles we have fought,
By the blood we shed together, by the vows
We made friends last, that you directly
Set me against Aufidius and his Antiates;
And that you do not delay the present, but,
Filling the air with advanced swords and darts,
We are proving it at this very hour.

COMINIUS:
Even though I could wish
You were led to a gentle bath
And balms applied to you, but I will never dare
Deny your request: choose from these
This can better help your action.

MARCIUS:
They are the ones
Most want it. If there are any here...
As if it were a sin to doubt - who like this painting
Where you see me smeared; if I'm afraid
Less his person than a bad relationship;
If anyone thinks a brave death trumps a bad life
And that his country is dearer than him;
Leave him alone, or so many others who wish,
Make a sign thus, to express his disposition,
And follow Marcius.
Oh me alone! make you a sword of me?
If these manifestations are not external, which of you
But are four Volsces? none of you are
Able to resist the great Aufidius
A shield as hard as his. A certain number,
But thanks everyone, should I select
of all: the rest
Must bear the matter in another fight,
As the cause will be obeyed. Please walk;
And four of them will quickly bring out my command,
Which men are most inclined.

COMINIUS:
Walk, my friends:
Realize this ostentation, and you will
Split it all up with us.

LARTIUS:
So let the ports be guarded: keep your duties,
As I filed them. If I send, send
These centuries to our aid: the rest will serve us
For a short outfit: if we lose ground,
We can't keep the city.

Lieutenant:
Do not be afraid of our care, sir.

LARTIUS:
Therefore, close your doors.
Our guide, come; take us to the Roman camp.

MARCIUS:
I will only fight with you; because I hate you
Worse than a promise breaker.

AUFIDIUS:
We hate the same:
It's not Afric who owns a snake that I abhor
More than your fame and your desire. Fix your foot.

MARCIUS:
May the first parakeet die a slave to the other,
And the gods will condemn him afterwards!

AUFIDIUS:
If I steal, Marcius,
Hello me like a hare.

MARCIUS:
During these three hours, Tullus,
Alone I fought within your walls of Corioli,
And I did the work I liked: it's not my blood
Where you see me masked; for your revenge
Increase your power to the highest.

AUFIDIUS:
Were you the Hector
It was the whip of your boastful offspring,
You shouldn't escape me here.
Officious and not valiant, you put me to shame
In your doomed seconds.

COMINIUS:
If I were to talk to you about your daily work,
You wouldn't believe your actions: but I will report it
Where the senators will mix tears and smiles,
Where the great patricians will be present and shrug their shoulders,
I admire the ending, where the ladies will be afraid,
And, joyfully shaken, hear more; where the
boring stands,
Who, with the rebellious plebeians, hate your honors,
Will say against their heart "We thank the gods
Our Rome has such a soldier.
Yet you came to a piece of this party,
Having completely dined before.

LARTIUS:
O general,
Here is the courier, we caparison him:
Would you have seen...

MARCIUS:
Pray now, pray no more: my mother,
Who has a charter to exalt his blood,
When she congratulates me, it saddens me. I did
As you did; this is what I can; induced
As you have been; this is for my country:
The one who only carried out his good will
I overstepped my act.

COMINIUS:
You will not be
The grave of your merit; Rome must know
The value of his: 'it was a cover-up
Worse than theft, no less than a translation,
To hide your actions; and to silence that,
Who, at the spire and summit of guaranteed praise,
This seems modest: that's why I beg you
As a sign of what you are, not to reward
What you did... before our army heard me.

MARCIUS:
I got some wounds on me, and they're smart
To hear yourself remember.

COMINIUS:
Shouldn't they,
Well, they might rage against ingratitude,
And tempts himself with death. Of all the horses,
Of which we took a good and good store, of all
The treasure in this area reaches and the city,
We return the tenth to you, to be withdrawn,
Before common distribution,
Your only choice.

MARCIUS:
I thank you, general;
But I can't make my heart agree to take
A bribe to pay for my sword: I refuse it;
And stand on my common share with these
This saw action.

MARCIUS:
That these same instruments that you desecrate,
Never ring the bell again! when the drums and trumpets
I' the field proves flattering, may the courts and cities be
Done all in fake soothing face!
When steel becomes soft as the parasite's silk,
Let it serve as a cover for wars!
No more, I say! For this I did not wash
My nose that bled, or that outwitted some miserable idiot.
What, without any remark, many others have done, -
You scream at me
In hyperbolic cheers;
As if I loved my little one, I had to go on a diet
Praises embellished with lies.

COMINIUS:
You are too modest;
More cruel to your good report than grateful
To us who truly give to you: through your patience,
If you are angry with yourself, we will detain you,
Like someone who wants his own harm, with handcuffs,
So reason with yourself safely. Therefore, know this,
As for us, for the whole world, this Caius Marcius
Wear the garland of this war: in sign of which,
My noble steed, known in the camp, I give him,
With all its trimmings belonging; and from that moment on,
For what he did before Corioli, call him,
With all the applause and clamor of the host,
CAIUS MARCIUS CORIOLANUS! Bear
The addition nobly ever!

All:
Caius Marcius Coriolanus!

CORIOLANUS:
I'm going to go wash;
And when my face is beautiful, you will perceive
Whether I blush or not: nevertheless, I thank you.
I want to ride your horse, and anytime
To highlight your good addition
To the equity of my power.

COMINIUS:
So, to our tent;
Where, before we rest, we will write
To Rome of our success. You, Titus Lartius,
Must return to Corioli: send us to Rome
The best, with whom we can articulate,
For their own sake and ours.

LARTIUS:
I will, my lord.

CORIOLANUS:
The gods are starting to laugh at me. Me, this now
Refused the most princely gifts, I am forced to beg
From my lord general.

COMINIUS:
Take it ; it's yours. This is t?

CORIOLANUS:
Sometimes I lay here in Corioli
At a poor man's house; he used me kindly:
He shouted to me; I saw him prisoner;
But then Aufidius was in my eyes,
And anger overwhelmed my pity: I ask you
To give freedom to my poor host.

COMINIUS:
Oh, well begged!
If he were my son's butcher, he should
Be free like the wind. Deliver him, Titus.

LARTIUS:
Marcius, his name?

CORIOLANUS:
By Jupiter! forget.
I'm tired ; yes, my memory is tired.
Don't we have any wine here?

COMINIUS:
Let's go to our tent:
The blood on your face dries; It's time
We should think about it: come.

AUFIDIUS:
The city is taken!

First soldier:
It will be returned in good condition.

AUFIDIUS:
Condition!
I wish I were Roman; because I can't,
Being a Volsce, let me be one. Condition!
What good condition can a treaty find
Am I the part that is at mercy? Five times, Marcius,
I fought with you: you beat me so often,
And I would, I think, if we met
As often as we eat. By the elements,
If I ever meet him beard to beard,
He is mine, or I am his: my emulation
Did he not have this honor? in case
I thought I would crush it with equal force,
Real sword to sword, I'll attack him one way or another
Or anger or cunning can catch him.

First soldier:
It's the devil.

AUFIDIUS:
Bolder, but not so subtle. My worth is poisoned
With only a spot of suffering on his part; for him
Will not fly away from itself: neither sleep nor sanctuary,
Being naked, sick, neither wilt nor Capitol,
The prayers of the priests nor the times of sacrifice,
The embarkations, all in fury, will rise
Their rotten privileges and customs against
My hatred towards Marcius: where do I find it, even if it
At home, under my brother's care, even there,
Against the hospital cannon, would I have
Wash my fierce hand in the heart. Go to town;
Learn how it happens; and what they are that must
Be hostages of Rome.

First soldier:
Won't you go?

AUFIDIUS:
I am being treated in the cypress grove: please...
It is to the south that the town's mills are located. Bring me a message there.
How is the world going, at its own pace
I can boost my journey.

First soldier:
I will, sir.

MENNIUS:
The omen tells me that we will have news this evening.

BRUTUS:
Good or bad?

MENNIUS:
Not according to the prayer of the people, for they
doesn't like Marcius.

SICINIUS:
Nature teaches animals to know their friends.

MENNIUS:
Please, who loves the wolf?

SICINIUS:
The lamb.

MENNIUS:
Yes, to devour it; like the hungry plebeians would do
noble Marcius.

BRUTUS:
It is indeed a lamb, which bathes like a bear.

MENNIUS:
He is indeed a bear, who lives like a lamb. you too
are old men: tell me one thing that I will ask you.

Both:
Well, sir.

MENNIUS:
How poor is Marcius, that you two
Don’t you have an abundance of it?

Especially in pride.

BRUTUS:
And ahead of everyone else in terms of bragging rights.

censored here in the city, I mean from us, the
right file? do you?

Both:
Why, how are we censored?

Since you are talking about pride now, won't you be angry?

Well, sir, well.

MENNIUS:
Well, it's not a big deal; for a little thief
this occasion will deprive you of a lot of patience:
give the reins to your dispositions and be angry at
your pleasures; at least if you take it as a
it's a pleasure for you to be. You blame Marcius
to be proud ?

BRUTUS:
We don't do it alone, sir.

MENNIUS:
I know you can't do much alone; For your help
are numerous, otherwise your actions would become marvelous
single: your abilities are too infantile to
do a lot of things alone. You speak of pride: oh that you
could turn your eyes to the back of your neck,
and only do an inner investigation into your well-being!
Oh, if you could!

BRUTUS:
And then, sir?

MENNIUS:
Well, then you should discover a pair of undeserved things,
proud, violent and irritable magistrates, alias imbeciles, like
none in Rome.

SICINIUS:
Menenius, you are quite well known too.

MENNIUS:
I am known for being a humorous patrician who
loves a cup of mulled wine without a drop of comfort
The Tiber is not there; we say that it is something imperfect in
favor the first complaint; hasty and tinder-like
on a movement that is too trivial; the one who talks more
with the buttock of the night than with the forehead
in the morning: what I think of pronouncing and spending my time
the nastiness in my breath. Meet two businessmen such as
you are... I cannot call you Lycurgus... if the drink
you give me a negative contact with my palate, I make a
twisted face. I cannot say that your cults have
I have settled the matter well, when I find the ass in it
composed with the majority of your syllables: and
even if I have to be content to put up with those who say
you are serious reverend men, and yet they lie mortally
I tell you that you have good faces. If you see this in
the map of my microcosm, it follows that I am known
pretty good too? what barm can your bison
conspectuities gleaned from this character, if I am
quite well known too?

BRUTUS:
Come, sir, come, we know you well enough.

MENNIUS:
You don't know me, or yourselves, or anything. You
are ambitious for the caps and legs of poor rascals: you
spend a good healthy morning hearing a
argument between an orange woman and a seller of dimples;
then postpone the controversy from three pence to one
second day of hearing. When you hear a
it's a question between party and party, if you are lucky enough to be
pinched by colic, you make grimaces like
moms; raise the bloody flag against all
patience; and, roaring for a chamber pot,
reject the most tangled bleeding controversy
by your hearing: all the peace you make in their
the cause is that he treats both parties as knaves. You are
a pair of strange ones.

BRUTUS:
Come, come, you are well known to be a
chatter more perfect for the table than necessary
advisor to the Capitol.

MENNIUS:
Our priests themselves must become mockers, if they want
encounter subjects as ridiculous as you. When
you speak best to the goal, it's not worth it
wiggle your beard; and your beard doesn't deserve
a grave so honorable that it would fill that of a bastard
cushion, or be buried in a donkey bag-
saddle. Yet you must say: Marcius is proud;
which, wisely, is worth its predecessors
since Deucalion, although perhaps some of the
the best of them were hereditary executioners. God-den to
your worship: a greater part of your conversation
infect my brain, being the shepherds of the beasts
plebeians: I will have the audacity to take leave of you.
Well, my ladies as beautiful as they are noble, and the moon,
if it was earthly, it was not nobler, - where do you follow
your eyes so quickly?

VOLUMNIA:
Honorable Menenius, my boy Marcius approaches; For

Where is he injured?

VOLUMNIA:
They are the bailiffs of Marcius: before him he

Death, that dark spirit, rests in his sinewy arm;
Which, being advanced, declines, and then men die.

Herald:
Know, Rome, that Marcius fought alone
At the gates of Corioli: where he won,
With fame, a name to Caius Marcius; these
In honor follows Coriolanus.
Welcome to Rome, famous Coriolanus!

Welcome to Rome, famous Coriolanus!

CORIOLANUS:
None of that anymore; It hurts my heart:
Pray now, no more.

COMINIUS:
Look, sir, at your mother!

CORIOLANUS:
Oh,
You have, I know, petitioned all the gods
For my prosperity!

VOLUMNIA:
No, my good soldier, stand up;
My sweet Marcius, worthy Caius, and
By an act which merits the newly appointed honor, -
What is it ? Coriolanus should I call you?
But oh your wife!

CORIOLANUS:
My gracious silence, salute!
Would you have laughed if I had come home in a coffin,
Who cries when they see me triumph? Yes my dear,
Such eyes bear the widows of Corioli,
And mothers who lack sons.

MENNIUS:
Now the gods crown you!

CORIOLANUS:
And you still live?
O my sweet lady, pardon.

VOLUMNIA:
I don't know where to turn: O, welcome home:
And welcome, general: and you are all welcome.

MENNIUS:
A hundred thousand welcomes. I could cry
And I could laugh, I'm light and heavy. To welcome.
A curse begins at the very root of the heart,
It's not good to see you! There are three of you
Rome should love it: yet, by the faith of men,
We have some old crabs here
at home, this will not be the case
Let yourself be grafted as you wish. But welcome, warriors:
We call a nettle but a nettle and
The faults of fools but madness.

COMINIUS:
Always right.

CORIOLANUS:
Menenius always, always.

Herald:
Give in and move on!

CORIOLANUS:

VOLUMNIA:
I lived
To see inherited my wishes
And the buildings of my fantasy: only
There's one thing missing, which I don't doubt, but
Our Rome will throw itself on you.

CORIOLANUS:
Know, good mother,
I prefer to be their servant in my own way,
Than to influence with them in theirs.

COMINIUS:
On the way to the Capitol!

BRUTUS:
All languages speak of him, and pale visions
We wear glasses to see it: your talkative nurse
In rapture, let her baby cry
While she talks to him: Malkin kitchen pins
His richest lockram about his rough neck,
Climbing the walls to look at it: stalls, bulk, windows,
Are choked, the tracks filled and the ridges ridden
With varying complexions, everyone agrees
Looking forward to seeing it: rarely shown flamens
Squeeze among the popular crowds and blow
To win a vulgar station: or veiled ladies
Engage in the war of whites and damasks
Their dazzling cheeks with free booty
Burning kisses from Phoebus: such a father
As if it was the god who led him
Were sneakily slipped into his human powers
And gave him a graceful posture.

SICINIUS:
At once,
I guarantee him consul.

BRUTUS:
So our office can,
While in power, go to sleep.

SICINIUS:
He cannot carry his honors with moderation
Where it should start and end, but it will
Lose those he won.

BRUTUS:
In this there is comfort.

SICINIUS:
I have no doubt about it
The commoners, whom we defend, but they
About their former wickedness they will forget
For the slightest cause, these new honors, which
That he will give them, I don't ask myself any questions
How proud he is to do so.

BRUTUS:
I heard him swear,
If he ran for consul, he would never do it
I appear on the market nor on him
The impeccable garment of humility;
Nor show, as is the custom, his wounds
To the people, implore their stinking breaths.

SICINIUS:
It's true.

BRUTUS:
It was his word: O, he would rather miss it
Than to wear it to him but in the costume of the nobility,
And the desire of the nobles.

SICINIUS:
I don't wish for better
Than ask him to keep this goal and say it
In execution.

BRUTUS:
That's exactly what he will do.

SICINIUS:
It will then be for him according to our good wishes,
Certain destruction.

BRUTUS:
So it must fall
To him or to our authorities. To finish,
We must suggest to people in what hatred
He always held them; it is in power that he would do it
I made them fools, I silenced their litigants and
Dispossessed their freedoms, holding them back,
In human action and capacity,
No more soul or ability in the world
Than the camels in war, which have their provisions
Only to bear burdens and painful blows
For sinking beneath them.

SICINIUS:
This, as you say, suggested
At a time when his growing insolence
Will touch people - whose time will not fail,
If it is put there; and it's that simple
As for putting dogs on sheep, that will be his fire
To kindle their dry stubble; and their flame
Will darken it forever.

BRUTUS:
What is the problem?

Messenger:
You are summoned to the Capitol. It is thought
That Marcius will be consul:
I saw the mute men crowding to see him and
The blind to carry it speak: the matrons threw down gloves,
Ladies and servants, their scarves and their handkerchiefs,
On him as he passed: the nobles leaned,
As for the statue of Jupiter and the commons
A downpour and thunder with their caps and their cries:
I have never seen that.

BRUTUS:
Let's go to the Capitol;
And take with us ears and eyes for time,
But with heart for the event.

SICINIUS:
To have with you.

First officer:
Come, come, they're almost there. How many are standing
for consulates?

Second officer:
Three, they say: but it's thought of for everyone
Coriolanus will carry it.

First officer:
He's a good boy; but he is proud to take revenge, and
doesn't like ordinary people.

Second officer:
Well, there have been many great men who have
flattered the people, who never loved them; and there
many of them have loved it, they don't know it

they hate not for a better motive: therefore, for
Coriolanus doesn't care if they love or hate
manifests to him the true knowledge that he has in their
arrangement; and by his noble carelessness, lets
they see it clearly.

First officer:
If he didn't care whether he had their love or not,
he waved his hand indifferently without making either
neither good nor evil: but he seeks their hatred with greater
devotion which can return it to him; and leaves
nothing undone that can fully reveal their
opposite. Now, to appear to affect wickedness and
the discontent of the people is as serious as that which they
does not love, to flatter them with their love.

Second officer:
He deserved his country with dignity: and his
the ascent is not made at degrees as easy as those which,

kindnesses, without any other act to have them
one in their estimate and report: but he did
has planted his honors in their eyes, and his actions

keeping quiet, and not confessing too much, were a kind of

After having determined the Volsces and
It remains to bring Titus Lartius,

please,

Leave nothing out and make us think
Our State rather lacks retaliation

He loves your people

First senator:

CORIOLANUS:
Forgiveness for your horror:
I'd rather my wounds heal again
Than to hear how I got them.

BRUTUS:
Sir, I hope
My words have not destabilized you.

CORIOLANUS:
No, sir: yet often,
When the blows made me stay, I fled the words.
You did not soothe, therefore you did not hurt: but
Your people,
I love them the way they weigh.

MENNIUS:
Pray now, sit down.

CORIOLANUS:
I'd rather scratch my head in the sun
When the alarm sounds, sit with your arms crossed
To hear my monstrous nothings.

MENNIUS:
Masters of the people,
Your multiplier offspring, how can they flatter...
It's a thousand to a good one - when you see now
He prefers to risk all his limbs for honor
That we have the ears to hear it? Go on, Cominius.

COMINIUS:
I shall lack voice: the acts of Coriolanus
Should not be pronounced weakly. It is held
This value is the greatest of virtues, and
Most worthy of the wearer: if so,
The man I'm talking about can't in the world
Be individually counterbalanced. At sixteen-year-old,
When Tarquin headed towards Rome, he fought
Beyond the mark of others: our dictator at the time,
The one I point to with all my praise, I saw him fight,
When with his Amazonian chin he drove
Lips bristling in front of him: be unbridled
A Roman in too much of a hurry and I am from the consul's point of view
Killed three adversaries: Tarquin whom he met,
And smote him on the knee: in the exploits of that day,
When he could play the woman in the scene,
He proved himself the best man on the field, and for his work
Was related to oak. His student age
So the man entered, he became like a sea,
And in seventeen battles since
He made all the swords in the garland waver. For the latter,
Before and at Corioli, let me say,
I can't talk to him at home: he stopped the leaflets;
And by his rare example made the coward
Transforming terror into sport: like the weed before
A sailing ship, so men obeyed
And fell under his rod: his sword, the seal of death,
Where he scored, he took; from face to toe
It was a thing of blood, whose every movement
Was timed with dying cries: alone he entered
The deadly city gate, which he painted
With a destiny without escape; without help, he got away with it,
And with a sudden reinforcement struck
Corioli like a planet: now everything is his:
When, little by little, the din of war pierces
His common sense; then straightens his mind doubled
I revived what in flesh was tired,
And he came to battle; where he did
Run stinking men's lives, as if
"It was perpetual spoil: and until we called
Both on the field and in the city, he never stood up
To relieve his chest while panting.

MENNIUS:
A worthy man!

First senator:
He can only live up to the honors
What we design for it.

COMINIUS:
He kicked our booty,
And I considered precious things as they were
The common shit of the world: he covets less
That misery itself would give; rewards
His actions by carrying them out, and he is content
Take the time to finish it.

MENNIUS:
He is right, noble:
Let us call him.

First senator:
Call Coriolanus.

Officer:
It appears.

MENNIUS:
The senate, Coriolanus, is very happy
To make you consul.

CORIOLANUS:
I still owe them
My life and my services.

MENNIUS:
It then remains
That you talk to people.

CORIOLANUS:
I beg you,
Let me go beyond this custom, for I cannot
Put on the robe, stay naked and beg them,
For the love of my wounds, to give their vote: please
So that I can achieve this.

SICINIUS:
Sir, people
Must have their votes; neither will they beat
A piece of ceremony.

MENNIUS:
Put them aside:
Please go adapt to custom and
Take yourself, like your predecessors,
Your honor with your form.

CORIOLANUS:
It's apart
That I will blush while playing, and that I could well
Be taken from the people.

BRUTUS:
Did you notice that?

CORIOLANUS:
To boast to them, I did so, and so;
Show them the callous scars I should hide,
As if I received them for rental
With their breath only!

MENNIUS:
Don't hold on to it.
We recommend to you, tribunes of the people,
Our aim towards them: and towards our noble consul
We wish everyone joy and honor.

Senators:
To Coriolanus come all joy and all honor!

BRUTUS:
You see how he intends to use the people.

SICINIUS:
Let them perceive the intention! He will need it,
As if he despised what he asked
Should be in them to give.

BRUTUS:
Come, we will inform them
Of our actions here: on the market,
I know, they help us.

First citizen:
Once, if he needs our votes, we should not deny him.

Second citizen:
We can, sir, if we want.

Third citizen:
We have the power within us to do it, but it is a
a power which we have no power to exercise; because if he shows us
his wounds and tell us about his actions, we must put our
speaks into these wounds and speaks for them; so if
he tells us of his noble deeds, we must also tell him
our noble acceptance from them. Ingratitude is
monstrous, and so that the multitude is ungrateful,
had to make a monster out of the multitude:
of which we, as members, should resolve to be
monstrous limbs.

First citizen:
And not to make us think better, a little help
be used for; for once we stood up about the corn, it
he himself tried not to call us the many-headed multitude.

Third citizen:
We have been called that by many; not just our heads
are some brown, some black, some auburn, some bald,
but that our minds are so diversely colored: and
really, I think if all our minds came out of
a skull, they would fly east, west, north, south,
and their consent in a direct manner should be to

In Antium.

and scattered,

'Duty'!
O good but very imprudent patricians! Why,

Since Hydra is here to choose an officer,
That with its peremptory “must”, being only
The monster's horn and noise don't want no mind
To say that it will turn your current into a ditch,
And make your channel their own? If he has the power
So boast of your ignorance; if there is none, wake up
Your dangerous clemency. If you are educated,
Do not be like simple fools; if you are not,
Give them cushions at your disposal. You are plebeians,
If they are senators: and they are no less,
When your two voices mixed, the best taste
Most of the palaces are theirs. They choose their magistrate,
And someone like him, who puts his "must",
His popular “must” against a more serious bench
Never frown in Greece. By Jupiter himself!
This demeans the consuls: and my soul suffers
Namely, when two authorities are in place,
Nor supreme, how long the confusion
Can enter between the gap of the two and take
One by the other.

I didn't deserve free corn. Being me the war

What their words sound like: “We asked for it; »

The nature of our seats and being a scoundrel

That by which one may swear, both divine and human,

I can only conclude yes and no
From general ignorance it is necessary to omit

it follows,
Nothing is done on purpose. Therefore, please...

Jumping a physically dangerous body
It's sure to die without it, tear it off immediately

Because we are peremptory to ship
This traitorous viper: to chase him from here
Were just a danger, and keeping him here
Our certain death: this is why it is decreed
He dies that night.

MENNIUS:
Now the good gods forbid us
May our famous Rome, whose gratitude
Towards his deserved children is registered
In Jupiter's own book, like an unnatural dam
He should eat his now!

SICINIUS:
It is a disease that must be eradicated.

MENNIUS:
Oh, it's a member who has only one illness;
Mortal, to cut it; To fix it, it's easy.
What did he do in Rome that deserves death?
Killing our enemies, the blood he lost...
Which, I dare guarantee, is more than he has,
By many ounces… he gave it up for his country;
And what remains, to lose him by his country,
If it were for all of us, who don't do it and suffer it,
A brand to the ends of the earth.

SICINIUS:
It's clean Kam.

BRUTUS:
Simply wrong: when he loved his country,
It honored him.

MENNIUS:
The foot service
Being once gangrenous is no longer respected
What it was for before.

BRUTUS:
We won't hear any more.
Pursue him to his house, and snatch him from there:
Lest his infection, being contagious in nature,
Spread more.

MENNIUS:
One more word, one word.
This tiger-footed rage, when he finds
The harm of unanalyzed speed will arrive too late
Attach pounds of lead to your heels. Proceed by process;
Lest feasts, as he is beloved, break out,
And sack great Rome with the Romans.

BRUTUS:
If it were so,...

SICINIUS:
What are you talking about ?
Have we not tasted his obedience?
Our councilors knocked? We ourselves resisted? Come.

MENNIUS:
Consider this: he was raised in wars
Since he knows how to draw a sword and he is poorly educated
In bolted language; meal and its whole
He throws indiscriminately. Give me leave,
I will go to him and commit to bringing him
Where he will respond, in a legal form,
In peace, at his greatest risk.

First senator:
Noble tribunes,
This is the human way: the other way
It will turn out to be too bloody, and the end
Unknown at first.

SICINIUS:
Noble Menenius,
So be yourself as an officer of the people.
Masters, lay down your arms.

BRUTUS:
Don't go home.

SICINIUS:
Go to the market square. We will be waiting for you there:
Where, if you don't bring Marcius, we will continue
In our first way.

MENNIUS:
I'll bring it to you.
Let me long for your company: he must come,
Or worse will follow.

First senator:
Please, let's go to him.

CORIOLANUS:
Let them blow around my ears, introduce me
Death while driving or following wild horses,
Or pile ten hills on the Tarpeian rock,
That the precipitation could spread
Under the beam of sight, but will I always
Be that way towards them.

A Patrician:
You do the noblest thing.

CORIOLANUS:
I think of my mother
Don't approve of me anymore, that was the habit
To call them vassals of wool, created things
Buy and sell with gruel, show bare head
In congregations, to yawn, stand still and marvel,
When only one of my orders stood
Talk about peace or war.
I'm talking about you :
Why did you wish me more gentleness? Do you want to have me
False in relation to my nature? Say instead that I play
The man that I am.

VOLUMNIA:
O, sir, sir, sir,
I would have asked you to put your power to good use,
Before having worn it out.

CORIOLANUS:
Let go.

VOLUMNIA:
Maybe you would have been enough of the man you are,
By trying less to be; less had been
The contradictions of your arrangements, if
You hadn't shown them how willing you were
Before, they lacked the power to upset you.

CORIOLANUS:
Let them hang.

A Patrician:
Yes, and burns too.

MENNIUS:
Come on, come on, you were too hard, something
too hard;
You have to come back and fix it.

First senator:
There is no cure;
Unless, in doing so, our good city
Split down the middle and perish.

VOLUMNIA:
Pray, be advised:
I have a heart as unfit as yours,
But yet a brain that directs my use of anger
For a better view.

MENNIUS:
Well said, noble woman?
Before he should thus lower himself towards the herd, but this
The violent crisis of time demands it as physical
For the whole state I would put on my armor,
Which I can barely stand.

CORIOLANUS:
What should I do?

MENNIUS:
Return to the stands.

CORIOLANUS:
Well, so what? so what ?

MENNIUS:
Repent of what you have said.

CORIOLANUS:
For them! I cannot do it to the gods;
Should I then do nothing to them?

VOLUMNIA:
You are too absolute;
Although one can never be too noble,
But when the extremities speak. I heard you say,
Honor and politics, like inseparable friends,
The war grows together: grant it and tell me,
In peace what each of them loses the other,
Let them not combine there.

CORIOLANUS:
Shh, shh!

MENNIUS:
A good request.

VOLUMNIA:
If it is an honor in your wars to appear
You are not the same, which for your best interests,
You adopt your policy, how is it less or worse,
That he will keep company in peace
With honor, as in war, since for both
Is it like a request?

CORIOLANUS:
Why force yourself into this?

VOLUMNIA:
Because now it's your turn to speak
To the people; not by your own instruction,
Nor by the things that your heart urges you,
But with such words that are only rooted in
Your language, however, but bastards and syllables
Without considering the truth of your breast.
Now it doesn't dishonor you at all
Than to visit a city with sweet words,
What else would put you to your fortune and
The danger of a lot of blood.
I would hide with my nature where
My fortune and friends at stake required
I should do it with honor: I am here,
Your wife, your son, these senators, the nobles;
And you will rather show our general thugs
How can you frown rather than devote a fawn to them,
For the inheritance of their loves and their preservation
Of what this desire could ruin.

MENNIUS:
Noble lady!
Come, come with us; speak honestly: you can save him,
It is not the present that is dangerous, but the loss
Of what happened.

VOLUMNIA:
I beg you now, my son,
Go towards them, with this cap in your hand;
And having extended it thus far, behold with them…
Your knee crushes stones - because in such matters
Action is eloquence, and the eyes of the ignorant
More educated than the ears, shaking the head,
Who often, thus correcting your valiant heart,
Now humble as the ripest mulberry
This will not hold the manipulation: nor will it tell them,
You're their soldier, and you're raised on grills
Don't you have the gentleness with which, you admit,
Are they worthy of being used as they claim,
By asking for their good loves, but you will frame
Yourself, in truth, now theirs, until now
How powerful and personable you are.

MENNIUS:
This but it is done,
Even as she speaks, well, their heart was yours;
Because they have forgiveness, requested, also free
Like useless words.

VOLUMNIA:
I beg you now,
Go and let yourself be governed: even though I know you would prefer
Follow your enemy into a fiery gulf
Than petting him in a cradle. This is Cominius.

COMINIUS:
I've been in the market; and, sir, it's okay
You make a strong party, or you defend yourself
By calm or by its absence: everything is angry.

MENNIUS:
Just fair speech.

COMINIUS:
I think it will be useful, if
Can thus frame his mind.

VOLUMNIA:
He must and he will
Please say it and go.

CORIOLANUS:
Should I go show them my barbless sconce?
Shall I, with a low tongue, give my noble heart
A lie he has to put up with? Well, I won't do:
Yet if there was only one plot to lose,
This mold of Marcius, they should grind it to dust
And throw it against the wind. At the market !
You have put me now in a role like never before
I will discharge to life.

COMINIUS:
Come, come, we will invite you.

VOLUMNIA:
Please now, sweet son, as you said
My praises made you a soldier first, so,
To get my praise for this, play a game
You've never done it before.

CORIOLANUS:
Well, I must not do:
Get away from my disposal and possess me
The spirit of a prostitute! my throat of war be turned,
Who sang with my drum, in a pipe
Small like a eunuch or a virgin voice
Let the babies go to sleep! the smiles of the rascals
Tent on my cheeks, and the tears of schoolchildren begin again
The glasses of my vision! the tongue of a beggar
Make movement through my lips and my armored knees,
Who only bowed in my stirrup, bends like his
This one received a handout! I will not do it,
Lest I stop honoring my own truth
And by the action of my body, teach my mind
A most inherent baseness.

VOLUMNIA:
Your choice, then:
Begging you is my greatest dishonor
Than you of them. Come all to ruin; to leave 
Your mother would rather feel your pride than your fear
Your dangerous corpulence, because I don't care about death
With a heart as big as you. Do what you say
Your valor was mine, you sucked it from me,
But you owe your pride to yourself.

CORIOLANUS:
Pray, be happy:
Mother, I am going to the market;
Don't scold me anymore. I will ridicule their loves,
Take away their hearts and come home beloved
Of all the trades in Rome. Listen, I'll:
Recommend me to my wife. I will return consul;
Or never trust what my tongue can do
I'm further down the flattery route.

VOLUMNIA:
Do your will.

COMINIUS:
Far! the tribunes assist you: arm yourself
To respond gently; because they are prepared
With accusations, as I hear it, stronger
Which is still on you.

CORIOLANUS:
The word is “slightly.” Please, let's go:
Let them accuse me of invention, I
I will answer in my honor.

MENNIUS:
Yes, but slowly.

CORIOLANUS:
Well, be gentle, then. Gently!

BRUTUS:
On this point, charge him at home, which he affects
Tyrannical power: if it escapes us there,
Strengthen him with his envy towards the people,
And the spoils fell on the Antiates
Was never distributed.
What, will he come?

AEdile:
He is coming.

BRUTUS:
How to accompany?

AEdile:
With old Menenius and these senators
This has always favored him.

SICINIUS:
Do you have a catalog
Of all the voices we've provided
Filed by the ballot?

AEdile:
I have; It's ready.

SICINIUS:
Did you collect them by tribe?

AEdile:
I have.

SICINIUS:
Now gather the people here;
And when they carry me they say "It will be so
I am the right and the strength of the commons, whether
For death, for fine or for banishment, then let them
If I say good, shout “Good”; if it's death, shout "Death."
Insist on the ancient prerogative
And power is the truth about the cause.

AEdile:
I will inform them.

BRUTUS:
And when they start to cry,
Let them not stop, but with a confused din
Apply this execution
Of what we have the chance to condemn.

AEdile:
Alright.

SICINIUS:
Make them be strong and ready to receive this hint,
When we can give them to them.

BRUTUS:
Go for it.
Make him angry directly: he was used
Always conquer and have your value
Of contradiction: being irritated, he can no longer
Be subject again to temperance; then he speaks
What is in his heart? and that's what looks like
It's up to us to break his neck.

SICINIUS:
Well, here it is.

MENNIUS:
Calmly, I beg you.

CORIOLANUS:
Yes, as a groom, it's for the poorest piece
Will support the valet by volume. The gods honored
Keep Rome safe and the seats of justice
Provided with worthy men! plant love among the!
Gather our great temples with the spectacles of peace,
And not our streets at war!

First senator:
Amen, amen.

MENNIUS:
A noble wish.

SICINIUS:
Come closer, you people.

AEdile:
Make the list to your tribunes. Audience: Peace, I say!

CORIOLANUS:
First, listen to me speak.

The two Tribunes:
We'll say. Peace, ho!

CORIOLANUS:
Will I not be charged beyond this gift?
Does everyone have to decide here?

SICINIUS:
I demand,
If you submit to the voice of the people,
Allow their officers and are satisfied
Suffering legal censorship for such mistakes
Will this be proven to you?

CORIOLANUS:
I am happy.

MENNIUS:
Here, citizens, he says he is happy:
Consider the warlike service he rendered; think
On the wounds that his body bears, which show
Like graves in the sacred cemetery.

CORIOLANUS:
Stripes with brambles,
Scars to move laughter only.

MENNIUS:
Consider further,
That when he doesn't speak like a citizen,
You find him like a soldier: don't take
His harsher accents for malevolent sounds,
But, as I said, he who becomes a soldier,
Rather than envying you.

COMINIUS:
Well, no more.

CORIOLANUS:
What is the problem
This being passed for consul in full voice,
I am so disgraced that right now
Are you taking it off again?

SICINIUS:
Answer us.

CORIOLANUS:
So say: it's true, I should.

SICINIUS:
We accuse you of having succeeded in taking
From Rome to the office in all seasons and in the wind
Yourself in tyrannical power;
For which you are a traitor to the people.

CORIOLANUS:
How! traitor!

MENNIUS:
No, in moderation; your promise.

CORIOLANUS:
Fires are the lowest hell and bring people together!
Call me their traitor! You, insulting tribune!
In your eyes were twenty thousand dead,
In your hand I held as many millions, in
Your lying tongue the two digits, I would say
"You're lying to yourself" in such a free voice
As I pray to the gods.

SICINIUS:
Do you notice that, friends?

Citizens:
To the rock, to the rock with him!

SICINIUS:
Peace!
We do not need to entrust him with a new matter:
What you saw him do and heard about,
Beat your officers, curse you,
Oppose the laws with strokes and here defy them
Those whose great power must experience it; even that,
So criminal and so capital,
Deserves the most extreme death.

BRUTUS:
But since he has
Served well in Rome,--

CORIOLANUS:
What do you do as a service?

BRUTUS:
I'm talking about that, you know it.

CORIOLANUS:
You?

MENNIUS:
Is this the promise you made to your mother?

COMINIUS:
Know, please,--

CORIOLANUS:
I do not know more :
Let them pronounce abrupt Tarpeian death,
Exile wanderer, radiant, cut off to linger
But with a grain a day, I wouldn't buy
Their mercy at the price of a just word;
Nor test my courage for what they can give,
You should not say “Hello”.

SICINIUS:
For this he has,
As much as it resides in him, from time to time
Envious against the people, looking for ways
To take away their power, like now at last
Given hostile blows, and that not in the presence
Of the feared justice, but on the ministers
This distributes it; in the name of the people
And in the power of us the tribunes, we,
From this moment on, ban him from our city,
In danger of precipitation
From the Tarpeian rock, never again
To enter our gates of Rome: this is the name of the people,
I say it will be so.

Citizens:
It will be so, it will be so; let him go:
He is banished, and so it will be.

COMINIUS:
Listen to me, my masters and my mutual friends,

SICINIUS:
He is condemned; more hearing.

COMINIUS:
Let me talk:
I was consul and I can present myself in Rome
The marks of his enemies on me. I really like
My country is good with a tenderer respect,
Holier and deeper than my own life,
The estimation of my dear wife, the increase of her belly,
And the treasure of my loins; so if i would
Speak that...

SICINIUS:
We know your drift: talk what?

BRUTUS:
There's nothing left to say, but he's banished,
As an enemy of the people and his country:
It will be so.

Citizens:
It will be so, it will be so.

CORIOLANUS:
You common cry of priests! whose breath I hate
Like the smell of rotten swamps, whose loves I appreciate
Like the dead carcasses of unburied men
He who corrupts my air, I banish you;
And stay here with your uncertainty!
Let every faint rumor shake your hearts!
Your enemies, nodding their feathers,
Tackle despair! I still have the power
To banish your defenders; until finally
Your ignorance, which only finds when it feels,
Make no reservations about yourselves,
Always your own enemies, deliver yourself like most
Captives slaughtered in a nation
This has won you without blows! Contemptuous,
To you, the city, I therefore turn my back:
There is a world elsewhere.

AEdile:
The enemy of the people is gone, he is gone!

Citizens:
Our enemy is banished! he left! Whoa! hoo!

SICINIUS:
Go to him at the gates and follow him,
As he followed you, despite everything;
Give him some deserved vexation. Leave a guard
Join us across town.

Citizens:
Come come; let us see him at the gates; come.
The gods preserve our noble tribunes! Come.

CORIOLANUS:
Come leave your tears: a brief farewell: the beast
With several heads, it cuts me. No mother,
Where is your old courage? you were used
To say that the extremity was the judge of spirits;
These common chances that ordinary men could bear;
That when the sea was calm, all boats were the same
Demonstrated mastery in floating; strokes of fortune,
When most hit home, being slightly injured, they yearn
A noble ruse: you used to charge me
With precepts that would make you invincible
The heart that deceived them.

VIRGILIA:
O heaven! O heaven!

CORIOLANUS:
No! I beg you, woman,...

VOLUMNIA:
Now the red plague hits all trades in Rome,
And the professions are perishing!

CORIOLANUS:
What what what!
I will be loved when I am missed. No mother.
Take back this spirit, when you said:
If you had been Hercules' wife,
You would have done six of his works and saved
Your husband is sweating so much. Cominius,
Don't slouch; Farewell. Farewell, my wife, my mother:
I'll be fine again. You, old and true Menenius,
Your tears are saltier than those of a younger man,
And poisonous in your eyes. My former general,
I saw you born, and you often saw
Breathtaking glasses; tell these sad women
I like to moan from the inevitable blows,
Because you have to make fun of them. My mother, you are fine
My dangers have always been your comfort: and
Don't take it lightly, even if I go alone,
Like a solitary dragon, that its swamp
Fears and speaks of more than what we have seen - your son
Will or will exceed average or will be caught
With careful baiting and practice.

VOLUMNIA:
My first son.
Where will you go ? Take good Cominius
With you for a while: determine a direction,
More than wild exposure at every chance
It starts like before you.

CORIOLANUS:
Oh the gods!

COMINIUS:
I will follow you for a month, I will design with you
Where you will rest, so you can hear about us
And we of you: so if time is short
A cause for your repeal we will not send
O'er the wide world to seek one man,
And lose the advantage, which is always cool
I' the absence of the needy.

CORIOLANUS:
Farewell :
You have years ahead of you; and you're too full
From the excesses of war, to go on a trip with a
It's still unharmed: bring me but to the door.
Come, my sweet wife, my dearest mother, and
My friends of noble touch, when I go out,
Say goodbye and smile. Please come.
While I stay above ground, you'll have to
Listen to me again, and never anything from me
But what was once like me?

MENNIUS:
It's worthy
As any ear can hear it. Come, let's not cry.
If I could get rid of just one seven year old
Of these old arms and legs, by the good gods,
I will be with you every step of the way.

CORIOLANUS:
Give me your hand: Come.

SICINIUS:
Invite them all to go home; he is gone, and we will go no further.
The nobility is upset, which we see having taken sides
In his name.

BRUTUS:
Now we have shown our power,
Let's be more humble after it's done
That when it was being done.

SICINIUS:
Invite them to go home:
To say that their great enemy is gone, and that they
Stay in their old strength.

BRUTUS:
Send them home.
This is his mother.

SICINIUS:
Let's not meet her.

BRUTUS:
For what?

SICINIUS:
They say she's crazy.

BRUTUS:
They noticed us: continue on your way.

VOLUMNIA:
Oh, you are welcome: the hoarded plague of the gods
Reward your love!

MENNIUS:
Peace, peace; don't be so loud.

VOLUMNIA:
If I could cry, you should hear,--
No, and you will hear some of them.
Will you be gone?

VIRGILIA:

SICINIUS:
Are you humanity?

VOLUMNIA:
Yes, fool; is it a shame? Note but this fool.
Wasn't my father a man? Do you have foxship
To banish the one who dealt more blows to Rome
How did you pronounce words?

SICINIUS:
O blessed heavens!

VOLUMNIA:
Strokes more noble than ever your wise words;
And for the good of Rome. I'll tell you what; but go ahead:
No, but you will also stay: I would like my son
Were in Arabia, and your tribe before him,
His good sword in hand.

SICINIUS:
So what ?

VIRGILIA:
So what !
He would put an end to your posterity.

VOLUMNIA:
Bastards and all.
Good man, the wounds he bears for Rome!

MENNIUS:
Come, come, peace.

SICINIUS:
I would have liked him to continue in his country
As it began, and did not undo
The noble knot he tied.

BRUTUS:
I wish he had.

VOLUMNIA:
"I would have done it" ! It was you who irritated the populace:
Cats, who can judge its worth as well
As I can of these mysteries that the sky
There will be no earth to know it.

BRUTUS:
Pray, let's go.

VOLUMNIA:
Now, please, sir, go:
You have performed a courageous act. Before you go, listen to this:--
To the extent that the Capitol exceeds
The meanest house in Rome so far, my son...
This lady's husband here, this, you see...
The one you banished surpasses you all.

BRUTUS:
Okay, okay, we'll leave you.

SICINIUS:
Why do we stay being baited
With someone who wants his intelligence?

VOLUMNIA:
Take my prayers with you.
I wish the gods had nothing else to do
But to confirm my curses! Could I meet them
But once a day it would unlock my heart
Of what is heavy to bear.

MENNIUS:
You brought them home;
And, my goodness, you are right. Will you have dinner with me?

VOLUMNIA:
Anger is my meat; I rely on myself,
And so will starve while feeding. Come on, let's go:
Leave this light beating and lament as I do,
Angry, like Juno. Come come come.

MENNIUS:
Fi, fi, fi!

Roman:
I know you well, sir, and you know
me: your name, I think, is Adrian.

Volsce:
It is so, sir: in truth, I have forgotten you.

Roman:
I am Roman; and my services are,
as you are, against them: do you already know me?

Volsce:
Nicanor? No.

Roman:
Same, sir.

Volsce:
You didn't have a beard the last time I saw you; but your
the favor is well approved by your tongue. What is the
any news in Rome? I have a note from the Volscian State,
to find you there: you saved me a lot
day of travel.

Roman:
There have been strange insurrections in Rome; THE
the people against the senators, the patricians and the nobles.

Volsce:
It was ! Is it over then? Our state does not think
therefore: they are in the most warlike preparation, and
I hope to meet them in the heat of their division.

Roman:
The main fire is over, but one little thing
would make it burn again: for the nobles receive
therefore at heart the banishment of this worthy
Coriolanus, which they are able to take
all power of the people and to wrest from them
their tribunes forever. This lie shines, I can
I tell you, and it is almost ripe for the violent
to burst.

Volsce:
Coriolanus banished!

Roman:
Banned, sir.

Volsce:
You will be welcome with this intelligence, Nicanor.

Roman:
The day serves them well now. I heard it
said, the best time to corrupt a man's wife is
when she falls out with her husband. Your noble
Tullus Aufidius will appear well in these wars, his
great adversary, Coriolanus, no longer being called upon
from his country.

Volsce:
He can't choose. I'm very lucky, so
accidentally meeting you: you ended my
business, and I will happily accompany you home.

Roman:
I will, between this and dinner, tell you the essentials
strange things coming from Rome; all tending to the good of
their adversaries. Do you have an army ready, you say?

Volsce:
One of the most royal; the centurions and their charges,
distinctly confined, already in entertainment,
and be on foot at one hour's warning.

Roman:
I am happy to hear that they are ready and I am
man, I think, that will put them into present action.
So, sir, I bid you a warm welcome and am very happy with your company.

Volsce:
You take my side, sir; I have the most reasons
be happy with yours.

Roman:
Well, let's go together.

CORIOLANUS:
A beautiful city is this Antium. City,
It is I who made your widows: many heirs
Of these beautiful buildings before my wars
Have I heard groaning and falling: then know me not,
Lest your women with spit and your boys with stones
In a puny battle, kill me.
Save yourself, sir.

Citizen:
And you.

CORIOLANUS:
Direct me, if it is your will,
Where does the great Aufidius rest: is he in Antium?

Citizen:
He is and delights the nobles of the State
At his place tonight.

CORIOLANUS:
What is his house, I beg you?

Citizen:
This, here in front of you.

CORIOLANUS:
Thank you, sir: goodbye.
O world, your slippery turns! Friends now swore quickly,
Whose double breasts seem to carry a single heart,
Whose house, whose bed, whose meal and exercise,
Are always together, who are twins, so to speak, in love
Inseparable, must in this hour,
On a dissension of a right, break out
To the bitterest enmity: thus, the dearest enemies,
Whose passions and plots have broken their sleep,
Take each other, by chance,
Something that is not worth an egg will grow, dear friends
And attach their problems. So with me:
My birthplace hates me and my love is there
This enemy city. I will enter: if he kills me,
He delivers fair justice; if he lets me pass,
I will do his national service.

First Servant:
Wine, wine, wine! What service
is here! I think our comrades are asleep.

Second servant:
Where is Cotus? my master calls
for him. Cotus!

CORIOLANUS:

My family name, Coriolanus: arduous service,
Extreme dangers and drops of blood
The shed for my ungrateful country is rewarded
But with this last name; a good memory,
And witness the wickedness and discontent
That you should bear me: only this name remains;
The cruelty and envy of the people,
Authorized by our ignoble nobles, who
They all abandoned me, they devoured the rest;
And let me be by the voice of slaves
It left Rome. Now this end
Brought me to your home; not out of hope...
Don't get me wrong, to save my life, because if
I was afraid of death, of all men in the world
I would have canceled you, but out of simple spite,
To be completely free from my banishers,
I stand here before you. So if you have it
A broken heart inside you, taking revenge
Your own particular wrongs and stop these mutilations
Shame seen across your country, speed
you straight,
And make my misery serve your turn: so use it
That my avenging services can prove
As a benefit to you, because I will fight
Against my country suffering from cankers with the spleen
Of all the sub-demons. But if that's the case
You don't dare this and that to prove more fortunes
You're tired, so, in a word, I am too
Longer to live the most tired and the most present
My throat to you and your ancient wickedness;
That not cutting would only show you a fool,
Since I always follow you with hatred,
I have drawn barrels of blood from the bosom of your country,
And I can only live to your shame, unless
It's to be of service to you.

Which, by daily fortune, always taints

Failing to manage these chances
Of whom he was the lord; or if nature,
Not to be anything other than one thing, not to move

To stifle it in the statement. So our virtues
Lying in the interpretation of the time:
And power, in itself very praiseworthy,
Is there no tomb as obvious as a chair
To praise what he did.
A fire chases a fire; a nail, a nail;

still a faction of your general's party.

Second senator:
Either way, you were his liar, like you said
have, I am he who, speaking truth under him, must
say, you can't pass. Therefore, go back.

MENNIUS:
Has he had dinner, can you tell? because I wouldn't
talk to him until after dinner.

First senator:
You are Roman, aren't you?

MENNIUS:
I am, as is your general.

First senator:
Then you should hate Rome, like him. Can you,
when you have pushed your doors open as quickly as possible
defender of them, and, in a violent popular campaign
ignorance, given your shield to your enemy, think about
face its vengeance with the easy groans of old
women, the virginal palms of your daughters, or with
the paralyzed intercession of a rotten endowment like
you seem to be? Can you think of blowing up the
fire predicted, your city is ready to go up in flames, with
breath as faint as this? No, you are deceived;
therefore, return to Rome and prepare for your
execution: you are condemned, our general has sworn
you no longer have reprieve and forgiveness.

MENNIUS:
Sirrah, if your captain knew I was here, he would
use me with estimation.

Second senator:
Come, my captain doesn't know you.

MENNIUS:
I mean, your general.

First senator:
My general doesn't care about you. Return, I say, go; of fear
I spilled your half-pint of blood; back, it's
the most of what you have: the return.

MENNIUS:
No, but, my friend, my friend,…

CORIOLANUS:
What is the problem?

MENNIUS:
Now, mate, I'll tell you a race:
You will know now that I am in esteem; you should
understand that a Jack guard can't order me since

with him, if you do not keep yourself in the state of
hanging, or a longer death
spectator and crueler in suffering; Here now
right now, and swoon at what is happening to you.
The glorious gods sit hourly in synod about your
special prosperity, and I love you no more than
