you prepare a fire for us; look, here it is
water to extinguish it. I was barely moved to come
you; but being assured that no one but me could move
you, I was blown out of your doors with
sighs; and begs you to forgive Rome and your
fellow petitioners. The good gods reassure your
anger, and returns the dregs on this varlet
here, this one who, like a block, denied my
access to you.

CORIOLANUS:
Far!

MENNIUS:
How! far!

CORIOLANUS:
Wife, mother, child, I don't know. My stuff
Are at the service of others: even if I must
My revenge proper, my remission lies
In the Volscian breasts. That we were familiar,
Ungrateful forgetting will rather poison
Too bad to note how many. Therefore, leave.
My ears against your suits are louder than
Your doors against my strength. Yet, because I loved you,
Take this with you; I write it for you
And I would have praised it. One more word, Menenius,
I won't hear you speak. This man, Aufidius,
Was my beloved in Rome: and yet you see him!

AUFIDIUS:
You maintain a constant character.

First senator:
Now, sir, is your name Menenius?

Second senator:
It is a spell, you see, of great power: you know the
back home.

First senator:
Do you hear how much we are blamed for keeping your
greatness has returned?

Second senator:
Why do you think I should faint?

MENNIUS:
I care neither for the world nor for your general: because
things like you I can hardly think there are,

he himself does not fear it from another: let your general
do his best. For you, be what you are, for a long time; And
your misery increases with your age! I'm telling you,
as I was told, Away!

First senator:
A noble boy, I guarantee it.

Second senator:
The brave boy is our general: he is the rock, the
the oak must not be shaken by the wind.

CORIOLANUS:
We will be before the walls of Rome tomorrow
Drop off our host. My partner in this action,
You must report to the Volscian lords, with what clarity
I put up with this affair.

AUFIDIUS:
Only their ends
You respected; you covered your ears against
The general trial of Rome; never admitted
A private whisper, no, not with such friends
That made them think they were sure of you.

CORIOLANUS:
This last old man,
Which I sent to Rome, with a broken heart,
Loved me above the measure of a father;
No, it really made me happy. Their last refuge
It was to send it; for whom I have old love,
Even though I showed him bitterly, once again I offered him
The first conditions, which they refused
And I cannot now accept; just to give him thanks
That thought he could do more, very little
I gave in to: new embassies and new costumes,
Neither from the State nor from private friends, now
Will I listen to. Ha! what cry is this?
Should I be tempted to break my vow
At the same time is it done? I'm not going to.
My wife comes first; then the honored mold
In which this trunk was framed, and in his hand
The granddaughter has his blood. But outside, affection!
All bonds and privileges of nature, break!
How virtuous it is to be stubborn.
What is this reverence worth? or those dove eyes,
What can make the gods renounce? I'm melting and I'm not
Of earth stronger than the others. My mother bows;
As if Olympus should be a molehill
As a sign of supplication: and my young boy
Has an aspect of intercession, which
The great nature cries “Don’t deny”. let the Volscians
Plow Rome and harrow Italy: I will never do it
Be such a gosling to obey your instinct, but stay upright,
As if a man were the author of himself
And didn't know any other relatives.

VIRGILIA:
My lord and husband!

CORIOLANUS:
These eyes are not the same as the ones I wore in Rome.

VIRGILIA:
The sorrow that delivers us thus changed
It makes you think so.

CORIOLANUS:
Like a boring actor now,
I forgot my role and I'm leaving,
Even to total shame. The best of my flesh,
Forgive my tyranny; but don't say
For this “Forgive our Romans”. O, a kiss
Long as my exile, sweet as my revenge!
Now, by the jealous queen of heaven, this kiss
I took it away from you, my dear; and my real lip
Since then, it has remained blank. Gods ! I'm kidding,
And the noblest mother in the world
Leave without salvation: sink, my knee, I am the earth;
Of your deep duty, more impressions show
Than that of common threads.

VOLUMNIA:
O, arise, blessed one!
While, without a cushion softer than flint,
I kneel before you; and bad
Show your duty, how wrong you've been all this time
Between child and parent.

CORIOLANUS:
What is this?
Your knees against me? to your son corrected?
So leave the stones on the hungry beach
Fill in the stars; so let the mutinous winds
Strike the proud cedars “against the fiery sun;
Murder the impossibility, to do
Which cannot be, light work.

VOLUMNIA:
You are my warrior;
I help supervise you. Do you know this lady?

CORIOLANUS:
The noble sister of Publicola,
The moon of Rome, chaste like the ice cube
It's curdled by the frost of the purest snow
And hanging on Dian's temple: dear Valeria!

VOLUMNIA:
That's a poor summary on your part.
Which, according to the interpretation of full time
Can show as all yourself.

CORIOLANUS:
The god of soldiers,
With the consent of Supreme Jupiter, inform
Your thoughts with nobility; so you can prove
Shame the invulnerable and stay in wars
Like a great marine brand, resistant to every fault,
And save those who look at you!

VOLUMNIA:
Your knee, sir.

CORIOLANUS:
That's my good boy!

VOLUMNIA:
Even him, your wife, this lady and myself,
Are your suitors.

CORIOLANUS:
I beg you, peace:
Or, if you ask, remember this first:
The thing I gave up giving can never
Be restrained by your denials. Don't bid me
Send back my soldiers or surrender
Once again with the mechanics of Rome: don't tell me
Where I seem unnatural: do not desire
To combine my rages and my vengeance with
Your coldest reasons.

VOLUMNIA:
Oh, no more, no more!
You said you wouldn't give us anything;
Because we have nothing more to ask than this
What you already deny: yet we will ask it;
That if you fail in our request, the blame
May you cling to your hardness: listen to us.

CORIOLANUS:
Aufidius, and you Volscians, note; For good
Don't hear anything from Rome in private. Your request?

VOLUMNIA:
Should we be silent and not speak, our clothes
And the state of the bodies would betray what life
We have ruled since your exile. Think with yourself
How more unfortunate than all the women alive
Have we come here: since your sight,
that should
Make our eyes flow with joy, hearts dance
with comfort,
Forces them to cry and tremble with fear and sorrow;
Show the mother, the woman and the child
The heartbreaking son, husband and father
His country's bowels are empty. And to the poor we
The greatest capital of your enmity: you forbid us
Our prayers to the gods, who are a comfort
That's it, but we appreciate it; because how can we,
Alas, how can we pray for our country.
To what we are bound, with your victory,
Where are we bound? alas, or we must lose
The country, our dear nurse, or your person,
Our comfort in the countryside. We must find
An obvious calamity, even if we had
Our wish, which side should win: either you
Must, as a foreign recreationalist, be driven
With handcuffs in our streets, otherwise
marches triumphantly over the ruin of your country,
And bears the palm for having courageously lost
The blood of your wife and your children. For me, my son,
I intend not to wait for fortune until
These wars determine: if I can't persuade you
Rather to show noble grace to both parties
Rather than looking for the end of one, you won't do it sooner
March to attack your country rather than march...
Trust him, you won't... in your mother's womb,
It brought you into this world.

VIRGILIA:
Yes, and mine,
It gave you birth to this boy, to keep your name
Live in time.

Young MARCIUS:
A' won't step on me;
I will run away until I am older, but then I will fight.

CORIOLANUS:
Not with the tenderness of a woman,
Does not require the face of a child or a woman to be seen.
I've been sitting too long.

VOLUMNIA:
No, don't walk away from us like that.
If it were so that our request tended
Save the Romans, therefore destroy
The Volscians you serve, you could condemn us,
Like poison for your honor: no; our costume
It is because you reconcile them: while the Volscians
Can say: “This mercy we have shown; » the Romans,
“This we have received; » and each on each side
I salute you and cry "Be blessed
For having invented this peace! » You know it, big son,
The end of the war is uncertain, but this certainty,
That if you conquer Rome, the profit
What you will thus reap is such a name,
The repetition of which will be accompanied by curses;
Whose chronicle writes: “This man was noble,
But on his last attempt, he erased it;
He destroyed his country and his name remains
In the following century, abhorred. Talk to me, my son:
You affected the beautiful tensions of honor,
Imitate the graces of the gods;
To tear with thunder the broad cheeks of the air,
And yet charge your sulfur with a bolt
This should only anger an oak tree. Why don't you speak?
Do you think it's honorable for a noble man
Do you still have to remember the wrongs? My daughter, speak to yourself:
He doesn't care about your crying. Speak, my boy:
Maybe your childishness will move him more
Just like our reasons. There is no man in the world
More related to the mother of; yet here he lets me chat
Like one in stock. You never in your life
I have shown your dear mother a courtesy,
When she, poor hen, not liking a second brood,
Took you to wars and brought you home safely,
Charged with honor. Say my request is unfair,
And push me away: but if it is not so,
You are not honest; and the gods will torment you,
That you hold me back from duty which
A mother's role belongs. He turns away:
Down, ladies; let's shame him off our knees.
Coriolanus yearns for more pride in his family name
What pity for our prayers. Down: an end;
This is the last: we will therefore return to Rome,
And die among our neighbors. No, here it is:
This boy, who can't say what he would have
But kneels and holds up bands for camaraderie,
Does he reason our petition more forcefully?
So you have to deny it. Come on, let's go:
This man had a Volscan woman for a mother;
His wife is in Corioli and his child
Like him by chance. However, give us our dispatch:
I'll keep quiet until our city is on fire,
And then I'll talk a little.

CORIOLANUS:
O mother, mother!
What have you done? Behold, the heavens are opened,
The gods look down, and this unnatural scene
They laugh. O my mother, mother! Oh!
You have won a happy victory against Rome;
But, for your son, believe it, oh, believe it,
The most dangerous thing is that you triumphed over him,
If not the most deadly for him. But let it come.
Aufidius, although I cannot wage real wars,
I will frame a suitable peace. Now, good Aufidius,
If you were in my place, would you have heard
One less mother? or granted less, Aufidius?

AUFIDIUS:
I was moved by this.

CORIOLANUS:
I dare to swear that you were:
And, sir, it's not nothing to do
My eyes sweat with compassion. But good sir,
What peace you will make, advise me: for my part,
I will not go to Rome, I will return with you; and I pray to you,
Stand with me in this cause. O mother! marry!

AUFIDIUS:

CORIOLANUS:
Yes, little by little;
But we will drink together; and you will bear
A better testimony than words, than us,
Under similar conditions, it will be counter-sealed.
Come, come in with us. Ladies, you deserve
To build you a temple: all the swords
In Italy and in its Confederate arms,
I couldn't have made this peace.

MENNIUS:
We'll see you there in front of the Capitol, over there
corner stone ?

SICINIUS:
Why, what about that?

MENNIUS:
If it is possible for you to move it with your
little finger, there is a little hope, the ladies of
Rome, and especially his mother, could prevail over him.
But I say there is no hope: our throats are
convicted and suspended until his execution.

SICINIUS:
Is it not possible that such a short period of time could change the
condition of man!

MENNIUS:
There is a difference between a worm and a butterfly;
yet your butterfly was a larva. This Marcius is grown
from man to dragon: he has wings; he is more than one
creeping thing.

SICINIUS:
He loved his mother very much.

MENNIUS:
Me too: and he no longer remembers his mother
now only an eight year old horse. Acidity
ripe grapes from his sour face: when he walks, he
moves like an engine, and the ground shrinks before
his trampling: he is capable of piercing a corset with
his eye; speaks like a death knell, and its hum is a
battery. He sits in his state, like a thing made for
Alexander. What he proposes to do is finished
his auctions. He wants nothing more from a god than eternity
and a paradise to enthrone.

SICINIUS:
Yes, mercy, if you denounce it sincerely.

MENNIUS:
I paint him in character. Show what mercy he
the mother will bring him: there is no more mercy
in him there is no milk in a male tiger; that
will our poor city find: and all this is long
You.

SICINIUS:
May the gods be good to us!

MENNIUS:
No, in such a case the gods will not be kind to
We. When we banned it, we did not respect them;
and, returning to break our necks, they do not respect us.

Messenger:
Sir, if you want to save your life, fly home:
The plebeians have your comrade from the platform
And haul it up and down, swearing, if
Roman ladies bring no comfort to the house,
They will kill him within a few centimeters.

SICINIUS:

Good news, good news; the ladies prevailed,
The Volscians are dislodged, and Marcius leaves:
Never has a more joyful day greeted Rome,
No, not the expulsion of the Tarquins.

SICINIUS:
Friend,
Are you sure this is true? is it very safe?

Where are you hiding to doubt it?

Second messenger:

Excellent reason to thank warmly.

And help joy.

Welcome ladies, welcome!

AUFIDIUS:
Go tell the city lords that I'm here:
Give them this paper: after reading it,

The city's ports entered this way and
Intends to appear before the people, hoping
Purge yourself with words: hurry.
Welcome!

First conspirator:
How are things going with our general?

AUFIDIUS:
Anyway
Like a man poisoned by his own alms,
And with his charity killed.

Second conspirator:
Very noble sir,
If you have the same intention in which

Of your great danger.

AUFIDIUS:
Sir, I cannot say:
We have to proceed as we find the people.

Third conspirator:
People will remain uncertain while
“There is a difference between you; but the fall of one or the other
Makes the survivor heir of all.

AUFIDIUS:
I know that;
And my pretext for hitting him confesses
A good build. I raised him and pawned him
My honor for his truth: which being so high,
He watered his new plants with dews of flattery,
Thus seduce my friends; and, to this end,
He bent his nature, never before known
But to be tough, steadfast and free.

Third conspirator:
Sir, his build
When he presented himself as consul, what he lost
Failing to bend down,...

AUFIDIUS:
which I would have spoken about:
Having been banished for this, he came to my home;
I presented his throat to my knife: I took it;
He made him a servant with me; gave him the way
In all his own desires; no, let him choose
From my files, his projects to accomplish,
My best and freshest men; served his purposes
In my own person; helps to reap fame
What he put an end to all his; and I took a certain pride
To do me this harm: until at the end,
I felt like I was his disciple, not his partner, and
He fought me with his face, as if
I had been a mercenary.

First conspirator:
This is what he did, my lord:
The army was amazed, and, in the end,
When he carried Rome and we watched
For no less waste than glory,

AUFIDIUS:
There was this:
This is why my tendons will be tense on him.
A few drops of woman's rum, which are
As cheap as lies, he sold blood and labor
Of our great deed: therefore will he die,
And I will renew myself at his fall. But listen!

First conspirator:
Your hometown you are entering would like a position,
And he was not welcomed home: but he comes again,
Divide the air with noise.

Second conspirator:
And patient fools,
Whose children he killed, their vile throats are torn

Third conspirator:
Therefore, in your opinion,
Before he speaks out or moves people
With what he would say, let him feel your sword,

AUFIDIUS:
Say no more:
Here are the lords.

I didn't deserve it.

Lords:
We have.

First Lord:
And I'm sad to hear it.
What mistakes he made before the last one, I think

Where he had to start and give
The benefit of our direct debits, we respond

AUFIDIUS:
He is coming closer: you will hear him.

CORIOLANUS:
Hail, lords! I have become your soldier,
I am no longer infected by the love of my country
That when I parted from here, but I still subsist
Under your great command. You have to know
It was with success that I tried and
With a bloody passage, your wars even led to
The gates of Rome. Our loot that we brought home
Do more than counterbalance a full third game
Accusations of action. We made peace
With no less honor to the Antiates
What shame for the Romans: and here we deliver,
Subscribed by consuls and patricians,
With the seal of the Senate, what
We have made the situation worse.

AUFIDIUS:
Do not read it, noble lords;
But tell the traitor, to the highest degree
He abused your powers.

CORIOLANUS:
Traitor! how now!

AUFIDIUS:
Yes, traitor, Marcius!

CORIOLANUS:
Marcius!

Coriolanus to Corioli?
You, lords and heads of state, treacherously
He betrayed your company and abandoned,

Breaking one's oath and resolve as
A twist of rotten silk, never admitting it
War council, but to the tears of his nurse
He cried and roared your victory,
That the pages blushed at him and men of heart

CORIOLANUS:
Do you hear, Mars?

AUFIDIUS:

CORIOLANUS:
Ha!

AUFIDIUS:
No more.

Who wears my stripes printed on him; that

First Lord:
Peace to both of you and hear me speak.

Cut me into pieces, Volsces; men and boys,

First Lord:
Carry his body from here;

Second Lord:
His own impatience
He takes much of the blame off Aufidius.

AUFIDIUS:
My rage is gone;
And I am struck with sadness. Take it.
To help, three of the main soldiers; I will be one.
Beat the drum, so that it speaks sadly:
Follow your steel spikes. Although in this city he
Many people are widowed and childless,
Who mourns the wound at this hour,
However, he will keep a noble memory. To assist.

GLOCKESTER:
Now is the winter of our discontent
Made summer glorious by this York sun;
And all the clouds that invaded our house
Deep within the buried ocean.
Now our foreheads are bound by victorious crowns;
Our bruised arms hung like monuments;
Our severe alarms turned into joyful meetings,
Our terrible steps towards delicious measures.
The grim-faced war has smoothed his wrinkled brow;
And now, instead of riding armored steeds
To frighten the souls of fearful adversaries,
He cavorts nimbly in a lady's bedroom
To the lascivious pleasure of a lute.
But I, who am not made for sporty tricks,
Nor made to court a loving mirror;
Me, who is crudely stamped and who wants the majesty of love
Strutting in front of a wanton and wandering nymph;
I, who am reduced by this just proportion,
Deceived in functionality by hiding nature,
Distorted, unfinished, sent before my time
In this breathing world, barely half made up,
And it's so lame and old fashioned
Let the dogs bark at me when I stop near them;
Why, me, in this time of weak peace,
I have no pleasure in passing the time,
Unless you spy on my shadow in the sun
And I descend upon my own deformity:
And so, since I can't prove that I'm a lover,
To entertain these well-spoken beautiful days,
I'm determined to prove that I'm a bad guy
And I hate vain pleasures these days.
I plotted, inductions are dangerous,
By drunken prophecies, slander and dreams,
To put my brother Clarence and the king
In mortal hatred against each other:
What if King Edward was also true and just
How subtle, false and treacherous I am,
On this day Clarence should be meowed closely,
About a prophecy that says "G"
Among Edward's heirs, the murderer will be.
Dive, thoughts, into my soul: here
Clarence arrives.
Brother, have a good day; what does this armed guard mean
Who is waiting for your grace?

CLARENCE:
His Majesty
To ensure my personal safety, I have appointed
This conduct to take me to the Tower.

GLOCKESTER:
For what cause?

CLARENCE:
Because my name is George.

GLOCKESTER:
Alas, my lord, this fault is not your fault;
To do this, he should engage your sponsors:
O, it seems that His Majesty has an intention
That you will be rebaptized in the Tower.
But what is it, Clarence? can I please know?

CLARENCE:
Yeah, Richard, when I know; because I protest
I do not know it yet: but, as I can learn,
He listens to prophecies and dreams;
And from the transverse row tears off the letter G.
And says a wizard told him that by G
His descendants should be disinherited;
And, because my name George starts with G,
It follows in his thought that I am he.
These, as I learn, and toys like these
I urged His Highness to engage me now.

GLOCKESTER:
Well, this is how men are ruled by women:
It's not the king who sends you to the Tower:
My Lady Grey, his wife, Clarence, is her
That tempers him at that end.
Was it not her and this good man of worship,
Anthony Woodville, his brother there,
This prompted him to send Lord Hastings to the Tower,
Where is it delivered from today?
We are not safe, Clarence; we are not safe.

CLARENCE:
By heaven I think no man is safe
But the queen's parents and the night heralds
This quarrel between the king and Mistress Shore.
Have you not heard what a humble supplicant
Was Lord Hastings with her for her delivery?

GLOCKESTER:
Humbly complain to his divinity
I have obtained my liberty from my lord chamberlain.
I'll tell you what; I think that's our way of doing things,
If we remain in favor of the king,
Be his men and wear his livery:
The jealous and worn-out widow and herself,
Since then, our brother has nicknamed them “gentlemen”.
Are powerful gossips in this monarchy.

FREINBURY:
I beg your graces to forgive me both;
His Majesty directly handed over responsibility
So that no one can have a private conference,
To what degree, with his brother.

GLOCKESTER:
Anyway; and I do not please your adoration, Brakenbury,
You can participate in everything we say:
We're not talking about treason, man: we're talking about the king
Is wise and virtuous, and his noble queen
Well aged, fair and not jealous;
We say Shore's wife has a pretty foot,
A cherry lip, a beautiful eye, a fleeting and pleasant tongue;
And may the queen's parents have become gentle people:
How do you say sir? Can you deny all this?

FREINBURY:
With that, my lord, I have nothing to do.

GLOCKESTER:
Nothing to do with Mistress Shore! I tell you, my friend,
He who does nothing with her, except one,
It was better that he did it in secret, alone.

FREINBURY:
Which one, my lord?

GLOCKESTER:
Her husband, rascal: do you want to betray me?

FREINBURY:
I beg your grace to forgive me, and at the same time
Abstain from your conference with the noble Duke.

CLARENCE:
We know your charge, Brakenbury, and we will obey.

GLOCKESTER:
We are the queen's abjects and must obey.
Brother, farewell: I will do it to the king;
And whatever field you employ me in,
If it was to call King Edward's widowed sister,
I will execute him to free you.
In the meantime, this deep shame in the fraternity
This touches me more deeply than you can imagine.

CLARENCE:
I know none of us like this.

GLOCKESTER:
Well, your imprisonment will not be long;
In the meantime, be patient.

CLARENCE:
I definitely have to. Farewell.

GLOCKESTER:
Go, walk the path from which you will never return.
Clarence simple and clear! I love you so much,
That I will soon send your soul to heaven,
If heaven will take the present into our hands.
But who comes here? the new Hastings delivered?

HASTING:
Have a good time of the day to my gracious lord!

GLOCKESTER:
So much to my good lord chamberlain!
Well, are you welcome outdoors.
How did your Lordship bear the imprisonment?

HASTING:
With patience, noble Lord, as prisoners must:
But I will live, my lord, to give them thanks
This was the cause of my imprisonment.

GLOCKESTER:
No doubt, no doubt; and Clarence too;
For those who were your enemies are his,
And I had as much success with him as with you.

HASTING:
It's even more of a shame that the eagle is meowing,
While kites and buzzards hunt freely.

GLOCKESTER:
What's the news abroad?

HASTING:
There is no news so bad abroad as this at home;
The King is sick, weak and melancholy,
And his doctors fear him greatly.

GLOCKESTER:
Now, by Saint Paul, this news is really bad.
Oh, he's been on a bad diet for a long time,
And he consumed his royal person too much:
It's very painful to think about it.
What, is he in his bed?

HASTING:
He is.

GLOCKESTER:
Go first, and I will follow you.
He cannot live, I hope; and must not die
Until George was loaded with post horses to the sky.
I will enter, to further incite his hatred towards Clarence,
With lies well reinforced by weighty arguments;
And if I don't fall into my deep intention,
Clarence doesn't have another day to live:
Which is done, may God take King Edward to his mercy,
And leave the world for me to worry about!
For then I will marry Warwick's youngest daughter.
What if I had killed her husband and her father?
The easiest way to make amends to the girl
It is to become her husband and her father:
Which one am I going to? not so much for love
As for another secret and close intention,
By marrying him, what I must achieve.
And yet I run in front of my horses to the market:
Clarence is still breathing; Edward still lives and reigns:
When they are gone, I will then have to count my winnings.

LADY ANNE:
Lay down, lay down your honorable charge,
If honor can be wrapped in a hearse,
While I lament obsequiously for a while
The premature fall of the virtuous Lancaster.
Poor cold face of a holy king!
Pale ashes of the house of Lancaster!
You, remain bloodless of this royal blood!
May I invoke your ghost,
To hear the lamentations of poor Anne,
Wife of your Edward, of your slain son,
Stabbed by the same hand that caused these wounds!
Here, in these windows which let your life escape,
I pour the helpless balm from my poor eyes.
Cursed be the hand that made these fatal holes!
Cursed be the heart that had the heart to do it!
Cursed the blood who let this blood out of here!
An even more terrible misfortune for this hated wretch,
It makes us unhappy with your death,
That I can wish to vipers, to spiders, to toads,
Or any living, poisonous thing!
If he ever has a child, even an aborted one,
Prodigious and inopportune brought to light,
Whose ugly and unnatural appearance
May frighten the hopeful mother at the sight;
And let him be the heir of his misfortune!
If he ever has a wife, let him make her
A wretched by his death
As I am made by my poor lord and you!
Come now to Chertsey with your sacred load,
Taken from Paul to be buried there;
And yet, as you are tired of the weight,
Rest while I lament the corpse of King Henry.

GLOCKESTER:
Stay, you who carry the corpse, and lay it down.

LADY ANNE:
Which black magician evokes this demon,
To stop dedicated acts of charity?

GLOCKESTER:
Wicked men, lay down the corpse; or, by Saint Paul,
I will make a corpse of the one who disobeys.

Gentleman:
My lord, step back and let the coffin pass.

GLOCKESTER:
Dog without manners! stand when I command:
Advance your halberd higher than my chest,
Or, by Saint Paul, I will strike you on the foot,
And reject yourself, beggar, because of your boldness.

LADY ANNE:
What, are you shaking? are you all afraid?
Alas, I don't blame you; because you are mortal,
And mortal eyes cannot bear the devil.
Advance, terrible minister of hell!
You had only power over his mortal body,
You can't have his soul; so leave.

GLOCKESTER:
Sweet saint, for charity’s sake, do not be so accursed.

LADY ANNE:
Infamous devil, for God's sake, then, and don't disturb us;
For you have made the happy earth your hell,
I filled it with abusive cries and deep exclamations.
If you take pleasure in seeing your heinous acts,
Here is this model of your butchers.
Oh, gentlemen, see, see! dead Henry's wounds
Open their frozen mouths and bleed again!
Blush, blush, you are a mass of filthy deformity;
Because it is your presence that exhales this blood
Cold and empty veins, where no blood remains;
Your act, inhuman and unnatural,
Causes this most unnatural flood.
O God, what this blood has done, avenge his death!
O earth, let this blood drink to avenge its death!
Let the sky with lightning strike the
dead murderer,
Or the earth, open wide and eat it quickly,
As you swallow the blood of this good king
That his arm governed by hell has massacred!

GLOCKESTER:
Madam, you know no rule of charity,
Which returns good for evil, blessing for curse.

LADY ANNE:
Wicked, you know no law of God or man:
No beast so ferocious knows a certain amount of mercy.

GLOCKESTER:
But I don't know any of them, and so I'm not stupid.

LADY ANNE:
O wonderful, when the devils speak the truth!

GLOCKESTER:
Even more wonderful, when the angels are so angry.
Guarantee yourself, divine perfection of a woman,
From these so-called evils, to give me leave,
By circumstance, but to acquit myself.

LADY ANNE:
Guarantee a defused infection of a man,
For these known evils, but to give me permission,
By circumstances, to curse your cursed self.

GLOCKESTER:
More beautiful than tongue can name you, let me
A little free time to apologize.

LADY ANNE:
Dirtier than your heart can think you can do
No common excuse but hanging yourself.

GLOCKESTER:
It is through such despair that I should blame myself.

LADY ANNE:
And, in despairing, you should be excused;
For having taken worthy revenge on yourself,
Who committed a shameful massacre on others.

GLOCKESTER:
You say I killed them, right?

LADY ANNE:
Well, then they are not dead:
But they are dead and evil slaves to you.

GLOCKESTER:
I didn't kill your husband.

LADY ANNE:
Well, then he's alive.

GLOCKESTER:
No, he is dead; and slain by the hand of Edward.

LADY ANNE:
In your fetid throat you lie: Queen Marguerite saw
Your murderous falchion smoking in his blood;
The one you once folded against his chest,
But let your brothers dismiss the subject.

GLOCKESTER:
I was provoked by his slanderous tongue,
which placed their guilt on my innocent shoulders.

LADY ANNE:
You were provoked by your damn mind.
Who has only ever dreamed of butcheries:
Didn't you kill this king?

GLOCKESTER:
I grant you.

LADY ANNE:
Will you grant me that, hedgehog? so God grant me too
You can be damned for this bad deed!
Oh, he was gentle, gentle and virtuous!

GLOCKESTER:
He who is best suited to the King of Heaven is he who possesses him.

LADY ANNE:
He is in heaven, where you will never come.

GLOCKESTER:
Let him thank me for helping me send him there;
For he was more fit for this place than the earth.

LADY ANNE:
And you are unfit for any place other than hell.

GLOCKESTER:
Yes, another place, if you hear me name it.

LADY ANNE:
Dungeon.

GLOCKESTER:
Your bedroom.

LADY ANNE:
I will rest near the room where you rest!

GLOCKESTER:
It will be like this, madam, until I sleep with you.

LADY ANNE:
I hope so.

GLOCKESTER:
I know it. But, sweet Lady Anne,
To leave this lively meeting of our minds,
And fall a little into a slower method,
Is he not the cause of timeless deaths?
Among these Plantagenets, Henry and Edward,
As guilty as the executioner?

LADY ANNE:
You are the most cursed cause and effect.

GLOCKESTER:
Your beauty was the cause of this effect;
Your beauty: which haunted me in my sleep
To undertake the death of the whole world,
So I could live for an hour in your sweet bosom.

LADY ANNE:
If I thought that, I'll tell you, homicide,
These nails should rip this beauty off my cheeks.

GLOCKESTER:
These eyes could never bear the shipwreck of sweet beauty;
You shouldn't ruin it, if I stayed here:
While the whole world is rejoicing in the sun,
So I'm over there; This is my day, my life.

LADY ANNE:
The dark night shades your day, and death your life!

GLOCKESTER:
Do not curse yourself, beautiful creature, you are both.

LADY ANNE:
I would like to take revenge on you.

GLOCKESTER:
It is a most unnatural quarrel,
To take revenge on the one who loves you.

LADY ANNE:
It's a fair and reasonable quarrel,
To take revenge on the one who killed my husband.

GLOCKESTER:
The one who deprived you, madam, of your husband,
I did it to help you find a better husband.

LADY ANNE:
His best does not blow on the earth.

GLOCKESTER:
He lives and loves you better than he could.

LADY ANNE:
Name it.

GLOCKESTER:
Plantagenet.

LADY ANNE:
Well, it was him.

GLOCKESTER:
The same name, but of a better nature.

LADY ANNE:
Where is he?

GLOCKESTER:
Here.
Why are you spitting on me?

LADY ANNE:
Would it be a deadly poison for you!

GLOCKESTER:
Never did poison come from such a sweet place.

LADY ANNE:
I never hung poison on a fouler toad.
Out of my sight! you infect my eyes.

GLOCKESTER:
Your eyes, sweet lady, have infected mine.

LADY ANNE:
Could they be basilisks to strike you to death!

GLOCKESTER:
I wish they were, so that I could die immediately;
For now, they're killing me with a living death.
Your eyes drew tears of salt,
Shamed their appearance with a reserve of childish drops:
Those eyes that never shed tears of remorse,
No, when my father York and Edward cried,
To hear the pitiful moan that Rutland uttered
When the black-faced Clifford shook his sword at him;
Nor when your warrior father, like a child,
I told the sad story of my father's death,
And twenty times I stopped to sob and cry,
That all the spectators had wet their cheeks
Like trees covered in rain: in this sad moment
My manly eyes disdained a humble tear;
And what these sorrows could not exhale from there,
Your beauty made them blind with tears.
I have never pursued a friend or an enemy;
My tongue has never been able to learn a sweet and soothing word;
But now your beauty is offered at my fee,
My proud heart pursues and makes my tongue speak.
Do not teach your lips such contempt, for they were made
For a kiss, madam, not for such contempt.
If your vengeful heart cannot forgive,
Behold, I lend you here this sharp sword;
Please hide in this true bosom.
And let out the soul that adores you,
I expose him naked to the mortal blow,
And humbly beg for death on my knees.
No, don't stop; because I killed King Henry,
But it was your beauty that provoked me.
No, now hurry up; it was I who stabbed young Edward,
But it was your heavenly face that turned me on.
Take back the sword, or take me.

LADY ANNE:
Rise up, dissembler: although I wish you dead,
I will not be the executioner.

GLOCKESTER:
So tell me to kill myself, and I will.

LADY ANNE:
I have already.

GLOCKESTER:
Tush, it was in your anger:
Repeat it, and, even with the word,
This hand which, for your love, killed your love,
Must, for your love, kill a much truer love;
You will be complicit in their two deaths.

LADY ANNE:
I would like to know your heart.

GLOCKESTER:
It's written in my language.

LADY ANNE:
I fear both are false.

GLOCKESTER:
So man has never been true.

LADY ANNE:
Well, raise your sword.

GLOCKESTER:
Say, my peace is made.

LADY ANNE:
You will know this later.

GLOCKESTER:
But should I live in hope?

LADY ANNE:
All men, I hope, live like this.

GLOCKESTER:
Guarantee to wear this ring safely.

LADY ANNE:
Taking is not giving.

GLOCKESTER:
Look how this ring encompasses the finger.
Thus your chest encloses my poor heart;
Wear them both, for they are both yours.
And if your poor devoted supplicant can
But ask a favor of your gracious hand,
You confirm his happiness forever.

LADY ANNE:
What is this?

GLOCKESTER:
That it would please you to leave these sad designs behind
To him who has more reason to mourn,
And currently, go to Crosby Place;
Where, after solemnly burying
In the monastery of Chertsey, this noble king,
And I wet his grave with my repentant tears,
I will see you with all my duty:
For various unknown reasons. I beg you,
Grant me this favor.

LADY ANNE:
With all my heart; and that makes me very happy too,
To see that you have become so penitent.
Tressel and Berkeley, follow me.

GLOCKESTER:
Say goodbye to me.

LADY ANNE:
This is more than you deserve;
But since you teach me to flatter you,
Imagine that I have already said goodbye.

GLOCKESTER:
Gentlemen, take the corpse.

GENTLEMEN:
Towards Chertsey, noble lord?

GLOCKESTER:
No, at White Friars; there witness my strike.
Has a woman of this mood ever been courted?
Has a woman in this humor ever been won?
I will have it ; but I won't keep it for long.
What! I, who killed her husband and her father,
To take her in the most extreme hatred of her heart,
With curses in my mouth, tears in my eyes,
The bloody witness of his hatred by;
Having God, his conscience and these bars
against me,
And I have nothing at all to support my suit,
But the simple devil and the hidden glances,
And yet, to win it, everyone did nothing!
Ha!
Has she already forgotten this brave prince,
Edward, her lord, whom I, about three months ago,
Stabbed in my angry mood at Tewksbury?
A gentler and more charming gentleman,
Framed in the lavishness of nature,
Young, valiant, wise and undoubtedly royal,
The spacious world can no longer afford
And will she lower her eyes on me again,
This cut off the golden flower of this sweet prince,
And made his widow a terrible bed?
About me, whose all is not equal to half of Edward?
On me, who stops me and am thus informed?
My duchy has a negationist beggar,
I've been getting the wrong person all this time:
On my life she discovers, even though I can't,
Myself for being a wonderful and decent man.
I will be charged for a mirror,
And entertain a score or two of tailors,
To study the ways to adorn my body:
Since I'm in favor of myself,
Will maintain it inexpensively.
But first, I'm going to turn this man over in his grave;
And then come back lamenting for my love.
Shine, beautiful sun, until I have bought a drink,
So that I can see my shadow as I pass by.

RIVERS:
Have patience, madam: there is no doubt about his majesty
Will soon return to usual health.

GRAY:
To the extent you tolerate it, it makes it even worse:
Therefore, for God's sake, have good comfort,
And proclaim his grace with quick and joyful words.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
If he were dead, what would become of me?

RIVERS:
No other evil than the loss of such a lord.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
The loss of such a lord includes all damages.

GRAY:
The heavens have blessed you with a good son,
To be your comforter when he is gone.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Oh, he's young and his minority
Is entrusted to the trust of Richard Gloucester,
A man who doesn't love me, or any of you.

RIVERS:
Is it concluded that he will be protective?

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
It is determined, not yet concluded:
But it will be like this if the king has a miscarriage.

GRAY:
Here come the lords of Buckingham and Derby.

BUCKINGHAM:
Have a good time of the day to your royal grace!

DERBY:
May God make your majesty as joyful as you have been!

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Countess Richmond, my good lord of Derby.
To your good prayers I will hardly say amen.
Yet, Derby, although she is your wife,
And don't love me, be you, good lord, assured
I don't hate you for your proud arrogance.

DERBY:
I beg you, either don't believe
The envious slanders of his false accusers;
Or, if she is accused according to a true report,
Bear with his weakness, which I think continues
Of a capricious illness and of no founded malice.

RIVERS:
Have you seen the king today, my lord of Derby?

DERBY:
But now the Duke of Buckingham and I
Came to visit his majesty.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
How likely is his amendment, my lords?

BUCKINGHAM:
Madam, good hope; his grace speaks joyfully.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
God grant him health! Did you talk with him?

BUCKINGHAM:
Madam, we have done it: he wishes to make atonement
Between the Duke of Gloucester and your brothers,
And between them and my lord chamberlain;
And he sent them to warn them of his royal presence.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
If everything went well! but that will never be the case
I fear our happiness is at its highest.

GLOCKESTER:
They hurt me, and I won't stand it:
Who are they who complain to the king,
That, in truth, I am severe and that I don't like them?
By Saint Paul, they love his grace but lightly
It fills his ears with such discordant rumors.
Because I can't flatter and speak fair,
Smile on the faces of men, smooth, deceptive and cogwheel,
Duck with French nods and the courtesy of monkeys,
I must be considered a spiteful enemy.
Can't a simple man live without thinking of evil,
But we must therefore abuse its simple truth
By silky, sly, insinuating Jacks?

RIVERS:
To whom, in all this presence, does your grace speak?

GLOCKESTER:
For you, this has neither honesty nor grace.
When did I hurt you? when did you wrong yourself?
Or you ? or you ? or a member of your faction?
A plague on you all! His royal person,...
May God preserve better than you wish!
I can't stay silent just to breathe,
But you have to bother him with obscene complaints.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Brother of Gloucester, you are wrong.
The king, by his own royal disposition,
And not provoked by any other pretender;
Aiming, it seems, at your inner hatred,
What manifests itself in your external actions
Against my family, my brothers and myself,
Has it sent; so that he can thus gather
The motive of your ill will, and so remove it.

GLOCKESTER:
I can't say it: the world has become so bad,
That troglodytes prey where eagles do not dare to perch:
Since every Jack became a gentleman
There are many sweet people who have made a Jack.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Come on, come on, we know what you mean, brother
Gloucester;
You envy my advancement and that of my friends:
God grant that we never need you!

GLOCKESTER:
In the meantime, God grant that we may need you:
Your brother is imprisoned by your means,
Myself dishonored and the nobility
Held in contempt; while many fair promotions
Are daily given to ennoble those
These rare items, about two days ago, were worth a noble.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
By Him who raised me to this prudent height
Of this happy happiness that I enjoyed,
I have never praised his majesty
Against the Duke of Clarence, but were
A serious advocate to argue in his favor.
My lord, you do me a shameful wrong,
Falsely to lure me to these vile suspects.

GLOCKESTER:
You can deny that you are not the cause
Of the late imprisonment of Lord Hastings.

RIVERS:
She can, my lord, for...

GLOCKESTER:
She can, Lord Rivers! why, who doesn't know?
She can do more, sir, than deny this:
It can help you get many fair preferences,
And then refuse him his help,
And attribute these honors to your high merits.
What can't she do? She can, yes, marry, can she...

RIVERS:
What, can she get married?

GLOCKESTER:
What, marry, may she! marry a king,
A single man, a handsome teenager too:
I think your grandmother had a worse game.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
My Lord of Gloucester, I have endured too long
Your brutal reprimands and bitter mockery:
By heaven I will make known to his majesty
With these crude taunts that I often endured.
I'd rather be a country servant
That a great queen, in this state,
To be mocked, scorned and harassed in this way:
I'm not very happy being the Queen of England.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
And the reduction would be so minimal, my God, I beg you!
Your honor, your state and your seat are owed to me.

GLOCKESTER:
What! Are you threatening me to talk about the king?
Tell him, and don't spare him: look, what I said
I will testify in the presence of the king:
I dare the adventure to be sent to the Tower.
It is time to speak; my pains are completely forgotten.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Out, devil! I remember it too well:
You killed my husband Henry in the Tower,
And Edward, my poor son, at Tewksbury.

GLOCKESTER:
Before you were queen, yes, or your husband was king,
I was a workhorse in his great affairs;
An eliminator of his proud adversaries,
A liberal rewarder of his friends:
To royalize his blood, I shed mine.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Yes, and much better blood than his or yours.

GLOCKESTER:
All this time, you and your husband Gray
We were partisans of the House of Lancaster;
And Rivers, you too. He wasn't your husband
In the battle of Marguerite at Saint Alban, killed?
Let me remind you, if you forget,
What you were before now and what you are;
With everything I have been and what I am.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
A wicked murderer, and you still are.

GLOCKESTER:
Poor Clarence abandoned his father, Warwick;
Yes, and he renounced himself, which Jesus forgives!

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
What vengeance from God!

GLOCKESTER:
Fighting with Edward's party for the crown;
And for his salary, poor lord, he is meowed.
I wish my heart were made of flint, like Edward's;
Or Edward is sweet and pitiful, like mine
I am too childish and stupid for this world.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Go to hell for shame and leave the world,
You, cacodemon! there is your kingdom.

RIVERS:
Monsignor of Gloucester, in these busy days
That you ask us here to prove that we are enemies,
We then followed our lord, our rightful king:
And so would we, if you were to be our king.

GLOCKESTER:
If I had to be! I would rather be a peddler:
Far from my heart this thought!

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
As little joy, my lord, as you suppose
You should take advantage of it, if you were the king of this country,
As little joy as you can suppose in me.
I like it, being the queen.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
The queen enjoyed a little joy;
Because I am her, and absolutely joyless.
I can't be patient anymore.
Listen to me, you pirates in conflict, who argue
By sharing what you took from me!
Which one of you doesn't tremble when looking at me?
Otherwise, being a queen, you bow like subjects,
Yet, because you have been deposed, you tremble like rebels?
O sweet villain, do not turn away!

GLOCKESTER:
Infamous wrinkled witch, what are you doing in my eyes?

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
But repetition of what you have wasted;
That's what I'll do before I let you go.

GLOCKESTER:
Have you not been banished under penalty of death?

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
I was; but I find more pain in banishment
That death can bring me back here near my home.
You owe me a husband and a son;
And you a kingdom; your allegiance to all:
The sorrow I feel is by right yours,
And all the pleasures you usurp are mine.

GLOCKESTER:
The curse that my noble father imposed on you,
When you crowned his warrior eyebrows with paper
And with your contempt you drew rivers from his eyes,
And then, to dry them, he gave weight to the duke
Imbued with the impeccable blood of the pretty Rutland...
His curses, then from the bitterness of the soul
Denounced against you, all fall on you;
And it was God, not us, who tormented your bloody deed.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
God is therefore just to right the innocent.

HASTING:
Oh, it was the most despicable act to kill that baby,
And the most ruthless one you've ever heard of!

RIVERS:
The tyrants themselves cried when this was reported.

DORSET:
No one prophesied his revenge.

BUCKINGHAM:
Northumberland, then present, wept when he saw him.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
What were you scolding before my arrival,
Ready to take each other by the throat,
And you turn all your hatred now on me?
Has the terrible curse of York prevailed so much in heaven?
That the death of Henry, the death of my adorable Edward,
The loss of their kingdom, my sad banishment,
Could everyone answer for this sullen kid?
Can curses pierce the clouds and enter the sky?
Why then do you yield, dark clouds, to my rapid curses!
If not by war, it is by excess that your king will die,
Like ours by murder, to make him a king!
Edward, your son, who is now Prince of Wales,
For Edward, my son, who was Prince of Wales,
To die in one's youth through such untimely violence!
You yourself are a queen, for me it was a queen,
Survive your glory, like my miserable self!
May you live long to mourn the loss of your children;
And see another, as I see you now,
Adorned with your rights, just as you are blocked from mine!
Long die your happy days before your death;
And after long hours of sorrow,
Do not die, neither mother, nor wife, nor Queen of England!
Rivers and Dorset, you were there,
And you too, Lord Hastings, when my son
Was stabbed with bloody daggers: God, I pray,
So that none of you lives out his natural age,
But by an unexpected accident, cut off!

GLOCKESTER:
You have done your charm, odious withered witch!

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
And forget you? stay, dog, because you will listen to me.
If the sky has a serious plague in store
Beyond those I can wish for you,
Oh, let them keep it until your sins are ripe,
And then reject their indignation
On you, the disturber of the peace of the poor world!
The worm of conscience is still gnawing at your soul!
Your friends suspect traitors while you live,
And take deep traitors for your dearest friends!
No sleep, close your mortal eye,
Unless it's during a tormenting dream
It scares you with one hell of bad devils!
You, elf-marked, aborted and rooted pig!
You who were sealed in your nativity
The slave of nature and the son of hell!
You, slander of your mother's heavy belly!
You hated the issues from your father's loins!
You, rag of honor! you hated...

GLOCKESTER:
Daisy.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Richard!

GLOCKESTER:
Ha!

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
I'm not calling you.

GLOCKESTER:
So I cry out to you for mercy, for I had thought
That you called me all those bitter names.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Well, that's what I did; but I wasn't expecting any response.
Oh, let me end my curse!

GLOCKESTER:
“I made it and it ends with 'Margaret.'

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Thus have you uttered your curse against yourself.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Poor painted queen, vain flourishing of my fortune!
Why are you pouring sugar on this bottle spider,
What mortal web are you entangled in?
Stupid, stupid! you sharpen a knife to kill yourself.
The time will come when you will wish me
To help you curse that poisonous toad.

HASTING:
Woman of ill omen, end your frenzied curse,
Lest you strain our patience.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Shame on you ! you all moved mine.

RIVERS:
If you were well served, you would learn your duty.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
To serve me well, you should all do my duty to me,
Teach me to be your queen, and you my subjects:
O, serve me well, and teach yourself this duty!

DORSET:
Don't argue with her; she is crazy.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Peace, master marquis, you are malapert:
Your brand new seal of honor is barely current.
O, that your young nobility may judge
What it was like to lose him and be unhappy!
Those who stand on high have many breaths to shake them;
And if they fall, they break into pieces.

GLOCKESTER:
Good advice, get married: learn it, learn it, marquis.

DORSET:
This affects you, my lord, as much as it does me.

GLOCKESTER:
Yes, and much more: but I was born so high,
Our area is built at the top of the cedar,
And he mocks the wind and despises the sun.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
And turns the sun into shadow; Alas! Alas!
Witness my son, now in the shadow of death;
Whose bright rays of your cloudy anger
Withdrew into eternal darkness.
Your area is built in the nest of our area.
O God, who sees this, do not suffer it!
As it was won with blood, so may it be lost!

BUCKINGHAM:
Have done! out of shame, if not out of charity.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Advise me neither charity nor shame:
You have dealt with me uncharitably,
And shamefully, because of you, my hopes are massacred.
My charity is an outrage, life my shame
And in this shame still lives the rage of my sorrow.

BUCKINGHAM:
I did, I did.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
O princely Buckingham, I will kiss your hand,
As a sign of league and friendship with you:
Now it's just for you and your noble house!
Your clothes are not stained with our blood,
Nor you within the perimeter of my curse.

BUCKINGHAM:
Nor anyone here; because curses never pass
The lips of those who breathe them in the air.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
I won't believe it but they go up to heaven,
And there the sweet sleeping peace of God awakens.
O Buckingham, beware of that dog!
Look, when he flatters, he bites; and when he bites,
Her venom tooth will irritate her to the point of death:
Don't deal with him, beware of him;
Sin, death and hell have marked him with their marks,
And all their ministers served him.

GLOCKESTER:
What does she say, my Lord of Buckingham?

BUCKINGHAM:
Nothing I respect, my gracious lord.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
What, do you despise me for my gentle advice?
And appease the devil I warn you against?
O, but remember that another day,
When he breaks your heart with sorrow,
And say that poor Margaret was a prophetess!
Live each of you subject to his hatred,
And he to yours, and all of you to God's!

HASTING:
My hair stands up to hear his curses.

RIVERS:
And mine too: I wonder why she is free.

GLOCKESTER:
I can't blame him: by the holy mother of God,
She was too wrong; and I repent
My part that I did to him.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
I've never done it to him, to my knowledge.

GLOCKESTER:
But you are completely wrong about her.
I was too hot to do anyone any good,
It's too cold to think about it now.
Marry, as for Clarence, he is well rewarded,
He is frankly fattened for his pain
God forgives those who cause it!

RIVERS:
A virtuous and Christian conclusion,
Pray for those who have hurt us.

GLOCKESTER:
And me too :
be well advised.
For if I had cursed now, I had cursed myself.

CATESBY:
Madam, his majesty is calling you,
And for your grace; and you, my noble lords.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Catesby, we are coming. Lords, will you come with us?

RIVERS:
Madam, we will attend your pardon.

GLOCKESTER:
I do bad and start fighting first.
The secret misdeeds I've committed
I leave myself to the heavy responsibility of others.
Clarence, whom I have indeed laid down in darkness,
I cry to many simple seagulls
Namely, at Hastings, Derby, Buckingham;
And say it's the queen and her allies
This raises the king against the duke, my brother.
Well, they believe it; and at the same time sharpens me
To get revenge on Rivers, Vaughan, Grey:
But then I sigh; and, with a piece of writing,
Tell them that God commands us to do good for evil:
And so I dress my naked villain
With weird old endings stolen from the holy scriptures;
And I look like a saint, while I play the devil the most.
But sweet ! here are my executioners.
Well, my robust and resolute friends!
Are you now going to expedite this act?

First murderer:
We are, my lord; and come get the money order
So that we may be admitted where he is.

GLOCKESTER:
Well thought; I have it here about me.
When you're done, head to Crosby Place.
But, gentlemen, be abrupt in your execution,
Despite your obstinacy, do not hear him plead;
Because Clarence expresses himself well, and perhaps
It might bring pity to your hearts if you mark it.

First murderer:
Poof!
Do not be afraid, my lord, we cannot bear to talk;
Talkers don't do good deeds: rest assured
We come to use our hands and not our tongue.

GLOCKESTER:
Your eyes drop millstones, when the eyes of fools drop tears:
I like you guys; about your business directly;
Come on, come on, hurry up.

First murderer:
We will, my noble lord.

FREINBURY:
Why is Your Grace looking so heavily today?

CLARENCE:
O, I spent a miserable night,
So full of ugly sights, of horrible dreams,
As I am a faithful and Christian man,
I won't spend another night like this,
Even if it was to buy a world of happy days,
The times were so full of gloomy terror!

FREINBURY:
What was your dream? I can't wait to hear you say it.

CLARENCE:
I thought I was out of the Tower,
And was embarked to pass through Burgundy;
And, in my company, my brother Gloucester;
Who from my cabin tempted me to walk
On the hatches: from there we looked towards England,
And quoted a thousand times frighteningly,
During the York and Lancaster Wars
This had happened to us. As we walked
On the dizzying foot of the hatches,
It seemed to me that Gloucester had stumbled; and, falling,
It struck me, this thought of remaining there, overboard,
In the tumultuous waves of the main one.
Lord, Lord! I thought, what pain it was to drown!
What a terrible sound of water in my ears!
What horrible visions of death in my eyes!
It seemed to me that I had seen a thousand terrifying wrecks;
Ten thousand men who fish are eaten away;
Quarters of gold, great anchors, heaps of pearls,
Priceless stones, worthless jewels,
All scattered at the bottom of the sea:
Some lay in the skulls of the dead; and, in these holes
Where eyes once dwelt they crept,
As if we despise the eyes, reflecting the precious stones,
Who courted the slimy bottom of the depths,
And he didn't care about the scattered dead bones.

FREINBURY:
Did you have so much leisure at the time of death
Contemplate the secrets of the depths?

CLARENCE:
I thought that was the case; and often I have strived
Give in the ghost: but still the envious flow
Kept in my soul, and I won't let it out
Seek the empty air, vast and wandering;
But I smothered it in my panting mass,
Which almost burst and threw it back into the sea.

FREINBURY:
Didn't you wake up with this painful agony?

CLARENCE:
no, my dream continued after life;
Oh, then began the storm on my soul,
Who passed, I thought, the melancholy flow,
With this sinister ferryman of whom the poets speak,
In the kingdom of perpetual night.
The first who greeted my foreign soul there,
Was my great-father-in-law, the famous Warwick;
Who cried out loud: “What a scourge for perjurer
Can this dark monarchy afford the fake Clarence?
And so he disappeared: then he came wandering that way
A shadow like an angel, with shiny hair
Tasted with blood; and he cried out loud,
“Clarence came; Clarence false, ephemeral and perjured,
It stabbed me in the field near Tewksbury;
Seize him, Furies, take him to your torments!
With this, I thought, a legion of evil demons
Surrounded me and screamed in my ears
Screams so hideous, that with the very noise
I woke up shaking, and for a season afterwards
I couldn't believe I was in hell,
Such a terrible impression made the dream.

FREINBURY:
It is not surprising, my lord, even if it frightened you;
I promise you, I'm afraid to hear you say it.

CLARENCE:
O Brakenbury, I have done these things,
Who now testify against my soul,
For Edward's sake; and see how he rewards me!
Oh my God! if my deep prayers cannot soothe you,
But you will take revenge for my misdeeds,
But execute your anger in me alone,
O, spare my innocent wife and my poor children!
I pray you, sweet guardian, stay close to me;
My soul is heavy and I would like to sleep.

FREINBURY:
I will, my lord: God give your grace good rest!
Grief breaks seasons and hours of rest,
Does the night in the morning and the night at noon.
Princes have only their tides for their glory,
An external honor for an internal work;
And, for an imagination not felt,
They often feel a world of restless worries:
So that, between their tides and their low names,
There is nothing different except external fame.

First murderer:
Ho! Who is here?

FREINBURY:
What in God's name are you and how did you get here?

First murderer:
I wanted to speak with Clarence, and I came here on my feet.

FREINBURY:
Yeah, are you so brief?

Second murderer:
O sir, it is better to be brief than tedious. To show
him our commission; do not speak anymore.

FREINBURY:
I am, in this, commanded to deliver
The noble Duke of Clarence in your hands:
I will not argue about what is meant by that,
Because I will be innocent of meaning.
Here are the keys, the duke sleeps there:
I am going to the king; and tells him
This is how I renounced my charge to you.

First murderer:
Do it, it's a matter of wisdom: good luck.

Second murderer:
What, are we stabbing him while he sleeps?

First murderer:
No; then he will say it was cowardly, when he wakes up.

Second murderer:
When he wakes up ! why, fool, he will never wake up until
the day of judgment.

First murderer:
Well, then he will say that we stabbed him in his sleep.

Second murderer:
The insistence of this word “judgment” has generated a sort of
of remorse in me.

First murderer:
What, are you afraid?

Second murderer:
Not to kill him, having a warrant for his arrest; but be
damned for having killed him, against whom no warrant can defend us.

First murderer:
I thought you were solved.

Second murderer:
This is what I do, to let him live.

First murderer:
Let's go back to the Duke of Gloucester and tell him.

Second murderer:
Please stay a moment: I hope my holy mood
will change; it used to hold me back but while we
I would say twenty.

First murderer:
How do you feel now ?

Second murderer:
"My faith, certain remnants of conscience are still
in me.

First murderer:
Remember our reward, when the deed is done.

Second murderer:
“Zounds, he dies: I forgot the reward.

First murderer:
Where is your conscience now?

Second murderer:
In the purse of the Duke of Gloucester.

First murderer:
So when he opens his purse to give us our reward,
your conscience flies away.

Second murderer:
Let go; there are few or none that will entertain him.

First murderer:
What if it came back to you?

Second murderer:
I will not get involved: it is a dangerous thing: that
makes man a coward: a man cannot fly, but he
accuses him; he cannot swear, but that stops him;
he cannot sleep with his neighbor's wife, but
detects it: it is a shameful and blushing spirit which
mutinies in a man's breast; it fills a lot of
obstacles: this made me once restore a gold purse
that I found; he begs every man who keeps him: he
is expelled from all cities for a
dangerous thing; and every man who wants to live
well strives to trust and live
without this.

First murderer:
'Zounds, he's still by my side now, persuading me
don't kill the duke.

Second murderer:
Take the devil in your mind and do not relieve him: he
I would like to insinuate with you, but to make you sigh.

First murderer:
But I'm strong, he can't get the better of me,
I guarantee it.

Second murderer:
He spoke like a guy who respected his
reputation. Come, shall we go to this equipment?

First murderer:
Take it on the suit with the handles of your
the sword, and then we will cut it in the butt of Malvasia
In the next room.

Second murderer:
O excellent design! do something stupid to him.

First murderer:
Listen ! he stirs: should I knock?

Second murderer:
No, let's reason it out first.

CLARENCE:
Where are you, guardian? give me a cup of wine.

Second murderer:
You will soon have enough wine, my lord.

CLARENCE:
What in the name of God are you?

Second murderer:
A man, like you.

CLARENCE:
But not, as I am, royal.

Second murderer:
Nor you, like us, faithful.

CLARENCE:
Your voice is thunderous, but your looks are humble.

Second murderer:
My voice is now that of the king, my appearance is my own.

CLARENCE:
How dark and deadly you speak!
Your eyes threaten me: why are you pale?
Who sent you here? Why are you coming?

Both:
To, to, to...

CLARENCE:
To murder me?

Both:
Aouch aouch.

CLARENCE:
You barely have the heart to tell me,
And so I can't have the heart to do it.
How, my friends, have I offended you?

First murderer:
You have not offended us, but the king.

CLARENCE:
I will reconcile with him again.

Second murderer:
Never, my lord; so prepare to die.

CLARENCE:
Are you called to come out of a man's world
To kill innocent people? What is my offense?
Where is the evidence that accuses me?
What legitimate quest has delivered its verdict
To the sullen judge? or who pronounced
The bitter sentence of poor Clarence's death?
Before being condemned by the law,
Threatening me with death is completely illegal.
I charge you, because you hope to have redemption
By the dear blood of Christ shed for our grave sins,
That you leave and don't lay your hand on me
The act you are undertaking is damnable.

First murderer:
What we will do, we do to order.

Second murderer:
And the one who commanded is the king.

CLARENCE:
Wrong vassal! the great king of kings
Has he ordained in the tables of his law
That thou shalt not commit murder: and therefore shalt thou do it,
Reject his edict and fulfill a man's?
Take care; for he holds vengeance in his hands,
To cast down on their heads those who break his law.

Second murderer:
And it is this same vengeance that he launches on you,
For perjury and for murder also:
You have received the holy sacrament,
Fighting in the House of Lancaster feud.

First murderer:
And, like a traitor in the name of God,
Did you break that vow? and with your treacherous blade
Get rid of the entrails of your sovereign's son.

Second murderer:
Whom you swore to cherish and defend.

First murderer:
How can you insist on the terrible law of God,
When did you break it this bad?

CLARENCE:
Alas! for whom did I commit this evil deed?
For Edward, for my brother, for him: well, gentlemen,
He sent you so as not to murder me for this
Because in this sin he is as deep as I am.
If God wants revenge for this act.
Oh, I still know you, he does it publicly,
Do not take away strife from his mighty arm;
He doesn't need any indirect or illegal route
To cut off those who offended him.

First murderer:
Who made you a damn minister,
When the courageous Plantagenêt rushes,
This princely novice was beaten to death by you?

CLARENCE:
My brother's love, the devil and my rage.

First murderer:
Your brother's love, our duty and your fault,
Provoke us here now to slaughter you.

CLARENCE:
Oh, if you love my brother, don't hate me;
I'm his brother and I like him.
If you're hired for me, go back,
And I will send you to my brother Gloucester,
Who will reward you better for my life
That Edward will do it for the news of my death.

Second murderer:
You are deceived, your brother Gloucester hates you.

CLARENCE:
no, he loves me and he cares about me:
Go to him for me.

Both:
Yes, we will.

CLARENCE:
Tell him when our princely father York
Blessed his three sons with his victorious arm,
And charged us with his soul to love us,
He hardly thought about this divided friendship:
Tell Gloucester to think about it, and he'll cry.

First murderer:
Yes, millstones; how it taught us to cry.

CLARENCE:
Oh, don't slander him, for he is good.

First murderer:
RIGHT,
Like snow harvests. You are deceiving yourself:
He's the one who sent us here now to slaughter you.

CLARENCE:
It can not be; because when I separated from him,
He hugged me and sobbed:
That he would work on my delivery.

Second murderer:
Well that's what he does, now he delivers you
From the servitude of this world to the joys of heaven.

First murderer:
Make your peace with God, for you must die, my lord.

CLARENCE:
Do you have this sacred feeling in your soul,
To advise me to make peace with God,
And yet you are so blind to your soul,
That you will make war on God by killing me?
Ah, gentlemen, think about who started you
Doing this act will make you hate for this act.

Second murderer:
What will we do ?

CLARENCE:
Give up and save your souls.

First murderer:
Give up! it's loose and feminine.

CLARENCE:
Not giving in is bestial, savage, diabolical.
Which of you, if you were the son of a prince,
Being turned away from freedom, as I am now,
if two murderers like you came to you,
Wouldn't you beg for life?
My friend, I see pity in your eyes:
O, if your eye is not more flattering,
Come to my side and beg for me,
As you would beg, were you in my distress
A beggar prince, what beggar does not have pity?

Second murderer:
Look behind you, my lord.

First murderer:
Take this, and this: if all this is not enough,
I'm going to drown you in Malvasia's ass inside.

Second murderer:
A bloody and desperately executed act!
Like Pilate, I would wash my hands
Of this most serious guilty murder committed!

First murderer:
How now! what do you mean, not to help me?
By heaven, the Duke will know how lazy you are!

Second murderer:
I wish he knew I saved his brother!
Take the prize, and tell him what I say;
For I repent of having killed the duke.

First murderer:
Me neither: leave, coward as you are.
Now must I hide his body in a hole,
Until the Duke orders his burial:
And when I have my meal, I must go;
Because it will disappear, and I must not stay here.

KING EDWARD IV:
Why, then: I have now done a good day's work:
You, peers, continue this united league:
I wait every day for an embassy
From my Redeemer to redeem me from now on;
And now, in peace, my soul will part from heaven,
Since I put my friends at peace on earth.
Rivers and Hastings, take each other's hands;
Don't hide your hatred, swear your love.

RIVERS:
By heaven, my heart is purged of reluctant hatred:
And with my hand I seal the true love of my heart.

HASTING:
So I flourish, as I sincerely swear!

KING EDWARD IV:
Take care not to linger before your king;
Lest he who is the supreme king of kings
Confound your hidden lie and reward
One of you has to be the end of the other.

HASTING:
Then I prosper, because I swear perfect love!

RIVERS:
And I, how I love Hastings with all my heart!

KING EDWARD IV:
Madam, you are not exempt from this,
Neither your son Dorset, Buckingham, nor you;
You have been factional against each other,
Woman, love Lord Hastings, let him kiss your hand;
And what you do, do it without pretense.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Here, Hastings; I will never remember it again
Our ancient hatred, so prosper me and mine!

KING EDWARD IV:
Dorset, kiss him; Hastings, I love Lord Marquess.

DORSET:
This exchange of love, I protest here,
For my part, I will be inviolable.

HASTING:
And so I swear, my lord

KING EDWARD IV:
Now, Prince Buckingham, seal this league
With your embraces towards my wife's allies,
And make me happy in your unity.

BUCKINGHAM:
Every time Buckingham turns his hatred
On you or yours,
but with all my love
I cherish you and yours, God punishes me
With hatred in those where I expect the most love!
When I most need to employ a friend,
And I'm assured he's a friend
Deep, hollow, treacherous and full of cunning,
Be it for me! this is what I beg God,
When I am cold in zeal towards yours.

KING EDWARD IV:
A friendly, princely and cordial Buckingham,
is this your wish towards my sick heart.
He now wants our brother Gloucester here,
To make the perfect period of this peace.

BUCKINGHAM:
And, in time, here comes the noble duke.

GLOCKESTER:
Hello to my sovereign king and queen:
And, princely peers, a happy moment of the day!

KING EDWARD IV:
Happy, indeed, for we made it through the day.
Brother, we have done acts of charity;
Make peace out of enmity, righteous love out of hatred,
Between these wrongly inflated and irritated peers.

GLOCKESTER:
Blessed work, my very sovereign overlord:
Among this princely pile, if there are any here,
Through false information or erroneous assumptions,
Consider me an enemy;
If, involuntarily or in my rage,
Having committed something that is barely tolerated
By anyone in this presence, I desire
To reconcile myself with his friendly peace:
It is death for me to be at enmity;
I hate it and I desire the love of all good men.
First, Madam, I implore you for true peace,
Which I will purchase with my devoted service;
From you, my noble cousin Buckingham,
If ever any rancor should arise between us;
Of you, Lord Rivers, and Lord Grey, of you;
Those who, without merit, disapproved of me;
Dukes, counts, lords, gentlemen; in fact, of all of them.
I don't know this living Englishman
With whom my soul disagrees
More than the child who is born tonight
I thank my God for my humility.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
A holy day will henceforth be observed:
I would like all conflicts to be well combined.
My sovereign liege, I implore Your Majesty
To bring our brother Clarence to your grace.

GLOCKESTER:
Why, ma'am, did I offer love for this
To be so excited in this royal presence?
Who does not know that the noble duke is dead?
You hurt him to despise his corpse.

RIVERS:
Who doesn't know he's dead! who knows he is?

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
All seeing the sky, what a world this is!

BUCKINGHAM:
You see, I am so pale, Lord Dorset, like the others?

DORSET:
Yes, my good lord; and no one in this presence
But the red color has left his cheeks.

KING EDWARD IV:
Is Clarence dead? the order was reversed.

GLOCKESTER:
But he, poor soul, died at your first command,
And that a winged Mercury wore:
A late invalid carried the counter-order,
It was too late to see him buried.
God grant that some, less noble and less loyal,
Closer in bloody thoughts, but not in blood,
Deserves no worse than miserable Clarence,
And yet, be aware of suspicion!

DORSET:
A boon, my sovereign, for my accomplished service!

KING EDWARD IV:
I pray to you, peace: my soul is full of sorrow.

DORSET:
I will not get up, unless Your Highness allows it.

KING EDWARD IV:
So say what you ask right away.

DORSET:
The sovereign crime of the life of my servant;
Who killed a righteous man today
Lately servant of the Duke of Norfolk.

KING EDWARD IV:
Have a tongue to condemn the death of my brother,
And will he pardon a slave?
My brother has not killed any man; his fault was thought,
And yet his punishment was a cruel death.
Who sued me for him? who, in my anger,
I knelt at my feet and asked me to be informed
Who talked about brotherhood? who spoke of love?
Who told me how the poor soul gave up
Mighty Warwick, and did he fight for me?
Who told me, on the ground near Tewksbury
When Oxford knocked me down, he saved me.
And he said: “Dear brother, live and be king”?
Who told me, when we were both lying on the field
Frozen almost to death, how he played a trick on me
Even in his own clothes, and gave himself,
All skinny and naked, in the cold, numb night?
It all comes from my memory, brutal anger
Sin, snatched, and not one of you
I had so much grace to put it in my mind.
But when your carters or your waiting vassals
I made a drunken and degraded massacre
The precious image of our dear Redeemer,
You are straight on your knees to ask for forgiveness, forgiveness;
And I too, unfairly, must grant it to you
But for my brother no man would speak,
And I, unsightly, don't talk to myself
For him, poor soul. The proudest of you all
I observed him in his life;
Yet none of you would plead for your life.
O God, I fear that your justice will take hold
On me, and you, and mine, and yours for that!
Come, Hastings, help me get to my closet.
Oh, poor Clarence!

GLOCKESTER:
It’s the fruit of temerity! You didn't score
How the guilty parents of the queen
Did you look pale when they heard of Clarence's death?
Oh, they insisted it to the king again!
God will avenge him. But come, let us in,
To comfort Edward with our company.

BUCKINGHAM:
We await your grace.

Boy:
Tell me, good grandmother, is our father dead?

DUCHESS OF YORK:
No boy.

Boy:
Why do you wring your hands and beat your chest,
And cry: “O Clarence, my unfortunate son!

Girl:
Why do you look at us and shake your head,
And treat us as miserable, orphans, shipwrecked
If our noble father is alive?

DUCHESS OF YORK:
My pretty cousins, you deceive me a lot;
I deplore the king's illness.
How I hate to lose him, not your father's death;
It was a lost sorrow to mourn the lost.

Boy:
So, grandmother, you conclude that he is dead.
The king my uncle is responsible for this:
God will avenge him; that I will bother
With daily prayers to this effect.

Girl:
And me too.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Peace, children, peace! the king likes you:
Incompetent and superficial innocents,
You can't guess who caused your father's death.

Boy:
Grandma, we can; for my good uncle Gloucester
Said to me, the king, provoked by the queen,
Indictments designed to imprison him:
And when my uncle told me, he cried,
And he hugged me and kissed me kindly on the cheek;
Asked me to count on him as on my father,
And he would love me very much as his child.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Oh, this deception should steal such sweet forms,
And with a virtuous vizard, hide a dastardly ruse!
It's my son; yes, and that is my shame;
However, he did not draw this deception from my hiding places.

Boy:
Do you think my uncle was faking it, grandmother?

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Yes, my boy.

Boy:
I can't think so. Listen ! what noise is that?

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Oh, who will stop me from moaning and crying,
To scold my fortune and torment me?
I will join in the black despair against my soul,
And become an enemy to me.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
What does this scene of gross impatience mean?

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
To commit an act of tragic violence:
Edward, my lord, your son, our king, is dead.
Why grow branches now that the root has withered?
Why don't the leaves wither when the sap is gone?
If you want to live, deplore yourself; if I die, be brief,
So that our swift-winged souls may catch those of the king;
Or, like obedient subjects, follow him
Towards his new kingdom of perpetual rest.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Ah, I care so much about your sorrow
What a title I had in your noble husband!
I mourned the death of a worthy husband,
And lived looking at his images:
But now two mirrors of her princely appearance
Are broken to pieces by a malignant death,
And for my comfort, I only have one false glass,
Which saddens me when I see my shame in him.
You are a widow; yet you are a mother,
And the comfort of your children has left you:
But death tore my husband from my arms,
And I tore two crutches from my weak limbs,
Edward and Clarence. O, what reason have I,
Your being is only half of my sorrow,
To overcome your complaints and drown your cries!

Boy:
Good aunt, you did not mourn the death of our father;
How can we help you with our sister tears?

Girl:
Our fatherless distress was not mourned;
Nor may your widow's grief be mourned!

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Give me no help in my lamentations;
I am not incapable of filing a complaint
All sources reduce their currents in my eyes,
That I, being ruled by the watery moon,
May we send abundant tears to drown the world!
Oh for my husband, for my dear lord Edward!

Children:
Oh for our father, for our dear lord Clarence!

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Alas for both, mine, Edward and Clarence!

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
What vacation did I have besides Edward? and he left.

Children:
What stay did we have other than Clarence? and he left.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
What remains did I have besides them? and they left.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Never has a widow suffered such a dear loss!

Children:
Never have orphans suffered such a dear loss!

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Never has a mother suffered such a dear loss!
Alas, I am the mother of these groans!
Their misfortunes are grouped, mine are general.
She cries for an Edward, and so do I;
I cry for Clarence, and neither does she:
These babies cry for Clarence and me too;
I, for an Edward, I cry, they too:
Alas, you three, on me, triple afflicted,
Shed all your tears! I am the nurse of your sorrow,
And I will pamper him with lamentations.

DORSET:
Comfort, dear mother: God is very displeased
That you take his fact with ingratitude:
In the common things of the world this is called ungrateful,
With a secret reluctance to repay a debt
Which, with a generous hand, was kindly lent;
Much more to be thus opposed to heaven,
Because he needs the royal debt that he lent you.

RIVERS:
Madam, think of yourself, like a prudent mother,
Of the young prince your son: send for him immediately
Let him be crowned; in him lives your comfort:
Drowning the desperate sorrow in Edward's dead grave,
And plant your joys living on Edward's throne.

GLOCKESTER:
Madam, rest assured: we all have a cause
To mourn the diminishing of our bright star;
But no one can cure their ills by crying over them.
Madam, my mother, I cry out to you for mercy;
I have not seen your grace: humbly on my knees
I need your blessing.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
God bless you ; and put sweetness in your mind,
Love, charity, obedience and true duty!

GLOCKESTER:

BUCKINGHAM:
You troubled princes and sad-hearted peers,
Who bear this heavy mutual burden of groans,
Now encourage one another in love for one another
Although we have spent our harvest from this king,
We must reap the harvest of his son.
The broken grudge of your swollen hearts,
