But lately burst, knitted and reunited,
Should be delicately preserved, cherished and preserved:
It seems good to me, with a little train,
Let the young prince be fetched immediately from Ludlow
Here in London, to be crowned our king.

RIVERS:
Why with a little train, my lord of Buckingham?

BUCKINGHAM:
Marry, my lord, lest by multitude
The newly healed wound of wickedness should burst forth,
Which would be all the more dangerous
How green and yet ungoverned is the domain:
Where each horse carries its reins,
And can direct his own course as he pleases,
Both the fear of harm and the apparent harm,
In my opinion this should be avoided.

GLOCKESTER:
I hope the king has made peace with us all
And the pact is firm and true in me.

RIVERS:
And so in me; and so, I think, in all:
However, as it is only green, it should be put
In the absence of an apparent likelihood of violation,
What many people might suggest:
Therefore I say with noble Buckingham,
It is fitting that so few people go looking for the prince.

HASTING:
And that's what I'm saying.

GLOCKESTER:
So be it ; and off we go to determine
Who they will be and who will be immediately posted to Ludlow.
Madam, and you, my mother, are you going to go
To give your censures in this heavy affair?

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
With all our hearts.

BUCKINGHAM:
Monsignor, whoever goes to the Prince,
For God's sake, let's not leave us both behind;
Because, by the way, I will sort out the opportunities,
As an index of the story we talked about later,
Separating the proud parents of the queen from the king.

GLOCKESTER:
My other self, the consistory of my council,
My oracle, my prophet! My dear cousin,
Like a child, I will follow your direction.
Direction Ludlow then, because we will not stay behind.

First citizen:
Neighbor, well met: where to go so quickly?

Second citizen:
I promise you, I barely know it myself:
Do you hear the news abroad?

First citizen:
Yes, the king is dead.

Second citizen:
Bad news, by madam; it's rarely the best:
I fear, I fear it will be a troubled world.

Third citizen:
Neighbors, good God!

First citizen:
Hello Sir.

Third citizen:
Does this news confirm the death of good King Edward?

Second citizen:
Yes, sir, it is too true; God help for now!

Third citizen:
So, masters, look at a troubled world.

First citizen:
No no; by the good grace of God, his son will reign.

Third citizen:
Woe to the country governed by a child!

Second citizen:
In him there is a hope of government,
That in his council of nonage under him,
And in his full and ripe years himself,
Without a doubt, we will govern well until then.

First citizen:
This was the state when Henry VI
Was crowned in Paris but at nine months.

Third citizen:
So did the State stand firm? No, no, my good friends, God knows;
For then this land was notoriously enriched
With serious political advice; then the king
Had virtuous uncles to protect his grace.

First citizen:
Well, the same goes for father and mother.

Third citizen:
Better that they all come to the father,
Or on the father's side, there was none at all;
For emulation now, which will be closest,
Will touch us too closely, if God does not prevent us.
Oh, the Duke of Gloucester is full of dangers!
And the sons and brothers of the queen haughty and proud:
And if they were to be governed, and not to govern,
This sickly land could comfort as before.

First citizen:
Come on, come on, we fear the worst; Everything will be alright.

Third citizen:
When the clouds appear, the wise put on their cloaks;
When the large leaves fall, winter is near;
When the sun sets, who does not seek out the night?
Untimely storms make men hope for a famine.
Everything can go well; but, if God arranges things like this,
It's more than we deserve, or so I imagine.

Second citizen:
Verily, the souls of men are full of fear:
You almost can't reason with a man
It doesn't look heavy and full of fear.

Third citizen:
Before the times of change, it is always like this:
By a divine instinct, the minds of men are wary
Dangers arising therefrom; as proof, we see
The waters swell before a violent storm.
But leave everything to God. where is it far?

Second citizen:
Get married, we have been summoned to the judges.

Third citizen:
And me too: I will keep you company.

ARCHBISHOP OF YORK:
Last night I heard they were lying at Northampton;
At Stony-Stratford will they be this evening:
Tomorrow or the day after tomorrow, they will be there.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
I long with all my heart to see the prince:
I hope he's grown a lot since I last saw him.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
But I hear, no; they say my son from York
It almost surpassed him in his growth.

YORK:
Yes mom ; but I wouldn't want to.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Well, my young cousin, growing up is good.

YORK:
Grandma, one evening, while we were sitting at supper,
My Uncle Rivers talked about how I grew up
More than my brother: “Yes”, said my uncle
Gloucester,
“Small weeds are graceful, big weeds grow quickly:”
And as I think I wouldn't grow up so quickly,
Because the sweet flowers are slow and the weeds rush.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Good faith, good faith, the saying did not hold
In him it opposed the same thing to you;
He was the most miserable thing when he was young,
So long growing and so quietly,
That if this rule were true, he should be kind.

ARCHBISHOP OF YORK:
Well, ma'am, that's definitely the case.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
I hope he is; but yet let mothers doubt.

YORK:
Now, my goodness, if I had been remembered,
I could have flouted my uncle's grace,
Touching his waist closer than he touched mine.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
What, my pretty York? Please let me hear it.

YORK:
Get married, they say my uncle grew up so fast
That he could gnaw a crust at two o'clock
It took me two years before I had a tooth.
Grandma, that would have been a biting joke.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Please, pretty York, who told you that?

YORK:
Grandmother, his nurse.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
His nurse! well, she was dead before you were born.

YORK:
If it wasn't her, I wouldn't know who told me.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
A talking boy: go ahead, you're too smart.

ARCHBISHOP OF YORK:
Good lady, don't be angry with the child.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Pitchers have ears.

ARCHBISHOP OF YORK:
Here is a messenger. What's new?

Messenger:
Such news, my lord, saddens me to announce it to you.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
How is the prince?

Messenger:
Well, ma'am, and in good health.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
So what's your news?

Messenger:
Lord Rivers and Lord Gray are sent to Pomfret,
With them Sir Thomas Vaughan, prisoners.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Who committed them?

Messenger:
The mighty dukes
Gloucester and Buckingham.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
For what offense?

Messenger:
I disclosed everything I could;
Why or what these nobles were hired for
All this is unknown to me, my gracious lady.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Yes, I see the fall of our house!
The tiger has now seized the gentle doe;
The insulting tyranny begins to fall
On the innocent and formidable throne:
Welcome, destruction, death and slaughter!
I see, like on a map, the end of everything.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Days of cursed and disturbing quarrels,
How many of you have seen my eyes!
My husband lost his life to obtain the crown;
And often my sons were shaken,
For me to rejoice and mourn their gains and losses:
And sit and grill at home
Own exaggeration, themselves, the conquerors.
Make war on themselves; blood against blood,
Self versus self: O, absurd
And frenzied indignation, put an end to your cursed spleen;
Or let me die, so as not to look at death again!

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Come, come, my boy; we are going to take refuge.
Madam, farewell.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
I will accompany you.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
You have no cause.

ARCHBISHOP OF YORK:
My gracious lady, go;
And bring there your treasure and your goods.
For my part, I will resign myself to your grace
The seal that I keep: and so on for me
Also I offer you and all yours!
Come, I'll take you to the sanctuary.

BUCKINGHAM:
Welcome, sweet prince, to London, to your room.

GLOCKESTER:
Welcome, dear cousin, sovereign of my thoughts
Fatigue has made you melancholy.

PRINCE EDWARD:
No, uncle; but our crosses on the way
I made it tedious, tedious and heavy
I want more uncles here to welcome me.

GLOCKESTER:
Sweet prince, the intact virtue of your years
Has not yet plunged into the deception of the world
You can't tell a man apart either
That of its external appearance; who, God knows,
He rarely or never jumps with his heart.
These uncles you want were dangerous;
Your Grace listened to their sweet words,
But don't look at the poison in their hearts:
God save you from them and these false friends!

PRINCE EDWARD:
God save me from false friends! but there was none.

GLOCKESTER:
My lord, the Mayor of London has come to greet you.

Lord Mayor:
May God bless your grace with health and happy days!

PRINCE EDWARD:
I thank you, good monseigneur; and thank you all.
I thought my mother and my brother York,
It would have been a long time before it met us on the path
Fie, what a slug Hastings is, that he won't come
To tell us if they will come or not!

BUCKINGHAM:
And, in time, here comes the sweaty lord.

PRINCE EDWARD:
Welcome, my lord: what, will our mother come?

HASTING:
On what occasion, God knows, not I,
The queen your mother and your brother York,
Have taken refuge: the tender prince
I would have liked to come with me to meet Your Grace,
But his mother inevitably held him back.

BUCKINGHAM:
Fie, what an indirect and sullen journey
Is it hers! Lord Cardinal, your grace
Persuade the Queen to send the Duke of York
To his princely brother currently?
If she denies it, Lord Hastings, go with him,
And from his jealous arms, we must tear him away.

CARDINAL:
My Lord of Buckingham, if my weak speech
May from his mother win the Duke of York,
Expect him here soon; but if she is stubborn
To gentle supplications, God in heaven preserve us
We should violate the holy privilege
From the blessed sanctuary! not for all this earth
Could I be guilty of such a deep sin?

BUCKINGHAM:
You are too foolish, obstinate, my lord,
Too formal and traditional
Weigh it but with the rudeness of this age,
You don't break your sanctuary by grabbing it.
The benefit is always granted
To those whose relationships have earned the place,
And those who have the spirit to claim the place:
This prince neither demanded nor deserved it;
And so, in my opinion, I can't have it:
Then, taking it from there, what is not there,
You are not violating any privileges or charters there.
I have often heard of men of the sanctuary;
But the sanctuary children never arrived until now.

CARDINAL:
My lord, you will dominate my mind for once.
Come on, Lord Hastings, will you come with me?

HASTING:
I'm going, my lord.

PRINCE EDWARD:
Good lords, do all you can with all haste.
Say, Uncle Gloucester, if our brother comes,
Where will we stay until our coronation?

GLOCKESTER:
Wherever it looks best to your royal being.
If I can advise you, a day or two
Your Highness will rest at the Tower:
So wherever you want, and we will judge it to be the most appropriate
For your better health and leisure.

PRINCE EDWARD:
I don't like the Tower, or any place.
Did Julius Caesar build this place, my lord?

BUCKINGHAM:
He indeed, my gracious lord, began this place;
Which, since then, successive eras have rebuilt.

PRINCE EDWARD:
Is it recorded, or reported?
Successively from age to age, did he build it?

BUCKINGHAM:
It's official, my gracious lord.

PRINCE EDWARD:
But say, my lord, that they were not recorded,
I think the truth should live from age to age,
As it was retailed to all posterity,
Even until the general day ends.

GLOCKESTER:

PRINCE EDWARD:
What do you say, uncle?

GLOCKESTER:
I say that without characters, fame lasts a long time.
Thus, like formal vice, Iniquity,
I moralize two meanings in one word.

PRINCE EDWARD:
That Julius Caesar was a famous man;
With which his value has enriched his mind,
His spirit began to bring his value to life
Death makes no conquest of this conqueror;
For now, he lives in glory, but not in life.
I will tell you, my cousin Buckingham,...

BUCKINGHAM:
What, my gracious lord?

PRINCE EDWARD:
And if I live until I am a man,
I will win our ancient right in France again,
Or die a soldier, as I lived a king.

GLOCKESTER:

BUCKINGHAM:
Now, in time, here comes the Duke of York.

PRINCE EDWARD:
Richard of York! how is our beloved brother?

YORK:
Well, my fearsome lord; so I have to call you now.

PRINCE EDWARD:
Yes, brother, to our sorrow, as it is yours:
He died too late when he could have retained this title,
Who by his death lost much majesty.

GLOCKESTER:
How is our cousin, noble Lord of York?

YORK:
Thank you, sweet uncle. O my lord,
You said unused weeds grow quickly
The prince my brother has become much too big for me.

GLOCKESTER:
He did it, my lord.

YORK:
And so is he idle?

GLOCKESTER:
O my beautiful cousin, I must not say it.

YORK:
So he looks at you more than me.

GLOCKESTER:
He can command me as my sovereign;
But you have power in me like in a parent.

YORK:
Please, uncle, give me this dagger.

GLOCKESTER:
My dagger, little cousin? with all my heart.

PRINCE EDWARD:
A beggar, my brother?

YORK:
From my kind uncle, who, I know, will give it to me;
And it's just a toy, which is no grief to give.

GLOCKESTER:
A greater gift than the one I will give to my cousin.

YORK:
A bigger gift! Oh, it's the sword.

GLOCKESTER:
A nice cousin, if that was light enough.

YORK:
Oh, then, I see, you will part but with light gifts;
In more important things, you will say a beggar no.

GLOCKESTER:
It is too heavy for your grace to bear.

YORK:
I weigh it slightly, if it were heavier.

GLOCKESTER:
What, would you like my weapon, little lord?

YORK:
I will, so I can thank you while you call me.

GLOCKESTER:
How?

YORK:
Little.

PRINCE EDWARD:
Monsignor of York will always be angry in his words:
Uncle, Your Grace knows how to handle it.

YORK:
You mean, put up with me, don't put up with me:
My uncle, my brother makes fun of you and me;
Because I am small, like a monkey,
He thinks you should carry me on your shoulders.

BUCKINGHAM:
With what finesse of mind he reasons!
To alleviate the contempt he has for his uncle,
He taunts himself nicely and rightly:
So cunning and so young, it's wonderful.

GLOCKESTER:
My lord, would you not like to let it pass?
Me and my good cousin Buckingham
Will to your mother, to beg her
To meet you at the Tower and welcome you.

YORK:
What, will you go to the Tower, my lord?

PRINCE EDWARD:
My lord protector will need it.

YORK:
I won't sleep peacefully at the Tower.

GLOCKESTER:
Why, what should we fear?

YORK:
Get married, angry ghost of my uncle Clarence:
My grandmother told me he was murdered there.

PRINCE EDWARD:
I'm afraid no uncle is dead.

GLOCKESTER:
Nor any of those who live, I hope.

PRINCE EDWARD:
And if they live, I hope I won't have to fear.
But come, my lord; and with a heavy heart,
Thinking of them, I go to the Tower.

BUCKINGHAM:
Do you think, my lord, that talkative little York
Wasn't irritated by his subtle mother
Taunting and scorning you in this way?

GLOCKESTER:
No doubt, no doubt; Oh, he's a strange boy;
Bold, fast, resourceful, forward-thinking, capable
It belongs entirely to the mother, from head to toe.

BUCKINGHAM:
Well, let them rest. Come here, Catesby.
You have sworn as deeply to carry out what we intend
We might as well hide what we transmit:
You know that our reasons are invoked along the way;
What do you think ? Isn't it an easy matter?
To make William Lord Hastings forget,
For the installation of this noble duke
At the royal seat of this famous island?

CATESBY:
He loves the prince so much, for his father's sake,
That nothing will be won against him.

BUCKINGHAM:
So what do you think of Stanley? what will he do?

CATESBY:
He will do everything like Hastings.

BUCKINGHAM:
Well, nothing more than this: Come on, sweet Catesby,
And, as if you were far away, Lord Hastings,
How is it affected by our design?
And summon him tomorrow to the Tower,
Sit around the crowning.
If you find it treatable with us,
Encourage him and show him all our reasons:
If he is leaden, cold, reluctant,
Be it too; and so interrupt your speech,
And let us know his inclination:
For tomorrow we will hold divided councils,
To which you will be highly employed.

GLOCKESTER:
Commend me to Lord William: tell him, Catesby,
His former group of dangerous adversaries
Tomorrow, blood will be shed at the Château de Pomfret;
And tell my friend, for the joy of this good news,
Give Mistress Shore one more sweet kiss.

BUCKINGHAM:
Well Catesby, go and see this matter through.

CATESBY:
My good lords both, with all the attention I can.

GLOCKESTER:
Can we hear from you, Catesby, before we sleep?

CATESBY:
You will, my lord.

GLOCKESTER:
At Crosby Place you will find us both.

BUCKINGHAM:
Now, my lord, what shall we do, if we perceive
Lord Hastings will not give in to our plots?

GLOCKESTER:
Cut his head off, man; a little we will do:
And look, when I'm king, claim me
County Hereford and furniture
Of which the king my brother was possessed.

BUCKINGHAM:
I will claim this promise in the hands of Your Grace.

GLOCKESTER:
And see to it that it is given up with all your will.
Come on, let's have an early sup, so that afterwards
We can digest our conspiracies in one form or another.

Messenger:
What, ho! My lord!

HASTING:

Messenger:
A messenger from Lord Stanley.

HASTING:
It's not time?

Messenger:
Around four o'clock.

HASTING:
Can't your master sleep these tedious nights?

Messenger:
So it seems I have to say.
Firstly, he recommends it to your noble lordship.

HASTING:
And then?

Messenger:
And then he sends you a note
He dreamed last night that the boar had shaved his helm:
Furthermore, he says that there are two councils held;
And this can be determined at one
which can lead you and him to miss the other.
This is why he sends to know the good pleasure of your Lordship,
If you now take a horse with him,
And with all speed post him with him towards the north,
To flee the danger that his soul senses.

HASTING:
Go, my friend, go, return to your lord;
Tell him not to fear separate advice
His honor and I agree,
And at the other is my servant Catesby
Where nothing can happen that affects us
Of which I will have no intelligence.
Tell him that his fears are superficial, for example:
And for his dreams, I wonder if he loves so much
Trusting the taunts of restless sleep
Make the boar fly before the boar chases him,
We had to praise the boar so that he would follow us
And give chase where he didn't want to.
Go, tell your master to get up and come to me
And we will both go together to the Tower,
Where, he sees, the boar will use us kindly.

Messenger:
My gracious lord, I will tell him what you say.

CATESBY:
Good tomorrow to my noble lord!

HASTING:
Hello, Catesby; You are ahead
What news, what news, in this tottering state?

CATESBY:
The world is truly shaken, my lord;
And I don't think he'll ever stand
Tim Richard wears the garland of the kingdom.

HASTING:
How! wear the garland! you mean the crown?

CATESBY:
Yes, my good lord.

HASTING:
I will have my crown cut off from my shoulders
Before then, I will see the crown so ignoble lost.
But can you guess he's aiming for that?

CATESBY:
Yes, about my life; and hopes to find a future
On his side for the gain of this one:
And with that he sends you this good news,
That this same day your enemies,
The queen's parents must die at Pomfret.

HASTING:
Indeed, I am not in mourning for this news,
Because they are still my enemies:
But I will give my vote on Richard's side,
To prevent my master's heirs from true descendants,
God knows I won't, until I die.

CATESBY:
God keep your lordship in this gracious spirit!

HASTING:
But I'll laugh about it in twelve months,
May those who brought me into hatred of my master
I live to contemplate their tragedy.
I tell you, Catesby...

CATESBY:
What, my lord?

HASTING:
Before fifteen days, make me elder,
I'm going to send packaging but I don't think about it.

CATESBY:
It is a vile thing to die, my gracious lord,
When men are not prepared and do not seek it.

HASTING:
Oh monstrous, monstrous! and this is how it falls
With Rivers, Vaughan, Grey: and that will do the trick
With other men, who think they're safe
Like you and me; which, as you know, are expensive
To Princely Richard and Buckingham.

CATESBY:
The princes hold you both in high esteem;
Because we count his head on the bridge.

HASTING:
I know they do; and I deserved it.
Come on; where's your boar, dude?
Do you fear the wild boar and leave without provisions?

STANLEY:
Monsignor, hello; Hello, Catesby:
You can joke, but, by the holy rood screen,
I don't like this advice.

HASTING:
My lord,
I hold my life as dear as yours;
And never in my life do I protest,
Was it more valuable to me than now:
Do you think, but I know our state is secure,
Would I be as triumphant as I am?

STANLEY:
The lords of Pomfret, when they came from London,
Were joyful and assumed their condition was safe,
And indeed they had no reason to be suspicious;
But yet, you see how quickly the day fell.
This sudden stag of resentment that I doubt:
I pray to God, I said, I prove myself to be a useless coward!
What, are we heading towards the Tower? the day has passed.

HASTING:
Come, come, be with you. What are you doing, my lord?
Today, the lords you speak of are beheaded.

LORD STANLEY:
For their truth they better wear their heads
So some who accused them wear their hats off.
But come, my lord, let us go.

HASTING:
Continue forward; I'm going to speak with this good guy.
And now, sir! how is the world with you?

Continuing:
Better your lordship asks me.

HASTING:
I tell you, man, it's better with me now
That the last time I met you, where now we meet:
So I went prisoner to the Tower,
By the suggestion of the queen's allies;
But now I tell you, keep it to yourself.
Today these enemies are put to death,
And I'm in better shape than ever.

Continuing:
God save him, to the good pleasure of Your Honor!

HASTING:
Gramercy, my friend: here, drink this for me.

Continuing:
God save your lordship!

Priest:
Welcome, my lord; I am happy to see your honor.

HASTING:
I thank you, good Sir John, with all my heart.
I am indebted to you for your last exercise;
Come next Sabbath and I will satisfy you.

BUCKINGHAM:
What, speak with a priest, Lord Chamberlain?
Your friends from Pomfret need the priest;
Your Honor has no pending tasks.

HASTING:
Good faith, and when I met this holy man,
These men you speak of came to mind.
What, are you going towards the Tower?

BUCKINGHAM:
Yes my Lord ; but I won't stay long
From there, I will return to your Lordship.

HASTING:
That's enough, because I'm staying here for dinner.

BUCKINGHAM:

HASTING:
I will wait for your lordship.

RATCLIFF:
Come, get the prisoners out.

RIVERS:
Sir Richard Ratcliff, let me say this to you:
Today you will see a subject die
For truth, for duty and for loyalty.

GRAY:
God save the prince of your entire pack!
You are a knot of bloody leeches!

VAUGHAN:
You live and will cry unhappiness because of this afterwards.

RATCLIFF:
Shipping; the limit of your life has been exceeded.

RIVERS:
O Pomfret, Pomfret! O you, bloody prison,
Fatal and worrying for the noble peers!
In the guilty closure of your walls
Richard II, here, was killed with an axe;
And, to further slander your sad seat,
We give you our innocent blood to drink.

GRAY:
Now Margaret's curse falls on our heads,
For standing by when Richard stabbed her son.

RIVERS:
Then she cursed Hastings, then she cursed Buckingham,
Then she cursed Richard. O, remember, my God
To hear his prayers for them, as now for us
And for my sister and her princely sons,
Be satisfied, dear God, with our true blood,
Which, as you know, must be unjustly poured out.

RATCLIFF:
Hurry up ; the hour of death has expired.

RIVERS:
Come, Grey, come, Vaughan, let's all kiss:
And let's take our leave, until we meet again in paradise.

HASTING:
My lords, immediately: the reason why we are met
This is to determine the coronation.
In the name of God, speak: when is the royal day?

BUCKINGHAM:
Is everything suitable for this royal period?

DERBY:
This is the case and all it takes is one nomination.

BISHOP OF ELY:
Tomorrow therefore, I judge a happy day.

BUCKINGHAM:
Who knows the spirit of the lord protector here?
Who is more inward with the royal duke?

BISHOP OF ELY:
We believe that Your Grace should know his mind as soon as possible.

BUCKINGHAM:
Who, I, my lord, know each other's faces,
But for our hearts, he no longer knows about mine,
Than me of yours;
I am no more of his than you are of mine.
Lord Hastings, you and he are very much in love.

HASTING:
I thank his grace, I know that he loves me;
But, for his purpose during the coronation.
I did not probe him, and he did not deliver to me
His gracious pleasure in any case:
But you, my noble lords, can set the time;
And in the name of the Duke I will give my voice,
Which he will take, I presume, gently.

BISHOP OF ELY:
Now, in time, here comes the Duke himself.

GLOCKESTER:
My noble Lords and cousins, good morning.
I slept a long time; but I hope,
My absence neglects no great design,
Which, by my presence, could have been concluded.

BUCKINGHAM:
If you had not answered your request, my lord
William Lord Hastings had pronounced your part,
I mean, your vote, for the coronation of the king.

GLOCKESTER:
No one is more daring than my Lord Hastings;
His Lordship knows me well and likes me well.

HASTING:
I thank your grace.

GLOCKESTER:
Monsignor of Ely!

BISHOP OF ELY:
My lord?

GLOCKESTER:
The last time I was in Holborn,
I saw some good strawberries there in your garden
Please send for some.

BISHOP OF ELY:
Get married and I will do it, my lord, with all my heart.

GLOCKESTER:
Cousin of Buckingham, a word with you.
Catesby probed Hastings in our affairs,
And finds the irritable gentleman so hot,
As he will lose his mind before giving his consent
His master's son, as venerable as he calls him,
Will lose the royalty of the throne of England.

BUCKINGHAM:
Leave here, my lord, I will follow you.

DERBY:
We have not yet fixed this day of triumph.
Tomorrow, in my opinion, is too sudden;
Because I myself am not so well endowed
As I would otherwise be if the day continued.

BISHOP OF ELY:
Where is my lord protector? I sent for this
strawberries.

HASTING:
Her grace seems cheerful and sweet today;
There is one vain person or another who likes him,
When he wishes good morning with such spirit.
I think there is never a man in Christianity
This can hide his love or his hatred less than he;
For by his upright face you will know his heart.

DERBY:
What does his heart perceive you in his face
In all likelihood he would have come today?

HASTING:
Marry, that without a man here he may be offended;
Because if he was, he showed it in his appearance.

DERBY:
I pray to God he isn't, I said.

GLOCKESTER:
Please tell me what they all deserve
Who plot my death with evil plots
Of cursed witchcraft, and which prevailed
On my body with their infernal charms?

HASTING:
The tender love that I bear your grace, my lord,
Makes me most prominent in this noble presence
To condemn the offenders, whoever they may be
I say, my lord, that they deserved death.

GLOCKESTER:
So be your eyes witness to this evil:
See how bewitched I am; here is my arm
Is, like a cursed sapling, withered:
And here is Edward's wife, this monstrous witch,
In association with that trumpet prostitute Shore,
Who by their witchcraft have thus marked me.

HASTING:
If they did this, my gracious lord...

GLOCKESTER:
If I'm the protector of this damn trumpet...
Are you talking to me about “if”? You are a traitor:
Cut off his head! Now, by Saint Paul, I swear,
I won't eat dinner until I see the same thing.
Lovel and Ratcliff, watch it be done:
The others, who love me, get up and follow me.

HASTING:
Woe, woe to England! not at all for me;
Because I, too affectionate, could have prevented this.
Stanley did dream that the boar shaved his helmet;
But I disdained it and I disdained to steal:
Three times today my cloth-footed horse has stumbled,
And surprised, when he looked at the Tower,
You might as well be reluctant to take me to the slaughterhouse.
Oh, now I want the priest who told me:
I repent now, I told the pursuer
As they triumphed over my enemies,
How they were bloodily massacred at Pomfret,
And I myself am assured of grace and favor.
O Margaret, Margaret, now your heavy curse
Is lit on poor Hastings' miserable head!

RATCLIFF:
Hurry up, my lord; the duke would be at dinner:
Make a small gesture; he wants to see your face.

HASTING:
O momentary grace of mortal men,
That we seek more than the grace of God!
Who builds his hopes on the air of your beauty,
He lives like a drunken sailor on a mast,
Ready, at every nod, to fall
In the fatal bowels of the depths.

LOVE :
Come, come, hurry; it is useless to exclaim.

HASTING:
Oh damn Richard! miserable England!
I prophesy to you the scariest moment
This always miserable age looked.
Come, take me to the operating room; take my head to him.
They smile at me that I will soon be dead.

GLOCKESTER:
Come, cousin, can you tremble and change color,
Kill your breath in the middle of a word,
And then start again, and stop again,
As if you were helpless and mad with terror?

BUCKINGHAM:
But I can counterfeit the profound tragedian;
Speak and look back, and search on all sides,
Tremble and start stirring a straw,
Intent of deep suspicion: terrible looks
Are at my service, like forced smiles;
And both are ready in their offices,
At any time, to honor my stratagems.
But what, Catesby is gone?

GLOCKESTER:
He is; and, you see, he brings the mayor with him.

BUCKINGHAM:
Lord Mayor,--

GLOCKESTER:
Look at the drawbridge over there!

BUCKINGHAM:
Listen ! a drum.

GLOCKESTER:
Catesby, look at the walls.

BUCKINGHAM:
Lord Mayor, the reason we sent...

GLOCKESTER:
Look back, defend yourself, here are the enemies.

BUCKINGHAM:
God and our innocence defend us and keep us!

GLOCKESTER:
Be patient, they are friends, Ratcliff and Lovel.

LOVE :
Here is the head of this vile traitor,
The dangerous and unsuspected Hastings.

GLOCKESTER:
I loved this man so much that I have to cry.
I took him for the most harmless creature
Who breathed on this earth a Christian;
I made him my book in which my soul recorded
The story of all his secret thoughts:
So gentle that he coated his vice with a display of virtue,
That, his apparent open guilt omitted,
I mean, his conversation with Shore's wife,
He lived off all the suspects.

BUCKINGHAM:
Well, well, he was the shelter's most secret traitor
Who ever lived.
Would you imagine, or almost would you believe,
Isn't it, by great preservation,
We live to tell you, the subtle traitor
This day had been plotted, in the council house
To murder me and my good lord of Gloucester?

Lord Mayor:
What, had he done it?

GLOCKESTER:
What, do you think we are Turks or infidels?
Or that we would, against the form of the law,
Proceed thus recklessly until the villain dies,
But this is the extreme danger of the matter,
The peace of England and the safety of our persons,
Did he force us to this execution?

Lord Mayor:
Now it's happening to you! he deserved his death;
And you, my good lords, have both done well,
To warn false traitors of such attempts.
I have never looked for better in his hands,
After he once fell out with Mistress Shore.

GLOCKESTER:
And yet, if we hadn't decided that he would die,
Until your lordship comes to see his death;
It is now the amorous haste of our friends,
A little against our senses, we prevented:
Because, my lord, we would have liked to make you hear
The traitor speaks and shyly confesses
The manner and purpose of his betrayal;
That you could have meant the same thing
To citizens, who could perhaps
Misunderstand him and mourn his death.

Lord Mayor:
But, my good lord, the word of your Grace will be useful,
As good as I had seen and heard about
And do not doubt it, both noble princes,
But I will inform our loyal citizens
With all your just efforts for this cause.

GLOCKESTER:
And to this end we wish your lordship to be here,
To avoid harsh criticism from the world.

BUCKINGHAM:
But as you arrive too late compared to our intentions,
Yet witness what you hear, we intended:
And so, my dear mayor, we say goodbye.

GLOCKESTER:
Come on, then, later, cousin Buckingham.
The Mayor of Guildhall holds it in all positions:
There, at your advantage of time,
Infer the bastardy of Edward's children:
Tell them how Edward put a citizen to death,
Only for saying he would make his son
Heir to the crown; that is indeed his house,
Which, by its sign, was called thus.
Moreover, exhort his hateful luxury
And bestial appetite as a replacement for lust;
Which extended to their servants, daughters, wives,
Even where his lustful eye or his wild heart,
Without control, he prepares to make it his prey.
Even more, if necessary, approach my person:
Tell them when my mother left with a child
Of this insatiable Edward, noble York
My princely father then had wars in France
And, by a simple calculation of time,
I discovered that the problem was not his creation;
Which stood out well in his features,
Having nothing to do with the noble Duke my father:
But touch it sparingly, for it was far away,
Because you know, my lord, my mother is alive.

BUCKINGHAM:
Have no fear, my lord, I will play the orator
As if the gold fees I plead for
Were for me: and so, my lord, farewell.

GLOCKESTER:
If you flourish well, take them to Baynard's Castle;
Where you will find me well accompanied
With reverend fathers and educated bishops.

BUCKINGHAM:
I'm going: and around three or four o'clock
Look for news from the Guildhall.

GLOCKESTER:
Go, Lovel, as quickly as possible to Doctor Shaw;
Go to Brother Penker; give them both
Meet me this hour at Baynard Castle.
Now I'm going to come in, to take a private order,
To lure Clarence's children out of sight;
And to point out that in no way can anyone
At all times resort to the princes.

Scribe:
This is the indictment of the good Lord Hastings;
Which, in an outstretched hand, is quite absorbed,
Let it be today, read in Paul's.
And note how well the following holds together:
I spent eleven hours writing it,
Because last night it was Catesby who brought me;
The previous one was full as long as it was:
And yet, during those five hours lived Lord Hastings,
Unaltered, unexamined, free, at large
In the meantime, it's good people! Why is that so disgusting,
Who does not see this palpable device?
Yet who is so blind, but says he does not see it?
The world is bad; and everything will come to nothing,
When such bad relationships must be seen in thought.

GLOCKESTER:
And now, my lord, what do the citizens say?

BUCKINGHAM:
Now, by the holy mother of our Lord,
The citizens are silent and do not say a word.

GLOCKESTER:
Have you touched on the bastardy of Edward's children?

BUCKINGHAM:
I did it; with his contract with Lady Lucy,
And his contract as a deputy in France;
The insatiable greed of his desires,
And his execution of the city's wives;
His tyranny over trifles; his own bastardy,
As having arrived, your father then in France,
His resemblance not being that of the Duke;
I deduced your lineaments,
Being your father's good idea,
Both in your form and in your nobility of spirit;
Opened all your victories in Scotland,
Your discipline in war, your wisdom in peace,
Your generosity, your virtue, your just humility:
Indeed, he left nothing suitable for this purpose
Untouched, or slightly manipulated, in speech
And when my oratory ended
I told them that they loved the good of their country
Shout “God save Richard, the royal king of England!” »

GLOCKESTER:
Ah! and did they do it?

BUCKINGHAM:
No, then God help me, they didn't say a word;
But, like mute statues or breathing stones,
They looked at each other and looked deathly pale.
When I saw them, I reprimanded them;
And he asked the mayor what this voluntary silence meant:
His response was: people weren't used to it
To be spoken but by the recorder.
Then he was invited to tell my story again,
“Thus said the Duke, thus he deduced; »
But there was nothing to justify it on his part.
When he had finished, some of my disciples said:
At the back of the room, they threw their caps in the air,
And a dozen voices cried: “May God save King Richard!”
And so I took advantage of these few,
“Thank you, dear citizens and friends,” I said;
"These general applause and these cries of love
Showcase your wisdom and your love towards Richard: '
And even here he stopped and started again.

GLOCKESTER:
What languageless blocks they were! would they not have spoken?

BUCKINGHAM:
No, by my faith, my lord.

GLOCKESTER:
Won't the mayor and his brothers come?

BUCKINGHAM:
The mayor is there: have fear;
It is not with you that you have spoken, but with a powerful trial:
And look, you have a prayer book in your hand,
And stand between two men of the Church, my good lord;
For on this basis I will construct a holy verse:
And don't be easily convinced by our request:
Play the role of the servant, say no anyway and accept it.

GLOCKESTER:
I go; and if you also plead for them
As I can say no to you for myself,
There is no doubt that we will bring about a happy outcome.

BUCKINGHAM:
Go, go, to the slopes; the mayor knocks.
Welcome my lord; I dance here attendance;
I don't think we'll talk about the Duke.
Here is his servant: Well, Catesby,
What's he saying ?

CATESBY:
Monsignor: he implores your grace;
To visit him tomorrow or the day after tomorrow:
He is inside, with two very reverend fathers,
Divinely immersed in meditation;
And no trial in the world would move it,
To get him out of his holy exercise.

BUCKINGHAM:
Return, good Catesby, to your lord;
Tell him, myself, the mayor and the citizens,
In deep purposes and matters of great importance,
No less important than our general good,
Came to have a conference with his grace.

CATESBY:
I will tell him what you say, my lord.

BUCKINGHAM:
Ah, ha, my lord, this prince is no Edward!
He doesn't lounge on a lewd daybed,
But on my knees in meditation;
Without hanging out with a few courtesans,
But meditate with two profound deities;
Not to sleep, to absorb his idle body,
But by praying, to enrich his vigilant soul:
Happy was England, this gracious prince
Assume sovereignty:
But of course, I fear, we will never be able to convince him to do so.

Lord Mayor:
Get married, God forbid that his grace should say no to us!

BUCKINGHAM:
I'm afraid he will.
And now, Catesby, what does your lord say?

CATESBY:
My lord,
He wonders for what purpose you assembled
Such troops of citizens to speak to him,
His grace not being previously informed:
Monsignor, he fears that you want nothing from him.

BUCKINGHAM:
Sorry, I'm my noble cousin, I should
Suspect me that I don't wish him anything good:
By heaven, I come for him in perfect love;
And so come back again and say grace to him.
When holy and pious religious
Are in their pearls, it is difficult to get them from there,
Zealous contemplation is so sweet.

Lord Mayor:
See where he stands between two clergymen!

BUCKINGHAM:
Two accessories of virtue for a Christian prince,
To protect him from the fall of vanity:
And see, with a prayer book in hand,
True ornaments for knowing a holy man.
Famous Plantagenet, very gracious prince,
Lend favorable ears to our request;
And forgive us for the interruption
Of your dedication and your just Christian zeal.

GLOCKESTER:
My lord, such excuses are not necessary:
Rather, I beg you to forgive me,
Who, sincere in the service of my God,
Neglecting the visit of my friends.
But, leaving this, what is your Grace's pleasure?

BUCKINGHAM:
Even this, I hope, which pleases God on high,
And all the good men of this ungoverned island.

GLOCKESTER:
I suspect that I have committed an offense
It seems shameful in the eyes of the city,
And that you come to reprimand my ignorance.

BUCKINGHAM:
You have done it, my lord: would it please your Grace,
To our supplications, to repair this fault!

GLOCKESTER:
Otherwise, why am I breathing in a Christian country?

BUCKINGHAM:
So know it's your fault if you quit
The supreme seat, the majestic throne,
The sceptered office of your ancestors,
Your state of wealth and your origin,
The linear glory of your royal house,
To the corruption of a stained vine:
While, in the sweetness of your sleeping thoughts,
And here we wake up for the good of our country,
This noble island lacks its own members;
His face disfigured by the scars of infamy,
His royal graft with vile plants,
And almost shouldered into the sunken abyss
Of blind oblivion and dark oblivion.
What to recover, we warmly request
Your gracious self to take charge
And the royal government of your country,
Not as protector, steward, substitute,
Or a weak factor for the gain of others;
But like successively from blood to blood,
Your birthright, your empire, yours.
To do this, in collaboration with citizens,
Your most devoted and loving friends,
And at their vehement instigation,
In this fair suit, I come to move your grace.

GLOCKESTER:
I don't know if I should leave in silence,
Or speak bitterly in your reproach.
Best matches my degree or your condition
If you don't respond, you might think
Mute ambition, not responding, gave way
To carry the golden yoke of sovereignty,
That you would impose me here with tenderness;
If I want to reprimand you for your trial,
So seasoned with your faithful love for me.
Then, on the other side, I checked on my friends.
Therefore, to speak and avoid the former,
And then, while speaking, so as not to incur the last,
Definitely this is how I answer you.
Your love deserves my thanks; but my desert
Undeserved avoids your high demand.
First, if all obstacles were removed,
And that my path was to the crown,
Like my income ripe and due by birth
Yet my poverty of spirit is such,
So powerful and so many of my faults,
As I would have preferred to hide from my greatness,
Being a boat to endure no mighty sea,
That in my greatness I desire to hide,
And in the vapor of my stifled glory.
But, thank God, I don't need me,
And I really need to help you, if necessary;
The royal tree left us royal fruits,
Who, softened by stolen hours,
Will indeed become the seat of majesty,
And undoubtedly makes us happy with his reign.
On him I ask what you would ask me,
The right and fortune of its happy stars;
May God forbid that I snatch it from him!

BUCKINGHAM:
Monsignor, this discusses conscience in your grace;
But their respects are kind and insignificant,
All circumstances considered.
You say Edward is your brother's son:
That's what we say, too, but not through Edward's wife;
For the first time, he was under contract with Lady Lucy...
Your mother is witness to this wish...
And then, by substitution, engaged
To Bona, sister of the King of France.
These two things were asked by a poor petitioner,
A crazy caring mother and many children,
A widow in decline and distress,
Even on the afternoon of his best days,
Makes price and purchase of his lustful eye,
Seduces the height and height of all his thoughts
To base the declination and hate bigamy
It was near her, in her illegal bed, that he received
This Edward, whom our manners call the prince.
Could I denounce with more bitterness,
Except that, out of respect for certain living people,
I give a limit of savings to my tongue.
So, good my lord, regain your royal self
This offered a benefit of dignity;
If we are not to bless ourselves and the earth,
Yet, to assert your noble ancestry
From the corruption of abusive times,
Towards a truly derived linear course.

Lord Mayor:
Do it, my lord, your citizens beg you.

BUCKINGHAM:
Do not refuse, mighty lord, this offered love.

CATESBY:
O, make them joyful, grant them their lawful trial!

GLOCKESTER:
Alas, why would you impose these worries on me?
I am unfit for the State and for majesty;
I beg you, don't take it the wrong way;
I cannot and will not give in to you.

BUCKINGHAM:
If you refuse it, as, out of love and zeal,
I am reluctant to put down the child, your brother's son;
We also know your tenderness of heart
And gentle, kind and effeminate remorse,
What we noted in you among your loved ones,
And also in all areas,
However, whether you accept our request or not,
Your brother's son will never reign over our king;
But we will plant another on the throne,
To the disgrace and ruin of your house:
And in this resolution we leave you here.--
Come, citizens: zounds! I won't beg anymore.

GLOCKESTER:
do not swear, my Lord of Buckingham.

CATESBY:
Call them again, my lord, and accept their request.

ANOTHER:
Do it, my good lord, lest the whole country regret it.

GLOCKESTER:
Would you impose a world of care on me?
Well, call them back. I'm not made of stone,
But penetrable for you. good supplications,
But against my conscience and my soul.
Cousin of Buckingham, and you, wise, grave men,
Since you will put fortune on my back,
To carry his burden, whether I like it or not,
I must have patience to bear the load:
But if a black scandal or a crude reproach
Attend the rest of your imposition,
Your simple execution will acquit me
Of all the impure stains and stains thereof;
For God knows it, and you can see it in part,
How far I am from desire.

Lord Mayor:
God bless your grace! we see it and we will say it.

GLOCKESTER:
By saying this, you will only be telling the truth.

BUCKINGHAM:
So I salute you with this royal title:
Long live Richard, the Royal King of England!

Lord Mayor:
Amen.

BUCKINGHAM:
Tomorrow, would you like to be crowned?

GLOCKESTER:
Even when you like, since you want to.

BUCKINGHAM:
Tomorrow then, we will witness Your Grace:
It is therefore with great joy that we take our leave.

GLOCKESTER:
Come, let us resume our holy task.
Farewell, good cousin; farewell, dear friends.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Who meets us here? my niece Plantagenêt
Driven into the hands of her kind aunt from Gloucester?
Now for my life she wanders to the Tower,
On the love of the pure heart to greet the tender princes.
My daughter, well met.

LADY ANNE:
God bless you both
A happy and joyful time of the day!

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Too bad for you, good sister! Where is it?

LADY ANNE:
No further than the Tower; and, as I suppose,
With the same dedication as you,
To congratulate the sweet princes there.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Good sister, thank you: we will all enter together.
And now the lieutenant arrives in time.
Master lieutenant, please, with your permission,
How are the prince and my young son of York?

FREINBURY:
Very well, dear madam. By your patience,
I cannot tolerate you visiting them;
The king clearly stated the opposite.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
The king! why, who is it?

FREINBURY:
I cry out to you for mercy: I mean the lord protector.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
May the Lord protect him from this royal title!
Did he put boundaries between their love and me?
I am their mother; who should keep me away from them?

DUCHESS OF YORK:
I am their father's mother; I will see them.

LADY ANNE:
Their aunt I am a mother-in-law, in love with their mother:
Then bring me to their sight; I will take your blame
And withdraw from your duties, at my own risk.

FREINBURY:
No, madam, no; I can't leave it like this:
I am bound by oath and therefore I forgive myself.

LORD STANLEY:
Let me meet you ladies in an hour,
And I will salute thy grace of York as a mother,
And reverend spectator of two beautiful queens.
Come, madam, you must straight to Westminster,
There to be crowned Richard's royal queen.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
O, cut my lace in two, so that my pent-up heart
I might have some room to fight, otherwise I'll pass out
With this deadly news!

LADY ANNE:
Despite news! Oh unpleasant news!

DORSET:
Take courage: mother, how is your grace?

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
O Dorset, don't talk to me, leave here!
Death and destruction pursue you;
Your mother's name is a bad omen for children.
If you want to get ahead of death, set sail across the seas,
And live with Richmond, far from hell
Go, go, go away from this slaughterhouse,
Lest you increase the number of dead;
And make me die under the influence of Margaret's curse,
Neither mother, nor wife, nor Queen of England.

LORD STANLEY:
This is your advice, madam, full of wisdom.
Enjoy the hours quickly;
You will have letters from me to my son
To meet you along the way, and welcome you.
Don't be caught late by careless delay.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
O wind of ill-dispersed misery!
O my cursed womb, bed of death!
You hatched into the world a cockatrice,
Whose unavoidable eye is murderous.

LORD STANLEY:
Come, madam, come; I was sent in a hurry.

LADY ANNE:
And I, reluctantly, will go.
I wish to God that inclusion was at the limit
Of golden metal which must round my forehead
Were red-hot steel, to burn me to the brain!
Anointed, let me be with deadly venom,
And die before men can say: God save the queen!

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Go, go, poor soul, I do not envy your glory
To feed my humor, don't wish you harm.

LADY ANNE:
No! Why ? When he is my husband now
I came to me, as I followed Henry's corpse,
When blood was scarce, it was well washed from his hands
Who came from my other angel husband
And this dead saint whom I then followed, weeping;
Oh, when, I say, I looked into Richard's face,
This was my wish: “Be, I said, cursed,
For making me, so young, so old, a widow!
And when you marry, let sorrow haunt your bed;
And be your wife, if someone is so crazy,
So miserable with your life
As you did to me by the death of my dear lord!
Behold, before I can repeat this curse,
Even in such a short space, my woman's heart
Grossly become captive of his honeyed words
And I have proved the subject of the curse of my own soul,
Which has since prevented my eyes from resting;
For never an hour in his bed
Have I enjoyed the golden dew of sleep,
But he was awakened by his fearful dreams.
Besides, he hates me because of my father Warwick;
And will no doubt soon be rid of me.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Poor heart, farewell! I pity your complaints.

LADY ANNE:
No more than with my soul I cry yours.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Farewell, unhappy host of glory!

LADY ANNE:
Farewell, poor soul, who takes leave of her!

DUCHESS OF YORK:

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Stay, but look with me towards the Tower.
Too bad, you old stones, these tender babies
That envy has locked up within your walls!
A crude cradle for such little pretties!
Ragged rude nurse, sullen old playmate
For the tender princes, use my babies well!
Thus, a senseless sadness bids farewell to your stones.

KING RICHARD III:
Stay away, cousin of Buckingham!

BUCKINGHAM:
My gracious sovereign?

KING RICHARD III:
Give me your hand.
So high, by your advice
And to thy aid sits King Richard;
But will we wear these honors for a day?
Or will they last, and we are happy about it?

BUCKINGHAM:
May they still live and may they last forever!

KING RICHARD III:
O Buckingham, now I play the touch,
To try if you are indeed current gold
Young Edward lives: now think what I would say.

BUCKINGHAM:
Continue, my dear lord.

KING RICHARD III:
Well, Buckingham, I say, I would be king,

BUCKINGHAM:
Well, you are, my thrice-renowned lord.

KING RICHARD III:
Ha! am I king? it is true: but Edward lives.

BUCKINGHAM:
It is true, noble prince.

KING RICHARD III:
O bitter consequence,
This Edward should still live! “It is true, noble prince!”
Cousin, you weren't so boring:
Should I be clear? I wish these bastards dead;
And I would like to have it executed suddenly.
What are you saying ? speak abruptly; be brief.

BUCKINGHAM:
Your grace can be your pleasure.

KING RICHARD III:
You are frozen, your goodness freezes:
Say, do I have your consent for them to die?

BUCKINGHAM:
Give me a little breath, a little break, my lord
Before saying positively:
I will resolve your grace immediately.

CATESBY:

KING RICHARD III:
I will converse with iron-minded fools
And disrespectful boys: none are for me
Who looks at me with caring eyes:
Buckingham, of great stature, becomes circumspect.
Boy!

Page:
My lord?

KING RICHARD III:
Don't you know anyone who corrupts gold
Would he attempt a near-death feat?

Page:
My lord, I know a disgruntled gentleman,
Whose humble means do not correspond to his haughty spirit:
Gold was worth twenty speakers,
And that will undoubtedly tempt him into anything.

KING RICHARD III:
What's her name?

Page:
His name, my lord, is Tyrrel.

KING RICHARD III:
I know part of this man: go call him here.
The witty and deeply turning Buckingham
No one will be next in my council anymore:
Did he resist me for so long without getting tired,
And does he stop now to catch his breath?
How now! what news from you?

STANLEY:
My lord, I have heard that the Marquis Dorset has fled
In Richmond, in these regions beyond the sea
Where he lives.

KING RICHARD III:
Catesby!

CATESBY:
My lord?

KING RICHARD III:
The rumor abroad
That Anne, my wife, is sick and would like to die:
I will take orders that she stays close.
Ask me for a born naughty gentleman,
Whom I will marry directly to Clarence's daughter:
This boy is stupid and I don't fear him.
Look how you dream! I repeat, give
That Anne my wife is sick and would like to die:
On this subject; because it is close to my heart,
To stop all the hopes whose growth could harm me.
I must be married to my brother's daughter,
Or my kingdom rests on fragile glass.
Murder her brothers, then marry her!
Uncertain method of winning! But I am in
Until now, it is in the blood that sin will uproot sin:
The pity that flows in tears dwells not in this eye.
Is your name Tyrrel?

TYRREL:
James Tyrrel, and your most obedient subject.

KING RICHARD III:
Are you really?

TYRREL:
Prove to me, my gracious sovereign.

KING RICHARD III:
Would you dare to decide to kill one of my friends?

TYRREL:
Yes my Lord ;
But I prefer to kill two enemies.

KING RICHARD III:
Well, there you have it: two deep enemies,
Enemies of my rest and disturbers of my sweet sleep
Are these that I would like you to take care of:
Tyrrel, I mean those bastards in the Tower.

TYRREL:
Let me have open ways to come to them,
And soon I will rid you of their fear.

KING RICHARD III:
You sing sweet music. Listen, come here, Tyrrel
Go, by this sign: arise and give ear:
There is nothing left but this: say that it is done,
And I will love you and prefer you too.

TYRREL:
It is done, my gracious lord.

KING RICHARD III:
Shall we hear from you, Tyrrel, before we sleep?

TYRREL:
Yes my Lord.

BUCKINGHAM:
My Lord, I have been thinking in my mind
The late request you asked me for.

KING RICHARD III:
Well, let's let that pass. Dorset fled to Richmond.

BUCKINGHAM:
I have heard this news, my lord.

KING RICHARD III:
Stanley, he's your wife's son, take a good look at him.

BUCKINGHAM:
My lord, I claim your gift, my due by promise,
For which your honor and your faith are pledged;
County Hereford and furniture
The one you promised me you'd have.

KING RICHARD III:
Stanley, look at your wife; if it transmits
Letters to Richmond, you will answer them.

BUCKINGHAM:
What does Your Highness say to my just request?

KING RICHARD III:
If I remember correctly, Henry VI
Prophesied that Richmond would be king,
When Richmond was a moody little boy.
A king, maybe, maybe...

BUCKINGHAM:
My lord!

KING RICHARD III:
How fortunate was it that the prophet could not, at that moment,
Did you tell me, standing there, that I should kill him?

BUCKINGHAM:
My lord, your promise for the county,...

KING RICHARD III:
Richmond! The last time I was in Exeter,
The mayor, out of courtesy, showed me the castle,
And I called it Rougemont: what name did I start with,
Because a bard from Ireland once told me
I wouldn't live long after seeing Richmond.

BUCKINGHAM:
My lord!

KING RICHARD III:
Yes, what time is it?

BUCKINGHAM:
So I am bold to think of your grace
Of what you promised me.

KING RICHARD III:
Well, but what time is it?

BUCKINGHAM:
Around ten o'clock.

KING RICHARD III:
Well, let him hit.

BUCKINGHAM:
Why let him hit?

KING RICHARD III:
Because, like Jack, you keep going
Between your begging and my meditation.
I'm not one to give today.

BUCKINGHAM:
Well, then solve me, whether you like it or not.

KING RICHARD III:
Tut tut,
You trouble me ; I'm not in the vein.

BUCKINGHAM:
Is this still the case? it rewards my true service
With such contempt, did I make him king for this?
O, let me think of Hastings and go
To Brecknock, while my fearful head is turned!

TYRREL:
The tyrannical and bloody act is accomplished.
The most pitiful massacre
What this land was always guilty of.
Dighton and Forrest, whom I bribed
To carry out this merciless butchery,
Even if they were flesh and blood villains, bloody dogs,
Fondant of tenderness and kind compassion
Wept like two children in the sad stories of their deaths.
“Here,” said Dighton, “lay these tender babies:”
“So, so,” said Forrest, “surrounding each other
In their innocent alabaster arms:
Their lips were four red roses on a stem,
Who, in their summer beauty, kissed each other.
A prayer book lay on their pillow;
Which once, said Forrest, almost changed my mind;
But oh! the devil - there the wicked stopped
While Dighton recounted: "We suffocated
Nature's sweetest most regenerated work,
This comes from the first creation that she framed.
So both go away with conscience and remorse;
They could not speak; and so I left them both,
To bring this news to the damn king.
And here it is.
Hello everyone, my sovereign liege!

KING RICHARD III:
Gentle Tyrrel, am I glad to hear your news?

TYRREL:
If I had done what you had entrusted to me
Generate your happiness, be happy then,
Because it is done, my lord.

KING RICHARD III:
But have you seen them dead?

TYRREL:
I did it, my lord.

KING RICHARD III:
And buried, kind Tyrrel?

TYRREL:
The Chaplain of the Tower buried them;
But how and where I don't know.

KING RICHARD III:
Come to me, Tyrrel, soon after dinner,
And you will tell the process of their death.
In the meantime, but think about what good I could do for you,
And be the heir of your desire.
Goodbye see you soon.
I locked Clarence's son up close;
I married his daughter miserably;
Edward's sons sleep in Abraham's bosom,
And Anne, my wife, wished the world a good night.
Now, because I know the Breton objectives of Richmond
At young Elizabeth, my brother's daughter,
And, through this knot, he proudly looks at the crown,
I go to her, a cheerful and prosperous courtesan.

CATESBY:
My lord!

KING RICHARD III:
Good news or bad news, that you come so suddenly?

CATESBY:
Bad news, my lord: Ely has fled to Richmond;
And Buckingham, supported by the sturdy Welsh,
He is on the ground, and his power continues to increase.

KING RICHARD III:
Ely with Richmond bothers me closer
Than Buckingham and his reckless army.
Come on, I heard that scary comment
Is a leaden servant of boring delay;
Delay leads to helpless, snail-paced begging
Then the fiery expedition will be my wing,
Mercury of Jupiter and herald of a king!
Come, gather men: my counsel is my shield;
We must be brief when traitors brave the field.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
So now the prosperity begins to soften
And falls into the rotten mouth of death.
Here, within these limits, I hid,
To observe the decline of my adversaries.
I witness a terrible induction,
And I will return to France, hoping for the consequence
Will also turn out to be bitter, dark and tragic.
Withdraw, miserable Marguerite: who comes here?

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Ah, my young princes! ah, my tender babies!
My unblown flowers, my new sweets!
If, however, your sweet souls fly in the air
And don't be stuck in perpetual destiny,
Circle around me with your aerial wings
And listen to your mother's lamentations!

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Hover around it; say, it's good for good
Turned your child's morning into an old night.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
So much misery has made my voice crazy,
That my tired tongue is mute and mute,
Edouard Plantagenêt, why did you die?

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Plantagenêt leaves Plantagenêt.
Edward for Edward pays a dying debt.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Will you, O God, flee from these gentle lambs,
And throw them into the bowels of the wolf?
When did you sleep when such an act was committed?

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
When Saint Harry died, and my sweet son.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Blind sight, dead life, poor mortal living ghost,
Scene of misfortune, shame of the world, grave due to a usurped life,
Brief summary and account of the tedious days,
Rest your troubles on the legal land of England,
Illegally drunk with the blood of innocents!

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Oh, you might as well give yourself a grave
How you can give up a melancholy seat!
Then I would hide my bones, I would not lay them here.
O, who has a reason to cry but me?

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
If the old pain is the most reverent,
Give mine the benefit of seniority,
And let my misfortunes take over.
If sorrow can admit society,
Recount your misfortunes again while looking at mine:
I had an Edward, until a Richard killed him;
I had a Harry, until a Richard killed him:
You had an Edward, until a Richard killed him;
You had a Richard, until a Richard killed him;

DUCHESS OF YORK:
I also had a Richard, and you killed him;
I also had a Rutland, you should kill him.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
You also had a Clarence, and Richard killed him.
From the kennel of your belly has slipped
A hellhound that chases us all to the death:
This dog who had his teeth in front of his eyes,
To worry the lambs and lap up their sweet blood,
This filthy destroyer of the work of God,
This excellent great tyrant of the earth,
Who reigns in the irritated eyes of crying souls,
Your stomach was unleashed to chase us to our graves.
O upright, just and sincere God,
How can I thank you, that this carnal dog
Feeds on the question of his mother's body,
And makes her bench companion with the moans of others!

DUCHESS OF YORK:
O wife of Harry, do not triumph over my misfortunes!
God be my witness, I cried for yours.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Bear with me; I thirst for revenge,
And now I miss seeing him.
Your Edward is dead, the one who stabbed my Edward:
Your other Edward died, to leave my Edward;
Young York, he's just a boot, 'cause they're both
Do not correspond to the high perfection of my loss:
Your Clarence is dead, the one who killed my Edward;
And the spectators of this tragic play,
Adulterers Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, Grey,
Untimely suffocated in their dark graves.
Richard still lives, the black intelligence of hell,
I only booked their postman, to buy souls
And send them there: but within reach, within reach,
His pitiful and merciless end follows:
The earth gapes, hell burns, demons roar, saints pray.
To have him taken away suddenly.
Cancel his life bond, my God, I'm taking it,
So that I can live and say: The dog is dead!

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
O, you prophesied that the time would come
That I should wish you would help me curse
This spider in a bottle, this filthy toad with a crooked back!

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
I called you then in vain, blossoming of my fortune;
I called you then poor shadow, painted queen;
The presentation of what I was;
The flattering hint of a terrible spectacle;
One of them rose high to be thrown down;
A mother only made fun of two adorable babies;
A dream of what you were, a breath, a bubble,
A sign of dignity, a garish flag,
To be the target of every dangerous shot,
A queen in joke, only to fill the stage.
Where is your husband now? where are your brothers?
Where are your children? why do you do it, joy?
Who is suing you and shouting “God save the queen”?
Where are the bent peers who flattered you?
Where are the assembled troops who followed you?
Refuse all this and see what you are now:
For a happy wife, a very sorrowful widow;
For a joyful mother, one who cries the name;
For queen, a carefully crowned very-caitiff;
For the one who is pursued, the one who pursues humbly;
For someone who despised me, now despised me;
For one being feared by all, now he fears one;
For one commands all things, and obeys no one.
Thus has the course of justice turned,
And left you prey to time;
Having nothing left to think about what you were,
To torture you more, being what you are.
You usurped my place, and you don't
Usurp the right proportion of my sorrow?
Now your proud neck bears half of my heavy yoke;
From where even here I slide my tired neck,
And leave the burden of all this on you.
Farewell, wife of York and queen of sad misfortune:
These English misfortunes will make me smile in France.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
O you who are gifted in curses, stay a while,
And teach me to curse my enemies!

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Do not sleep at night and fast during the day;
Compare dead happiness with living unhappiness;
Think your babies were prettier than them,
And he who killed them is more vile than him:
Improving your loss makes the bad person worse:
Spinning this will teach you to curse.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
My words are boring; Oh, quicken them with yours!

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Your misfortunes will make them sharp and piercing like mine.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Why should calamity be full of words?

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
From windy lawyers to the misfortunes of their clients,
Aerial successors of intestate joys,
Poor speakers of misery who breathe!
Give them room for action: even if what they transmit
They don't help everyone, but they ease the heart.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
If so, don't be speechless: come with me.
And in the breath of bitter words we stifle
My damn son, whom your two sweet sons suffocated.
I hear his drum: be copious in shouting.

KING RICHARD III:
Who intercepts my shipment?

DUCHESS OF YORK:
O the one who could have intercepted you,
By strangling you in her cursed womb
Of all the massacres, wretch, that you have committed!

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Do you hide this forehead with a golden crown,
Where should we engrave, if this right were just,
The massacre of the prince who owed this crown,
And the tragic death of my two sons and brothers?
Tell me, wicked slave, where are my children?

DUCHESS OF YORK:
You toad, you toad, where is your brother Clarence?
And little Ned Plantagenet, his son?

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Where are the nice Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, Grey?

KING RICHARD III:
A boast, trumpets! sound the alarm, battery!
May the heavens not hear these revealing women
Mock the Lord's anointed: strike, I say!
Be patient, and beg me honestly,
Or with the loud sound of war
So I will cover your exclamations.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Are you my son?

KING RICHARD III:
Yes, I thank God, my father and yourself.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
So listen patiently to my impatience.

KING RICHARD III:
Madam, I have a touch of your condition,
Which cannot bear the accent of reprimand.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Oh, let me talk!

KING RICHARD III:
Do then: but I will not hear.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
I will be gentle and gentle in my speech.

KING RICHARD III:
And in short, good mother; because I'm in a hurry.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Are you in such a hurry? I stayed for you,
God knows, in anguish, pain and agony.

KING RICHARD III:
And have I not finally come to console you?

DUCHESS OF YORK:
No, by the holy rood screen, you know it well,
You came to earth to make the earth my hell.
Your birth was a heavy burden for me;
Your childhood was irritable and capricious;
Your scary, desperate, wild and furious school days,
Your peak of daring, daring and adventurous manhood,
Your age confirmed, proud, submissive, bloody,
perfidious,
Gentler, but yet more harmful, kinder in hatred:
What comfortable hour can you name,
Has it ever made me happy to be in your company?

KING RICHARD III:
Well, none, except Humphrey Hour, who called
your grace
Have breakfast once I leave my company.
If I am so ashamed in your eyes,
Let me continue without offending Your Grace.
Hit the drum.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Please listen to me speak.

KING RICHARD III:
You speak too bitterly.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Listen to me a word;
Because I will never speak to you again.

KING RICHARD III:
SO.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Either you will die, by the just ordinance of God,
Before this war you become a conqueror,
Or I will perish with sorrow and extreme age
And never look at your face again.
So take with you my heaviest curse;
Who, on the day of battle, tires you more
Let all the full armor you wear!
My prayers for the fight of the opposing party;
And there the little souls of Edward's children
Whisper the spirits of your enemies
And promise them success and victory.
You are bloody, your end will be bloody;
Shame serves your life and your death accompanies it.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Although there are many more causes, but much less spirit to curse
Abide in me; I say amen to everyone.

KING RICHARD III:
Stay, madam; I have to say a word to you.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
I no longer have a son of royal blood
For you to murder: for my daughters, Richard,
They will be nuns in prayer, not queens in tears;
And so level so as not to clash with their lives.

KING RICHARD III:
You have a daughter called Elizabeth,
Virtuous and just, royal and gracious.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
And must she die for this? Oh, let her live,
And I will corrupt her ways, stain her beauty;
Slandering me as being false to Edward's bed;
Throw the veil of infamy over her:
So that she can live without the scars of a bloody massacre,
I admit that she was not Edward's daughter.

KING RICHARD III:
This is not false about her birth, she is of royal blood.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
To save her life, I'll say she's not.

KING RICHARD III:
His life is no longer secure than when he was born.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
And it was only in this security that his brothers died.

KING RICHARD III:
Behold, at their birth the lucky stars were opposite.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
No, bad friends were contrary to their lives.

KING RICHARD III:
All that is inevitable is the catastrophe of destiny.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
It is true that when it is avoided, grace makes destiny:
My babies were destined for a fairer death,
If grace had blessed you with a more beautiful life.

KING RICHARD III:
You talk like I killed my cousins.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Cousins, indeed; and by their uncle
Of comfort, of kingdom, of kinship, of freedom, of life.
Whose hand pierced their tender hearts,
Your head, indirectly, gave instructions:
There is no doubt that the murderous knife was dull and dull.
Until it is sharpened on your stone-hard heart,
To delight in the entrails of my lambs.
But the use of sorrow makes wild sorrow tame,
My tongue should not in your ears name my boys
Until my nails were anchored in your eyes;
And I, in a bay of death so desperate,
Like a poor boat, with sails and rigging,
Run in pieces on your rocky bosom.

KING RICHARD III:
Madam, then I flourish in my business
And the dangerous success of bloody wars,
As I intend to do more good for you and yours,
That you or yours have never been wronged by me!

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
What is the face of heaven for?
Can being discovered do me any good?

KING RICHARD III:
The advancement of your children, sweet lady.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
To some scaffold, there to lose your head?

KING RICHARD III:
No, to dignity and the height of honor
The high imperial type of the glory of this land.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Flatter my sorrows by reporting it;
Tell me what state, what dignity, what honor,
Can you give in to one of my children?

KING RICHARD III:
Even everything I have; yes, and me and everything,
Will I also endow one of your children;
So in the Lethe of your angry soul
You drown the sad memory of these wrongs
What you suppose I did to you.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Be brief, lest it be a process of your kindness
Lasts longer than the appointment of your kindness.

KING RICHARD III:
So know that with all my soul I love your daughter.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
My daughter's mother thinks so with her soul.

KING RICHARD III:
What do you think?

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
That you love my daughter with all your soul:
So with the love of your soul you loved his brothers;
And from the bottom of my heart, I thank you.

KING RICHARD III:
Don't be so hasty as to confuse my meaning:
I mean, with my soul I love your daughter,
And I want to make her Queen of England.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
So say: who do you think will be its king?

KING RICHARD III:
Even the one that makes her queen, who should be otherwise?

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
What you ?

KING RICHARD III:
Me, even me: what do you think, madam?

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
How can you woo her?

KING RICHARD III:
This is how I will learn from you,
Like the one who knows his humor best.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
And do you want to learn from me?

KING RICHARD III:
Madam, with all my heart.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Send him, by the man who killed his brothers,
A pair of bleeding hearts; engrave on it
Edward and York; then maybe she will cry:
So introduce him - like Margaret sometimes
I made to your father, imbued with the blood of Rutland,...
A tissue; which, tell him, drained
The purple sap from her sweet brother's body
And tell him to dry his watery eyes with it.
If this incitement forces her not to love,
Send him the story of your noble deeds;
Tell him you chased away his uncle Clarence,
His uncle Rivers; yes, and, for her,
Fastest travel with his good aunt Anne.

KING RICHARD III:
Come, come, you're making fun of me; it's not like that
To win our daughter.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
There's no other way
Unless you can take another form,
And don't be Richard, the one who did all this.

KING RICHARD III:
Say I did all this out of love for her.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
No, then indeed, she can only hate you,
Having bought love with such bloody spoils.

KING RICHARD III:
Look, what is done cannot be changed now:
Men will sometimes act recklessly,
Which, after hours, gives time to repent.
If I took the kingdom from your sons,
To make it up to you, I'll give it to your daughter.
If I killed the issue from your womb,
To accelerate your growth, I will generate
My question of your blood on your daughter
A grandmother's name is a little less loving
What is a mother's affectionate title;
They are like children but one step below,
Even of your courage, of your very blood;
Of one pain, except for a night of moaning
Endured by the one for whom you offer as sorrow.
Your children were a nuisance to your youth,
But mine will be a comfort to your age.
The loss you have is only a son being king,
And through this loss, your daughter became queen.
I can't make the repairs I would do,
So accept all the kindness I can.
Dorset your son, who has a fearful soul
Leads discontented steps into foreign soil,
This righteous alliance will quickly be called to us
To high promotions and great dignity:
The king, who calls your beautiful daughter wife.
You will familiarly call your brother Dorset;
You will be the mother of a king again,
And all the ruins of hard times
Repaired with a double wealth of content.
What! we have many beautiful days to see:
The liquid drops of tears you shed
Will return, transformed to direct the pearl,
Take advantage of their loan with interest
A tenfold increase in happiness.
Go, then my mother, go to your daughter
Highlight his shy years with your experience;
Prepare his ears to hear a courtier's story
Put in his tender heart the aspiring flame
Of golden sovereignty; introduce the princess
With the sweet silent hours of the joys of marriage
And when my arm chastised
The little rebel and the stupid Buckingham,
Bound with triumphant garlands I will come
And lead your daughter to the bed of a conqueror;
To whom I will tell of my won conquest,
And she will be the only winner, the Caesar of Caesar.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
What did I have best to say? his father's brother
Could this be his lord? or should I say, his uncle?
Or the one who killed his brothers and uncles?
Under what title should I court you,
May God, the law, my honor and his love,
Could this seem pleasant to his younger years?

KING RICHARD III:
Deduce the equitable peace of England by this alliance.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Which it will buy with a still lasting war.

KING RICHARD III:
Say that the king, who can command, begs.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
This in his hands, what the king of the king forbids.

KING RICHARD III:
Say, she will be a high and mighty queen.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
To moan the tide, as its mother does.

KING RICHARD III:
Say, I will love him forever.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
But how long will this title last?

KING RICHARD III:
Slowly gaining strength until the end of his beautiful life.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
But how long will his sweet lie last?

KING RICHARD III:
Hopefully the sky and nature lengthen it.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
As hell and Richard likes it.

KING RICHARD III:
Say, I, his sovereign, am his subject of love.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
But she, your subject, hates such sovereignty.

KING RICHARD III:
Be eloquent in my favor to her.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
It's best if an honest story is told clearly.

KING RICHARD III:
Then, in clear terms, tell him my love story.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
The simple and not honest style is too harsh a style.

KING RICHARD III:
Your reasons are too superficial and too quick.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Oh no, my reasons are too deep and dead;
Too deep and dead, poor children, in their graves.

KING RICHARD III:
No harp on this string, madam; It's from the past.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
I will continue to play the harp there until the heartstrings break.

KING RICHARD III:
Now, by my George, my garter and my crown,...

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Desecrated, dishonored and the third usurped.

KING RICHARD III:
I swear--

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
By nothing; because it is not an oath:
The desecrated George has lost his holy honor;
The garter, stained, pledged her chivalrous virtue;
The crown, usurped, dishonored its royal glory.
if you swear something to be believed,
So swear by something you have done no wrong.

KING RICHARD III:
Now, around the world...

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
It's full of your horrible wrongs.

KING RICHARD III:
The death of my father...

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Your life has been dishonored.

KING RICHARD III:
Then, by myself...

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
You are abusing it yourself.

KING RICHARD III:
Why then, by God...

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
God's wrong is the most important.
If you had been afraid of breaking an oath he had taken,
The unity that the king your brother made
Had not been broken, nor my brother killed:
If you had been afraid of breaking an oath he had taken,
The imperial metal, now surrounding your forehead,
Had honored the tender temples of my child,
And the two princes breathed here,
And now, two tender playmates to dust,
Your broken faith has become prey for worms.
What can you swear by now?

KING RICHARD III:
The time to come.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
That you have done wrong in the past;
Because I have a lot of tears to wash myself
Beyond time, for past time has been wronged by you.
The children live, whose parents you have
massacre,
Ungoverned youth, to lament him at his age;
The parents live, whose children you massacred,
Old withered plants, to lament with their age.
Do not swear by the time to come; for this you have
Misused before being used, by time misused in the past.

KING RICHARD III:
As I intend to prosper and repent,
So I prosper in my dangerous attempt
Enemy weapons! confuse myself!
Heaven and fortune forbid me happy hours!
Day, do not give me your light; nor, at night, your rest!
Be in front of all the planets of good luck
To my steps, if, with the love of a pure heart,
Immaculate devotion, holy thoughts,
I'm not waiting for your beautiful princely daughter!
In it consist my happiness and yours;
Without her, we follow this earth and I,
To you, to herself and to many Christian souls,
Death, desolation, ruin and decay:
This can only be avoided by this;
This will only be avoided by this.
This is why, good mother, I must be able to do this to you...
Be the attorney of my love for her:
Plead for what I will be, and not for what I have been;
Not my merits, but what I deserve:
Emphasize the necessity and the state of the times,
And don't be glum about big designs.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Will I be thus tempted by the devil?

KING RICHARD III:
Yes, if the devil tempts you to do good.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Should I forget myself to be myself?

KING RICHARD III:
Yes, if your memory is wrong.
