QUEEN ELIZABETH:
But you killed my children.

KING RICHARD III:
But in the womb of your daughter I bury them:
Where in this nest of spices they will breed
Self of themselves, for your comfort.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Should I go and win my daughter to your will?

KING RICHARD III:
And be a happy mother through deeds.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
I go. Write to me very soon.
And you will understand his spirit from me.

KING RICHARD III:
Give him the kiss of my true love; and then, goodbye.
Implacable fool and superficial and changeable woman!
How now! What's new?

RATCLIFF:
My gracious sovereign, on the west coast
Rides a powerful navy; to the shore
A crowd of doubtful and hollow-hearted friends,
Disarmed and unresolved to repel them:
Richmond is believed to be their admiral;
And there they cry, just waiting for help
From Buckingham to welcome them ashore.

KING RICHARD III:
A light-hearted friend sends a message to the Duke of Norfolk:
Ratcliff, yourself or Catesby; where is he?

CATESBY:
Here, my lord.

KING RICHARD III:
Fly to the Duke:
Station yourself in Salisbury
When you come there...
Boring and unconscious villain,
Why do you stay quiet and don't go to the duke?

CATESBY:
First of all, mighty ruler, let me know what you think,
That with your grace I will deliver him.

KING RICHARD III:
O, that's right, good Catesby: tell him to get up straight
The greatest strength and power he can create,
And find me currently in Salisbury.

CATESBY:
I go.

RATCLIFF:
What would Your Highness want me to do?
Salisbury?

KING RICHARD III:
Why, what would you do there before I leave?

RATCLIFF:
Your Highness told me I should post first.

KING RICHARD III:
I've changed my mind, sir, I've changed my mind.
And now, what news from you?

STANLEY:
Nothing good, my lord, to please you by hearing you;
Nor anything that serious, but one could well say.

KING RICHARD III:
Hello, a riddle! neither good nor bad!
Why do you run so many miles,
When will you be able to tell your story more closely?
Once again, what news?

STANLEY:
Richmond is on the seas.

KING RICHARD III:
There, let him flow, and be the sea on him!
White liver runagate, what is it doing there?

STANLEY:
I do not know, mighty sovereign, but I guess it.

KING RICHARD III:
Well, sir, as you guess, as you guess?

STANLEY:
Stirred by Dorset, Buckingham and Ely,
He is heading to England to claim the crown.

KING RICHARD III:
Is the chair empty? is the sword unshakable?
Is the king dead? the empire dispossessed?
Which heir of York is alive besides us?
And who is the king of England if not the heir of the great York?
So tell me, what is he doing on the sea?

STANLEY:
Without this, my lord, I cannot guess.

KING RICHARD III:
Unless he becomes your liege,
You can't guess why the Welshman is coming.
You will rebel and flee to him, I fear.

STANLEY:
No, mighty lord; so don't be suspicious of me.

KING RICHARD III:
Where is your power to repel him?
Where are your tenants and your supporters?
Are they not now on the West Bank?
Drive the rebels off their ships!

STANLEY:
No, my good lord, my friends are in the north.

KING RICHARD III:
Cold friends of Richard: what are they doing in the north,
When should they serve their sovereign in the West?

STANLEY:
They were not commanded, mighty sovereign:
Please, Your Majesty give me permission,
I will gather my friends and meet your grace
Where and at what time Your Majesty pleases.

KING RICHARD III:
Aouch aouch. you would have left to join Richmond:
I won't trust you, sir.

STANLEY:
Most powerful ruler,
You have no reason to doubt my friendship:
I have never been fake and I never will be.

KING RICHARD III:
GOOD,
Go and gather men; but, listen to yourself, leave behind you
Your son, George Stanley: look, your faith be firm.
Or else the confidence of his head is fragile.

STANLEY:
So deal with it while I prove my loyalty to you.

Messenger:
My gracious sovereign, now in Devonshire,
As my friends have told me,
Sir Edward Courtney and the Haughty Prelate
Bishop of Exeter, his brother there,
With many more Confederates, they are up in arms.

Second messenger:
My lord, in Kent the Guildfords are in arms;
And every hour more competitors
Act to their aid, and their power continues to increase.

Third messenger:
My lord, the army of the Duke of Buckingham...

KING RICHARD III:
It’s your turn, owls! nothing but death songs?
Take this, until you bring me better news.

Third messenger:
The news I must announce to Your Majesty
That is, through flash floods and waterfalls,
Buckingham's army is scattered and dispersed;
And he himself went away alone,
Nobody knows where.

KING RICHARD III:
I cry out to you for mercy:
Here is my purse to treat your injury.
A wise friend proclaimed
Reward for the one who brings the traitor?

Third messenger:
Such a proclamation has been made, my lord.

Fourth Messenger:
Sir Thomas Lovel and Lord Marquess Dorset,
They say, my lord, that in Yorkshire we are in arms.
Yet this good comfort brings me to your grace,
The Breton navy is scattered by the storm:
Richmond, Yorkshire, sent a boat
To the shore, to ask those on the banks
Whether they were his assistants, yes or no;
Those who answered him came from Buckingham.
To his side: he, distrusting them,
Sail hoisted and departure for Brittany.

KING RICHARD III:
Walk, walk, since we are armed;
If not to fight foreign enemies,
However, we must defeat these rebels here at home.

CATESBY:
My liege, the Duke of Buckingham, is taken;
This is the best news: that the Earl of Richmond
Has a mighty power landed in Milford,
The news is colder, but it must be announced.

KING RICHARD III:
On the way to Salisbury! while we reason here,
A battle royale could be won and lost
Someone orders Buckingham brought
In Salisbury; the others walk with me.

DERBY:
Sir Christopher, tell Richmond this for me:
Than in the stable of this bloodiest boar
My son George Stanley is franked in the hold:
If I rebel, young George's head goes;
The fear of this holds back my current help.
But tell me, where is Prince Richmond now?

CHRISTOPHE:
In Pembroke, or in Harford-west, Wales.

DERBY:
Which famous men use him?

CHRISTOPHE:
Sir Walter Herbert, a renowned soldier;
Sir Gilbert Talbot, Sir William Stanley;
Oxford, Pembroke Redoubt, Sir James Blunt,
And Rice ap Thomas with a gallant crew;
And many others of noble fame and value:
And towards London they bend their course,
If, moreover, they are not fought.

DERBY:
Return to your lord; recommend me to him:
Tell him that the queen has heartily consented
He will marry Elisabeth, his daughter.
These letters will put him out of my mind. Farewell.

BUCKINGHAM:
Won't King Richard let me speak to him?

Sheriff:
No, my good lord; so be patient.

BUCKINGHAM:
Hastings and Edward's children, Rivers, Grey,
Holy King Henry and your son-in-law Edward,
Vaughan, and all that had a miscarriage
By a sneaky and corrupt injustice,
If these are your sullen and discontented souls
Through the clouds, contemplate this present hour,
Even to avenge me, mock my destruction!
It's All Saints' Day, folks, isn't it?

Sheriff:
It is true, my lord.

BUCKINGHAM:
Well, then All Saints' Day is my body's doomsday.
It is the day when, in the time of King Edward,
I wish it didn't fall on me when I was found
False to his children or his wife's allies
This is the day I wish I fell
It was through his false faith that I had the most confidence;
This, this day for all souls for my fearful soul
Will the determined respite from my wrongs:
This great All-Seer with whom I lingered
Spilled my false prayer on my head
And I seriously gave what I jokingly asked for.
This is how he forces the swords of the wicked
To turn their own arguments on the bosom of their masters:
Now Margaret's curse has fallen upon my head;
“When he,” she said, “breaks your heart with sorrow,
Remember that Margaret was a prophetess.
Come, gentlemen, lead me to the block of shame;
Evil only has evil, and blame whoever is due to blame.

RICHMOND:
Companions in arms and my most loving friends,
Bruised under the yoke of tyranny,
So far in the bowels of the earth
Did we walk without obstacle?
And we receive here from our father Stanley
Fair lines of reassurance and encouragement.
The miserable, bloody and usurping boar,
It has spoiled your summer fields and your fruitful vines,
Makes your warm blood flow like a wash and makes its hollow
In your interlocking breasts, this dirty pig
Now stands in the very center of this island,
Near the town of Leicester, as we learn
From Tamworth it is only a day's walk.
In the name of God, good courage, courageous friends,
To reap the harvest of perpetual peace
By this bloody ordeal of a fierce war.

OXFORD:
Every man's conscience is a thousand swords,
To fight against this damn homicide.

HERBERT:
I don't doubt it, but his friends will fly to us.

BLUNT:
He has no friends who are friends out of fear.
Which, in his greatest need, will withdraw from him.

RICHMOND:
All this for our benefit. So, in the name of God, walk:
True hope is swift and flies with swallow's wings:
Kings make gods and more wicked creatures kings.

KING RICHARD III:
Here let us pitch our tents, even here, in the field of Bosworth.
My Lord of Surrey, why do you look so sad?

SURREY:
My heart is ten times lighter than my appearance.

KING RICHARD III:
Monsignor of Norfolk,...

NORFOLK:
Here, very kind Liège.

KING RICHARD III:
Norfolk, we must have shots; Ha! is not it ?

NORFOLK:
We must give and receive, my gracious lord.

KING RICHARD III:
Pitch my tent there! I'm going to bed here tonight;
But where tomorrow? Well, it's all one for that.
Who knew the number of the enemy?

NORFOLK:
Six or seven thousand is their greatest power.

KING RICHARD III:
Well, our battalion triples that account:
Moreover, the king's name is a tower of strength,
What they want from the opposing party.
Pitch my tent there! Valiant gentlemen,
Let's look at home advantage
Call for men of good leadership
We don't want any discipline, let's not delay,
Because, lords, tomorrow will be a busy day.

RICHMOND:
The tired sun made a golden sunset,
And by the luminous trace of his flaming car,
Gives the signal of a beautiful day tomorrow.
Sir William Brandon, you will carry my standard.
Give me ink and paper in my tent
I will draw the shape and pattern of our battle,
Limit each leader to his different charges,
And share our little strength in fair proportion.
My Lord of Oxford, you, Sir William Brandon,
And you, Sir Walter Herbert, stay with me.
The Earl of Pembroke guards his regiment:
Good Captain Blunt, bid him good night
And from the second hour in the morning
Want the count to see me in my tent:
One more thing, good Blunt, before you go,
Where is Lord Stanley, do you know?

BLUNT:
Unless I was very wrong about its colors,
Which I am sure I did not do,
His regiment is at least 800 meters away
South of the mighty power of the king.

RICHMOND:
If this is possible without danger,
Good Captain Blunt, bid him good evening,
And give him this essential parchment for me.

BLUNT:
On my life, my lord, I take charge of it;
And so, God give you a peaceful rest this night!

RICHMOND:
Good night, good Captain Blunt. Come gentlemen,
Let's consult on tomorrow's business
In our tent; the air is raw and cold.

KING RICHARD III:
It's not time?

CATESBY:
It is dinner time, my lord;
It's nine o'clock.

KING RICHARD III:
I won't have supper tonight.
Give me some ink and paper.
What, is my beaver easier than it was?
And all my armor left in my tent?

CATESBY:
If so, my lord; and everything is ready.

KING RICHARD III:
Good Norfolk, at your charge;
Be attentive, choose reliable sentries.

NORFOLK:
I'm going, my lord.

KING RICHARD III:
Mix with the lark tomorrow, nice Norfolk.

NORFOLK:
I guarantee it to you, my lord.

KING RICHARD III:
Catesby!

CATESBY:
My lord?

KING RICHARD III:
Send an armed pursuer
To Stanley's regiment; tell him to bring his power
Before sunrise, lest her son George fall
In the blind cave of eternal night.
Fill me a bowl of wine. Give me a watch.
Saddle the white Surrey for the field tomorrow.
Make sure my poles are sturdy and not too heavy.
Ratcliff!

RATCLIFF:
My lord?

KING RICHARD III:
Have you seen the melancholy Lord Northumberland?

RATCLIFF:
Thomas the Earl of Surrey and himself,
A lot about the time the taps are turned off, from troop to troop
I walked through the army, encouraging the soldiers.

KING RICHARD III:
So, I'm satisfied. Give me a bowl of wine:
I don't have this eagerness of mind,
Nor the joy of life that I used to have.
Drop it off. Are the ink and paper ready?

RATCLIFF:
It is true, my lord.

KING RICHARD III:
Tell my guard to keep watch; leave me.
Ratcliff, in the middle of the night, come to my tent
And help me arm myself. Leave me, I said.

DERBY:
Fortune and victory are on your helmet!

RICHMOND:
All the comfort that the dark night can offer
Be kind to yourself, noble father-in-law!
Tell me, how is our beloved mother?

DERBY:
I, by lawyer, bless you on behalf of your mother
Who continually prays for the good of Richmond:
So much for that. The silent hours pass,
And flaky darkness rises in the east.
In short, because this is what the season asks of us,
Prepare your fight early in the morning,
And put your fortune to arbitration
Bloody blows and breathtaking war.
Me, as I can, what I would like, I cannot,
With the best advantage we will deceive time,
And help you in this dubious clash of arms:
But on your side I'm perhaps not too forward
Lest being seen, your brother, tender George,
Being executed before his father's eyes.
Farewell: Leisure and Scary Times
Cut ceremonial vows of love
And many exchanges of sweet speeches,
On which friends so long separated should dwell:
God gives us leisure for these rites of love!
Once again, farewell: be brave and run well!

RICHMOND:
Good lords, lead him to his regiment:
I will try, with troubled thoughts, to take a nap,
Lest a heavy sleep bore me tomorrow,
When I should ride with wings of victory:
Once again, good night, kind lords and gentlemen.
O You, whose captain I consider myself to be,
Look at my strength with a kind eye;
Put your irons bruised with anger into their hands,
That they may crash in a heavy fall
The usurping helmets of our adversaries!
Make us your ministers of punishment,
So that we can praise you in victory!
I entrust my vigilant soul to you,
Before I let the windows fall from my eyes:
Sleeping and waking, oh, defend me again!

Ghost of Prince Edward:

Ghost of King Henry VI:

Ghost of CLARENCE:

Ghost of RIVIÈRES:

Ghost of GRAY:

Ghost of VAUGHAN:

All:

Ghost of HASTINGS:

Ghosts of the young Princes:

Ghost of DAME ANNE:

Ghost of BUCKINGHAM:

KING RICHARD III:
Give me another horse: heal my wounds.
Have mercy, Jesus!--Gentle! I only dreamed.
O let go of conscience, how you afflict me!
The lights glow blue. It is now dead midnight.
Cold, frightening drops stand on my trembling flesh.
What am I afraid of? myself? there is no one else by:
Richard loves Richard; that is to say, I am me.
Is there a murderer here? No. Yes I am :
So fly. What, about myself? Excellent reason why:
Lest I take revenge. What, myself on myself?
A lack. I love myself. For this reason? for all good
What did I do to myself?
Oh no! alas, I rather hate myself
For heinous acts committed by myself!
I am a villain: yet I lie. I'm not.
Fool, speak well of yourself; foolish, do not flatter.
My conscience has a thousand languages,
And each language brings several stories,
And every tale condemns me as a villain.
Perjury, perjury, to the highest degree
Murder, contained murder, to the most extreme degree;
All sins, all used in every degree,
Crowd at the bar, everyone shouting: Guilty! guilty!
I will despair. No creature loves me;
And if I die, no one will pity me:
No, why should they, since it's me
Do I not find any pity for myself?
I thought the souls of all those I had murdered
I came to my tent; and everyone threatened
Tomorrow's revenge on Richard's head.

RATCLIFF:
My lord!

KING RICHARD III:
“Zounds!” Who is here?

RATCLIFF:
Ratcliff, my lord; it's me. The first rooster in the village
Twice saluted in the morning;
Your friends are standing and strapping on their armor.

KING RICHARD III:
O Ratcliff, I had a fearful dream!
What do you think, will our friends prove that everything is true?

RATCLIFF:
Without a doubt, my lord.

KING RICHARD III:
O Ratcliff, I fear, I fear...

RATCLIFF:
No, my good lord, do not be afraid of the shadows.

KING RICHARD III:
By the apostle Paul, shadows tonight
Sowed even more terror in Richard's soul
Than the substance of ten thousand soldiers
Armed to the test and led by shallow Richmond.
The day is not yet near. Come, come with me;
Under our tents, I will play trickle-down,
To see if anyone wants to turn away from me.

LORDS:
Hello, Richmond!

RICHMOND:
Cry for mercy, vigilant lords and gentlemen,
That you have caught a lazy sloth here.

LORDS:
How did you sleep, my lord?

RICHMOND:
The sweetest sleep and the most promising dreams
Who ever entered a sleepy head,
I have had it since your departure, my lords.
I thought that their souls, whose bodies Richard had murdered,
I came to my tent and shouted in victory:
I promise you, my soul is very joyful
In memory of such a beautiful dream.
How far is it morning, lords?

LORDS:
Around four o'clock.

RICHMOND:
Well, then it's time to arm yourself and give direction.
More than I said, dear compatriots,
Leisure and the application of time
It is forbidden to linger there: but remember this,
God and our good cause fight alongside us;
The prayers of saints and wronged souls,
Like ramparts with a lofty rear, stand before our faces;
Richard except, those against whom we fight
We would rather win than follow him:
Why are they being followed? truly, gentlemen,
A bloody tyrant and a homicide;
One raised in the blood, and the other established in the blood;
He who has found the means to come with what he has,
And he massacred those who were the means of helping him;
Filthy and debased stone, made precious by aluminum foil
From the English chair, where he is falsely seated;
The one who has always been the enemy of God:
So if you fight against the enemy of God,
God will protect you in justice like his soldiers;
If you sweat to take down a tyrant,
You sleep in peace, the tyrant being killed;
If you fight the enemies of your country,
The fat of your country will pay the wages of your toils;
If you fight for the protection of your women,
Your women will welcome the conquerors into their homes;
If you free your children from the sword,
Your children's children stopped it at your age.
So, in the name of God and all these rights,
Advance your standards, draw your willing swords.
For me, the price of my daring attempt
It will be this cold corpse on the cold face of the earth;
But if I succeed, the gain of my attempt
The least among you will share his share.
Sound the drums and trumpets boldly and cheerfully;
God and Saint George! Richmond and victory!

KING RICHARD III:
What did Northumberland say affected Richmond?

RATCLIFF:
That he was never trained in the use of weapons.

KING RICHARD III:
He told the truth: and what then did Surrey say?

RATCLIFF:
He smiled and said, “It’s better for our purpose.” »

KING RICHARD III:
He was right ; and this is indeed the case.
It's ten o'clock. Give me a timeline.
Who saw the sun today?

RATCLIFF:
Not me, my lord.

KING RICHARD III:
So he disdains to shine; for the book
He should have braved the East an hour ago
It will be a dark day for someone. Ratcliff!

RATCLIFF:
My lord?

KING RICHARD III:
We won't see the sun today;
The sky frowns and turns towards our army.
I wish these pink tears came from the ground.
No shine today! Why, what does it do to me
More than in Richmond? for the same paradise
The one who frowns at me looks at him sadly.

NORFOLK:
Arms, arms, my lord; the enemy boasts on the ground.

KING RICHARD III:
Come, agitation, agitation; caparison my horse.
Call Lord Stanley, ask him to bring his power:
I will lead my soldiers into the plain,
And thus my battle will be ordered:
My front will be stretched to its full length,
Composed of equal parts horse and foot;
Our archers will be placed in the middle
John Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Earl of Surrey,
Must be at the head of this foot and this horse.
Thus they led, we will follow
In the main battle, whose power each side
Must be well winged with our main horse.
This, and Saint George to boot! What do you think, Norfolk?

NORFOLK:
Good leadership, warrior sovereign.
This found me on my tent this morning.

KING RICHARD III:

Messenger:
Monsignor, he refuses to come.

KING RICHARD III:
Take off his son George's head!

NORFOLK:
My lord, the enemy has passed the swamp
After the battle, let George Stanley die.

KING RICHARD III:
A thousand hearts are big in my bosom:
Advance our standards, imposed on our enemies
Our ancient word of courage, beautiful Saint George,
Inspire us with the spleen of fire dragons!
On them! victory is on our rudders.

CATESBY:
Save, my lord of Norfolk, save, save!
The king does more wonders than a man,
Dare to do the opposite in the face of any danger:
His horse is killed, and he fights on foot,
Searching for Richmond in Death Gorge.
Save yourself, fair lord, or else the day is lost!

KING RICHARD III:
Horse! horse! my kingdom for a horse!

CATESBY:
Withdraw, my lord; I'll help you ride a horse.

KING RICHARD III:
Slave, I put my life on a plaster,
And I will bear the risk of death:
I think there are six Richmonds on the field;
I killed five today in his place.
Horse! horse! my kingdom for a horse!

RICHMOND:
Praise be to God and your arms, victorious friends,
The day is ours, the damn dog is dead.

DERBY:
Brave Richmond, you have acquitted yourself well.
Here, here, is this long-usurped royalty
Dead temples of this damn wretch
Have I torn off, to adorn your forehead:
Wear it, enjoy it and enjoy it.

RICHMOND:
Great God of heaven, say Amen to everyone!
But tell me, is young George Stanley alive?

DERBY:
He is, my lord, safe in the city of Leicester;
Where, if it pleases you, we can now withdraw.

RICHMOND:
Which men of note are killed on each side?

DERBY:
John Duke of Norfolk, Walter Lord Ferrers,
Sir Robert Brakenbury and Sir William Brandon.

RICHMOND:
Between their bodies as befits their births:
Proclaim forgiveness to fleeing soldiers
This will come back to us in submission:
And then, as we took the sacrament,
We will unite the white rose and the red:
Smile heaven at this beautiful conjunction,
They have long disapproved of their enmity!
What traitor hears me and says no amen?
England has long been mad and scarred herself;
A brother has shed his brother's blood blindly,
The father recklessly slaughtered his own son,
The son, forced, was massacred for the father:
All this divided York and Lancaster,
Divided in their terrible division,
Oh, now that Richmond and Elizabeth,
The true successors of each royal house,
By the righteous ordinance of God, unite!
And may their heirs, God, if you wish.
Enrich the time to come with gentle-faced peace,
With lots of smiles and fair and prosperous days!
Reduce the edge of traitors, gracious Lord,
This would further reduce these bloody days,
And make poor England cry in floods of blood!
Let them not live to taste the increase of this earth
It would be, through treason, to harm the peace of this beautiful country!
Now the civilian injuries are stopped, peace returns:
So that she can live here for a long time, God says amen!

KING RICHARD II:
Old John of Gaunt, revered Lancaster,
Have you, according to your oath and your covenant,
I have brought here Henry Hereford, your bold son,
Here to compensate for the loud and late call,
What our leisure time would not allow us to hear,
Against the Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Mowbray?

JEAN DE GANT:
Yes my Lord.

KING RICHARD II:
Tell me, moreover, have you probed it,
If he appeals to the Duke on an old wickedness;
Or with dignity, as a good subject should do,
On some known motive for treason?

JEAN DE GANT:
As far as I have been able to examine this argument,
On an apparent danger seen in him
Intended for Your Highness, without inveterate malice.

KING RICHARD II:
Then call them into our presence; face to face,
And frowning we ourselves will hear
The accuser and the accused speak freely:
They are high-bellied and full of anger,
Angry, dull like the sea, pressed like fire.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Many years of happy days have come
My gracious sovereign, my most loving overlord!

THOMAS MOWBRAY:
Every day further improves the happiness of others;
Until the heavens, envying the happiness of the earth,
Add an immortal title to your crown!

KING RICHARD II:
We thank you both: yet one but flatters us,
This is also evident by the reason why you come;
Namely to appeal for high treason.
Cousin of Hereford, what do you oppose
Against the Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Mowbray?

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
First, may heaven be the record of my speech!
In the dedication of a subject's love,
Ensuring the precious safety of my prince,
And free from other ill-begotten hatreds,
Come, I call upon this princely presence.
Now, Thomas Mowbray, do I turn to you,
And notice my greeting carefully; for what I'm talking about
My body will do good on this earth,
Or my divine soul will answer it in heaven.
You are a traitor and a disbeliever,
Too beautiful to be and too bad to live,
Since the more beautiful and crystalline the sky is,
The uglier the clouds flying there seem.
Again, to make the rating even worse,
With the name of a vile traitor, I stuff your throat;
And I wish, so please my sovereign, before I move,
What my tongue says, my right sword can prove.

THOMAS MOWBRAY:
Let my cold words not accuse my zeal:
This is not the test of a women's war,
The bitter clamor of two eager tongues,
Can arbitrate this cause between the two of us;
The blood is hot and it must be cooled for this:
Yet may I not boast of such tamed patience
As for keeping quiet and saying nothing at all:
First, Your Highness's righteous reverence slows me down
To give reins and spurs to my freedom of expression;
Who else would post until he got back
These terms of betrayal were repeated down his throat.
Setting aside the royalty of his high blood,
And he is not related to my liege,
I challenge him and spit on him;
Call him a slanderous coward and a villain:
To maintain it, I would give it chances,
And I'll meet him, if I was tied up to run on foot
Even to the frozen ridges of the Alps,
Or any other habitable land,
Wherever an Englishman dared to set foot.
In the meantime, let this defend my loyalty,
Despite all my hopes, he lies very falsely.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Coward pale and trembling, there I throw my pledge,
Denying here the king's kinship,
And set aside the royalty of my high blood,
It's fear, not respect, that forces you to exclude him.
If guilty fear left you with so much strength
As for taking the pawn of my honor, then stoop:
By this and by all other rites of chivalry,
Will I do good against you, arm to arm,
What I said, or you can imagine worse.

THOMAS MOWBRAY:
I take it; and by this sword I swear
Who gently placed my knighthood on my shoulder,
I will answer you to a certain extent,
Or chivalrous conception of a chivalrous trial:
And when I go up, let me not light up alive,
If I am a traitor or if I fight unfairly!

KING RICHARD II:
What does our cousin blame Mowbray for?
It must be great to be able to inherit us
So much evil thought in him.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Listen, what I say, my life will prove true;
That Mowbray received eight thousand nobles
In the name of loans for Your Highness's soldiers,
The one he detained for obscene jobs,
Like a false traitor and an insulting villain.
Besides, I say it and I will prove it in battle,
Or here or elsewhere to the farthest edge
This has never been examined by the English eye,
That all the betrayals of these eighteen years
Plotted and contrived in this country
Collect their first head and spring from the fake Mowbray.
Moreover I say and I will maintain further
On his bad life to make it all good,
That he plotted the death of the Duke of Gloucester,
Suggest to his adversaries who soon believe,
And therefore, like a cowardly traitor,
He drained his innocent soul through streams of blood:
What blood, like that of Abel's sacrifice, weeps,
Even from the silent caverns of the earth,
Mine for justice and severe punishment;
And, by the glorious valor of my descendants,
This arm will do it, or this life will be gone.

KING RICHARD II:
How high his resolve rises!
Thomas of Norfolk, what do you say to that?

THOMAS MOWBRAY:
O, let my sovereign turn away his face
And strain his ears for a moment so that he is deaf,
Until I told this slander on his blood,
How God and good men hate such a vile liar.

KING RICHARD II:
Mowbray, our eyes and ears are impartial:
Was he my brother, or even the heir to my kingdom,
As he is only my father's brother's son,
Now, through the fear of my scepter, I make a vow,
Such closeness to our sacred blood
Nothing should privilege it, nor partialize it
The unwavering firmness of my right soul:
He is our subject, Mowbray; you too :
I allow you freedom of speech and fearlessness.

THOMAS MOWBRAY:
So, Bolingbroke, as low as your heart,
Through the false passage of your throat, you lie.
Three parts of this receipt that I had for Calais
I duly paid it to His Highness's soldiers;
The other part is reserved for me by consent,
For this my sovereign overlord was my debt
On the rest of a dear account,
Since the last time I went to France to look for its queen:
Now swallow this lie. For Gloucester's death,
I didn't kill him; but to my great shame
I have neglected my duty in this matter.
For you, my noble Lord of Lancaster,
The honorable father of my enemy
I once ambushed your life,
An intrusion that vexes my afflicted soul
But before I receive the sacrament for the last time
I confessed it and I exactly begged
Your Grace's forgiveness, and I hope I have had it.
It's my fault: for the rest, I appealed,
It comes from a wicked man's grudge,
A recreating and most degenerate traitor
What I will boldly defend in myself;
And I throw my gauge interchangeably
On the foot of this insolent traitor,
To prove that I'm a faithful gentleman
Even in the best blood contained in her breast.
In haste, I pray with all my heart
Your Highness to award our trial day.

KING RICHARD II:
Gentlemen inflamed with anger, be governed by me;
Let's purge this anger without letting blood flow:
This is what we prescribe, but without a doctor;
Deep malice makes an incision too deep;
Forget to forgive; conclude and be agreed;
Our doctors say this is not a month to bleed.
Good uncle, may it end where it began;
We will calm the Duke of Norfolk, you your son.

JEAN DE GANT:
Being a peacemaker will become my age:
Throw away, my son, the gauge of the Duke of Norfolk.

KING RICHARD II:
And Norfolk, throw his.

JEAN DE GANT:
When, Harry, when?
Obedience Bids I shouldn't bid anymore.

KING RICHARD II:
Norfolk, throw it away, we bid; there is no start.

THOMAS MOWBRAY:
I throw myself, formidable sovereign, at your feet.
You will command my life, but not my shame:
The one I owe to my duty; but my beautiful name,
Despite the death that lives on my grave,
You will not resort to dark dishonor.
I am here disgraced, indicted and disconcerted,
Pierced to the soul by the venomous spear of slander,
The one that no balm can heal except his heart and his blood
Who breathed this poison.

KING RICHARD II:
We must resist rage:
Give me his gauge: lions tame leopards.

THOMAS MOWBRAY:
Yes, but don't change your places: only take my shame.
And I resign my pledge. My dear dear lord,
The purest treasure mortal times offer
It's an unblemished reputation: it's far away,
Men are nothing but golden clay or painted clay.
A jewel in a chest crossed ten times
He is a bold spirit in a faithful heart.
My honor is my life; the two grow into one:
Take honor from me, and my life is over:
So, dear my liege, let me try;
In this I live and for this I will die.

KING RICHARD II:
Cousin, throw up your gauge; do you start.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
O, God defend my soul from such deep sin!
Should I appear discouraged to my father?
Or with pale fear of the beggar, destroy my waist
Before this extraordinary bastard? Before my tongue
Will hurt my honor with such a slight wrong,
Or it seems so vulgar that my teeth will tear
The servile motive of renouncing fear,
And spit it out bleeding in its great disgrace,
Where shame hides, even before Mowbray's face.

KING RICHARD II:
We are not born to pursue, but to command;
And since we can't make you friends,
Be ready, for your lives will respond,
In Coventry, on Saint Lambert's Day:
There your swords and your spears will arbitrate
The growing difference of your installed hatred:
Since we cannot atone for you, we will see
Justice designs the chivalry of the victor.
Lord Marshal, command our officers at arms
Be prepared to direct those home alarms.

JEAN DE GANT:
Alas, the part I had in Woodstock's blood
Requests me more than your cries,
Get agitated against the butchers of your life!
But since the correction is in these hands
What made the mistake that cannot be corrected,
Let us leave our quarrel to the will of heaven;
Who, when they see the ripe hours on earth,
A burning vengeance will fall on the heads of the offenders.

DUCHESS:
Does he not find in you a sharper brotherhood?
Has the love in your old blood no living fire?
Edward's seven sons, one of whom is yourself,
Were like seven vials of his sacred blood,
Or seven beautiful branches springing from a single root:
Some of these seven are dried by nature,
Some of these branches cut by the Fates;
But Thomas, my dear lord, my life, my Gloucester,
A vial full of Edward's sacred blood,
A flourishing branch from its most royal root,
Is cracked, and all the precious liquor spilled,
Is hacked, and its summer leaves are all withered,
By the hand of envy and the bloody ax of murder.
Ah, Gaunt, his blood was yours! this bed, this belly,
This metal, this self-modeling, which shaped you
I made him a man; and even though you live and breathe,
Yet you are killed in him: you consent
To a large extent when your father died,
In that you see your unfortunate brother die,
Who was the model of your father's life.
Call it not patience, Gaunt; it is despair:
By allowing your brother to be massacred,
You show the bare path of your life,
Teaching Severe Murder How to Slaughter You:
What among evil men we call patience
It is a pale and cold cowardice in noble breasts.
What should I say ? to save your own life,
The best way is to avenge the death of my Gloucester.

JEAN DE GANT:
The quarrel belongs to God; for God's substitute,
His deputy anointed in his eyes,
Caused his death: if wrongly,
May heaven take revenge; because I will never be able to lift
An angry arm against his minister.

DUCHESS:
Where then, alas, can I complain?

JEAN DE GANT:
To God, the champion and defense of the widow.

DUCHESS:
Well, then, I will. Farewell, old Gaunt.
You go to Coventry, there to see
Our cousin Hereford and the deceased Mowbray are fighting:
Oh, lay my husband's wrongs on Hereford's spear,
So he can get into the butcher Mowbray's chest!
Or, if misfortune misses the first career,
May Mowbray's sins be so heavy in his bosom,
They could break the back of his foaming steed,
And throws the rider headlong into the lists,
A caitiff recreating my Hereford cousin!
Farewell, old Gaunt: your brother's wife sometimes
Along with his companion, grief must end his life.

JEAN DE GANT:
My sister, farewell; I have to go to Coventry:
You might as well stay with you as come with me!

DUCHESS:
One more word: sorrow leaps where it falls,
Not with emptiness, but with weight:
I take my leave before I have started,
Because grief doesn't end when it seems over.
Recommend me to your brother, Edmund York.
That's all: no, but don't go like that;
Although that's all, don't leave so quickly;
I will remember it more. Tell him...ah, what?...
Pay me a hasty visit at Plashy's.
Alas, and what will good old York see there?
But empty dwellings and unfurnished walls,
Deserted offices, unexplored stones?
And what do you hear as a welcome if not my groans?
Congratulate me then; let him not come there,
To search for the sorrow that dwells everywhere.
Sorry, sorry, will I go away and die:
Your last leave takes my eye to tears.

Lord Marshal:
Milord Aumerle, is Harry Hereford armed?

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
Yes, in every way; and aspires to enter it.

Lord Marshal:
The Duke of Norfolk, lively and bold,
All that remains is the call of the caller's trumpet.

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
Why then the champions are prepared and stay
For nothing other than the approach of His Majesty.

KING RICHARD II:
Marshal, request from that champion over there
The cause of his arrival here in arms:
Ask him his name and proceed in an orderly manner
To swear him to the justice of his cause.

Lord Marshal:
In the name of God and the king, say who you are
And why do you come thus chivalrous, clad in weapons,
Against what man you come, and what is your quarrel:
Speak sincerely of your chivalry and your oath;
So defend the sky and your worth!

THOMAS MOWBRAY:
My name is Thomas Mowbray, Duke of Norfolk;
Who came here bound by my oath?
God forbid, a knight should rape! -
Both to defend my loyalty and my truth
To God, my king and my successor,
Against the Duke of Hereford I like it
And, by the grace of God and this mine arm,
To prove to him, by defending myself,
A traitor to my God, my king and me:
And since I'm really fighting, defend me, heavens!

KING RICHARD II:
Marshal, ask this knight-at-arms,
Who he is and why he comes here
Thus plated in war attire,
And formally, according to our law,
Depose him to the righteousness of his cause.

Lord Marshal:
What is your name ? and why do you come here,
Before King Richard in his royal lists?
Who are you coming against? and what is your quarrel?
Speak like a true knight, so defend yourself, heavens!

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Harry of Hereford, Lancaster and Derby
Am I; who are ready here to take up arms,
To prove, by the grace of God and the worth of my body,
In lists, on Thomas Mowbray, Duke of Norfolk,
That he is a traitor, filthy and dangerous,
To the God of heaven, to King Richard and to me;
And since I'm really fighting, defend me, heavens!

Lord Marshal:
Under penalty of death, no one will be so bold
Or bold to touch the lists,
Except the marshal and the other officers
Appointed to lead these righteous designs.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Lord Marshal, allow me to kiss the hand of my sovereign,
And bow the knee before his majesty:
For Mowbray and I are like two men
This vow is a long and painful pilgrimage;
So let's take a ceremonial leave
And affectionate farewell to our many friends.

Lord Marshal:
The caller, in all duty, salutes Your Highness,
And wants to kiss your hand and take his leave.

KING RICHARD II:
We will go down and take him in our arms.
Cousin of Hereford, how just is your cause,
So be your fortune in this royal battle!
Farewell, my blood; and if today you pour,
We can lament, but we cannot avenge our dead.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
O let no noble eye desecrate a tear
For me, if I am gored by Mowbray's spear:
As confident as the flight of the falcon
Against a bird, I fight with Mowbray.
My dear lord, I take leave of you;
From you, my noble cousin, Lord Aumerle;
Not sick, even if I deal with death,
But vigorous, young and breathing happily.
Lo, as in English festivals, then I regret
The last one, the most delicate, to make the ending the sweetest:
O you, the earthly author of my blood,
Whose youthful spirit regenerates in me,
With double vigor he lifts me
To achieve victory above my head,
Add proof to my armor with your prayers;
And with your blessings strengthen the tip of my spear,
So that he may enter Mowbray's wax cloak,
And renew the name of John a Gaunt,
Even in his son's vigorous behavior.

JEAN DE GANT:
God, in your good cause, make you prosperous!
Be lightning fast in execution;
And that your blows, doubly redoubled,
Falls like incredible thunder on the helmet
From your pernicious enemy:
Awaken your youthful blood, be valiant and live.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
My innocence and Saint George to prosper!

THOMAS MOWBRAY:
However God or fortune chose me,
There lives or dies, faithful to the throne of King Richard,
A loyal, fair and honest gentleman:
Never captive with a freer heart
Cast off his chains of bondage and embrace yourself
His golden and uncontrolled emancipation,
More than my dancing soul celebrates
This battle party with my opponent.
Most powerful overlord, and my fellow peers,
Take the wish for happy years out of my mouth:
As sweet and as joyful as a joke
I will fight: the truth has a quiet breast.

KING RICHARD II:
Farewell, my lord: I safely consider
Virtue with valor lying in your eyes.
Order the trial, Commissioner, and begin.

Lord Marshal:
Harry of Hereford, Lancaster and Derby,
Receive your spear; and God defends the right!

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Strong as a tower of hope, I cry amen.

Lord Marshal:
Take this spear to Thomas, Duke of Norfolk.

First Herald:
Harry of Hereford, Lancaster and Derby,
Stands here for God, his sovereign and himself,
Under penalty of being found false and recreating,
To prove that the Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Mowbray,
A traitor to his God, to his king and to him;
And challenges him to fight.

Second Herald:
Here stands Thomas Mowbray, Duke of Norfolk,
Under penalty of being found false and recreating,
Both to defend and to approve
Henry of Hereford, Lancaster and Derby,
To God, his sovereign and to him disloyal;
With courage and with free desire
Waiting for the signal to begin.

Lord Marshal:
Sound, trumpets; and put yourselves forward, fighters.
Stay, the king has overthrown his guardian.

KING RICHARD II:
Let them rest by their helmets and their spears,
And both return to their chair:
Depart with us: and let the trumpets sound
While we render to these dukes what we decree.
Get closer,
And list what we did with our council.
So that the land of our kingdom is not defiled
With this dear blood that he nourished;
And because our eyes hate the disastrous appearance
Civilian wounds plowed with neighbors' swords;
And because we believe that eagle-winged pride
Of ambitious and ambitious thoughts,
With a desire that hates rivals, I attack you
To awaken our peace, which in the cradle of our country
Inhale the sweet infant breath of sweet sleep;
Who woke up so to loud and out of tune drums,
With the terrible braying of trumpets,
And the grinding shock of angry iron arms,
From our quiet confines could we frighten a just peace
And make us wade even in the blood of our brothers,
This is why we ban you from our territories:
You, cousin Hereford, on pain of death,
Until twice five summers have enriched our fields
I will not regret our beautiful estates,
But follow the strange paths of banishment.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Your will will be done: this must be my consolation,
The sun that warms you here will shine on me;
And those that its golden rays have lent you here
Must point the finger at me and gild my banishment.

KING RICHARD II:
Norfolk, for you remains a heavier fate,
What I say, reluctantly:
Slow and sneaky hours won't determine
The dateless limit of your dear exile;
The desperate word “never come back”
I breathe against you, under penalty of living.

THOMAS MOWBRAY:
A heavy sentence, my very sovereign overlord,
And all this was unexpected from the mouth of Your Highness:
A more expensive merit, a less profound mutilation
As for being thrown into the common air,
Have I deserved in the hands of Your Highness.
The language I learned for forty years,
My native English I must now give up:
And now my tongue is no longer useful to me
Than a viol without strings or a harp,
Or like a cunning instrument locked up,
Or, being opened, put into his hands
Who knows no key to tune harmony:
In my mouth you locked my tongue,
Doubly harrowed with my teeth and my lips;
And sterile, insensitive, boring ignorance
It's my jailer who takes care of me.
I'm too old to worship a nurse,
Too far in years to be a student now:
What then is your sentence but a voiceless death,
What prevents my tongue from breathing its native breath?

KING RICHARD II:
It disgusts you not to be compassionate:
After our sentence, the complaint comes too late.

THOMAS MOWBRAY:
So thus I turn away from the light of my country,
Inhabiting the solemn nuances of an endless night.

KING RICHARD II:
Come back and take the oath with you.
Place your banished hands on our royal sword;
Swear by your duty to God...
We share our role with you.
To respect the oath we take:
You never will, so help yourself, the truth and God!
Embrace the love of the other in banishment;
Never look each other in the face either;
Neither ever write, regret, nor reconcile
This sinister storm of your native hatred;
Nor ever for a recommended purpose
To plot, invent or plot any evil
“Against us, our state, our subjects or our land.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
I swear.

THOMAS MOWBRAY:
And me, to keep it all.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Norfolk, regarding the mining enemy: -
At that time, if the king had allowed us,
One of our souls had wandered through the air.
Banished this frail sepulcher of our flesh,
As now our flesh is banished from this country:
Confess your betrayals before fleeing the kingdom;
Since you have to go far, don't bear
The obstructing burden of a guilty soul.

THOMAS MOWBRAY:
No, Bolingbroke: if ever I were a traitor,
May my name be erased from the book of life,
And I was banished from heaven as well as from here!
But what you are, God, you and I know;
And all too soon, I fear, the king will regret it.
Farewell, my lord. Now I can no longer go astray;
Go back to England, the world is my way.

KING RICHARD II:
Uncle, even in the glasses of your eyes
I see your afflicted heart: your sad appearance
Of the number of his years of banishment
I tore off four.
Six frozen winters passed,
Come back with welcome home after banishment.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
How much time fits in a little word!
Four winters late and four springs free
Let us end in a word: such is the breath of kings.

JEAN DE GANT:
I thank my liege, that as far as I am concerned
It shortens my son's four years of exile:
But I will get little benefit from it;
Because, before the six years he must spend
Can change their moons and advance their times
My lamp dried up in oil and my light lost in time
Must fade with age and endless night;
My cone thumb will be burned and finished,
And blindfolded death won't let me see my son.

KING RICHARD II:
Well, uncle, you have many years to live.

JEAN DE GANT:
But not a minute, king, that you can give:
You can shorten my days with sullen sorrow,
And take away nights from me, but do not lend a tomorrow;
You can stop time from crossing me with age,
But stops no wrinkle in his pilgrimage;
Your word is current with him for my death,
But dead, your kingdom cannot buy my breath.

KING RICHARD II:
Your son is banished on good advice,
To which your tongue gave a party verdict:
Why do you seem to complain about our justice?

JEAN DE GANT:
Things sweet in taste turn out to be sour in digestion.
You pressed me as judge; but I would have preferred
You would have asked me to talk like a father.
Oh, if it was a stranger, not my child,
To soften his fault, I should have been gentler:
I was trying to avoid partial slander,
And in that sentence, my own life is destroyed.
Alas, I looked when some of you said:
I was too strict to enforce mine;
But you gave leave to my reluctant tongue
Against my will to do this harm to myself.

KING RICHARD II:
Cousin, farewell; and, uncle, tell him:
We'll ban him for six years and he'll go away.

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
Cousin, farewell: what presence must not know,
From where you stand, let the paper appear.

Lord Marshal:
Monsignor, I will not leave you; because I will go up,
As far as the earth allows me, at your side.

JEAN DE GANT:
O, for what purpose do you accumulate your words,
That you don't respond to your friends?

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
I have too little to take leave of you,
When the language office should be lavish
Breathe the abundant pain of the heart.

JEAN DE GANT:
Your sorrow is only your absence for a time.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Joy absent, sorrow is present for that moment.

JEAN DE GANT:
What are six winters? they quickly left.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
To men in joy; but the sorrow lasts an hour and ten.

JEAN DE GANT:
Call it a trip you take for fun.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
My heart will sigh when I call it that,
Which finds it a forced pilgrimage.

JEAN DE GANT:
The sullen passage of your tired steps
Estimate like the foil you have to put in
The precious jewel of your return home.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
No, rather, every tedious step I take
I will remember myself, what a worldly affair
I'm moving away from the jewelry I love.
Don't I have to do a long apprenticeship
At foreign passages, and at the end,
Having my freedom, I boast of nothing else
But that I was a companion of mourning?

JEAN DE GANT:
All the places visited by the eye of heaven
Are for the wise ports and happy refuges.
Teach your necessity to reason thus;
There is no virtue like necessity.
Don't think that the king has banished you,
But you, the king. Woe to the heaviest seated,
Where he perceives it, it is only weakly supported.
Go, say I sent you to buy honor
And it was not the king who exiled you; or suppose
A devouring plague hangs in our air
And you fly to a cooler climate:
Look, what is dear to your soul, imagine it
To lie, that's where you're going, not where you're coming from:
Suppose songbirds are musicians,
The grass on which you walk the presence is strewn,
The beautiful flowers ladies, and your footsteps are no more
Than a delicious measure or a dance;
For knotty sorrow has less power to bite
The man who makes fun of it and brings it to light.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
O, who can hold a fire in his hand
Thinking of the icy Caucasus?
Or nauseate the hungry side of the appetite
By the simple imagination of a feast?
Or wallow naked in the December snow
Thinking about the fantastic heat of summer?
Oh no! the apprehension of good
Gives the feeling from greatest to worst:
The tooth of fallen sorrow never scratches again
Only when he bites, but does not sting the wound.

JEAN DE GANT:
Come, come, my son, I'll take you on your way:
If I had your youth and your cause, I wouldn't stay.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
So, land of England, farewell; sweet earth, farewell;
My mother and my nanny still carry me!
Wherever I wander, I can boast,
Although banished, he is nevertheless a true born Englishman.

KING RICHARD II:
We have observed. Cousin Aumerle,
How far have you taken Hereford on its path?

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
I raised Hereford, if you call it that,
But until the next highway, and there I left it.

KING RICHARD II:
And say, what store of parting tears have been shed?

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
Well, nothing for me; except the northeast wind,
Which then blew bitterly in our faces,
I woke up the sleeping cold, and so by chance
Honored our hollow separation with a tear.

KING RICHARD II:
What did our cousin say when you separated from him?

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
'Farewell:'
And, because my heart disdained that my tongue
Should he desecrate the word, it taught me the trade
To counterfeit the oppression of such sorrow
These words seemed buried in the grave of my sorrow.
Get married, would the word "farewell" have prolonged the hours
And he added years to his short banishment,
There should have been a volume of farewells;
But since that wasn't the case, he had nothing of me.

KING RICHARD II:
He's our cousin, cousin; but it's a doubt,
When time calls him back from banishment,
Let our relative come and see his friends.
Us and Bushy, Bagot here and Green
Observed his courtship of common people;
How he seemed to sink into their hearts
With humble and familiar courtesy,
What respect he cast on the slaves,
Wooing poor artisans with the art of smiling
And patiently bearing his fortune,
As if to banish their affects with him.
He goes with his hat to an oyster girl;
A pair of carters asked God to speed it up
And had the homage of his supple knee,
With “Thank you, my countrymen, my loving friends; »
As our England was in return to his,
And he gives the next level of hope to our subjects.

GREEN:
Well, he's gone; and with him go these thoughts.
Now let's move on to the rebels who stand out in Ireland,
Timely measures must be taken, my lord,
Before new hobbies give them other means
For their benefit and for the loss of Your Highness.

KING RICHARD II:
We will personally participate in this war:
And, for our coffers, with too big a yard
And liberal largesse becomes somewhat light,
We are obliged to cultivate our royal kingdom;
The income which will provide us
For our current affairs: if this fails,
Our replacements at home will have blank charters;
Therefore, when they know which men are rich,
They will subscribe them for large sums of gold
And then send them to provide for our needs;
Because we will soon be heading towards Ireland.
Bushy, what news?

BUSHY:
Old John of Gaunt is seriously ill, my lord,
Suddenly caught; and he sent the mail in haste
To beg your Majesty to visit him.

KING RICHARD II:
Where is he ?

BUSHY:
At Ely House.

KING RICHARD II:
Now put it, God, in the doctor's mind
To immediately help him go to his grave!
The lining of its chests will make coats
To equip our soldiers for these Irish wars.
Come, gentlemen, let's all visit him:
Let's pray that we can hurry and be too late!

All:
Amen.

JEAN DE GANT:
Will the king come so I can breathe my last
In salutary advice to his unpredictable youth?

THE DUKE OF YORK:
Do not torment yourself or struggle with your breath;
For advice comes to his ear in vain.

JEAN DE GANT:
O, but they speak the tongues of the dying
Strengthen attention like deep harmony:
Where words are scarce, they are rarely spent in vain,
For they breathe the truth who breathe their words with pain.
He who no longer has to say anything is listened to more
Only those to whom youth and ease have taught to close their eyes;
The ends of men are more marked than their previous lives:
The setting sun and the music at the end,
Like the last taste of candy, the sweetest is the last,
Write in remembrance more than things long past:
Although Richard will not hear my life's advice,
The sad story of my death could still deaf ears to him.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
No; he is stopped by other flattering sounds,
As praises that the wise are fond of,
Lascivious meters, whose venom resonates
The open ear of youth always listens;
Report on fashions in proud Italy,
Whose ways are still our late nation of apes
Box according to basic imitation.
Where does the world throw a conceit?
So it's new, there's no respect for how vile it is...
Didn't that quickly come to his attention?
Then, too late, advice arrives to be heard,
Where the gaze of the mind will revolt.
Do not direct the one who chooses the path he chooses:
It is a breath that you lack, and this breath you will lose.

JEAN DE GANT:
I think I'm a newly inspired prophet
And while exhaling like this, predict it:
His violent riot fire cannot last,
For violent fires soon extinguish themselves;
Small showers last a long time, but sudden storms are short;
He tires early, which stimulates too quickly from time to time;
With greedy feeding, food chokes the feeder:
Light vanity, insatiable cormorant,
To consume means, soon to attack itself.
This royal throne of kings, this scepter island,
This land of majesty, this seat of Mars,
This other Eden, half-paradise,
This fortress built by Nature for itself
Against infection and the hand of war,
This happy race of men, this little world,
This precious stone set in the silver sea,
Who acts as a wall for him,
Or as a defensive ditch for a house,
Against the desire for less happy lands,
This blessed plot, this land, this kingdom, this England,
This nurse, this belly teeming with royal kings,
Feared by their race and famous by their birth,
Renowned for their exploits so far from home,
For Christian service and true chivalry,
Like the sepulcher of stubborn Jews,
From the ransom of the world, blessed Son of Mary,
This land of so dear souls, this dear land,
Dear for its reputation throughout the world,
Is now praised, I die pronouncing it,
As in a building or a skinning farm:
England, linked to the triumphant sea
Whose rocky shore repels the envious siege
From water Neptune, is now bound by shame,
With ink stains and rotten parchment ties:
This England, which was used to conquering others,
Made a shameful conquest of himself.
Ah, would the scandal disappear with my life,
How happy my death was then!

THE DUKE OF YORK:
The king has come: treat his youth gently;
For rabid hot young foals, rage even more.

QUEEN:
How is our noble uncle, Lancaster?

KING RICHARD II:
What comfort, man? How's it going with old Gaunt?

JEAN DE GANT:
Oh how this name suits my composition!
A gaunt old man indeed, and emaciated by his old age:
In me grief has maintained a tedious fast;
And who refrains from eating meat that is not lean?
For a long time I watched over sleeping England;
Looking breeds thinness, thinness is very thin:
The pleasure that some fathers feed on,
This is my strict fast; I mean, the appearance of my children;
And it was by fasting that you made me thin:
I am skinny for the grave, skinny as a grave,
Whose hollow stomach only inherits bones.

KING RICHARD II:
Can sick men play with their names so well?

JEAN DE GANT:
No, poverty makes sport laugh at itself:
Since you seek to kill my name in me,
I mock my name, great king, to flatter you.

KING RICHARD II:
Should the dying flatter those who are living?

JEAN DE GANT:
No, no, living men flatter those who are dying.

KING RICHARD II:
You, now dying, say that you flatter me.

JEAN DE GANT:
Oh no! you die, even if I am the sickest.

KING RICHARD II:
I am healthy, I breathe and I see you sick.

JEAN DE GANT:
Now he who created me knows that I see you sick;
I am sick of seeing in myself, and in you I see evil.
Your deathbed is nothing less than your land
This is why you lie with a sick reputation;
And you, too carefree patient that you are,
Entrust your anointed body to the remedy
Of these doctors who hurt you first:
A thousand flatterers sit in your crown,
Whose compass is no bigger than your head;
And yet, confined in such a small space,
Waste is not less than your land.
O, your grandfather had the eye of a prophet
I saw how his son's son must destroy his sons,
Out of your reach, he would have deposited your shame,
Deposing you before you are possessed,
What art now possessed of putting you down.
Why, cousin, were you regent of the world,
It was a shame to rent this land;
But so that your world only benefits from this earth,
Isn't it more than shameful to shame people like this?
You are now owner of England, not king:
Your rule of law is a slave to the law; And you--

KING RICHARD II:
A crazy, skinny fool,
Relying on the privilege of a league,
Dare with your cold warning
Make our cheeks pale, driving away the royal blood
With fury from his native residence.
Now, by the royal majesty of my seat,
Were you not the brother of the great Edward's son,
This language that runs so roundly in your head
Should take your head off your sassy shoulders.

JEAN DE GANT:
Oh, spare me not, son of my brother Edward,
For this I was his father Edward's son;
This blood already, like the pelican,
Did you bang and party drunk:
My brother Gloucester, pure and well-meaning soul,
Who is the best in heaven among happy souls!
Perhaps a precedent and a good witness
That you respect not to shed Edward's blood:
Join in the present illness I have;
And your wickedness be like a tortuous age,
Immediately harvest a flower that has faded for too long.
Live in your shame, but don't die in your shame!
These words will now be your executioners!
Lead me to my bed, then to my grave:
Love them to experience this love and honor.

KING RICHARD II:
And let them die of this age and sullenness;
For you have both, and both have become the grave.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
I beg your Majesty, impute his words
To the capricious illness and old age in him:
He loves you, in my life, and holds you dear
As Harry Duke of Hereford, was he here.

KING RICHARD II:
It is true, you speak the truth: as Hereford's love, so is his;
Like theirs, like mine; and everything be like that.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
My liege, old Gaunt recommends it to your Majesty.

KING RICHARD II:
What's he saying ?

NORTHUMBERLAND:
No nothing ; all is said
His tongue is now an instrument without strings;
Words, life and everything, old Lancaster spent them.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
So be York the next to go bankrupt!
Even if death is poor, it puts an end to mortal misfortune.

KING RICHARD II:
The ripest fruit falls first, and so does he;
His time is past, our pilgrimage must be.
So much for that. Now for our Irish Wars:
We must supplant these rough-headed kerns,
Who live like venom where there is no other venom
But only they have the privilege of living.
And for these big matters, ask for something,
Towards our help we grasp
The plate, the wheat, the income and the furniture,
Which our uncle Gaunt was in possession of.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
How long should I be patient? oh how long
Will tender duty make me suffer harm?
Neither the death of Gloucester, nor the banishment of Hereford
Neither Gaunt's reprimands, nor England's private wrongs,
Nor the prevention of poor Bolingbroke
Of his marriage, nor of my own shame,
Have already made my patient cheek sour,
Or fold a wrinkle on my sovereign's face.
I am the last of the noble Edward's sons,
Of which your father, Prince of Wales, was the first:
In times of war, never was a lion more ferocious,
In peace, never was a gentle lamb more gentle,
Than this young and princely gentleman.
You have his face, because he looked at him anyway,
Accomplished with the number of your hours;
But when he frowned, it was against the French
And not against his friends; his noble hand
He did what he spent and didn't spend that
That his father's triumphant hand had won;
His hands were not guilty of any kindred blood,
But bloody with the enemies of those close to him.
O Richard! York has gone too far in sorrow,
Or he would never make a comparison.

KING RICHARD II:
Why, uncle, what is it?

THE DUKE OF YORK:
O my lord,
Excuse me please ; otherwise, I'm happy
Not being forgiven, I'm happy with that.
I seek you to grasp and grasp in your hands
The royalties and rights of the banished Hereford?
Is not Gaunt dead, and is not Hereford alive?
Wasn't Gaunt right, and wasn't Harry right?
Didn't this one deserve to have an heir?
Isn't his heir a very deserving son?
Remove rights from Hereford and remove time
Its charters and customary rights;
Let tomorrow not follow today;
Don't be yourself; because how are you king
But by equitable sequence and succession?
Now, before God – God forbid that I speak the truth!
If you unjustly seize Hereford's rights,
Call the letters patent he has
By his attorneys general to prosecute
His livery, and denies the homage offered to him,
You put a thousand dangers on your head,
You lose a thousand willing hearts
And pricks my tender patience, at these thoughts
What honor and allegiance cannot think.

KING RICHARD II:
Think what you want, we take it in our hands
His plate, his goods, his money and his land.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
I will not be there for the moment: my liege, farewell:
What will result from this, no one can say;
But by bad course can be understood
That their events can never go well.

KING RICHARD II:
Go, Bushy, straight to the Earl of Wiltshire:
Offer to take us to Ely House
To see this case. Next tomorrow
We will do it for Ireland; and it's time, I say:
And we create, in the absence of ourselves,
Our Uncle York, Lord Governor of England;
Because he is just and has always loved us well.
Come, our queen: tomorrow we will have to separate;
Be cheerful, for our stay time is short

NORTHUMBERLAND:
Well, my lords, the Duke of Lancaster is dead.

LORD ROSS:
And live too; for the moment his son is duke.

LORD WILLOUGHBY:
Barely in title, not in revenue.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
Rich in both cases, if justice was right.

LORD ROSS:
My heart is big; but we must break with the silence,
Don't let liberal language get you down.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
No, say what you think; and never let him speak any more
Who still speaks your words to harm you!

LORD WILLOUGHBY:
Does he tend to talk to the Duke of Hereford?
If so, bring it out boldly, man;
My ear is quick to hear good things about him.

LORD ROSS:
I can't do anything good for him;
Unless you find it good to pity him,
Deprived and castrated of his heritage.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
Now, before God, it is a shame that such wrongs should be borne
In him, a royal prince, and a lot of moe
Of noble blood in this declining country.
The king is not himself, but he is basely ruled
By flatterers; and what they will inform,
Simply out of hatred, against each of us,
That the king will pursue severely
“Against us, our lives, our children and our heirs.

LORD ROSS:
He plundered the communes with heavy taxes,
And they completely lost their hearts: the nobles were fined
For old quarrels, and they have completely lost their hearts.

LORD WILLOUGHBY:
And every day new abuses are imagined,
Like white people, benevolence, and I don’t know what:
But what in the name of God has become of this?

NORTHUMBERLAND:
Wars have not wasted him, for he has not waged war,
But basely gave in to compromise
What his noble ancestors achieved with their fists:
He spent more on peace than they did on wars.

LORD ROSS:
The Earl of Wiltshire owns the kingdom as a farm.

LORD WILLOUGHBY:
The king is bankrupt, like a broken man.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
Reproach and dissolution weigh on him.

LORD ROSS:
He has no money for these Irish wars,
Despite its heavy taxes,
But by the flight of the banished duke.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
His noble relative: the most degenerate king!
But, lords, we hear this terrible storm singing,
Yet I see no shelter to avoid the storm;
We see the wind blowing on our sails,
And yet we do not strike, but safely perish.

LORD ROSS:
We see the very shipwreck that we must endure;
And the danger is now inevitable,
For having thus suffered from the causes of our shipwreck.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
This is not the case ; even through the hollow eyes of death
I spy on life by scrutinizing; but I don't dare say it
How near is the news of our comfort.

LORD WILLOUGHBY:
No, let's share your thoughts, as you do ours.

LORD ROSS:
Be confident to speak, Northumberland:
The three of us are just you; and, speaking thus,
Your words are only thoughts; so be bold.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
So thus: I have Port le Blanc, a bay
In Brittany, information received
This Harry Duke of Hereford, Rainold Lord Cobham,
The latter separated from the Duke of Exeter,
His brother, the late Archbishop of Canterbury,
Sir Thomas Erpingham, Sir John Ramston,
Sir John Norbery, Sir Robert Waterton and Francis Quoint,
All this well provided by the Duke of Brittany
With eight large sailing ships, three thousand men of war,
Arrive here in complete convenience
And I would like to touch our northern coast soon:
Maybe they had it before, but they stay
The king's first departure for Ireland.
If then we can shake off our servile yoke,
Take out the broken wing of our falling country,
Redeem the stained crown from the pawnbroker,
Wipe away the dust that hides the gilding of our scepter
And make the high majesty look like itself,
Go with me to be stationed at Ravenspurgh;
But if you faint, for fear of doing so,
Stay and be secret, and I myself will leave.

LORD ROSS:
On horseback, on horseback! incite doubt to those who fear.

LORD WILLOUGHBY:
Tend my horse, and I will be there first.

BUSHY:
Madam, Your Majesty is too sad:
You promised, when you separated from the king,
To put aside the heaviness that harms life
And have a cheerful disposition.

QUEEN:
To please the king, I did it; just for me
I can not do it; yet I don't know any cause
Why should I welcome such a guest as sorrow,
Save saying goodbye to such a sweet guest
Like my sweet Richard: once again, I think,
An unborn sorrow, ripe in the bosom of fortune,
Comes to me and my inner soul
Without trembling at all: something is bothering him,
More than separating me from my lord the king.

BUSHY:
Every substance of a sorrow has twenty shadows,
Which sounds like grief itself, but it’s not;
For the eye of sorrow, glazed with blinding tears,
Divides a whole thing into several objects;
Like perspectives that rightly looked
Shows nothing but confusion, eyes turned wrong
Distinguish the form: thus your sweet majesty,
Looking askance at the departure of your lord,
Finding forms of sorrow, more than itself, to moan;
Which, seen as it is, is only shadows
Of what he is not. So, queen thrice gracious,
Weep no more than the departure of your lord: we see no more;
Or if it is, it is with a false eye of sorrow,
Who mourns imaginary things for true things.

QUEEN:
This may be the case; but yet my inner soul
Convinces me that it is otherwise: whatever it may be,
I can only be sad; so heavy and sad
Like, even though I don't think any thoughts, I think,
Makes me faint and shrink without anything heavy.

BUSHY:
It is only vanity, my gracious lady.

QUEEN:
It is nothing less: vanity is always derivative
From an ancestor's grief; mine is not,
For nothing had caused my sorrow;
Or something that doesn't bother me:
It is in reversion that I own;
But what it is is not yet known; What
I cannot name; It's an unspeakable misfortune, I know.

GREEN:
God save your majesty! and welcome, gentlemen:
I hope the king is not yet shipped to Ireland.

QUEEN:
Why do you hope so? it is better to hope that it is;
For his plans require haste, his haste is a good hope:
So why are you hoping it doesn't ship?

GREEN:
So that he, our hope, has withdrawn his power,
And drives an enemy's hope to despair,
Who has firmly established a foothold in this country:
The banished Bolingbroke revokes himself,
And with arms raised we arrived safe and sound
At Ravenspurgh.

QUEEN:
Now, God in heaven forbid!

GREEN:
Ah! Madam, it's too true: and it's worse,
The Lord Northumberland, his son young Henry Percy,
The lords of Ross, Beaumond and Willoughby,
With all his powerful friends, they fled to him.

BUSHY:
Why didn't you proclaim Northumberland
And all the other rebellious faction traitors?

GREEN:
We have: whereupon the Earl of Worcester
Broke his staff, resigned his stewardship,
And all the servants fled with him
In Bolingbroke.

QUEEN:
So, Green, you are the midwife of my misfortune,
And Bolingbroke the sad heir of my pain:
Now my soul has given birth to its miracle,
And I, a panting newly-given mother,
Have misfortune with misfortune, sorrow with sorrow together.

BUSHY:
Do not despair, madam.

QUEEN:
Who will stop me?
I will despair and be at enmity
With a comforting hope: it is flattering,
A parasite, a guardian of death,
Who would gently dissolve the bonds of life,
What false hope persists in the extremity.

GREEN:
This is the Duke of York.

QUEEN:
With signs of war on his old neck:
Oh, her appearance is full of neat affairs!
Uncle, for God's sake, say comfortable words.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
If I do, I should disprove my thoughts:
Comfort is in heaven; and we are on earth,
Where nothing lives but crosses, worries and sorrow.
Your husband, he went to save far away,
While others come to destroy him at home:
Here I am left to support his land,
Who, weakened by age, cannot meet his needs:
Now comes the hour of illness caused by his excess;
Now he will try his friends who flattered him.

Servant:
My lord, your son left before my arrival.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
It was? Well then! go in all directions!
The nobles are on the run, the towns are cold,
And I fear he will revolt alongside Hereford.
Sirrah, take you to Plashy, to my sister Gloucester;
Tell him to send me a thousand pounds at once:
Wait, take my ring.

Servant:
My lord, I forgot to tell your lordship,
Today, in passing, I passed there;
But I will pain you to bring back the rest.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
What is it, rascal?

Servant:
An hour before my arrival, the duchess died.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
God for his mercy! what a tide of misfortunes
Come immediately to this sad country!
I don't know what to do: I wish it to God,
So my lie didn't make him do it,
The king had cut off my head along with that of my brother.
What, there's no mail sent to Ireland?
How are we going to find money for these wars?
Come on, my sister, cousin, I said, please forgive me.
Go, buddy, go home, give carts.
And take the armor that is there.
Gentlemen, are you going to gather men?
If I know how or in what manner to order these affairs
Thus thrown the mess into my hands,
Never believe me. Both are my parents:
One is my sovereign, to whom my oath
And duty offers defend; the other again
Is my kinsman, whom the king has wronged,
To whom conscience and those close to me want to straighten out.
Well, we have to do something. Come, cousin, I'm going
Get rid of yourself.
Gentlemen, go, gather your men,
And find me currently in Berkeley.
I should also go to Plashy;
But time does not allow it: everything is uneven,
And everything is left at six and seven o'clock.

BUSHY:
The wind is good for the news to reach Ireland,
But none comes back. For us to raise power
Proportionate to the enemy
All this is impossible.

GREEN:
Besides, our proximity to the king in love
Is close to the hatred of those who do not love the king.

BAGOT:
And it is the faltering common good: for their love
Lies in their purse, and whoever empties them
It fills their hearts with deadly hatred.

BUSHY:
In which the king is generally condemned.

BAGOT:
If the judgment rests on them, then so do we,
Because we have always been close to the king.

GREEN:
Well, I will take refuge directly at Bristol Castle:
The Earl of Wiltshire is already here.

BUSHY:
I will go there with you; for small office
The hateful commons will play for us,
Except like dogs tearing us all to pieces.
Do you want to come with us?

BAGOT:
No; I will go to Ireland to see his majesty.
Farewell: if the omens of the heart are not in vain,
The three of us are here and we will never see each other again.

BUSHY:
It was then that York attempted to repel Bolingbroke.

GREEN:
Alas, poor duke! the task he undertakes
Is counting the sands and drinking the oceans dry:
Where one side fights, thousands will flee.
Goodbye now, for once, for all and forever.

BUSHY:
Well, we might meet again.

BAGOT:
I fear myself, never.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
How far is it now to Berkeley, my lord?

NORTHUMBERLAND:
Believe me, noble lord,
I'm a stranger here in Gloucestershire:
These high wild hills and these rough and uneven paths
It lengthens our miles and makes them boring,
And yet your beautiful speech was like sugar,
Making the difficult path sweet and delicious.
But I remember in what a weary way
From Ravenspurgh to Cotswold will lie
To Ross and Willoughby, wanting your company,
Which, I protest, was very attractive
The arduousness and progress of my trip:
But theirs is softened by the hope of having
The current profit that I have;
And hope in joy is a little less in joy
That hope enjoyed: by this the weary lords
Their path will seem short, as mine did
In view of what I have, your noble company.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
My business is worth much less
Only your good words. But who comes here?

NORTHUMBERLAND:
This is my son, young Harry Percy,
Sent by my brother Worcester, wherever that is.
Harry, how is your uncle?

HENRY PERCY:
I thought, my lord, that I had learned of his state of health from you.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
Why isn't he with the queen?

HENRY PERCY:
No, my good God; he abandoned the court,
Broke his office stick and scattered
The king's house.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
What was his reason?
He wasn't as resolute the last time we spoke together.

HENRY PERCY:
Because Your Lordship has been proclaimed a traitor.
But he, my lord, has gone to Ravenspurgh,
To offer his services to the Duke of Hereford,
And sent me to Berkeley to find out
What power the Duke of York had raised there;
Then with instructions for repairing at Ravenspurgh.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
Have you forgotten the Duke of Hereford, my boy?

HENRY PERCY:
No, my good lord, because this cannot be forgotten
Which I never remembered: to my knowledge,
I've never watched it in my life.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
So get to know him now; it's the duke.

HENRY PERCY:
My gracious lord, I offer you my service,
As it is, being tender, raw and young:
Which ancient days will ripen and confirm
Towards a more approved service and desert.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
I thank you, sweet Percy; and be sure
I don't count myself in anything else so happy
As in a soul remembering my good friends;
And, as my fortune matures with your love,
This will always be the reward of your true love:
My heart makes this alliance, my hand thus seals it.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
How far is Berkeley? and what agitation
He keeps good old York there with his men of war?

HENRY PERCY:
There stands the castle, near this clump of trees,
Equipped with three hundred men, as I have heard it said;
And within are the lords of York, Berkeley, and Seymour;
No other of name and noble esteem.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
Here are the lords of Ross and Willoughby,
Bloody with impulse, fiery red with haste.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Welcome, my lords. I know your love continues
A banished traitor: all my treasure
It is still only an unfelt thank you, which is even more enriched
Will be the reward for your love and your work.

LORD ROSS:
Your presence makes us rich and very noble lord.

LORD WILLOUGHBY:
And far surpasses our work to achieve it.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Thank you always, treasurer of the poor;
And until my childish fortune reaches years,
Represents my bounty. But who comes here?

NORTHUMBERLAND:
This is my lord of Berkeley, as I suppose.

LORD BERKELEY:
Monsignor of Hereford, my message is addressed to you.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
My Lord, my answer is: in Lancaster;
And I came to look for this name in England;
And I have to find this title in your language,
Before responding to everything you say.

LORD BERKELEY:
Make no mistake, my lord; that's not my meaning
To shave a title of your honor:
To you, my lord, I come, which lord you want,
From the most gracious regent of this country,
The Duke of York, to find out what's bothering you
To take advantage of the time away
And frighten our native peace with self-born weapons.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
I will not need to transport my words through you;
Here is his grace in person. My noble uncle!

THE DUKE OF YORK:
Show me your humble heart, not your knee,
Whose duty is deceptive and false.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
My gracious uncle...

THE DUKE OF YORK:
Tut tut!
Grace me no grace, nor uncle-me no uncle:
I am not the uncle of a traitor; and this word “grace”.
In an unsightly mouth, it is only profane.
Why are these legs banned and forbidden?
Have you dared to touch a piece of dust from English soil?
But then no more “why?” » why did they dare to walk
So many kilometers on its peaceful breast,
Scaring its pale-faced villages with war
And the ostentation of despised weapons?
Are you coming because the anointed king is from here?
Well, foolish boy, the king is left behind,
And in my faithful bosom lies his power.
Was I but now the lord of such hot youth
As when brave Gaunt, your father and I
Saved the Black Prince, this young Mars of men,
Ranks of several thousand French people,
Oh, so how fast should my arm do it.
Now a prisoner of paralysis, punish yourself
And correct your mistake!

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
My gracious uncle, make me know my fault:
What condition is it in and where?

THE DUKE OF YORK:
Even in the worst conditions,
In gross rebellion and hated betrayal:
You are a banished man, and here you have come
Before your time expires,
By braving arms against your sovereign.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
As I was banished, I was banished Hereford;
