But when I come, I come for Lancaster.
And, noble uncle, I implore your mercy
Look at my wrongs with indifferent eyes:
You are my father, because I think in you
I see old Gaunt alive; O then, my father,
Do you allow me to be condemned
A wandering vagabond; my rights and royalties
Torn from my arms by force and given
For upstarts who are not thrifty? Why was I born?
If my cousin is king of England,
It must be admitted that I am Duke of Lancaster.
You have a son, Aumerle, my noble cousin;
If thou hadst died the first time, and thus been trodden under foot,
He should have found a father for his uncle Gaunt,
To awaken his wrongs and chase them back to the bay.
I am refused to continue my livery here,
And yet my letters patent give me leave:
My father's possessions are all seized and sold,
And all this and all this is misused.
What would you like me to do? I am a subject,
And I challenge the law: they refuse me lawyers;
And so, personally, I claim
To my inheritance of free descent.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
The noble duke has been too badly treated.

LORD ROSS:
Your grace is to do him good.

LORD WILLOUGHBY:
Vile men, through its endowments, become great.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
My Lords of England, let me say this to you:
I felt my cousin's wrongs
And I worked all I could to do him good;
But in this kind to come, in brave arms,
Be his own sculptor and trace his path,
To discover good and evil, this may not be the case;
And you who encourage him in this way
Let us cherish rebellion and be all rebels.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
The noble duke swore that his coming was
But for his own; and for this right
We all swore strongly to help him;
And may he never see the joy that breaks this oath!

THE DUKE OF YORK:
Well, I see the issue with these weapons:
I can't fix it, I must confess,
Because my power is weak and everyone is sick:
But if I could, through Him who gave me life,
I'll tie you all up and bring you down
To the sovereign mercy of the king;
But since I can't, just know
I remain neutral. Then good luck ;
Unless you like to enter the castle
And then, rest for the night.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
An offer, uncle, that we will accept:
But we must earn your grace to come with us
At Bristol Castle, said to be held
By Bushy, Bagot and their accomplices,
The Commonwealth caterpillars,
That I swore to weed and pull.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
It may be that I will go with you: but yet I will stop;
Because I am loath to break the laws of our country.
Neither friends nor enemies, for me, you are welcome:
Things that cannot be repaired are now inconceivable to me.

Captain:
Monsignor of Salisbury, we stayed ten days,
And barely kept our compatriots together,
And yet we have no news from the king;
So we are going to disperse: goodbye.

COUNTY OF SALISBURY:
Stay one more day, faithful Welshman:
The king places all his trust in you.

Captain:
It is believed that the king is dead; we will not stay.
The laurels of our country are all withered
And the meteors frighten the fixed stars of the sky;
The pale-faced moon appears bloodied on the earth
And the thin-looking prophets whisper fearful changes;
The rich men look sad and the thugs dance and jump,
He who is afraid of losing what he enjoys,
The other to enjoy through rage and war:
These signs announce the death or fall of kings.
Farewell: our compatriots have left and fled,
Might as well assure Richard that their king is dead.

COUNTY OF SALISBURY:
Ah, Richard, with the eyes of a heavy spirit
I see your glory like a shooting star
Fall from the firmament to the lower earth.
Your sun sets weeping in the humble west,
To witness the coming storms, misfortune and troubles:
Your friends have fled to serve your enemies,
And all fortune goes to your good.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Get these men out.
Bushy and Green, I won't offend your souls...
Since currently your souls must separate your bodies...
By pressing too hard on your pernicious lives,
For there was no charity; yet, to wash your blood
From my hands, here, in the eyes of men
I will reveal some of the causes of your death.
You deceived a prince, a royal king,
A happy gentleman in blood and features,
By you, unhappy and disfigured, clean:
You are in tune with your hours of sin
He divorced his queen and himself,
Broke the possession of a royal bed
And stained the beauty of a fair queen's cheeks
With tears drawn from his eyes by your horrible wrongs.
Myself, prince of fortune from my birth,
Close to the king by blood and close by love
Until you make him misinterpret me,
I bowed my neck under your wounds,
And sighed my English breath in the foreign clouds,
Eat the bitter bread of banishment;
While you were feeding off my signatories,
I destroyed my parks and cut down my forests,
From my own windows I tore off my housecoat,
I shaved off my footprint, leaving me no sign,
Save the opinions of men and my living blood,
To show the world that I'm a gentleman.
This and much more, much more than double all of this,
Sentences you to death. See them delivered
To execution and the hand of death.

BUSHY:
The death blow is more welcome for me
Than Bolingbroke in England. Lords, farewell.

GREEN:
My comfort is that heaven will take our souls
And torment injustice with the pains of hell.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
My Lord Northumberland, have them sent away.
Uncle, you say that the queen is at your house;
For the love of God, let her be honestly begged:
Tell him that I send him my kind congratulations;
Take particular care that my greetings are delivered.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
One of my gentlemen that I sent
With letters of your love for her in general.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Thank you, kind uncle. Come, lords, go.
To fight Glendower and his accomplices:
A time to work and after vacation.

KING RICHARD II:
Is Barkloughly Castle called that?

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
Yes my Lord. How your grace supports the air,
After your lateness on the breaking sea?

KING RICHARD II:
I have to like him: I cry with joy
To stand on my kingdom again.
Dear earth, I greet you with my hand,
Even if the rebels hurt you with the hooves of their horses:
As a long-separated mother with her child
Tenderly plays with her tears and smiles in meetings,
So, crying and smiling, I salute you, my land,
And do you a favor with my royal hands.
Do not feed the enemy of your sovereign, my sweet land,
Nor with your sweetness comfort his voracious sense;
But let your spiders, which suck your venom,
And heavy-stepping toads stand in their way,
Annoying treacherous feet
Who tramples you with usurping steps:
Give nettles to my enemies;
And when they pluck a flower from your bosom,
Keep it, please, with a hidden viper
Whose double tongue can with mortal touch
Cast death on the enemies of your sovereign.
Do not mock my foolish conspiracy, lords:
This land will have a feeling and these stones
Prove armed soldiers, before his native king
Must weaken under the weapons of filthy rebellion.

BISHOP OF CARLISLE:
Do not fear, my lord: this power which made you king
Has the power to keep you king despite everything.
The means that heaven gives must be adopted,
And not neglected; otherwise, if heaven wanted it,
And we won't, we refuse heaven's offer,
The means of relief and repair offered.

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
He means, my lord, that we are too careless;
While Bolingbroke, thanks to our security,
Becomes strong and great in substance and power.

KING RICHARD II:
Uncomfortable cousin! you do not know
That when the searching eye of heaven is hidden,
Behind the globe which illuminates the lower world,
Then thieves and thieves spread abroad unseen
In murders and outrages, here boldly;
But when under this earth ball
It fires on the proud tops of the eastern pines
And shines its light through all the guilty holes,
Then murders, betrayals and hated sins,
The cloak of night being torn from their backs,
Standing naked and naked, trembling on their own?
So when this thief, this traitor, Bolingbroke,
Who all this time has been enjoying the night
While we wandered to the antipodes,
Will see us rise on our throne, in the east,
His betrayals will blush in his face,
Unable to bear the sight of day,
But he trembles in fear before his sin.
Not all the water in the choppy, choppy sea
Can wash away the balm of an anointed king;
The breath of the men of the world cannot drop
The deputy elected by the Lord:
For every man Bolingbroke pressed
To raise shrewd steel against our golden crown,
God for his Richard has a heavenly reward
A glorious angel: then, if the angels fight,
Weak men must fall, for heaven always preserves the good.
Welcome, my lord, how far is your power?

COUNTY OF SALISBURY:
Neither near nor further, my gracious lord,
May this weak arm: discomfort guides my tongue
And orders me to speak only of despair.
One day too late, I fear, noble lord,
Has darkened all your happy days on earth:
O, remember yesterday, return from auction time,
And you will have twelve thousand fighters!
Today, today, unfortunate day, too late,
O'ermet your joys, your friends, your fortune and your state:
For all the Welsh, hearing that you were dead.
Went to Bolingbroke, dispersed and fled.

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
Comfort, my lord; why does your Grace look so pale?

KING RICHARD II:
But now the blood of twenty thousand men
They triumphed before me, and fled;
And, until so much blood returns,
Don't I have a reason to look pale and dead?
All the souls that will be safe fly to my side,
Because time has tarnished my pride.

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
Comfort, my lord; remember who you are.

KING RICHARD II:
I had forgotten myself; I'm not a king?
Wake up, cowardly majesty! you sleep.
Is not the king's name twenty thousand names?
Arm, arm, my name! a puny subject strikes
To your great glory. Don't look at the ground,
You, favorites of a king: are we not high?
High be our thoughts: I know my uncle York
Has enough power to serve our tower. But who comes here?

SIR STEPHEN SCROOP:
More health and happiness for my lord
That my well-regulated tongue cannot deliver him!

KING RICHARD II:
My ear is open and my heart prepared;
The worst is the material loss you can cause.
Say, is my kingdom lost? why, that was my concern
And what loss does it represent to get rid of care?
Is Bolingbroke striving to be as big as us?
It will not be bigger; if he serves God,
We will also serve Him and be like Him thus:
Revolt our subjects? that we cannot repair;
They break their faith in God as well as in us:
Cry woe, destruction, ruin and decadence:
The worst is death, and death will have its day.

SIR STEPHEN SCROOP:
I am glad that Your Highness is so armed
To bear the news of a calamity.
Like an unseasonably stormy day,
Which makes the silver rivers drown their shores,
As if the world was dissolved to the point of tears,
So far above its limits, the rage swells
From Bolingbroke, covering your fearful land
With hard, shiny steel and hearts harder than steel.
White beards have armed their thin, hairless scalps
Against your majesty; boys, with women's voices,
Strive to speak big and clap their feminine joints
In arms stiff and cumbersome against your crown:
The same pearlers learn to bend their bows
Of a deadly double yew against your state;
Yeah, the distaffs handle the rusty bills
Against your seat: young and old rebels,
And everything is worse than I can say.

KING RICHARD II:
Too good, too good you tell such a bad story.
Where is the Earl of Wiltshire? Where is Bagot?
What happened to Bushy? where is green?
That they left the dangerous enemy
Measure our limits with such peaceful steps?
If we win, their leaders will pay the price:
I guarantee they made peace with Bolingbroke.

SIR STEPHEN SCROOP:
They have truly made peace with him, my lord.

KING RICHARD II:
O villains, vipers, damned without redemption!
Dogs, easy to win over to adore any man!
Snakes, in my heart warmed by blood, stinging my heart!
Three Judases, each three times worse than Judas!
Would they make peace? a terrible hell, to make war
On their souls stained for this offense!

SIR STEPHEN SCROOP:
Sweet love, I see, changing ownership,
Turns to the bitterest and deadliest hatred:
Curse their souls again; their peace is made
With heads, not hands; those you curse
I felt the worst destructive wound of death
And rest low, etched in the hollow ground.

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
Are Bushy, Green and the Earl of Wiltshire dead?

SIR STEPHEN SCROOP:
Yes, in Bristol, everyone has lost their minds.

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
Where is the Duke my father with his power?

KING RICHARD II:
No matter where; of comfort, no man speaks:
Let's talk about tombs, verses and epitaphs;
Make dust our paper and with rainy eyes
Write sorrow on the bosom of the earth,
Let's choose executors and talk about wills:
And yet this is not the case, because what can we bequeath
Save our bodies lying on the ground?
Our lands, our lives and everything belong to Bolingbroke,
And nothing can belong to us except death
And this little model of the barren earth
Which serves as paste and covering for our bones.
For God's sake let's sit on the floor
And tell sad stories of the death of kings;
How some were deposited; some killed in war,
Some haunted by the ghosts they left behind;
Some poisoned by their wives: some asleep killed;
All murdered: because in the hollow crown
Who surrounds the mortal temples of a king
He keeps death in his court and that's where the tomfoolery is,
Mocking his state and smiling at his pomp,
Allowing him to breathe, a little scene,
To monarchize, fear and kill with looks,
Infusing it with self and vain vanity,
As if this flesh which walls up our life,
Were the brass impregnable and were they thus humored
Comes last and with a small pin
Break through the walls of his castle, and farewell king!
Cover your head and do not mock flesh and blood
With solemn respect: cast respect,
Tradition, form and ceremonial duty,
Because all this time you've been wrong about me:
I live with bread like you, I want,
Taste sorrow, need friends: submissive thus,
How can you tell me, I'm a king?

BISHOP OF CARLISLE:
My lord, wise men never sit and bemoan their misfortunes,
But for now, avoid the ways of whining.
Fear the enemy, since fear oppresses strength,
Give strength to your enemy in your weakness,
And so your follies fight against yourself.
Fear and be killed; nothing worse can happen in combat:
And to fight and to die, it is death that destroys death;
Where the fear of dying pays for the servile breath of death.

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
My father has a power; ask about him
And learn how to make a body from one limb.

KING RICHARD II:
You reprimand me well: proud Bolingbroke, I come
To change things with you for our day of misfortune.
This attack of fear is exaggerated;
An easy task is to earn ours.
Say, Scroop, where is our uncle with his power?
Speak softly, man, even if your air is sour.

SIR STEPHEN SCROOP:
Men judge by the color of the sky
The state and inclination of the day:
So may you, through my dull and heavy eye,
My tongue only has a heavier story to tell.
I play the executioner, little by little
To prolong the worst that must be said:
Your uncle York is joined by Bolingbroke,
And all your northern castles have given way,
And all your southern gentlemen-at-arms
At his party.

KING RICHARD II:
You've said enough.
Here you are, cousin, what led me
In this sweet way, I was in despair!
What do you say now? what comfort do we have now?
By heaven, I will hate him forever
This requires me to comfort myself further.
Go to Flint Castle: there I will waste away;
A king, slave of misfortune, must obey royal misfortune.
This power that I have, discharge it; and let them go
To spy on the earth which has a hope of growth,
Because I don't have one: let no one speak anymore
To change this, because the advice is only in vain.

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
My lord, a word.

KING RICHARD II:
It hurts me doubly
It hurts me by the flattery of his tongue.
Unload my supporters: let them go,
From Richard's Night to Bolingbroke Fair Day.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
So that through this intelligence we learn
The Welsh are scattered and Salisbury
Went to meet the king, who recently landed
With some private friends on this coast.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
The news is very fair and good, my lord:
Richard, not far from here, hid his head.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
It would suit Lord Northumberland
To say "King Richard:" alas, it's a difficult day
When such a sacred king should hide his head.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
Your errors of grace; just to be brief
I left out its title.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
The time has come,
Would you have been so brief with him, he
I was so brief with you, to make it shorter,
To take the head in this way, along the entire length of your head.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Make no mistake, uncle, further than you should.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
Do not go, good cousin, further than you should.
Make no mistake, the heavens are above our heads.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
I know it, uncle, and I do not object
Against their will. But who comes here?
Welcome, Harry: what, won't this castle give in?

HENRY PERCY:
The castle is royally inhabited, my lord,
Against your entrance.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Royally!
Why does it not contain a king?

HENRY PERCY:
Yes, my good lord,
It contains a king; King Richard lies
Within the limits of this lime and this stone:
And with him are Lord Aumerle, Lord Salisbury,
Sir Stephen Scroop, besides a clergyman
Of holy reverence; which, I cannot learn.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
Oh, it seems to be the Bishop of Carlisle.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Noble lords,
Go to the rough shores of this ancient castle;
Through the brass trumpet send the breath of talks
Into his ruined ears, and thus delivers:
Henry Bolingbroke
On his knees, he kisses King Richard's hand
And send allegiance and true faith of heart
To his most regal person, come here
Even at his feet to lay down my weapons and my power,
Provided my ban is repealed
And the returned lands are again granted free of charge:
Otherwise I will use the advantage of my power
And lays down the summer dust with rains of blood
It was raining wounds from the massacred English:
The what, how far from Bolingbroke's mind
That's right, such a crimson storm should soak
The new green lap of King Richard's fair land,
My leaning duty will show it with tenderness.
Come on, mean it as much, while here we walk
On the grassy carpet of this plain.
Let us walk without the sound of threatening drums,
It comes from the tattered battlements of this castle
Our fair appointments can be well consulted.
I think King Richard and I should meet
With no less terror than the elements
Fire and water, when their thunderous clash
At the meeting, the cloudy cheeks of the sky are torn.
Let him be the fire, I will be the water that gives:
Rage be his, while on earth I rain
My waters; on the earth, and not on him.
Continue walking and observe what King Richard looks like.
See, see, King Richard himself appears,
Just like the blushing and discontented sun
From the fiery portal of the east,
When he notices that the envious clouds are bending
To dull its glory and stain the trail
Of his brilliant passage in the West.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
Yet he is like a king: behold, his eye,
As bright as that of the eagle, it lights up
Controlling majesty: alas, alas, woe,
How much evil should stain such a beautiful spectacle!

KING RICHARD II:
We are surprised; and we stood for so long
To watch the terrible bending of your knee,
Because we considered ourselves your rightful king:
And if so, how dare your joints forget
To fulfill their terrible duty to our presence?
If we are not, show us the hand of God
This dismissed us from our stewardship;
Because we know it well, no hand of blood and bone
Can grasp the sacred handle of our scepter,
Unless he desecrates, steals or usurps.
And even if you think that everything, as you did,
Tore away their souls by turning them away from us,
And we are barren and deprived of friends;
But know, my master, Almighty God,
Gathers in its clouds in our name
Armies of plague; and they will strike
Your children yet unborn and unbegotten,
Who raises your vassal hands against my head
And threatens the glory of my precious crown.
Tell Bolingbroke, for it seems to me he is standing there.
That every step he takes on my land
It's a dangerous betrayal: he came to open
The Purple Testament of Bloody War;
But before the crown he seeks lives in peace,
Ten thousand bloody crowns of mothers' sons
Will ill become the flower of England's face,
Change the complexion of his pale peace
To scarlet indignation and dew
The grass of his pastures with faithful English blood.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
The king of heaven forbids our lord the king
Should it be like this with civilian and uncivil weapons
Be in a hurry! Your thrice noble cousin
Harry Bolingbroke humbly kisses your hand;
And by the honorable tomb he swears,
Which rests on the bones of your royal grandfather,
And by the royalties of your two bloods,
Currents that flow from a most graceful head,
And by the buried hand of warrior Gaunt,
And by his valor and his honor,
Comprising everything that can be sworn or said,
His coming here no longer has any significance
That for its linear royalties and to beg
Immediate postage on your knees:
What your royal party once granted,
He will rust his glittering arms,
His barbed horses in the stables and his heart
In faithful service to Your Majesty.
He swears that as a prince, he is just;
And as I am a gentleman, I do him honor.

KING RICHARD II:
Northumberland, say thus that the king returns:
His noble cousin is welcome here;
And all the number of his just demands
Must be accomplished without contradiction:
With all the gracious words you have
Speak to his sweet hearing and give praise.
We degrade ourselves, cousin, don't we,
Look so bad and speak so right?
Shall we call back Northumberland and send
Defy the traitor, and thus die?

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
No, good monsignor; let's fight with sweet words
In the meantime, lend your friends and friends their useful swords.

KING RICHARD II:
O God, oh God! that it is still my language,
This pronounced the sentence of dreadful banishment
On your proud man you should take it off again
With soothing words! Oh that I was so big
Like my sorrow, or less than my name!
Or that I could forget what I was,
Or don't remember what I should be now!
Are you swollen, proud heart? I will give you the chance to fight,
Since enemies have the ability to beat you and me.

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
Northumberland returns from Bolingbroke.

KING RICHARD II:
What should the king do now? should he submit?
The king will do it: must he be deposed?
The king will be happy: must he lose
The name of the king? O name of God, let it go:
I will give my jewels for a set of pearls,
My magnificent palace for a hermitage,
My gay clothing for a chaplain's robe,
My cups figured for a wooden dish,
My scepter for walking stick from a palm tree,
My subjects for a pair of sculpted saints
And my great kingdom for a small grave,
A small little grave, a dark grave;
Or I will be buried on the king's road,
A common trade route, where the feet of the subjects
Can trample on the head of their sovereign every hour;
For they tread upon my heart now while I live;
And buried once, why not on my head?
Aumerle, you are crying, my tender cousin!
We will make bad weather with despised tears;
Our sighs and they will lay down the summer corn,
And make a famine in this revolting country.
Or will we play wanton with our misfortunes,
And have a nice match while shedding tears?
So, to place them again in the same place,
Until they bore us with a pair of graves
In the ground ; and, in there, that's where we find
Two parents dug their graves with crying eyes.
Wouldn't that feel good? Well I see
I speak but without saying anything, and you make fun of me.
Most powerful prince, my Lord Northumberland,
What does King Bolingbroke say? does his majesty
Give Richard permission to live until he dies?
You do a leg, and Bolingbroke says yes.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
Monsignor, he attends the basic court
To talk with you ; please come down.

KING RICHARD II:
Down below, I go down; like the brilliant Phaethon,
Wanting to deal with unruly jades.
At the basic court? Base court, where kings cultivate their base,
Answer the calls of traitors and grant them mercy.
At the basic court? To come down? Down, court!
down, king!
For the night owls cry where the larks soar
should sing.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
What does his majesty say?

NORTHUMBERLAND:
Grief and heartbreak
Makes him speak with tenderness, like a frenzied man
Yet he came.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Everyone stay away,
And show just duty to his majesty.
My gracious lord,--

KING RICHARD II:
Beautiful cousin, you degrade your princely knee
To make the base land proud to embrace it:
I wish my heart felt your love
Let my displeased eye see your courtesy.
Stand up, cousin, stand up; your heart is on high, I know,
So high at least, although your knee is low.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
My gracious lord, I come but for mine.

KING RICHARD II:
Yours is yours, and I'm yours, and all.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Until now be mine, my most formidable lord,
How my true service will merit your love.

KING RICHARD II:
Well, you deserve it: they deserve to have it,
Who know the strongest and safest way to achieve this.
My uncle, give me your hands; no, dry your eyes;
Tears show their love, but want their remedies.
Cousin, I'm too young to be your father,
Even if you are old enough to be my heir.
What you have I will give, and I will also do it;
For we must do what force will make us do.
Go to London, cousin, won't you?

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Yes, my good lord.

KING RICHARD II:
So I don't have to say no.

QUEEN:
What sport are we going to imagine here in this garden,
To chase away the heavy thought of worry?

Lady:
Madam, we will play bowls.

QUEEN:
"It will make me think that the world is full of friction,
And let my fortune rub shoulders with bias.

Lady:
Madam, we are going to dance.

QUEEN:
My legs cannot keep any measure of pleasure,
When my poor heart cannot bear any measure in sorrow:
Therefore, no dancing, my daughter; another sport.

Lady:
Madam, we will tell stories.

QUEEN:
Of sorrow or of joy?

Lady:
One or the other, ma'am.

QUEEN:
Neither, my daughter:
Because of joy, totally lacking in joy,
This reminds me of all the more sorrow;
Or if, with grief, being thoroughly tried,
This adds even more sorrow to my lack of joy:
For what I have, I need not repeat it;
And what I want are the boots so I don't complain.

Lady:
Madam, I'm going to sing.

QUEEN:
It's good that you have a reason
But you should please me more, do you want to cry.

Lady:
I could cry, madam, it would do you good.

QUEEN:
And I could sing, would crying do me any good,
And never borrow a single tear from you.
But stay, here are the gardeners:
Let's enter the shade of these trees.
My misery has a row of pins,
They will talk about the State; because everyone does it
Against a change; misfortune is preceded by misfortune.

Gardener:
Go, tie up your dangling abricocks,
Who, like unruly children, make their father
Stoop with the oppression of their prodigal weight:
Give the bent twigs some support.
Go, and like an executioner,
Cut off the heads of sheaves that grow too quickly,
This seems too high in our Commonwealth:
Everything must be equal in our government.
You are thus employed, I will leave
Noxious weeds that suck without profit
Soil fertility through healthy flowers.

Servant:
Why should we in the compass of a pale
Keep the law, the form and the proportion,
Showing, as in a model, our farm domain,
When our garden bordered by the sea, all the earth,
Is full of weeds, its most beautiful flowers smothered,
Its fruit trees overturned, its hedges destroyed,
Its messy knots and healthy herbs
A swarm of caterpillars?

Gardener:
Shut up :
The one who suffered from this disorderly spring
Now he himself encountered falling leaves:
The weeds that its broad leaves sheltered,
It seemed to eat him to hold him back,
Roots and all are pulled out by Bolingbroke,
I mean the Earl of Wiltshire, Bushy, Green.

Servant:
What, are they dead?

Gardener:
They are; and Bolingbroke
Seized the waster king. O, what a pity is it
That he had not pruned and dressed his land so well
Like us this garden! Us at the time of year
Wound the bark, the skin of our fruit trees,
Lest, too proud of sap and blood,
With too much wealth he gets confused:
If he had done this to tall and growing men,
They could have lived to endure and he to taste
Their fruits of duty: superfluous branches
We prune so that the branches that carry:
If he had done so, he would have worn the crown himself,
What a waste of idle hours has completely destroyed.

Servant:
What, do you think the king will be deposed then?

Gardener:
Depressed, he is already and deposited
I doubt it is: the letters arrived last night
To a dear friend of the good Duke of York,
This heralds dark news.

QUEEN:
Oh, I'm in a hurry to death for want of words!
You, likeness of old Adam, ready to dress this garden,
How dare your harsh and coarse tongue announce this unpleasant news?
What Eve, what snake suggested to you
Make a second fall of the cursed man?
Why do you say that King Richard is deposed?
Would you dare, little thing better than the earth,
Can you guess his fall? Say where, when and how,
Did you hear this bad news? speak, wretch.

Gardener:
Forgive me, madam: I have little joy
To breathe this news; yet what I say is true.
King Richard, he's in the mighty hold
From Bolingbroke: Their fortunes are both weighed:
In your lord's ladder there is nothing but himself,
And some vanities which make it light;
But in the balance of great Bolingbroke,
Besides him, all the English peers are
And with these odds he weighs down King Richard.
Send yourself to London, and you will find it so;
I don't talk any more than everyone knows.

QUEEN:
Agile misfortune, who is so light on your feet,
Doesn't your embassy belong to me,
And am I the last to know? O, you think
To serve me last, so I can keep the longest
Your pain in my chest. Come, ladies, go,
To meet the ill-fated King of London in London.
What, was I born for this, that my sad look
Should we honor the triumph of the great Bolingbroke?
Gardener, for telling me this unfortunate news,
Pray to God that the plants you graft never grow.

GARDENER:
Poor queen! so that your condition is not worse,
I would like my skills to be subject to your curse.
Here she shed a tear; here at this place
I will put a street bank, sour grass of grace:
Rue, even for Ruth, will soon be seen here,
In memory of a crying queen.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Call Bagot.
Now, Bagot, express freely what you think;
What you know of the death of noble Gloucester,
Who did it with the king and who executed him
The bloody office of its timeless end.

BAGOT:
Then place Lord Aumerle before me.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Cousin, get up and look at this man.

BAGOT:
Monsignor Aumerle, I know your bold language
He scorns to deny what he has delivered once he has delivered it.
In that dead age when Gloucester's death was planned,
I heard you say: "Isn't my arm long,
It comes from the peaceful English court
To Calais, to my uncle's head?
Among so many other discussions, at that moment,
I heard you say that you preferred to refuse
The offer of one hundred thousand crowns
Than the return of Bolingbroke to England;
Adding how blessed this land would be
It's the death of your cousin.

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
Princes and noble lords,
What response should I make to this vile man?
Should I so dishonor my beautiful stars,
On an equal footing to give him punishment?
Either I have to do it or I have to sully my honor.
With the reaching of his slanderous lips.
There is my gauge, the manual seal of death,
This marks you for hell: I say, you lie,
And I will argue that what you said is wrong
In your heart's blood, even if you're too low
To stain the temper of my knightly sword.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Bagot, abstain; you won't take it.

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
Except one, I wish he was the best
In all this presence which moved me so much.

LORD FITZWATER:
If your value lies in sympathy,
Here is my pledge, Aumerle, in pledge with yours:
By this beautiful sun which shows me where you are,
I heard you say, and you said it with boasting
That you are the cause of the death of noble Gloucester.
If you deny it twenty times, you lie;
And I will turn your lie to your heart,
Where it was forged, with the tip of my rapier.

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
You dare not, coward, live to see that day.

LORD FITZWATER:
Now, by my soul, I would like it at this hour.

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
Fitzwater, you are damned to hell for this.

HENRY PERCY:
Aumerle, you are lying; his honor is also true
In this appeal, how unjust you are;
And you are, there I throw my pledge,
To prove it to you to the most extreme point
Of deadly breath: seize it, if you dare.

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
And if I don't, may my hands rot
And never wield more vengeful steel
On the glittering helmet of my enemy!

Lord:
I entrust the land to the same, Aumerle perjure;
And encourage you with so many lies
How hollow can be in your treacherous ear
From sun to sun: here is the pawn of my honor;
Engage him in the test, if you dare.

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
Who else defines me? by heaven, I will throw away at all:
I have a thousand spirits in one breast,
To respond to twenty thousand like you.

DUKE OF SURREY:
Monsignor Fitzwater, I remember well
The very time you and Aumerle spoke.

LORD FITZWATER:
It is very true: you were then in the presence;
And you can testify with me that it's true.

DUKE OF SURREY:
As false, by heaven, as heaven itself is true.

LORD FITZWATER:
Surrey, you're lying.

DUKE OF SURREY:
Dishonorable boy!
This lie will lie so heavy on my sword,
That he will repay vengeance and revenge
Until you're the one who gives the lie and that lie lies
On a land as calm as your father's skull:
As proof, here is the pawn of my honor;
Engage him in the test, if you dare.

LORD FITZWATER:
With what tenderness you encourage a horse forward!
If I dare to eat, or drink, or breathe, or live,
I dare to meet Surrey in a desert,
And spit on him, while I say he lies,
And lies, and lies: this is my bond of faith,
To bind you to my strong correction.
As I intend to flourish in this new world,
Aumerle is guilty of my real call:
Besides, I heard banished Norfolk say
That you, Aumerle, sent two of your men
Execute the noble duke at Calais.

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
An honest Christian entrusts me with a gauge
Let Norfolk lie: here I throw this,
If he can be revoked, to judge his honor.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
These differences must all remain under gauge
Until Norfolk is repealed: it shall be repealed,
And, although my enemy, restored again
To all his lands and lordships: when he returns,
Against Aumerle we will enforce his trial.

BISHOP OF CARLISLE:
This honorable day will never be seen.
Many times banishment Norfolk fought
For Jesus Christ in the glorious Christian field,
Disseminating the sign of the Christian cross
Against black pagans, Turks and Saracens:
And worked with war work he retired
In Italy; and there in Venice gave
His body on the earth of this pleasant country,
And his pure soul to his captain Christ,
Under whose colors he had fought so long.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Why, Bishop, did Norfolk die?

BISHOP OF CARLISLE:
As surely as I live, my lord.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Sweet peace leads her gentle soul to the bosom
Good old Abraham! Lords Appellant,
Your differences will all remain under gauge
Until we assign you your days of trial.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
Grand Duke of Lancaster, I come to you
Of Richard plucked in feathers; who with a willing soul
Adopts you heir, and his high scepter gives way
To the possession of your royal hand:
Ascend his throne, now come down from him;
And long live Henry, fourth of this name!

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
In the name of God, I will ascend the royal throne.

BISHOP OF CARLISLE:
Marry. God forgives!
The worst in this royal presence, may I speak,
But it's better that I tell the truth.
God would have someone in this noble presence
Were we noble enough to be an honest judge
From noble Richard! then true nobility would do it
Teach him to refrain from such heinous wrong.
What subject can pronounce judgment on his king?
And who is sitting here if not Richard's subject?
Thieves are not judged but they are there to hear,
Although an apparent guilt is visible in them;
And the figure of the majesty of God,
His captain, his steward, his deputy,
Anointed, crowned, planted many years,
Be judged on the subject and the lower breath,
And he himself is not present? Oh, forgive him, my God,
That in a Christian climate souls are refined
Should show such a heinous, black and obscene act!
I speak to subjects, and a subject speaks,
Recited by God, thus boldly for his king:
My lord of Hereford, whom you call king,
Is a vile traitor to the proud king of Hereford:
And if you crown him, let me prophesy:
The blood of the English will fertilize the soil,
And future ages groan because of this vile act;
Peace will go to sleep with the Turks and the infidels,
And in this seat of peace tumultuous wars
Will be relatives with relatives and gentiles with gentiles mixed together;
Disorder, horror, fear and mutiny
Must live here, and this land will be called
The field of Golgotha and the skulls of the dead.
Oh, if you raise this house against this house,
It will be the saddest division that will prove it
Who has ever fallen on this cursed earth.
Prevent it, resist it, let it not be so,
Lest children, children of children, cry out against you, woe!

NORTHUMBERLAND:
Well, have you argued, sir; and, for your pains,
Of capital treason, we stop you here.
My Lord of Westminster, let it be your charge
To keep him safe until his day of trial.
May you, lords, grant the request of the commons.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Bring here Richard, who is of the common opinion
He can surrender; so we will proceed
Without suspicion.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
I will be his conduct.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Lords, you who are here under our arrest,
Get your guarantees for your response days.
We don't recognize your love,
And little was expected of your helping hands.

KING RICHARD II:
Alas, why am I sent for a king,
Before I rid myself of royal thoughts
With what did I reign? I have barely learned yet
To insinuate, flatter, tilt and bend my limbs:
Give sorrow some time to guide me
To this submission. Yet I remember well
The favors of these men: were they not mine?
Have they not sometimes shouted: “Hello everyone! volume?
Thus did Judas treat Christ: but he, in twelve,
I found the truth in all but one: me, in twelve thousand, none.
May God save the king! Will no one say amen?
Am I both priest and cleric? well, amen.
May God save the king! although I am not him;
And yet, amen, if heaven thinks so, it is me.
For what service am I sent here for?

THE DUKE OF YORK:
To do this work of your own good will
What tired majesty made you offer,
The resignation of your state and your crown
To Henry Bolingbroke.

KING RICHARD II:
Give me the crown. Here, cousin, grab the crown;
Here cousin:
On one side my hand, and on the other yours.
Now this golden crown is like a deep well
Who owes two buckets filling each other,
The emptiest still dancing in the air,
The other down, invisible and full of water:
This bucket down and full of tears I am,
Drink my sorrows, while you climb to the heights.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
I thought you were ready to quit.

KING RICHARD II:
My crown, I am; but my sorrows are always mine:
You can depose my glory and my state,
But not my sorrows; I am still the king of those.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Part of your care you give me with your crown.

KING RICHARD II:
Your worries don't take away my worries.
My care is a waste of care, by old care accomplished;
Your healing is a gain of healing, by new healing gained:
The care I give, I have, although given;
They take care of the crown, but they always stay with me.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Are you happy to give up the crown?

KING RICHARD II:
Yes No ; no Yes ; for I must be nothing;
So no no, because I resign myself to you.
Now mark me how I am going to undo myself;
I give this heavy weight off my head
And this cumbersome scepter in my hand,
The pride of royal influence issues from my heart;
With my own tears I wash away my balm,
With my own hands I give my crown,
With my own tongue, deny my sacred state,
With my own breath, release all the rites of duty:
I renounce all pomp and majesty;
I renounce my mansions, my rents, my income;
I deny my acts, decrees and statutes:
God forgive all the oaths that are broken to me!
God keep intact all the vows that swear to you!
Grant me that I have nothing, that I be afflicted with nothing,
And you are happy to have accomplished everything!
Long may you live in Richard's seat to sit,
And soon Richard will rest in an earthly pit!
God save King Harry, Richard, no king, said:
And send him many years of sunny days!
What more is left?

NORTHUMBERLAND:
No more, but that you read
These serious accusations and crimes
Engaged by you and your followers
Against the State and the profit of this land;
That in confessing them, the souls of men
May consider that you are worthily deposited.

KING RICHARD II:
Do I have to do it ? and should I get out of it
My woven madness? Sweet Northumberland,
If your offenses were recorded,
Wouldn't it shame you in such a beautiful troop?
Read a lecture on them? If you wanted it,
There you should find a hateful article,
Containing the dismissal of a king
And breaking the strong mandate of an oath,
Marked with a stain, damned in the book of heaven:
No, all of you who stand and watch,
While my misery lures me,
Even if some of you with Pilate wash your hands
Show outward pity; yet you do Pilates
Have delivered me here to my bitter cross,
And water cannot wash away your sin.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
My lord, hurry; read these articles.

KING RICHARD II:
My eyes are full of tears, I can't see:
And yet salt water doesn't blind them that much
But they see some sort of traitor here.
No, if I turn my eyes on myself,
I find myself treacherous with others;
For here I have given the consent of my soul
To dismantle the pompous body of a king;
Has made glory a basis and sovereignty a slave,
Proud majesty of a subject, declares a peasant.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
My lord,--

KING RICHARD II:
No lord of yours, you have insulted man,
Nor the lord of anyone; I have neither name nor title,
No, this name was not given to me at the police,
But it is usurped: alas, the day is heavy,
That I have worn so many winters,
And I don't know what name to give myself anymore!
Oh that I was a mocking king of the snow,
Standing before the Bolingbroke sun,
Melt into drops of water!
Good king, great king, and yet not very good,
And if my word is still valid in England,
Let him order a straight mirror here,
So that it shows me what face I have,
Since he is bankrupt from his majesty.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Some of you go get a mirror.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
Read this document while the glass arrives.

KING RICHARD II:
Demon, you torment me before I come to hell!

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Do not insist any further, my Lord Northumberland.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
The commons will then not be satisfied.

KING RICHARD II:
They will be satisfied: I will read enough,
When I see the book itself
Where all my sins are written, and that is myself.
Give me the glass and I'll read it.
No deeper wrinkles yet? has sorrow struck
So many blows on my face,
And didn't he make deeper wounds? O flattering glass,
Like my disciples in prosperity,
You are cheating on me ! Was this face the face
That every day under the roof of his house
Did you keep ten thousand men? was it the face
Did this, like the sun, make the spectators' eyes blink?
Was it the face that faced so much madness,
And was he finally beaten by Bolingbroke?
A fragile glory shines on this face:
As fragile as glory is the face;
Because there he is, broken into a hundred shudders.
Mark, silent king, the morality of this sport,
How long my grief has destroyed my face.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
The shadow of your sorrow has destroyed
The shadow or your face.

KING RICHARD II:
Say that again.
The shadow of my sorrow! Ha! Let's see:
It’s very true, my grief is entirely internal;
And these external ways of lamenting
Are only shadows to invisible sorrow
It swells with silence in the tortured soul;
Therein lies the essential: and I thank you, king,
For your great generosity, which not only gives
I want to cry but you teach me the way
How to deplore the cause. I'm going to ask you a favor,
And then go away and don't bother you anymore.
Should I get it?

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Say it, beautiful cousin.

KING RICHARD II:
" Pretty cousin " ? I am greater than a king:
Because when I was king, my flatterers
Were then only subjects; now being a subject,
I have a king here for my flatterer.
Being so big, I don't need to beg.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Still, ask.

KING RICHARD II:
And should I have it?

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
You should.

KING RICHARD II:
So give me permission to leave.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Or?

KING RICHARD II:
Wherever you wanted, I was out of your sight.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Come on, some of you are taking him to the Tower.

KING RICHARD II:
Oh good! to transmit? the conveyors are you all,
Who rises thus with agility by the fall of a true king.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Next Wednesday we solemnly settle down
Our crowning glory: Lords, prepare yourselves.

Abbe:
We witnessed a lamentable spectacle here.

BISHOP OF CARLISLE:
Misfortune is coming; children yet to be born.
This day will seem as sharp as a thorn to them.

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
You, holy ecclesiastics, is there no conspiracy
To rid the kingdom of this pernicious stain?

Abbe:
My lord,
Before freely saying what I think here,
You will not only partake of the sacrament
To bury the intentions of the mines, but also to realize
Whatever I can imagine.
I see that your eyebrows are full of discontent,
Your hearts of sorrow and your eyes of tears:
Come and have supper with me; and I'm going to lie down
A conspiracy will show us all a joyful day.

QUEEN:
This is how the king will come; this is the way
To the poorly erected tower of Julius Caesar,
In whose bosom my lord condemned
Is condemned to be a prisoner by the proud Bolingbroke:
Let us rest here, if this rebellious land
Give the queen a rest from her true king.
But sweet, but see, or rather don't see,
My beautiful rose withers: but lift up your eyes, behold,
So that, through pity, you may dissolve into dew,
And wash it away again with tears of true love.
Ah, you, the model where old Troy stood,
You, card of honor, you, tomb of King Richard,
And not King Richard; you are the most beautiful inn,
Why should sorrow hard favored be lodged in thee,
When does the triumph become a guest of the brewery?

KING RICHARD II:
Do not join in sorrow, beautiful woman, do not,
To make my end too sudden: learn, good soul,
Consider our former state as a happy dream;
From where the truth of what we are awoke
He only shows us this: I am my sworn brother, my sweet one,
To the dark necessity, and he and I
Will keep a league until death. Hello to you in France
And lock yourself in some religious house:
Our holy lives must win the crown of a new world,
That our secular hours here have been canceled.

QUEEN:
What, is my Richard both in form and in spirit
Transformed and weakened? Has Bolingbroke been trademarked
Your intellect? is he in your heart?
The dying lion stretches out his paw,
And hurt the earth, at least, with rage
Be under control; and you want, like a student,
Take your correction gently, kiss the rod,
And wild with rage with base humility,
What is a lion and a king of beasts?

KING RICHARD II:
A king of beasts, indeed; if anything other than animals,
I was still a happy king of men.
Good queen, prepare yourself for France:
Think that I am dead and that even here you take,
From my deathbed, your last living leave.
During the tedious nights of winter, sit by the fire
With good old people and let them tell you stories
Lamentable ages, long ago;
And before wishing them good night, to put an end to their sorrows,
Tell yourself the sad story of me
And sends the listeners to cry in their beds:
Why Foolish Brands Will Sympathize
The heavy accent of your moving tongue
And with compassion cry for fire;
And some will cry in the ashes, others in the coal black,
For the removal of a legitimate king.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
My lord, Bolingbroke's mind has changed:
You need to go to Pomfret, not the Tower.
And, madame, the order is taken for you;
At full speed, you must leave for France.

KING RICHARD II:
Northumberland, you have a ladder with which
The rising Bolingbroke ascends my throne,
The time should not be several hours
More than he was before heinous sin gathered his head
You will sink into corruption: you will think,
Although he divides the kingdom and gives you half of it,
It's too little, helping him with everything;
And he will think that you, who know the way
To plant unjust kings, I will still know,
Never in such a hurry, in another way
To tear him headlong from the usurped throne.
The love of the wicked turns into fear;
This fear of hating, and hatred transforms one or both
To worthy danger and deserved death.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
My guilt rests on my head, and that is an end.
Take your leave and go; because you must separate immediately.

KING RICHARD II:
Double divorced! Bad men, you rape
A double marriage, between my crown and me,
And then between me and my married woman.
Let me break the oath between you and me;
And yet this is not the case, because it was done with a kiss.
Separate us, Northumberland; I'm heading north,
Where cold and disease ravage the climate;
My wife in France: from where, leaving in pomp,
She came here dressed like sweet May,
Dismissed as Hallowmas or the Shortest Day.

QUEEN:
And should we be divided? should we separate?

KING RICHARD II:
Yes, hand in hand, my love, and heart in heart.

QUEEN:
Banish us both and send the king with me.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
It was a little love but little politics.

QUEEN:
So where he's going, let me go.

KING RICHARD II:
So two crying together make one misfortune.
Cry for me in France, me for you here;
Far is better than near, never be close.
Go, count your way while sighing; I mine with moans.

QUEEN:
The longest path will therefore have the longest groans.

KING RICHARD II:
Twice for one step I will groan, the path being short,
And chart the path forward with a heavy heart.
Come, come, to woo sorrow, let's be brief,
Since then, the marriage has been so long in sorrow;
A kiss will close our mouths and stupidly separate us;
So I give mine, and so I take your heart.

QUEEN:
Give me mine again; it was not a good role
Take me to guard and kill your heart.
So, now I have mine again, go,
So that I can strive to kill him with a whimper.

KING RICHARD II:
We are making misfortune with this affectionate delay:
Once again, farewell; the rest lets the sorrow speak.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
My lord, you told me you would tell the rest,
When the tears made you interrupt the story,
of our two cousins coming to London.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
Where have I gone?

DUCHESS OF YORK:
At this sad stop, my lord,
Where crude and ill-governed hands from above the windows
Threw dust and rubbish on King Richard's head.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
Then, as I said, the Duke, the great Bolingbroke,
Mounted on a burning and fiery steed
What his aspiring rider seemed to know,
With a slow but majestic pace kept on its course,
While all tongues cried "God save you,
Boling Broke!
You would have thought that the very windows were speaking,
So many greedy looks from young and old
Through the doors their longing eyes flashed
On his face, and all the walls
With painted images he had said immediately
“Jesus, protect yourself! welcome, Bolingbroke!
While he, turning from side to side,
Bare head, lower than the neck of his proud steed,
Speak to them thus: “I thank you, compatriots:”
And so he continued to do it, so he passed on.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Alas, poor Richard! where did he go during this time?

THE DUKE OF YORK:
As in the theater, the eyes of men,
After a distinguished actor leaves the stage,
Are lazily leaning over whoever enters next,
Thinking that his chatter is tedious;
Yet, or with much more contempt, the eyes of men
I looked at kind Richard sullenly; no man cried “God save him!”
No cheerful tongue welcomed him home:
But dust was thrown on his sacred head:
Which he shook with such sweet sadness,
Her face still struggling with tears and smiles,
The badges of his sorrow and his patience,
God had not, for some mighty purpose, strengthened
The hearts of men must have melted
And barbarism itself took pity on him.
But heaven has a hand in these events,
At the top of whom will we want to link our calm content.
We are now sworn subjects of Bolingbroke,
Whose state and honor I authorize.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
This is my son Aumerle.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
It was Aumerle;
But it's lost to be Richard's friend,
And, ma'am, you must call him Rutland now:
I'm in Parliament and I promise its truth
And lasting loyalty to the new king.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Welcome, my son: who are the violets now
Who sprinkles the green lap of the new spring?

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
Madam, I don't know anything about it and I don't care:
God knows I wanted just as much to be just one.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
Well, be well in this new spring of time,
Lest you get cut off before you get to the primer.
What news from Oxford? hold these righteous people and these triumphs?

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
As far as I know, my lord, this is the case.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
You will be there, I know.

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
If God doesn't forbid it, I intend to.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
What is this seal that hangs from your bosom?
Yeah, you look pale? let me see the writing.

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
My lord, it's nothing.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
So it doesn't matter who sees it;
I will be satisfied; let me see the writing.

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
I beg Your Grace to forgive me:
It's a matter of little consequence,
Which, for certain reasons, I would not have seen.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
And for some reason, sir, I want to see it.
I'm scared, I'm scared...

DUCHESS OF YORK:
What should we fear?
It is nothing but a bond in which it is concluded
For gay clothing against the day of triumph.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
Linked to himself! what does he do with a link
That he has to? Woman, you are an idiot.
Boy, let me see the writing.

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
I beg you, forgive me; I can't show it.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
I will be satisfied; let me see, I said.
Treason! vile betrayal! Wicked! traitor! slave!

DUCHESS OF YORK:
What is it, my lord?

THE DUKE OF YORK:
Ho! who is in there?
Saddle my horse.
God for his mercy, what betrayal here!

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Why, what is it, my lord?

THE DUKE OF YORK:
Give me my boots, I said; saddle my horse.
Now, by my honor, by my life, by my faith,
I'm going to call the bad guy.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
What is the problem?

THE DUKE OF YORK:
Peace, stupid woman.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
I will not make peace. What is it, Aumerle?

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
Good mother, be happy; it's no more
So my poor life must respond.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Your life responds!

THE DUKE OF YORK:
Bring me my boots: I will do it to the king.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Hit him, Aumerle. Poor boy, you are surprised.
So, naughty! will never come into my sight again.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
Give me my boots, I said.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Why, York, what are you going to do?
Won't you hide your fault?
Do we have more sons? or do we like to have?
Isn't my busy date drunk on time?
And will you snatch my beautiful son from my age,
And steal the name of a happy mother from me?
Isn't he like you? Isn't it yours?

THE DUKE OF YORK:
You love the crazy one,
Do you want to hide this dark conspiracy?
A dozen of them here have taken the sacrament,
And indiscriminately they placed their hands,
Kill the King at Oxford.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
There will be none;
We'll keep him here: so what does that do to him?

THE DUKE OF YORK:
Go away, dear woman! was he twenty times my son,
I would approach him.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Would you have moaned for him
As I did it, you would be more pitiful.
But now I know your spirit; you suspect
That I have been disloyal to your bed,
And that he's a bastard, not your son:
Sweet York, sweet husband, do not be in this spirit:
He looks as much like you as a man can,
Not like me, nor any of my loved ones,
And yet I love him.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
Walk away, unruly woman!

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Afterwards, Aumerle! rides on his horse;
Ram the post, and arrive before him near the king,
And ask for forgiveness before he accuses you.
I won't be far behind; even though I am old,
I have no doubt I'll ride as fast as York:
And I will never rise from the ground
Until Bolingbroke has forgiven you. Go, go!

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Can no one tell me about my unthrifty son?
It's been three months since I last saw him;
If there is a scourge hanging over us, it is him.
I would to God, my lords, that it might be found:
Ask in London, among the taverns there,
For there, they say, he frequents daily,
With free and unrestrained companions,
Even those who, they say, stand in the narrow streets,
And beat our watch, and steal our passengers;
And he, an effeminate and wanton young boy,
Takes the point of honor to support
So it’s a dissolute crew.

HENRY PERCY:
Monsignor, it is about two days since I saw the prince,
And told him about these triumphs won at Oxford.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
And what did the gallant say?

HENRY PERCY:
His response was: he would go to the stews,
And from the most common creature, tear off a glove,
And wear it as a favor; And with that
He would unhorse the most vigorous challenger.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
As dissolute as he is desperate; yet through both
I see sparks of a better hope, whose older years
Can happily give birth. But who comes here?

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
Where is the king?

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
What does our cousin mean, let him look and look
So wildly?

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
God keep your grace! I beg Your Majesty,
Have a conference with Your Grace alone.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Withdraw and leave us here alone.
What's wrong with our cousin now?

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
May my knees join the earth forever,
My tongue clings to my roof in my mouth
Unless you get my forgiveness before you get up or speak.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Was this mistake intentional or committed?
If from the first, how odious it is,
To earn your love, I forgive you.

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
So give me permission so I can turn the key,
Let no one enter until my story is finished.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Have your desire.

THE DUKE OF YORK:

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Bad guy, I'll get you to safety.

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
Stop your avenging hand; you have no reason to fear.

THE DUKE OF YORK:

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
What is it, uncle? talk;
Recover your breath; tell us how near the danger is,
So that we can arm ourselves to face it.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
Go through this writing here, and you will know
The betrayal that my haste forbids me to show.

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
Remember, as you read, your promise has been kept:
I repent; don't read my name there
My heart is not complicit with my hand.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
It was, wicked one, before your hand laid it.
I have torn him from the breast of the traitor, king;
Fear, not love, generates his penance:
Forget to pity him, lest your pity prove
A snake that will sting you to the heart.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
O odious, strong and daring conspiracy!
O faithful father of a treacherous son!
You, pure, immaculate and silvery fountain,
Since when does this stream cross muddy passages
Retained his current and soiled himself!
Your excess of good turns into evil,
And your abundant kindness will excuse
This deadly stain in your digressing son.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
Thus my virtue will be the debauchery of his vice;
And he will spend my honor with his shame,
As thrifty sons, their fathers scraped for gold.
My honor lives when his dishonor dies,
Or my shameful life lies in his dishonor:
You killed me in his life; giving him breath,
The traitor lives, the true man is put to death.

DUCHESS OF YORK:

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Which high-voiced supplicant utters this eager cry?

DUCHESS OF YORK:
A woman and your aunt, great king; it's me.
Talk to me, pity me, open the door.
A beggar begs like never before.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Our scene is changed from a serious thing,
And now changed to “The Beggar and the King”.
My dangerous cousin, let your mother in:
I know she came to pray for your foul sin.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
If you forgive everyone who prays,
More sins could flourish because of this forgiveness.
This infected joint has been cut, the rest remains healthy;
And even less will it confuse everything else.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
O king, do not believe this hard-hearted man!
Love does not love itself, no one else can.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
You, unbridled woman, what are you doing here?
Will your old hovel be a traitor again?

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Sweet York, be patient. Listen to me, sweet lord.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Get up, good aunt.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Not yet, I beg you:
I will always walk on my knees,
And never see the day that the happy see,
Until you give joy; until you give me joy,
By forgiving Rutland, my transgressor boy.

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
At my mother's prayers, I bend my knee.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
Against them, my two true joints buckled.
You will not be able to prosper if you grant grace!

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Is he seriously pleading? look at his face;
His eyes shed no tears, his prayers are pleasant;
His words come from his mouth, ours from our bosom:
He prays only weakly and would be refused;
We pray with heart and soul and alongside:
His tired joints would gladly rise again, I know;
Our knees will kneel until they push to the ground:
His prayers are full of false hypocrisy;
We are of true zeal and deep integrity.
Our prayers surpass his; so let them have
This mercy that true prayer should have.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Good aunt, get up.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
No, don’t say “stand up”;
First say “sorry,” then “stand up.”
And if I were your nurse, your tongue to teach,
“Sorry” should be the first word of your speech.
I never wanted to hear a word until now;
Say “pardon,” king; may pity teach you how:
The word is short, but not so short as sweet;
There is no word like “forgiveness” for the lips of kings, so surrender.

THE DUKE OF YORK:
Speak it in French, king; say, “Forgive me.”

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Do you teach forgiveness forgiveness to destroy?
Ah, my sour husband, my hard-hearted lord,
This pits the word itself against the word!
Speak “forgiveness,” as is common in our country;
We don't understand broken French.
Your eye begins to speak; put your tongue there;
Or, in your pitiful heart, plant your ear;
May hearing how our complaints and our prayers pierce,
Pity can push you to “forgive” to repeat.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Good aunt, get up.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
I'm not suing;
Forgiveness is all I have in my hand.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
I forgive him, as God will forgive me.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
O happy sight of a kneeling knee!
Yet I am sick with fear: speak of it again;
Saying “sorry” twice does not forgive both,
But it makes forgiveness strong.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
With all my heart
I forgive him.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
You are a god on earth.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
But for our faithful brother-in-law and the abbot,
With all the rest of this consorted crew,
Direct destruction will follow on their heels.
Good uncle, help command several powers
To Oxford, or wherever these traitors are:
They won't live in this world, I swear,
But I will get them, if I ever know where.
My uncle, farewell; and, cousin too, farewell:
Your mother prayed well and proved your truthfulness to you.

DUCHESS OF YORK:
Come, my old son: I pray that God will make you new.

EXTON:
Have you not noticed the king, the words he spoke,
“Have I no friend who would rid me of this living fear?
Wasn't that so?

Servant:
These are his own words.

EXTON:
“I don’t have a friend?” he said: he said it twice,
And he pushed it together twice, didn't he?

Servant:
He did.

EXTON:
And while speaking thus, he looked at me with a nostalgic look,
And who should say: "I wish you were the man"
It would take this terror away from my heart;
That is to say the king at Pomfret. Come on, let's go:
I am the king's friend and I will rid his enemy.

KING RICHARD II:
I studied how I could compare
This prison where I live in the world:
And because the world is populated
And behold, there is no creature other than myself,
I can not do it; but I will solve it.
My brain, I will prove the female to my soul,
My soul the father; and these two generate
A generation of thoughts still reproducing,
And these same thoughts populate this little world,
In a mood like the people of this world,
Because no thought is happy. The best kind,
As thoughts of divine things mingle
With scruples and puts the word itself
Against the word:
Like so: “Come, little ones,” and then again:
"It's as difficult to come as it is for a camel
To thread the postern with a small eye of a needle.
Thoughts tend towards ambition, they plot
Improbable wonders; how these vain weak nails
Can tear a passage through flint ribs
From this harsh world, from my tattered prison walls,
And, because they cannot, die in their own pride.
Thoughts tending towards content flatter themselves
That they are not the first slaves of fortune,
It won't be the last either; like stupid beggars
Who sit in the vines and hide their shame,
Many have done it and others must remain there;
And in this thought they find a kind of ease,
Carry their own misfortunes on their backs
Of those who have already endured the same.
So I play in one person with several people,
And no one is happy: sometimes I am king;
So betrayals make me wish myself a beggar,
And that's what I am: then crushing misery
Convinces me that I was better when I was king;
So I am king again: and little by little
I think I'm not king by Bolingbroke,
And I am nothing: but whatever I am,
Neither me nor any other man but man.
Nothing will be happy with, until it is relieved
By being nothing. Music do I hear?
Ha, ha! keep time: as the music is bittersweet,
When time is broken and no proportion is respected!
It is the same in the music of men's lives.
And there you have it, I have the delicacy of the ear
To check the time, it broke into a disorderly chain;
But for the harmony of my state and my time
I didn't have an ear to hear my true broken time.
I wasted time, and now time is wasting me;
For now, time has made me its digital clock:
My thoughts last for minutes; and with sighs they shake
Their watches over my eyes, the external surveillance,
Where is my finger, like the tip of a dial,
He always points, cleaning them of tears.
Now sir, the sound that tells you what time it is
Are loud moans that strike my heart,
What is the bell: then sighs, tears and groans
Show minutes, hours and hours: but my time
He posts messages in Bolingbroke's proud joy,
While I stay here fooling around, it's Jack o' the clock.
This music drives me crazy; that it no longer rings;
Because even though it helped the madmen regain their minds,
It seems to me that this will drive wise people crazy.
Yet blessing on his heart which gives it to me!
Because it is a sign of love; and I love Richard
It's a strange brooch in this world that hates everything.

Married:
Hello, royal prince!

KING RICHARD II:
Thank you, noble peer;
The cheapest among us is ten groats too expensive.
What are you ? and how do you come here,
Where no man ever comes except this sad dog
Does it bring me food to keep misfortune alive?

Married:
I was a poor groom in your stable, king,
When you were king; who, traveling towards York,
With much ado I finally got a leave of absence
Watching the face of my sometimes royal master.
O, how my heart ached when I saw
In the streets of London, this coronation day,
When Bolingbroke rode the Barbary roan,
This horse that you have ridden so often,
This horse that I dressed so carefully!

KING RICHARD II:
Did he climb Barbary? Tell me, sweet friend,
How did it go under him?

Married:
So proudly as if he disdained the ground.

KING RICHARD II:
So proud to have Bolingbroke on his back!
This jade has eaten the bread from my royal hand;
This hand made him proud by applauding him.
Wouldn't he stumble? would he not fall,
Since pride must fall and break its neck
Of this proud man who usurped his back?
Sorry, horse! why am I picking on you,
Since you, created to be impressed by man,
Was I born to endure? I was not made a horse;
And yet I carry a burden like a donkey,
Stimulated, irritated and tired by Bolingbroke's jump.

Guardian:
Friend, give way; here, there is no longer any stay.

KING RICHARD II:
If you love me, it's time for you to leave.

Married:
What my tongue does not dare, my heart will say.

Guardian:
My lord, would you not like to fall?

KING RICHARD II:
Taste some first, as you usually do.

Guardian:
My lord, I dare not: Sir Pierce of Exton, who
recently come from the king, orders the opposite.

KING RICHARD II:
May the devil take Henry of Lancaster and you!
Patience is boring and I'm tired of it.

Guardian:
Help, help, help!

KING RICHARD II:
How now! what does death mean in this brutal assault?
Wicked, your own hand yields the instrument of your death.
Go ahead and fill another room of hell.
This hand will burn in a fire that never goes out
This astounds me. Exton, your fierce hand
He has stained the king's own land with the king's blood.
Come up, come up, my soul! your seat is upstairs;
As my gross flesh sinks downward, I am here to die.

EXTON:
As full of valor as of royal blood:
I overturned both; Oh, if the action was good!
For now the devil, who told me that I had done well,
He says this act is recounted in hell.
This dead king to the living king, I will carry him
So take the rest and bury them here.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Kind Uncle York, the latest we hear
It is because the rebels have consumed by fire
Our town of Cicester in Gloucestershire;
But whether they will be captured or killed, we don't know.
Welcome, my lord, what is the news?

NORTHUMBERLAND:
First, to your sacred state, I wish all happiness.
The next news is that I am to be sent to London
The heads of Oxford, Salisbury, Blunt and Kent:
The way to take them may appear
Generally discussed in this article here.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
We thank you, sweet Percy, for your troubles;
And to your value will be added just and worthy gains.

LORD FITZWATER:
My lord, I have been sent from Oxford to London
The heads of Brocas and Sir Bennet Seely,
Two of the group's dangerous traitors
Who sought in Oxford your terrible overthrow.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Thy sorrows, Fitzwater, shall not be forgotten;
Your merit is very noble, well, I know it.

HENRY PERCY:
The great conspirator, Abbot of Westminster,
With a clouded conscience and sour melancholy
Delivered his body to the grave;
But here is Carlisle alive, to remain
Your royal condemnation and the sentence of his pride.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Carlisle, this is your destiny:
Choose a secret place, a reverend's room,
More than you have, and with it, rejoice your life;
So, while you live in peace, die without conflict:
For although you have always been my enemy,
I saw great sparks of honor in you.

EXTON:
Great king, in this coffin I present
Your buried fear: here all the breathless lies
The most powerful of your greatest enemies,
Richard of Bordeaux, whom I brought here.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Exton, I don't thank you; because you worked
An act of slander from your fatal hand
On my head and all this famous earth.

EXTON:
It is from your own mouth, my lord, that I have done this deed.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
They don't like poison that poison needs,
You neither: even if I wished him dead,
I hate the murderer, I love him murdered.
The guilt of conscience do you take for your work,
But neither my good word nor princely favor:
With Cain, will wander in the shadows of the night,
And never show your face in the daytime or in the light.
Lords, I protest, my soul is full of misfortune,
This blood should water me to make me grow:
Come, cry with me what I deplore,
And put on a moody black incontinent:
I will take a trip to the Holy Land,
To wash this blood from my guilty hand:
Walks sadly afterwards; honor my mourning here;
Crying after that untimely beer.


SAMPSON:
Gregory, my word, we will not transport coal.

GREGORY:
No, because then we would be coal miners.

SAMPSON:
I mean, if we're angry, we'll draw lots.

GREGORY:
Yes, while you are alive, remove your neck from the collar.

SAMPSON:
I knock quickly, being moved.

GREGORY:
But you are not quick to strike.

SAMPSON:
A dog from Montague's house moves me.

GREGORY:
To move is to stir; and to be valiant is to stand up:
therefore, if you are moved, you run away.

SAMPSON:
A dog in this house will push me to get up: I will
take the wall from any man or maid in Montague.

GREGORY:
This shows you a weak slave; because the weakest are leaving
on the wall.

SAMPSON:
TRUE; and therefore women, being the weakest vessels,
are always pushed against the wall: that's why I will push
Montague's men from the wall and pushed his maids
on the wall.

GREGORY:
The quarrel is between our masters and us, their men.

SAMPSON:
It's all one, I will show myself to be a tyrant: when I
I have fought with men, I will be cruel to them
servants and cut off their heads.

GREGORY:
The chief servants?

SAMPSON:
Yes, the heads of the servants, or their virgins;
take it in whatever direction you want.

GREGORY:
They have to take it in the sense of feeling it.

SAMPSON:
Me, they will smell me while I am able to stand: and
we know that I am a pretty piece of flesh.

GREGORY:
It’s good that you’re not a fish; if you had done it, you
you had been poor John. Draw your tool! Here is
two from the house of Montaigu.

SAMPSON:
My naked weapon is drawn: quarrel, I will support you.

GREGORY:
How! turn around and run?

SAMPSON:
Do not fear me.

GREGORY:
No, get married; I fear you!

SAMPSON:
Let us take the law on our side; let them begin.

GREGORY:
I'll frown as I pass and let them take it as
they list.

SAMPSON:
No, as they dare. I will bite their thumb;
which is a shame for them, if they put up with it.

ABRAHAM:
Are you biting our thumb, sir?

SAMPSON:
I'm biting my thumb, sir.

ABRAHAM:
Are you biting our thumb, sir?

SAMPSON:

GREGORY:
No.

SAMPSON:
No, sir, I'm not biting your thumb, sir, but I
bite my thumb, sir.

GREGORY:
Are you arguing, sir?

ABRAHAM:
Quarrel sir! no sir.

SAMPSON:
If you do, sir, I am for you: I serve a man as good as you.

ABRAHAM:
Not better.

SAMPSON:
Well, sir.

GREGORY:
Say “better”: here is one of my master’s relatives.

SAMPSON:
Yes, better, sir.

ABRAHAM:
You lie.

SAMPSON:
Draw, if you are men. Gregory, remember your violent blow.

BENVOLIO:
Leave, you fools!
Put on your swords; you don't know what you're doing.

TYBALT:
What, are you drawn among these heartless deer?
Turn around, Benvolio, look at your death.

BENVOLIO:
I only keep the peace: raise your sword,
Or manage to separate these men from me.

TYBALT:
What, draw, and talk about peace! I hate the word,
How I hate hell, all the Montagues and you:
To you, coward!

First citizen:
Clubs, Bills and Supporters! strike! shoot them down!
Down with the Capulets! down with the Montagues!

CAPULET:
What noise is it? Give me my long sword, ho!

LADY CAPULET:
A crutch, a crutch! why call you for a sword?

CAPULET:
My sword, I say! Old Montague has arrived,
And brandished his blade despite myself.

ASSEMBLY :
You wicked Capulet, don't hold me back, let me go.

LADY MONTAGUE:
You will not move a foot to look for an enemy.

PRINCE:
Rebellious subjects, enemies of peace,
Desecrators of this steel stained by the neighbor,
Won't they hear? What, ho! you men, you beasts,
Who extinguishes the fire of your pernicious rage
With purple fountains flowing from your veins,
Under penalty of torture, from these bloody hands
Throw your damaged weapons to the ground,
And listen to the sentence of your moved prince.
Three civil fights, born from an airy word,
By you, old Capulet and Montague,
I have three times disturbed the calm of our streets,
And made former citizens of Verona
Thrown away by their ornaments worthy of their tomb,
Handling old partisans, in such old hands,
Canker of peace, to separate your hatred from canker:
If you ever disturb our streets again,
Your lives will pay the price for peace.
This time, everyone else is leaving:
You Capulet; will accompany me:
And, Montague, come this afternoon,
To know our further pleasure in this matter,
Towards the Old Free City, our common place of judgment.
Once again, under penalty of death, all the men leave.

ASSEMBLY :
Who gave a new dimension to this old feud?
Speak up, nephew, were you there when this started?

BENVOLIO:
Here are the servants of your adversary,
And yours, close combat before I approach:
I drew to separate them: the moment has come
The fiery Tybalt, with his sword prepared,
Which, as he whispered defiance into my ears,
He turned his head and cut off the winds,
To whom nothing hurt, he hissed with contempt:
While we exchanged blows and blows,
I came more and more and fought partly,
Until the prince came, who separated the two parties.

LADY MONTAGUE:
O, where is Romeo? have you seen him today?
I'm really glad he wasn't at that scrimmage.

BENVOLIO:
Madam, an hour before the sun adored
I looked through the golden east window,
A troubled spirit impelled me to go abroad;
Where, under the sycamore grove
Which takes root in the west side of the city,
It was so early that I saw your son while walking:
I went towards him, but he was wary of me
And he slipped into the secret of the wood:
I, measuring his affections by my own means,
That most are busy when they are most alone,
I pursued my humor without pursuing his,
And I gladly avoided him who gladly shunned me.

ASSEMBLY :
We saw him there many mornings,
With tears increasing the fresh dew of the morning.
Adding more clouds to the clouds with his deep sighs;
But all this as soon as the encouraging sun
Should he, in the far east, start drawing
The shadowy curtains of Aurora's bed,
Far from the light flies home my heavy son,
And the soldier locks himself in his room,
Close your windows, lock out the daylight
And an artificial night is created:
This humor must be dark and sinister,
Unless good advice can make the cause disappear.

BENVOLIO:
My noble uncle, do you know the cause?

ASSEMBLY :
I don't know and I can't learn more about him.

BENVOLIO:
Did you bother him in any way?

ASSEMBLY :
By myself and many other friends:
But he, counselor of his own affections,
Is it for himself--I won't say how true it is--
But to himself so secret and so close,
So far from probing and discovery,
Like the bud bitten by an envious worm,
Before it can spread its sweet leaves into the air,
Or dedicate its beauty to the sun.
Could we only learn where his sorrows originate.
We would be as gladly curative as we know how.

BENVOLIO:
See where he's coming: then please step aside;
I will know his grievance, or I will be widely denied.

ASSEMBLY :
I wish you were so happy with your stay,
To hear the truth. Come, madam, let's go.

BENVOLIO:
Hello cousin.

ROMEO:
Is the day so young?

BENVOLIO:
But nine o'clock struck.

ROMEO:
Yes me! the sad hours seem long.
Was it my father who left so quickly?

BENVOLIO:
It was. What sadness lengthens Romeo's hours?

ROMEO:
Not having that makes them small.

BENVOLIO:
Lover?

ROMEO:
Out--

BENVOLIO:
Of love?

ROMEO:
Out of his favor, where I am in love.

BENVOLIO:
Alas, this love, so sweet in his eyes,
This should be so tyrannical and so hard to prove!

ROMEO:
Alas, this love, the sight of which is still stifled,
Must, without eyes, see the paths leading to his will!
Where are we going to have dinner? O me! What fight was going on here?
But don't tell me, because I've heard everything.
This has a lot to do with hatred, but more to do with love.
Well, oh brawling love! O loving hatred!
O anything, anything, create first!
O heavy lightness! serious vanity!
