Distorted chaos of shapes that look good!
Plume of lead, bright smoke, cold fire,
sick health!
Sleep while still awake, that's not it!
This love, I feel it, I who feel no love in this.
Aren't you laughing?

BENVOLIO:
No, because I prefer to cry.

ROMEO:
Good heart, for what?

BENVOLIO:
To the oppression of your good heart.

ROMEO:
Well, such is the transgression of love.
My own sorrows weigh heavily in my chest,
That you will propagate, so that it remains
With more of yours: that love you showed
This adds even more heartache to too much of my own suffering.
Love is a smoke that rises with the smoke of sighs;
To be purged, a fire sparkling in the eyes of lovers;
To be vexed by a sea nourished by the tears of lovers:
What else is it? a most discreet madness,
A stifling gall and a preservative candy.
Farewell, my cousin.

BENVOLIO:
Soft! I go ;
And if you leave me like this, you're hurting me.

ROMEO:
But I got lost; I'm not here;
It's not Romeo, it's another where.

BENVOLIO:
Tell me with sadness, who do you love.

ROMEO:
What, should I moan and tell you?

BENVOLIO:
Groan! why no.
But unfortunately, tell me who.

ROMEO:
Tell a sad sick person to make his will:
Ah, evil words to one who is so ill!
Unfortunately, cousin, I love a woman.

BENVOLIO:
I aimed so close, when I thought you liked it.

ROMEO:
A real good shooter! And she's blonde, I love it.

BENVOLIO:
A good grade just, just because, is hit the earliest.

ROMEO:
Well, in this shot you miss: she won't be hit
With Cupid's arrow; she has the spirit of Dian;
And, as proof of chastity, well armed,
From the weak childish bow of love she lives unscathed.
She will not resist the siege of amorous terms,
Nor wait for the encounter of aggressive looks,
Nor open his knees to holy-seductive gold:
Oh, she is rich in beauty, only poor,
That when she dies with beauty, her store dies.

BENVOLIO:
So she swore she would always live chaste?

ROMEO:
She did it, and by saving this she generates enormous waste,
For the beauty hungry for its severity
Cut off the beauty of all posterity.
She is too fair, too wise, wisely too fair,
To deserve happiness by making me despair:
She gave up loving, and in this vow
Do I live dead and live to tell now.

BENVOLIO:
Be governed by me, forget to think about her.

ROMEO:
O, teach me how to forget to think.

BENVOLIO:
By giving freedom to your eyes;
Examine other beauties.

ROMEO:
It's like that
To qualify hers as exquisite, in question more:
These joyful masks that kiss the eyebrows of beautiful ladies
Being black makes us think they are hiding the fair;
He who is blinded cannot forget
The precious treasure of his lost sight:
Show me a mistress who looks good,
What is the use of its beauty, if not as a note
Where can I read who passed this passing fair?
Farewell: you can't teach me to forget.

BENVOLIO:
I will pay for this doctrine, or I will die in debt.

CAPULET:
But Montague is bound as well as I,
Also for penalties; and it's not difficult, I think,
For men as old as us to keep the peace.

PARIS:
You are both honorable;
And it's a shame that you lived at odds for so long.
But now, my lord, what do you say about my trial?

CAPULET:
But I repeat what I already said:
My child is, however, a stranger in the world;
She hasn't seen change in fourteen years,
Let two more summers fade in their pride,
We might think she was ready to become a wife.

PARIS:
Younger than her, they are happy mothers.

CAPULET:
And too soon those that were made so early are wasted.
The earth has swallowed up all my hopes but it,
She is the hopeful lady of my land:
But court her, sweet Paris, recover her heart,
My desire to obtain his consent is only part;
And she agrees, within the limits of her choice
Lies my consent and just according to my voice.
Tonight I'm throwing a regular old party,
Where I invited many guests,
As I like; and you, among the store,
One more, welcome, increases my number.
In my poor house, look at this night
Stars that walk the Earth and light up the dark sky:
Such comfort that vigorous young men feel
When April well dressed on the heel
Lame winter walks, even such a delight
Among the fresh feminine buds you will be this night
Inherit at home; I hear everything, I see everything,
And as the one whose merit will be greatest:
Which, on a larger scale, among many others, mine is one
Perhaps in number, but without counting any,
Come, come with me.
Come on, sir, trudge on
By the Verona fair; find these people
Whose names are written there, and tell them:
My house and welcome for their pleasure stay.

Servant:
Discover those whose names are written here! It is
written, that the shoemaker must mind his own
yard, and the tailor with his last, the fisherman with
his pencil, and the painter with his nets; but I am
sent to find the people whose names are here
written, and I never find the name of the writing
no one here has a brief. I must address the scholars. - In proper time.

BENVOLIO:
But, man, one fire burns another's burn,
One pain is alleviated by the anguish of another;
Become dizzy and be helped by turning backwards;
One desperate sorrow heals with the languor of another:
Get a new infection in your eye,
And the infamous poison of the old will die.

ROMEO:
Your plaintain sheet is excellent for this.

BENVOLIO:
For what, I pray you?

ROMEO:
For your broken shin.

BENVOLIO:
Why, Romeo, are you crazy?

ROMEO:
Not crazy, but bound more than crazy;
Locked up in prison, kept without my food,
Whipped and tormented and... God, good boy.

Servant:
God give it to God. Please, sir, can you read?

ROMEO:
Yes, my own fortune in my misery.

Servant:
Perhaps you learned it without a book: but, I
Please, can you read everything you see?

ROMEO:
Yes, if I know the letters and the language.

Servant:
You honestly say: rest, cheerful!

ROMEO:
Stay, my friend; I can read.
“Signor Martino, his wife and daughters;
the county of Anselme and its sisters-in-law; the Lady
widow of Vitravio; Signior Placentio and his charming
nieces; Mercutio and his brother Valentine; mine
Uncle Capulet, his wife and daughters; my beautiful niece
Rosaline; Livia; Signior Valentio and his cousin
Tybalt, Lucio and lively Helena. A fair
assembly: where should they come?

Servant:
Up.

ROMEO:
Or?

Servant:
Supper; to our house.

ROMEO:
Whose house?

Servant:
My teacher.

ROMEO:
Actually, I should have asked you first.

Servant:
Now I will tell you without asking: my master is the
the great rich Capulet; and if you're not from home
de Montagues, please come and crush a cup of wine.
Rest happily!

BENVOLIO:
At that same old Capulet party
Imagine the beautiful Rosaline that you love so much,
With all the admired beauties of Verona:
Go for it ; and, with an unknown eye,
Compare his face with some that I will show,
And I will make you believe that your swan is a raven.

ROMEO:
When the pious religion of my eyes
Maintains such a lie, then turns her tears into fires;
And those who often drowned could never die,
Transparent heretics, be burned for liars!
A more beautiful one than my love! the sun that sees everything
I have never seen his equal since the creation of the world.

BENVOLIO:
But you saw her beautiful, no one else was there,
Itself in balance with itself in each eye:
But in this crystal balance, we can weigh
Your wife's love against another maid
That I will show you brilliant at this party,
And it will hardly show what is now more visible.

ROMEO:
I'll go, nothing like that to show,
But to rejoice in my own splendor.

LADY CAPULET:
Nurse, where is my daughter? call her to me.

Nurse:
Now, near my virginity, at twelve years old,
I told him to come. What, lamb! what, ladybug!
God forgives! Where is this girl? What, Juliette!

JULIET:
How now! who calls ?

Nurse:
Your mother.

JULIET:
Madam, I am here.
What is your will?

LADY CAPULET:
Here is the question: nurse, give leave for a moment,
We must speak in secret: nurse, come back;
I remember me, you heard our advice.
You know that my daughter is of a beautiful age.

Nurse:
My goodness, I can give his age up to an hour.

LADY CAPULET:
She's not fourteen.

Nurse:
I will put fourteen of my teeth,--
And yet, let it be said about my teeth, I only have four...
She's not fourteen. How much time is left now
At the Lammas tide?

LADY CAPULET:
A fortnight and odd days.

Nurse:
Even or odd, every day of the year,
Come Lammas Eve, she will be fourteen.
Susan and her--God rest all Christian souls!--
We were of an age: well, Susan is with God;
She was too good for me: but, as I said,
On the night of Lammas, she will be fourteen years old;
This is what she will marry; I remember it well.
It has now been eleven years since the earthquake;
And she was weaned, I will never forget it.
Of all the days of the year, on this day:
Because I then put wormwood in my burrow,
Sitting in the sun under the wall of the dovecote;
Monsignor and you were then in Mantua:
No, I have a brain: but, as I said,
When he tasted wormwood on the nipple
From my dug and I felt it bitter, rather stupid,
To see him irritable and quarreling with the dug!
Shake, said the dovecote: it was not necessary, I think,
To make me walk painfully:
And since then it has been eleven years;
For then she could stand alone; no, near the rood screen,
She could have run and waddled anywhere;
Because just the day before, she broke her forehead:
And then my husband, may God be with his soul!
A' was a cheerful man - he took the child:
“Yes,” he said, “are you falling on your face?”
You will fall back when you have more spirit;
Isn't that right, Jule? and, by my vacation,
The pretty wretch left crying and said “Yes.”
Now let's see how a joke will turn out!
I guarantee it, and I should live a thousand years,
I should never forget: “Will you, Jule? he said;
And, stupid enough, he stopped and said “Yes.”

LADY CAPULET:
Enough of that; Please be quiet.

Nurse:
Yes, madam: yet I can only laugh,
Saying he should leave crying and say “Yes”.
And yet, I guarantee it, he had on his forehead
A bump as big as a cock's stone;
A perplexed blow; and he cried bitterly:
“Yes,” said my husband, “are you falling on your face?”
You will fall back when you grow old;
Isn't that right, Jule? he hesitated and said “Yes”.

JULIET:
And you too, please, nurse, I said.

Nurse:
Peace, I did it. God reserves his grace for you!
You were the prettiest baby I ever breastfed:
And I might live to see you married once,
I have my wish.

LADY CAPULET:
Getting married, this “getting married” is the very theme
I came to talk about it. Tell me, my daughter Juliette,
How ready are you to get married?

JULIET:
It’s an honor I couldn’t dream of.

Nurse:
An honor! Was I not your only nurse,
I would say you have sucked wisdom from your breast.

LADY CAPULET:
Well, think about marriage now; younger than you,
Here in Verona, ladies of esteem,
Are already made mothers: in my opinion,
I was your mother during those years
That you are now a maid. So in short:
The valiant Paris seeks you for his love.

Nurse:
A man, young woman! madam, such a man
Like everyone else... well, he's a wax man.

LADY CAPULET:
Verona summer has no such flower.

Nurse:
No, it's a flower; in faith, a very flower.

LADY CAPULET:
What you say? can you love this gentleman?
This night you will see him at our party;
Read the volume of young Paris's face,
And find pleasure written there with the pen of beauty;
Examine every married lineament,
And see how everyone lends content
And what is obscured in this beautiful volume lies
Find written in the depths of his eyes.
This precious book of love, this unbound lover,
To beautify it, all that is missing is a cover:
The fish lives in the sea, and it is a great pride
For the fair without the interior fair to hide:
This book in the eyes of many shares the glory,
He in the golden clasps locks up the golden story;
Then you will share everything he has,
By having it, you are doing nothing less.

Nurse:
Not less! no, bigger; women grow thanks to men.

LADY CAPULET:
Speak briefly, can you love Paris love?

JULIET:
I will look like, if you want to move:
But I won't stick my eye deeper
May your consent give the strength to make it fly.

Servant:
Madam, the guests have arrived, supper is served, you
called, my lady asked, the nurse swore
the pantry and everything extreme. I have to
therefore wait; Please follow straight ahead.

LADY CAPULET:
We follow you.
Juliette, the county remains.

Nurse:
Go, my daughter, look for happy nights and happy days.

ROMEO:
What, will this speech be given for our apology?
Or will we continue without apologizing?

BENVOLIO:
The date comes out of such prolixity:
We won't have a deceived Cupid with a scarf,
Carrying the painted slat arch of a Tartar,
Scare the ladies like a guardian of crows;
Nor no prologue without book, spoke weakly
After the prompter, for our entrance:
But let them measure us by what they want;
We will measure them and leave.

ROMEO:
Give me a torch: I am not for this loitering;
Being only heavy, I will bear the light.

MERCUTIO:
No, kind Romeo, you must dance.

ROMEO:
Not me, believe me: you have dancing shoes
With agile soles: I have a soul of lead
So I'm pinned to the ground, I can't move.

MERCUTIO:
You are a lover ; borrows Cupid's wings,
And soar with them above a common limit.

ROMEO:
I was pierced too badly by his handle
To soar with its light feathers, and thus bound,
I cannot limit a tone above a sad misfortune:
Under the heavy burden of love, I sink.

MERCUTIO:
And to sink into it, we must burden love;
Too great oppression for a tender thing.

ROMEO:
Is love a tender thing? it is too hard,
Too rude, too loud, and it stings like a thorn.

MERCUTIO:
If love is hard on you, be hard on love;
Poke love for the sake of poking, and you beat love.
Give me a case to put my face in:
A visor for a visor! what does it matter to me
What curious eye cites deformities?
Here are the beetle's eyebrows that will blush for me.

BENVOLIO:
Come, knock and enter; and barely entered,
But everyone put him back on his feet.

ROMEO:
A torch for me: let the wanton have a light heart
Tickle the senseless rushes with their heels,
Because I am proverbial with a grandfather phrase;
I will be a candle holder and I will watch.
The game has never been fairer, and I'm done.

MERCUTIO:
But, it's the mouse, it's the constable's own words:
If you're dun, we'll pull you out of the mud
Of this love of reverence, to which you hold
Up to the ears. Come, let's burn the day, ho!

ROMEO:
No, this is not the case.

MERCUTIO:
I mean, sir, late
We waste our lights in vain, like day lamps.
Take our good intention, for our judgment rests
Five times in there, before once in our five minds.

ROMEO:
And we have good intentions in opting for this mask;
But it's not a good idea to go there.

MERCUTIO:
Why, one may ask?

ROMEO:
I had a dream last night.

MERCUTIO:
And me too.

ROMEO:
Well, what was yours?

MERCUTIO:
That dreamers often lie.

ROMEO:
In bed, asleep, while they dream of real things.

MERCUTIO:
Oh, so I see Queen Mab was with you.
She is the midwife of the fairies and she comes
Shaped no bigger than an agate stone
On the index finger of an alderman,
Drawn with a team of little atoms
Through the noses of sleeping men;
Its chariot spokes made of long spider legs,
The covering of the grasshoppers' wings,
The traces of the smallest spider web,
The necklaces of the watery rays of moonlight,
His cricket bone whip, his film whip,
Its carter a little gray-haired gnat,
Not as big as a small roundworm
Stung by a servant's lazy finger;
His chariot is an empty nut
Made by the carpenter squirrel or the old worm,
Free time without thinking about the fairy bodybuilders.
And in this state, she gallops night after night
In the brains of lovers, and then they dream of love;
On the knees of the courtiers, who dream straight about the courtiers,
O'er the fingers of lawyers, who dream directly of fees,
O'er lips of ladies, who directly dream of kisses,
That often the angry Mab with plague blisters,
Because their breaths soiled with treats are:
Sometimes she gallops on a courtier's nose,
And then he dreams that he smells a suit;
And sometimes she comes with a tithe pigtail
Tickle a priest's nose while he sleeps,
Then he dreams of another benefit:
Sometimes it passes over a soldier's neck,
And then he dreams of slitting the throats of strangers,
Breaches, ambushes, Spanish blades,
Of a deep health of five fathoms; and then immediately
Drums in his ear, to which he jumps and wakes up,
And being so afraid, swear a prayer or two
And sleeps again. That's it Mab
Who raises the horses' manes at night,
And cooks the elves in filthy slut hairs,
Which once unraveled, many misfortunes bode:
It's the witch, when the maids lie on their backs,
This presses them and first teaches them to endure,
By making women of good behavior:
It's her--

ROMEO:
Peace, peace, Mercutio, peace!
You don't talk about anything.

MERCUTIO:
It's true, I'm talking about dreams,
What are the children of an idle brain,
Spawned from nothing but vain fancies,
Who is as thin as air
And more fickle than the wind, which courts
Even now, the frozen bosom of the north,
And being angry, he went away from there,
Turning his face towards the south falling with dew.

BENVOLIO:
This wind, of which you speak, takes us away from ourselves;
Dinner is over and we will arrive too late.

ROMEO:
I fear it's too soon: for my mind is wandering
Consequences still hanging in the stars
Must bitterly begin his terrible tryst
With tonight's festivities and expire the term
Of a despised life locked in my bosom
By some ignoble abandonment of an untimely death.
But He, who directs my path,
Steer my sail! Come on, strong gentlemen.

BENVOLIO:
Strike, drum.

First Servant:
Where is Potpan, whom he helps not to take away? He
move a slicer? he scrapes a slicer!

When good manners all depend on one or two men
hands and they are not washed too, it is a filthy thing.

No more common stools, remove it
yard cupboard, look in the plate. Okay, save

Yes, boy, ready.

First Servant:
You are sought and called, asked and

We can't be here and there too. Happy, boys; be

CAPULET:
Welcome gentlemen! ladies who have their toes
People without corns will have a fight with you.
Ah ha, my mistresses! which one of you
Will he now refuse to dance? she who makes you delicate,
She, I swear, has corns; do I come closer to you now?
Welcome gentlemen! I saw the day
That I wore a visor and I could tell
A story whispered in the ear of a beautiful lady,
As you wish: here we go, here we go, here we go:
You're welcome, gentlemen! come, musicians, play.
A room, a room! leave some space! and put your foot down, girls.
No more light, rascals; and turn the situation around,
And turn off the heat, the room is getting too hot.
Ah, sir, this unexpected sport is coming along well.
No, sit down, no, sit down, good cousin Capulet;
For you and me, our dancing days are past:
How long has it been since the last time you and I
Were you masked?

Second Capulet:
By madame, thirty years old.

CAPULET:
What a man! it's not so much, it's not so much:
It is since Lucentio's wedding,
Come to Pentecost as quickly as possible,
About twenty-five years old; and then we masked ourselves.

Second Capulet:
It's more, it's more, his son is the eldest, sir;
His son is thirty years old.

CAPULET:
Do you want to tell me that?
His son was just a ward two years ago.

ROMEO:

Servant:
I do not know sir.

ROMEO:
Oh, she teaches the torches to shine brightly!
It seems as if she clings to the cheek of the night
Like a rich jewel in an Ethiopian's ear;
Beauty is too rich to use, land is too expensive!
So shows a snowy dove in the company of crows,
As shown by this lady among her comrades.
Once the measurement is done, I will monitor his stand position,
And, touching his, bless my coarse hand.
Has my heart loved until now? give it up, view!
For I never saw true beauty until that night.

TYBALT:
This, from his voice, should be a Montague.
Go get me my rapier, boy. What dares the slave
Come here, covered with an ancient face,
Flee and despise our solemnity?
Now, by the valor and honor of my parents,
Beating him to death, I don't consider it a sin.

CAPULET:
Well, how, my relative! why bother yourself like this?

TYBALT:
My uncle, here is a Montague, our enemy,
A villain who came despite everything,
To despise our solemnity this night.

CAPULET:
Is this young Romeo?

TYBALT:
It's him, that bad Romeo.

CAPULET:
Be content, sweet coz, leave him alone;
He wears it like a portly gentleman;
And truth be told, Verona brags about it
To be a virtuous and well-governed youth:
I wouldn't do it for the wealth of the whole city
Here, at my house, denigrate him:
So be patient, don't pay attention to him:
This is my will, and if you respect it,
Show beautiful presence and push away those frowns,
And an appearance unsuitable for a feast.

TYBALT:
It is appropriate, when such a villain is a guest:
I won't stand for it.

CAPULET:
It will be endured:
What, my good boy! I say, he must: go to;
Am I the master here, or you? go to.
You won't be able to stand it! God will repair my soul!
You will provoke a mutiny among my guests!
You're going to do cock-a-hoop! you will be the man!

TYBALT:
Well, uncle, that's a shame.

CAPULET:
Come on;
You are an impertinent boy: aren't you, indeed?
This tip may hurt you, I know what:
You must upset me! get married, it's time.
Well said, my hearts! You are a prince; go:
Be quiet, or... More light, more light! Damage !
I'm going to shut you up. What, cheerfully, my heart!

TYBALT:
Forced patience with a voluntary meeting of anger
Makes my flesh tremble in their different salvation.
I will withdraw: but this intrusion will not
What now seems sweet turns into bitter gall.

ROMEO:

JULIET:
Good pilgrim, you do too much harm to your hand,
What polite devotion shows in this;
For the saints have hands that the hands of pilgrims touch,
And palm to palm is the sacred kiss of the palm trees.

ROMEO:
Don't the saints have lips, and the holy palm trees too?

JULIET:
Yes, pilgrim, lips they must use in prayer.

ROMEO:
O then, dear saint, let the lips do what the hands do;
They pray, grant it, lest faith turn to despair.

JULIET:
The saints do not move, although they hear him for the sake of their prayers.

ROMEO:
So don't move, while I take the effect of my prayer.
So from my lips, through yours, my sin is purged.

JULIET:
So let my lips bear the sin they have committed.

ROMEO:
Has sin left your lips? O intrusion gently encouraged!
Give me back my sin again.

JULIET:
You kiss by the book.

Nurse:
Madam, your mother wants to talk to you.

ROMEO:
Who is his mother?

Nurse:
Get married, single,
His mother is the mistress of the house,
And a good lady, and a wise and virtuous
I fed his daughter, and you talked with her;
I tell you, he who can grasp it
Must have the slots.

ROMEO:
Is she a Capulet?
O dear account! my life is the debt of my enemy.

BENVOLIO:
Go, go; the sport is at the top.

ROMEO:
Yes, that's what I fear; the greater my worry.

CAPULET:
No, gentlemen, prepare yourself not to leave;
We have a senseless and meaningless banquet.
Is this really the case? why, then, I thank you all
I thank you, honest gentlemen; Good night.
No more torches here! Come on, let's go to bed.
Ah, sir, in my opinion, it's getting late:
I am going to rest.

JULIET:
Come here, nurse. What is this gentleman?

Nurse:
The son and heir of old Tiberio.

JULIET:
What's coming out now?

Nurse:
Get married, I think it will be young Petrucio.

JULIET:
Who is next there who wouldn't want to dance?

Nurse:
I don't know.

JULIET:
Go ask him his name: if he is married.
My grave is like my wedding bed.

Nurse:
Its name is Romeo and Montague;
The only son of your great enemy.

JULIET:
My only love is born from my only hatred!
Too soon seen unknown, and known too late!
Prodigious birth of love is for me,
That I must love a hated enemy.

Nurse:
What is this? What is this?

JULIET:
A rhyme I learned even now
From one I danced with.

Nurse:
Anon, anon!
Come, let's go; the foreigners are all gone.

Chorus:
Now the old desire lies on its deathbed,
And young affection is gaping to be his heir;
This fair for which love groaned and died,
With the tender Juliette, it is no longer fair.
Now Romeo is loved and still loves,
Also captivated by the charm of looks,
But he had to complain to his enemy,
And she steals the sweet bait of love from the fearful hooks:
Being considered an enemy, he cannot have access
Expressing the vows that lovers used to swear;
And she is as much in love, she matters much less
To meet your new loved one anywhere:
But passion gives them the power, time means, to meet
Temper the ends with extreme gentleness.

ROMEO:
Can I move forward when my heart is there?
Return, dull earth, and find your center.

BENVOLIO:
Romeo! my cousin Romeo!

MERCUTIO:
He is wise ;
And, upon my lie, I took him home to bed.

BENVOLIO:
He ran this way and jumped this orchard wall:
Call, good Mercutio.

MERCUTIO:
No, I will also conjure.
Romeo! moods! mad! passion! lover!
Appear in the form of a sigh:
Say just one rhyme and I'm satisfied;
Cry but “Yes, me!” pronounce only “love” and “dove”;
Say a fair word to my gossip Venus,
A nickname for his blind son and heir,
Young Adam Cupid, the one who shot so well,
When King Cophetua loved the beggar woman!
He doesn't listen, he doesn't move, he doesn't move;
The monkey is dead and I must ward it off.
I conjure you through the shining eyes of Rosaline,
By his high forehead and his scarlet lip,
By her fine foot, her right leg and her quivering thigh
And the domains adjacent to it are,
May you appear to us in your likeness!

BENVOLIO:
And if he hears you, you will make him angry.

MERCUTIO:
This cannot make him angry: it would make him angry
To elevate the spirit in the circle of his mistress
Of a strange nature, leave it there
Until she put it down and invoked it;
It was spite: my invocation
Is fair and honest, and in the name of his mistress
I only conjure to relieve him.

BENVOLIO:
Come, he hid among these trees,
To accompany the humorous evening:
Blind is his love and is best suited to darkness.

MERCUTIO:
If love is blind, love cannot reach its target.
Now will he sit under a medlar tree,
And I wish his mistress had this kind of fruit
As the maids call the medlars, when they laugh alone.
Romeo, that she was, oh, that she was
An open et cetera, you a poperin pear!
Romeo, good night: I'm going to my trundle bed;
This camp bed is too cold for me to sleep:
Come on, shall we go?

BENVOLIO:
Go ahead; because it is in vain
To seek him here is not to be found.

ROMEO:
He mocks the scars who never felt hurt.
But sweet ! what light through this window breaks?
It is the east and Juliet is the sun.
Rise up, beautiful sun, and kill the envious moon,
Who is already sick and pale with grief,
That you, her servant, are much more beautiful than her:
Do not be her servant, since she is envious;
Its vestal livery is only sick and green
And only fools wear it; reject it.
This is my lady, oh, this is my love!
Oh, how she knew she was!
She speaks and she says nothing: what about?
His eyes speak; I will answer it.
I'm too bold, it's not me she's talking to:
Two of the most beautiful stars in the sky,
I have business, his eyes beg
To sparkle in their spheres until they return.
What if his eyes were there, in his head?
The shine of her cheek would put these stars to shame,
As daylight makes a lamp; his eyes in heaven
Would through the airy region flow such a brilliant stream
That the birds were singing and thinking it wasn't night.
See how she rests her cheek on her hand!
Oh, that I was a glove on this hand,
So I can touch that cheek!

JULIET:
Yes me!

ROMEO:
She speaks:
Oh, speak again, bright angel! because you are
As glorious as this night, being over my head
Just like a winged messenger from heaven
With white and amazed eyes
Mortals who fall back to look at him
When he steps over the lazy clouds
And sails through the air.

JULIET:
O Romeo, Romeo! why are you Romeo?
Deny your father and refuse your name;
Or, if you don't want it, swear to yourself, my love,
And I won't be a Capulet anymore.

ROMEO:

JULIET:
It is only your name that is my enemy;
You are yourself, but you are not a Montague.
What is Montague? it is neither a hand nor a foot,
Neither arms, nor face, nor any other part
Belonging to a man. Oh, be another name!
What's in a name? what we call a rose
By any other name it would smell just as good;
So would Romeo, if he were not called Romeo,
Preserve this dear perfection that he must
Without this title. Romeo, take away your name,
And for this name that is not part of you
Take it all myself.

ROMEO:
I take you at your word:
Call me but love, and I will be baptized again;
From now on I will never be Romeo again.

JULIET:
What man are you thus hidden in the night
So, are you stumbling upon my advice?

ROMEO:
By a name
I don't know how to tell you who I am:
My name, dear saint, is odious to me,
Because he is an enemy to you;
If I had written it, I would tear up the note.

JULIET:
My ears have not yet drunk a hundred words
Of the speech of this language, yet I know the sound:
Are you not Romeo and Montague?

ROMEO:
Neither, fair saint, if one or the other pleases you.

JULIET:
How did you come here, tell me, and why?
The orchard walls are high and difficult to climb,
And the place of death, considering who you are,
If one of my parents finds you here.

ROMEO:
With the light wings of love I flew over these walls;
For stony boundaries cannot hold love,
And what can love do that it dares to attempt?
This is why your parents are not allowed to me.

JULIET:
If they see you, they will kill you.

ROMEO:
Alas, there is more peril in your eyes
Than twenty of their swords: look at you but gentle,
And I am proof against their enmity.

JULIET:
I wouldn't want them to see you here for anything in the world.

ROMEO:
I have a night coat to hide me from their sight;
And but you love me, let them find me here:
My life would be better ended by their hatred,
That death has been postponed, for lack of your love.

JULIET:
Which way did you discover this place?

ROMEO:
By love, which first impelled me to inquire;
He lent me advice and I lent him eyes.
I am not a pilot; yet, were you that far away
Like this vast shore bathed by the most distant sea,
I would venture for such merchandise.

JULIET:
You know that the mask of the night is on my face,
Otherwise a girl would blush on my cheek
For what you heard me say tonight
I would like to dwell on the form, I would like, I would deny
What I said: but goodbye compliment!
Do you love me ? I know you'll say "Yes",
And I will take your word for it: but if you swear,
You can prove yourself wrong; to the perjury of lovers
Then say: Jupiter laughs. O sweet Romeo,
If you love, pronounce it faithfully:
Or if you think I'm won too quickly,
I'll frown and be perverted and tell you no,
Then you will court; but otherwise, not for the world.
Truly, handsome Montague, I love too much,
And this is why you can think that my behavior is light:
But believe me, sir, I'll prove more true
Than those who have more cunning to be strange.
I should have been stranger, I must admit,
But you heard it, before I knew it,
The passion of my true love: forgive me then,
And do not attribute this surrender to light love,
That the dark night thus discovered.

ROMEO:
Madam, by this blessed moon, I swear
Who silver tips all these fruit tree tops...

JULIET:
Oh, don't swear by the moon, the fickle moon,
Than the monthly changes in its circled orb,
Lest your love also prove variable.

ROMEO:
What should I swear by?

JULIET:
Don't swear at all;
Or, if you wish, swear by your grace,
Who is the god of my idolatry,
And I will believe you.

ROMEO:
If my heart is my dear love...

JULIET:
Well, do not swear: although I rejoice in you,
I have no joy from this contract tonight:
It is too rash, too imprudent, too sudden;
Too similar to lightning that ceases to be
Before you can say, “It’s clearing up.” Sweet, good night!
This bud of love, by the ripening breath of summer,
This could prove to be a beautiful flower the next time we meet.
Good night Good Night! like a sweet rest and rest
Come to your heart as to that of my chest!

ROMEO:
Oh, will you leave me so unsatisfied?

JULIET:
What satisfaction can you have this evening?

ROMEO:
The exchange of your love's faithful wish for mine.

JULIET:
I gave you mine before you asked:
And yet I would love to give back.

ROMEO:
Would you like to remove it? for what purpose, my love?

JULIET:
But to be frank, and give it back to you.
And yet I wish, but for what I have:
My generosity is as boundless as the sea,
My love as deep; the more I give you,
The more I have, because both are infinite.
I hear a noise inside; dear love, farewell!
Anon, good nurse! Sweet Montague, be true.
Stay a little longer, I'll come back.

ROMEO:
O blessed and blessed night! I am scared.
Being night, it's all a dream,
Too flattering-sweet to be substantial.

JULIET:
Three words, dear Romeo, and good night.
If your love is honorable,
Your wedding plan, send me a note tomorrow,
By him whom I will bring to you,
Where and at what time will you perform the rite;
And all my fortune at your feet, I will place it
And follow you my lord throughout the world.

Nurse:

JULIET:
I'm coming soon. But if you don't have good intentions,
I beg you...

Nurse:

JULIET:
Little by little, I arrive :--
To stop your trial and leave me to my sorrow:
Tomorrow I will send.

ROMEO:
So prosper my soul...

JULIET:
Good night a thousand times!

ROMEO:
A thousand times worse, wanting your light.
Love goes towards love, like schoolchildren
their books,
But love for love, towards school with heavy looks.

JULIET:
History! Romeo, hist! O, for the voice of a falconer,
To attract that sweetness of pompoms again!
Bondage is hoarse and cannot speak out loud;
Otherwise, I would tear apart the cave where Echo is,
And make his airy tongue hoarser than mine,
With repetition of my Romeo's name.

ROMEO:
It is my soul that calls upon my name:
As the tongues of lovers ring sweet and silvery at night,
Like the sweetest music for attentive ears!

JULIET:
Romeo!

ROMEO:
My dear?

JULIET:
At what time tomorrow
Should I send you?

ROMEO:
At nine o'clock.

JULIET:
I will not fail: there will be twenty years.
I forgot why I called you back.

ROMEO:
Let me stay here until you remember.

JULIET:
I will forget, so that you are always there,
I remember how much I love your company.

ROMEO:
And I will always stay, so that you forget again,
Forget any other house than this one.

JULIET:
It's almost morning; I would have made you leave:
And yet no further than a wanton bird;
Who lets it jump a little from his hand,
Like a poor prisoner in his twisted gyves,
And with a silken thread he takes it back,
So in love and jealous of his freedom.

ROMEO:
I would like to be your bird.

JULIET:
Sweet, me too:
Yet I should kill you with great dearness.
Good night Good Night! the separation is such
sweet sorrow,
That I will say good night to you until tomorrow.

ROMEO:
Sleep remains in your eyes, peace in your bosom!
Would I have sleep and peace, so sweet to rest!
That's why I go to my ghostly father's cell,
Its help to desire, and my dear luck to tell.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
The gray-eyed morning smiles at the sullen night,
Tiles the oriental clouds with streaks of light,
And the dark dappled like a drunk spins
From the Path of the Fourth Day and the Fiery Wheels of Titan:
Now, before the sun sets forth its burning eye,
The day to rejoice and the wet dew of the night to dry,
I have to fill our wicker cage
With harmful weeds and flowers with precious juice.
The earth, mother of nature, is her tomb;
What is his grave, what is his womb,
And from her womb children of various kinds
We suck her natural tits discovery,
Much for many excellent virtues,
None but for some and yet all different.
O, Mickle is the mighty grace that resides
In herbs, plants, stones, and their true qualities:
Because nothing so vile lives on earth
But to the earth some particular good gives,
Nor anything so good but constrained by this fair use
Revolts from the real birth, stubborn against abuse:
Virtue itself becomes vice, being poorly applied;
And vice sometimes through worthy action.
In the infantile bark of this little flower
The poison has the power of residence and medicine:
For this, being felt, with this part applauds each part;
Being tasted, kills all the senses with the heart.
Two kings so opposed always camp them
In man as in herbs, grace and gross will;
And where the worst prevails,
Soon the canker eats away at this plant.

ROMEO:
Hello, father.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
Benedict!
What ancient language, so sweet, greets me?
Young son, that makes a sick head worth it
So, I wish you good morning in your bed soon:
Care keeps his watch in every old man's eye,
And where worry resides, sleep will never reside;
But where an intact youth with an unstuffed brain
He lies down his limbs, there reigns a golden sleep:
This is why your precociousness assures me
You are awakened by some bad temperature;
Or if it doesn't, then I got it right,
Our Romeo didn't go to bed last night.

ROMEO:
This last point is true; the sweetest rest was for me.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
God forgives sin! were you with Rosaline?

ROMEO:
With Rosaline, my ghostly father? No;
I forgot this name, and this name is a misfortune.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
He's my good son: but where have you been?

ROMEO:
I'll tell you before you ask me again.
I feasted with my enemy,
Where suddenly I was hurt,
It is by me injured: our two remedies
In your help and your holy physics are found:
I bear no hatred, blessed man, for behold,
My intercession also strengthens my enemy.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
Be clear, good son, and simple in your conduct;
Enigmatic confessions, but enigmatic discoveries.

ROMEO:
So know clearly that the dear love of my heart is settled
On the beautiful daughter of the rich Capulet:
Like mine on his, so his is placed on mine;
And everything combined, except what you have to combine
Through holy matrimony: when, where and how
We met, we courted and exchanged vows,
I'll tell you in passing; but that's what I pray,
That you agree to marry us today.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
Saint Francis, what a change here!
Did Rosaline, whom you loved so much,
So quickly abandoned? The love of young men lies then
Not really in their hearts, but in their eyes.
Jesu Maria, what a briny affair
I washed your yellowed cheeks for Rosaline!
How much salt water is thrown into waste,
To season love, it has no taste!
The sun does not yet dissipate your sighs from the sky,
Your old moans still ring in my old ears;
Behold, here on your cheek the stain lies
From an old tear that is not yet washed:
If you were ever yourself and these misfortunes were yours,
You and these misfortunes were all for Rosaline:
And are you changed? then say this sentence,
Women can fall when men have no strength.

ROMEO:
You have often criticized me for loving Rosaline.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
To worship, not to love, raise mine.

ROMEO:
And it's bad for me to bury love.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
Not in a grave,
To put one in, another to have.

ROMEO:
Please do not reprimand yourself; her that I love now
Do grace for grace's sake and love for love's sake permit it?
The other didn't.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
O, she knew well
Your love read by heart and didn't know how to spell.
But come, young waver, come, come with me,
In one respect, I will be your assistant;
For this alliance can so happily prove,
To transform the resentment in your home into pure love.

ROMEO:
O! let's go; I stand in sudden haste.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
Wisely and slowly; they stumble and run quickly.

MERCUTIO:
Where the hell should this Romeo be?
Didn't he come home this evening?

BENVOLIO:
Not at his father's house; I spoke with her man.

MERCUTIO:
Ah, that same pale girl with a hard heart, that Rosaline.
Torments him so much that he will certainly go crazy.

BENVOLIO:
Tybalt, kinsman of old Capulet,
Sent a letter to his father's house.

MERCUTIO:
A challenge, on my life.

BENVOLIO:
Romeo will answer it.

MERCUTIO:
Any man who knows how to write can respond to a letter.

BENVOLIO:
No, he will answer the master of the letter, how he
dare, be daring.

MERCUTIO:
Alas, poor Romeo! he is already dead; stabbed with a
black eye of the white girl; shot in the ear with a
love song; the very pin of his heart split with the
the shaft of the boy with the blind bow: and is he a man to
meet Tybalt?

BENVOLIO:
Why, what is Tybalt?

MERCUTIO:
More than prince of cats, I can tell you that. Oh, he is
the courageous captain of compliments. He fights like
you sing spicy songs, you keep time, distance and
proportion; I rest my minimum rest, one, two, and
the third in your breast: the butcher of a silk
button, a duelist, a duelist; a gentleman from
very first house, of the first and second cause:
ah, the immortal past! the point reverso! THE
Hey!

BENVOLIO:
The what?

MERCUTIO:
The pox of such antiquity, lisping, affecting
fantastic; these new accent tuners! 'By Jesus,
a very good blade! a very tall man! a very good
whore!' Well, isn't it a lamentable thing,
grandfather, may we be thus afflicted with
these strange flies, these fashion merchants, these
Perdona-mi's, who stand so on the new form,
that they can't be comfortable on the old bench? Oh, their
bones, their bones!

BENVOLIO:
This is Romeo, this is Romeo.

MERCUTIO:
Without its eggs, like a dried herring: flesh, flesh,
how are you fished! Now it's him for the numbers
that Petrarch flocked: Laura for his lady was only a
kitchen maid; get married, she had a better love for
make him rhyme; Dido was poor; Cleopatra a gypsy;
Helen and Hero Hildings and Prostitutes; It's a gray
eye or other, but not to the point. Signor
Romeo, hello! there is a French greeting
to your French slope. You gave us the counterfeit
enough last night.

ROMEO:
Hello to both of you. What counterfeit have I given you?

MERCUTIO:
The ship, sir, the hold; you can't conceive?

ROMEO:
Pardon me, good Mercutio, my business was great; and in
in a case like mine, a man can be courteous.

MERCUTIO:
That is to say, a case like yours
forced a man to bow in the hams.

ROMEO:
That is to say at court.

MERCUTIO:
You hit him very nicely.

ROMEO:
A most courteous exhibition.

MERCUTIO:
No, I am the very pink of courtesy.

ROMEO:
Rose for flower.

MERCUTIO:
RIGHT.

ROMEO:
Well, then my pomp is indeed flowery.

MERCUTIO:
Well said: follow this joke now until you get it
your pump is worn out, only when the only sole of it
is carried, the joke can remain after the unique port in the singular.

ROMEO:
O joke with only one sole, unique only for the
single.

MERCUTIO:
Between us, good Benvolio; my mind fades.

ROMEO:
Switch and spurs, switch and spurs; or I'll cry a match.

MERCUTIO:
No, if your mind goes on a wild goose chase, I have
done, because you have more wild goose in one of the
your spirit which, I am sure, I have in all of my five:
Was I with you there for the goose?

ROMEO:
You were never with me for anything when you were
not there for the goose.

MERCUTIO:
I'm going to bite your ear off for that joke.

ROMEO:
No, good goose, don't bite.

MERCUTIO:
Your spirit is a very bitter sweetness; It's a plus
hot sauce.

ROMEO:
And isn't it well served in a sweet goose?

MERCUTIO:
O, here is a spirit of Cheveril, which extends from a
narrow inch to a wide yardstick!

ROMEO:
I extend it for this word “broad”; who added
to the goose, you are by far a big goose.

MERCUTIO:
Why, isn't it better now than to moan with love?
now you are sociable, now you are Romeo; now the art
you what you are, by art as well as by nature:
because this talkative love is like a great natural,
who runs up and down to hide his trinket in a hole.

BENVOLIO:

Killed ten thousand Tybalts. The death of Tybalt
It was bad enough if everything had stopped there:
Or, if bitter woe rejoices in companionship
And it will necessarily be classed among other sorrows,
Why didn't she follow him, when she said "Tybalt is dead",
Your father, or your mother, no, or both,
What modern laments could have moved?
But with a rearguard after Tybalt's death,
"Romeo is banished", to pronounce this word,
Did the father, the mother, Tybalt, Romeo, Juliet,
All killed, all dead. “Romeo is banished!”
There is no end, no limit, no measure, no limit,
In the death of this word; no words can express this misfortune.
Where are my father and my mother, nurse?

Nurse:
Weeping and wailing over Tybalt's corpse:
Will you go to them? I will take you there.

JULIET:
They wash his wounds with tears: mine will be spent,
When theirs are dry, for the banishment of Romeo.
Take back these strings: poor strings, you are deceived,
You and me ; because Romeo is exiled:
He has prepared you for a road leading to my bed;
But I, a servant, die a widow.
Come, ropes, come, nurse; I am going to my wedding bed;
And death, not Romeo, take my virginity!

Nurse:
Hello in your room: I will find Romeo
To console you: I know where he is.
Listen, your Romeo will be there at night:
I go to him; he is hidden in Laurence's cell.

JULIET:
Oh, find it! give this ring to my true knight,
And tell him to come and say his last goodbyes.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
Romeo, come out; come out, fearful man:
Affliction is in love with your parts,
And you are married to calamity.

ROMEO:
Father, what news? what is the destiny of the prince?
What sadness needs knowledge from me,
What I don't know yet?

BROTHER LAURENCE:
Too familiar
Is my dear son in such bad company:
I bring you the news of the prince's fate.

ROMEO:
What's less than the day the world ends for the prince?

BROTHER LAURENCE:
A gentler judgment disappeared from his lips,
Not the death of the body, but the banishment of the body.

ROMEO:
Ha, banishment! be merciful, say “death”;
For exile has more terror in its eyes,
Much more than death: don’t say “banishment”.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
This is why you are banished from Verona:
Be patient, because the world is big and wide.

ROMEO:
There is no world without the walls of Verona,
But purgatory, torture, hell itself.
Therefore the outcast is banished from the world,
And exile from the world is death: then banished,
Is death misinterpreted: calling death banishment,
You cut off my head with a golden ax,
And I smile at the blow that kills me.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
O mortal sin! O gross ingratitude!
Your fault, our law calls for death; but the kind prince,
By taking your side, you set aside the law,
And I transformed this black word, death, into banishment:
It's a dear mercy, and you don't see it.

ROMEO:
It is torture and not pity: paradise is here,
Where Juliette lives; and every cat and dog
And little mouse, everything unworthy,
Live here in heaven and be able to contemplate it;
But Romeo cannot: no more validity,
A more honorable state, more court lives
In the carrion that Romeo: they are mine
On the white wonder of my dear Juliette's hand
And steal the immortal blessing from his lips,
Who even in pure and vestal modesty,
Always blush, as if you thought their own kisses were a sin;
But this may not be the case with Romeo; he is banned:
Flies can do this, but I have to fly:
They are free men, but I am banished.
And do you still say that exile is not death?
Did you not mix poison, nor a sharp knife,
No sudden death, although never so bad,
But “banished” to kill me? – “banned”?
O brother, the damned use this word in hell;
Howls accompany it: how is your heart,
Being a divine and ghostly confessor,
An absolute of sins, and my friend declared,
Mutilate myself with this word “banished”?

BROTHER LAURENCE:
You like the crazy, listen to me but say a word.

ROMEO:
Oh, you'll talk about banishment again.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
I will give you armor to avoid this word:
The sweet milk of adversity, philosophy,
To comfort you, even if you are banished.

ROMEO:
Yet “banned”? Hang up philosophy!
Unless philosophy can make a Juliet,
Move a city, reverse the destiny of a prince,
This doesn't help, it doesn't prevail: don't speak any more.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
Oh, then I see that fools have no ears.

ROMEO:
How should they do it, when the wise have no eyes?

BROTHER LAURENCE:
Let me argue with you about your domain.

ROMEO:
You can't talk about what you don't feel:
Were you as young as me, Juliette your love,
An hour but married, Tybalt murdered,
Loving like me and banished like me,
Then you could talk, then you could tear your hair out,
And fall to the ground, like I do now,
Take the measurement of an undug grave.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
Arise; someone knocked ; good Romeo, hide yourself.

ROMEO:
Not me ; unless the breath of the sick heart groans,
Like a mist, envelops me in the search of eyes.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
Listen, how they strike! Who is here? Romeo, get up;
You will be caught. Stay a little! Get up;
Run to my office. Gradually ! God's will,
What simplicity! I'm coming, I'm coming!
Who hits so hard? where do you come from ? what is your will?

Nurse:

BROTHER LAURENCE:
Welcome, then.

Nurse:
O holy brother, oh, tell me, holy brother,
Where is my lady's lord, where is Romeo?

BROTHER LAURENCE:
There, on the ground, with her own drunken tears.

Nurse:
Oh, it is even in the case of my mistress,
Just in his case! O awful sympathy!
Pitiful situation! Even so, she lies,
cry and cry, cry and cry.
Get up, get up; get up and be a man:
For Juliet's sake, for her sake, get up and stand up;
Why should you fall into such a deep O?

ROMEO:
Nurse!

Nurse:
Ah sir! ah sir! Well, death is the end of everything.

ROMEO:
Did you talk about Juliette? how are you with her?
Doesn't she consider me an old murderer,
Now I have sullied the childhood of our joy
With little blood removed from his?
Where is she? and how is she? and what does it say
My lady hidden from our canceled love?

Nurse:
Oh ! she says nothing, sir, but she cries and cries;
And now she falls on her bed; then starts,
And Tybalt calls; and then Romeo cries,
And then it falls again.

ROMEO:
As if this name,
Shot from the lethal level of a gun,
I murdered her; like the cursed hand of this name
She murdered her relative. Oh, tell me, brother, tell me,
In what vile part of this anatomy
Does my name remain? tell me, so I can lay off
The hateful mansion.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
Hold your desperate hand:
Are you a man? your form screams you are:
Your tears are feminine; your wild acts denote
The unreasonable fury of a beast:
An unseemly woman in a man who seems!
Or an unhealthy beast appearing to be both!
You amazed me: by my holy order,
I thought your character was more temperate.
Did you kill Tybalt? Do you want to kill yourself?
And also remain your lady who lives in you,
By making you really hate it?
Why do you insult your birth, heaven and earth?
Since birth, heaven and earth, all three meet
In you at the same time; that you would like to lose immediately.
Fi, fi, you shame your form, your love, your spirit;
Who, like a usurer, abounds in all,
And use none in this true use
Who should adorn your form, your love, your spirit:
Your noble form is only a form of wax,
Moving away from the value of a man;
Your dear love sworn but hollow perjury,
Kill this love you swore to cherish;
Your spirit, this ornament to shape and love,
Deformed in the conduct of both,
Like powder in the flask of a soldier without skill,
Is inflamed by your own ignorance,
And you were dismembered in your own defense.
What, wake up, man! your Juliette is alive,
For whose love you had recently died;
You are happy there: Tybalt would kill you,
But you killed Tybalt; there you are happy too:
The law that threatened death becomes your friend
And transforms him into exile; there you are happy:
A bundle of blessings lights up on your back;
Happiness woos you in its most beautiful finery;
But, like an ill-bred and sullen girl,
You pout about your fortune and your love:
Be careful, be careful, because these people die miserable.
Go, go to your love, as it was decreed,
Go up to her room and comfort her:
But look, don't stay until the watch is set,
Because then you cannot go to Mantua;
Where you will live, until we can find a time
To ignite your marriage, reconcile your friends,
Ask the prince for forgiveness and remember
With twenty hundred thousand times more joy
So you went out wailing.
Go ahead, nurse: recommend me to your lady;
And tell him to hurry the whole house to bed,
To what heavy sadness makes them apt:
Romeo arrives.

Nurse:
O Lord, I could have stayed here all night
To hear good advice: O, what is learning!
Monsignor, I will tell my lady that you will come.

ROMEO:
Do it, and ask my sweetheart to prepare to scold you.

Nurse:
Here, sir, is a ring that she asked me to give you, sir:
Hey, hurry up because it's getting really late.

ROMEO:
How this revives my comfort!

BROTHER LAURENCE:
Go; Good night; and here is your entire state:
Either you leave before the watch is set,
Or at dawn, disguised from here:
Stay in Mantua; I'm going to discover your man,
And it will mean from time to time
All the good fortunes that come your way here:
Give me your hand ; it's late: goodbye; Good night.

ROMEO:
But let a past joy call me,
It was such a brief sorrow to part with you: Farewell.

CAPULET:
Things went wrong, sir, so unfortunately,
That we didn't have time to move our daughter:
Look, she loved her kinsman Tybalt very much,
And me too:--Well, we were born to die.
It's very late, she won't come down this evening:
I promise you, but for your company,
I would have been in bed an hour ago.

PARIS:
These times of misfortune leave us no time to woo.
Madam, good evening: recommend me to your daughter.

LADY CAPULET:
I will do it, and I will know his opinion early tomorrow;
Tonight, she is meowed to the point of heaviness.

CAPULET:
Sir Paris, I will make a desperate offer
From the love of my child: I think she will be governed
In all respects by me; much more, I have no doubt.
Woman, go to her before you go to bed;
Let him know here the love of my son Paris;
And tell him, notice me, next Wednesday...
But sweet ! what day is it ?

PARIS:
Monday, my lord,

CAPULET:
Monday! ah, ah! Well, Wednesday is too early,
O Thursday, let it be: O Thursday, tell him,
She will be married to this noble count.
Will you be ready? do you like this rush?
We won't keep much noise, a friend or two;
For, hear ye, Tybalt being slain so late,
You would think we held it carelessly,
Being our parent, if we delight greatly:
So we will have half a dozen friends,
And there, an end. But what do you say about Thursday?

PARIS:
Monsignor, I would like Thursday to be tomorrow.

CAPULET:
Well, off you go: let it be Thursday, then.
Go see Juliette before you go to bed,
Prepare her, wife, for this wedding day.
Farewell, my lord. Light in my room, ho!
In front of me ! it's so very late,
So we can call him early every now and then.
Good night.

JULIET:
Do you want to leave? it is not yet close to the day:
It was the nightingale, not the lark,
It pierced the fearful hollow of your ear;
Every evening, she sings on your pomegranate tree:
Believe me, my love, it was the nightingale.

ROMEO:
It was the lark, the herald of the morning,
No nightingale: look, my love, what desires
Lace the parting clouds yonder in the east:
The candles of the night are extinguished and the day is merry
Stands on tiptoe on misty mountain peaks.
I must go and live, or stay and die.

JULIET:
This light is not that of day, I know it, I:
It is a meteor that the sun exhales,
Be a torchbearer for you this night,
And enlighten yourself on the way to Mantua:
So stay still; you don't need to leave.

ROMEO:
Let me be taken, let me be put to death;
I'm happy, so you want it that way.
I will say that your gray is not the eye of the morning,
It is only the pale reflection of Cynthia's forehead;
Nor is it the lark whose notes beat
The celestial vault so high above our heads:
I have more worries about staying than wanting to leave:
Come, death, and welcome! Juliette wants it that way.
How is it, my soul? let's talk; it's not daylight.

JULIET:
It's, it's: hey, go away, go away!
It's the lark that sings so out of tune,
Harsh discords and unpleasant sharp objects.
Some say that the lark makes gentle divisions;
This is not the case, because it divides us:
Some say that the lark and the hated toad change their eyes,
Oh, now I wish they had changed their voices too!
Since arm after arm this voice has fought us,
So I hunt you with the day by day hunt,
Oh, now go away; more light and light it grows.

ROMEO:
More light and light; our misfortunes become darker and darker!

Nurse:
Madam!

JULIET:
Nurse?

Nurse:
Your lady mother comes to your room:
The day has dawned; beware, look around you.

JULIET:
Then open the window, let the day in and let life out.

ROMEO:
Farewell, farewell! one kiss and I'll come down.

JULIET:
Did you leave like this? love, lord, yes, husband, friend!
I have to hear from you every day on time,
Because in a minute there are several days:
O, on this account, I will be many in years
And here I see my Romeo again!

ROMEO:
Farewell!
I won't forget any opportunity
This will convey my greetings to you, my love.

JULIET:
Do you think we'll ever see each other again?

ROMEO:
I have no doubt about it ; and all these misfortunes will serve
For sweet speeches in our time to come.

JULIET:
O God, I have a misguided soul!
It seems to me that I see you, now you are down,
Like a dead man at the bottom of a tomb:
Either my eyesight is failing or you're pale.

ROMEO:
And believe me, my love, in my eyes you too:
Dry sorrow drinks our blood. Farewell, farewell!

JULIET:
O fortune, fortune! all men call you fickle:
If you are fickle, what do you do with him?
Is it known for its faith? Be fickle, fortune;
Because then, I hope, you won't keep it for long,
But send it back.

LADY CAPULET:

JULIET:
Who is calling? is this my lady mother?
Doesn't she go to bed so late or get up so early?
What unusual cause prompts her to come here?

LADY CAPULET:
Well, how now, Juliette!

JULIET:
Madam, I am not well.

LADY CAPULET:
Are you still mourning the death of your cousin?
What, are you going to wash him from his grave with tears?
And if you could, you couldn't keep him alive;
Therefore do it: some sorrows show much love;
But much of the grief still shows a lack of spirit.

JULIET:
Yet let me mourn such a loss of feeling.

LADY CAPULET:
Then you will feel the loss, but not the friend
For which you cry.

JULIET:
Thus feeling the loss,
I can't choose but I always cry friend.

LADY CAPULET:
Well, my daughter, you don't cry so much for his death,
This is how the villain who massacred him lives.

JULIET:
What a bad lady?

LADY CAPULET:
This same villain, Romeo.

JULIET:

LADY CAPULET:
It's because the murderous traitor lives.

JULIET:
Yes, madam, within reach of my hands:
No one would want me to avenge my cousin's death!

LADY CAPULET:
We will take revenge for this, fear not:
So don't cry anymore. I will send one to Mantua,
Where this same banished runagate lives,
I will give him such an unusual drama,
That he will soon keep Tybalt company:
And then, I hope, you will be satisfied.

JULIET:
Indeed, I will never be satisfied
With Romeo, until I saw him... dead...
My poor heart is vexed for a parent.
Madam, if you could find out, but a man
To tolerate a poison, I would temper it;
That Romeo should, upon receipt of it,
Soon, sleep peacefully. O, how my heart hates
To hear him named, and cannot come to him.
To break the love I had for my cousin
On his body which massacred him!

LADY CAPULET:
Find the means, and I will find such a man.
But now I'm going to tell you some happy news, my daughter.

JULIET:
And joy comes in such a needy time:
What is this, I beg you, Your Lordship?

LADY CAPULET:
Well, well, you have a prudent father, my child;
The one who, to relieve you of your heaviness,
Settled a sudden day of joy,
What you didn't expect and what I didn't hope for.

JULIET:
Madam, in happy times, what day is it?

LADY CAPULET:
Get married, my child, early next Thursday morning,
The valiant, young and noble gentleman,
The County of Paris, at the Saint-Pierre church,
I will happily make you a happy wife.

JULIET:
Now, near the church of St. Peter and Peter too,
It won't make me a happy wife.
I am surprised at this haste; that I must marry
Before the one who should be her husband comes to court.
Please tell my lord and father, madam,
I will not marry yet; and, when I do, I swear,
It will be Romeo, who you know I hate,
Rather than Paris. This is indeed news!

LADY CAPULET:
Here is your father; tell him yourself,
And see how he will take it in your hands.

CAPULET:
When the sun sets, the air is covered with dew;
But for my brother's son's sunset
It's definitely raining.
How now! a conduit, my daughter? what, still in tears?
Are you still showering? In a small body
You have counterfeited a boat, a sea, a wind;
For calm your eyes, that I can call the sea,
Ebb and flow with tears; the shell that is your body,
Navigate this salty flood; the winds, your sighs;
Who, furious with your tears, and them with them,
Without a sudden calm, it will get worse
Your body shaken by the storm. Well, my wife!
Did you give him our decree?

LADY CAPULET:
Yes sir ; but she doesn't want it, she thanks you.
I would like this idiot to get married at his grave!

CAPULET:
Soft! take me with you, take me with you, woman.
How! will she not have any? Does she not give us thanks?
Isn't she proud? Doesn't she consider herself happy?
As unworthy as it was, what we did
A gentleman then worthy to be her husband?

JULIET:
You are not proud, you are; but grateful, that you have:
I can never be proud of what I hate;
But grateful even for hatred, it means love.

CAPULET:
How now, how now, chop-logic! What is this?
“Proud,” and “I thank you,” and “I don’t thank you; »
And yet, you are not proud, mistress servant,
Thank you no thanks, nor, proud of me, no proud,
But get your beautiful joints back into shape against next Thursday,
To accompany Paris to Saint-Pierre church,
Or I'll drag you there on a rack.
Out, you green carrion! outside, baggage!
You tallow face!

LADY CAPULET:
Fi, fi! what, are you crazy?

JULIET:
Good father, I beg you on my knees,
Listen to me with patience but just to say a word.

CAPULET:
Hang yourself, young baggage! disobedient wretch!
I tell you what: go to church on Thursday,
Or never look at me in the face again:
Don't speak, don't answer, don't answer me;
My fingers itch. Woman, we hardly thought we were happy
That God had only lent us this only child;
But now I see that this one is one too many,
And that we have a curse to have it:
On her I stand!

Nurse:
May God in heaven bless her!
You are guilty, my lord, of judging her like this.

CAPULET:
And why, my lady wisdom? hold your tongue,
Good caution; sprinkle with your gossip, leave.

Nurse:
I'm not talking about betrayal.

CAPULET:
Oh, god, fuck.

Nurse:
Can't we talk?

CAPULET:
Peace out, you mumbling idiot!
Express your gravity on the bowl of a gossip;
Because here we don't need it.

LADY CAPULET:
You're too hot.

CAPULET:
The bread of God! It makes me angry:
Day, night, hour, tide, hour, work, play,
Alone, in company, my care has always been
For it to be paired: and having now provided
A gentleman of noble descent,
Beautiful estates, young and nobly formed,
Stuffed, as they say, with honorable pieces,
Proportioned as a man's mind would wish;
And then have a miserable fool,
A whining mammet, in the offering of his fortune,
To answer “I will not marry; I can't love,
I am too young; Please forgive me.
But as you will not marry, I forgive you:
Graze where you want, you will not lodge with me:
Look, think about it, I'm not in the habit of joking.
Thursday is near; place your hand on your heart, advise:
If you are mine, I will give you to my friend;
And you won't be, hang, beg, starve, die
the streets,
For, through my soul, I will never recognize you,
And what is mine will never do you any good:
Trust it, think about it; I won't give up.

JULIET:
Is there no mercy sitting in the clouds,
Does this see the depths of my sorrow?
O sweet mother, do not reject me!
Delay this marriage for a month, for a week;
Or, if you don't, make the bridal bed
In this dark monument where Tybalt rests.

LADY CAPULET:
Don't talk to me, because I won't say a word:
Do what you want, because I'm done with you.

JULIET:
O God! O nurse, how can we prevent this?
My husband is on earth, my faith in heaven;
How will this faith return to earth,
Unless this husband sends it to me from heaven
By leaving Earth? console me, advise me.
Alas, alas, may heaven practice stratagems
On a subject as sweet as me!
What are you saying ? don't you have a word of joy?
A little comfort, nurse.

Nurse:
Well, here it is.
Romeo is banished; and everyone has nothing,
May he never dare to come back to challenge you;
Or, if he does, he must do it by stealth.
Since this is so,
I think it's best for you to marry into the county.
Oh, he's a charming gentleman!
Romeo is a dish for him: an eagle, madame,
Doesn't he have an eye so green, so lively, so beautiful?
Like Paris. Devour my heart,
I think you are happy in this second match,
For he surpasses your first: or if he did not,
Your first is dead; or if he was as good as he was,
Like living here and you don't use it.

JULIET:
Do you speak from your heart?

Nurse:
And my soul too;
Or reject them both.

JULIET:
Amen!

Nurse:
What?

JULIET:
Well, you comforted me wonderfully.
Come in: and tell my lady that I am gone,
Having displeased my father, in Laurence's cell,
Make a confession and be absolved.

Nurse:
Get married, I will; and this is wisely done.

JULIET:
Ancient damnation! O the wickedest demon!
Is it no longer a sin to wish me thus perjured,
Or to defame my lord with this same tongue
With which she congratulated him above
So many thousands of times? Come on, advisor;
You and my breast will now be two.
I go to the brother's house to find out his remedy:
If all else fails, I myself have the power to die.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
Thursday, sir? time is very short.

PARIS:
My father Capulet wants it that way;
And it doesn't take long for me to slow down his rush.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
You say you don't know the lady's mind:
The route is uneven, I don't like it.

PARIS:
She mourns immoderately the death of Tybalt,
This is why I have spoken little about love;
For Venus does not smile in a house of tears.
Now, sir, his father considers it dangerous
That she gives so much influence to her sorrow,
And in his wisdom hastens our marriage,
To stop the flood of her tears;
Who, too preoccupied with herself,
May be distanced from her by society:
Now do you know the reason for this rush.

BROTHER LAURENCE:

PARIS:
Fortunately met, my lady and my wife!

JULIET:
It will perhaps be, sir, when I can be a wife.

PARIS:
Perhaps it will be necessary, my love, next Thursday.

JULIET:
What must be will be.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
It is a certain text.

PARIS:
Are you coming to confess to this father?

JULIET:
To answer that, I would have to admit it to you.

PARIS:
Don't deny him that you love me.

JULIET:
I will admit to you that I love it.

PARIS:
You too, I am sure, love me.

JULIET:
If I do it it will cost more,
Being talked to behind your back rather than to your face.

PARIS:
Poor soul, your face is much abused by tears.

JULIET:
Tears achieved a small victory through this;
Because it was bad enough before their grudge.

PARIS:
You are wrong, beyond tears, with this report.

JULIET:
This is not a slander, sir, it is a truth;
And what I said, I said it to his face.

PARIS:
Your face is mine, and you have slandered it.

JULIET:
It may be so, because it is not mine.
Are you free, holy father, now?
Or should I come to your house for evening mass?

BROTHER LAURENCE:
My leisure serves me, thoughtful girl, now.
My lord, we must beg for time alone.

PARIS:
Shield God, I should disrupt the devotion!
Juliette, I will wake you up early on Thursday:
In the meantime, farewell; and keep this holy kiss.

JULIET:
O close the door! and when you have done it,
Come cry with me; hope past, remedy past, help past!

BROTHER LAURENCE:
Ah, Juliette, I already know your sorrow;
This strains me beyond the compass of my mind:
I hear that you must do it, and nothing can prolong it,
Next Thursday I will get married in this county.

JULIET:
Don't tell me, brother, that you heard about this,
Unless you tell me how I can prevent it:
If in your wisdom you cannot help,
Call my resolution wise,
And with this knife, I'm going to help him later.
God has joined my heart and that of Romeo, you our hands;
And before this hand, by you to Romeo, is sealed,
Will be the label of another act,
Or my true heart with a treacherous revolt
Turn to another, this will kill them both:
This is why, from your time of long experience,
Give me counsel present, or behold,
"Between my extremes and me, this damn knife
Must play referee, referee this
What commission of your years and your art
It could bring no question of true honor.
Don’t delay speaking; I want to die,
If what you say doesn't talk about a cure.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
Wait, my daughter: I see a kind of hope,
Which calls for an equally desperate execution.
How desperate it is, we would like to prevent it.
If, rather than marrying the County of Paris,
You have the strength to want to kill yourself,
So is it likely that you will undertake
Something like death to drive away this shame,
Who himself faces death to escape it:
And if you dare, I will give you a cure.

JULIET:
O, tell me to jump rather than marry Paris,
From the battlements of this tower;
Or walk in a thief manner; or tell me to hide
Where are the snakes? chain me with roaring bears;
Or lock myself in a mass grave at night,
Covered with bones of dead men,
With stinking shanks and chapless yellow skulls;
Or tell me to go to a newly made grave
And hide me with a dead man in his shroud;
Things which, hearing them, made me tremble;
And I will do it without fear or doubt,
Live a spotless wife for my sweet love.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
So wait; go home, be cheerful, give your consent
To marry Paris: Wednesday is tomorrow:
Tomorrow evening, make sure you are alone;
Let your nurse not sleep with you in your room:
Take this vial, while in bed,
And drink this distilled liquor;
When soon in all your veins will flow
Cold and sleepy humor, for no pulse
Should retain native progress, but stop:
No heat, no breath will testify that you live;
The roses of your lips and your cheeks will fade
The windows of your eyes fall into ashes,
Like death, when it silences the day of life;
Each party, deprived of flexible government,
Must, stiff, austere and cold, appear like death:
And in this borrowed likeness of shrunken death
You will continue for forty-two hours,
And then wakes up as if from a pleasant sleep.
Now when the groom comes in the morning
To wake up from your bed, you are there dead:
So, according to the way of life of our country,
In your most beautiful dresses discovered on the beer
You will be carried to this same ancient vault
Where are all the Capulets' relatives?
In the meantime, against you you will wake up,
Will Romeo, through my letters, know our drift,
And here he will come: and he and I
I will watch over your awakening, and this very night
Will Romeo take you from here to Mantua.
And this will free you from this present shame;
If there is no fickle toy, nor female fear,
Reduce your value by acting on it.

JULIET:
Give me, give me! Oh, don't talk to me about fear!

BROTHER LAURENCE:
Socket; go away, be strong and prosperous
In this resolution: I will send a brother with speed
In Mantua, with my letters to your lord.

JULIET:
Love give me strength! and strength will help to afford.
Farewell, dear father!

CAPULET:
So many guests are invited as here is the brief.
Sirrah, go hire me twenty crafty cooks.

Second servant:
You will not have any sick people, sir; because I will try if they
can lick your fingers.

CAPULET:
How can you try them like this?

Second servant:
Marry you, sir, he's a sick cook who can't lick his
own fingers: therefore the one who cannot lick himself
fingers don't go with me.

CAPULET:
Come on, go.
We will be very sparsely furnished this time.
What, my daughter has gone to Brother Laurence?

Nurse:
Yes, indeed.

CAPULET:
Well, maybe he will have the opportunity to do him some good:
She is a sullen and willful prostitute.

Nurse:
See where she's coming from with a happy look.

CAPULET:
Well, my stubborn one! where did you go?

JULIET:
Where I learned to repent of sin
From the disobedient opposition
To you and your orders, and I enjoin
By Saint Laurence for prostrating me here,
And I beg your pardon: pardon, I beg you!
From now on, I am still governed by you.

CAPULET:
Send for the county; tell him this:
I will tie this knot tomorrow morning.

JULIET:
I met the young lord in Laurence's cell;
And I gave him what became the love I could,
Do not exceed the limits of modesty.

CAPULET:
Well, I'm happy about it; that's good: get up:
This is how it should be. Let me see the county;
Yes, get married, come on, I said, and take him here.
Now, before God! this reverend holy brother,
Our entire city is closely linked to it.

JULIET:
Nurse, will you come with me to my closet,
To help me sort out these necessary ornaments
As you see fit to provide me tomorrow?

LADY CAPULET:
No, not until Thursday; there is enough time.

CAPULET:
Come on, nurse, follow her: we will go to church tomorrow.

LADY CAPULET:
We will run out of supplies:
Night is approaching now.

CAPULET:
Tush, I'll stir,
And everything will be fine, I guarantee you, woman:
Go see Juliette, help her adorn it;
I won't go to bed tonight; leave me alone;
I'm going to play the housewife this time. What, ho!
They all came out. Well I'll walk myself
In the County of Paris, to prepare it
Against tomorrow: my heart is a wonderful light,
Since this same rebellious girl is so recovered.

JULIET:
Yes, these clothes are the best: but, sweet nurse,
Please leave me alone tonight,
Because I need many prayers
To move the heavens and smile at my state,
Which, you know well, is wicked and full of sin.

LADY CAPULET:
What, you're busy, ho? do you need my help?

JULIET:
No Madam ; we have selected these necessities
As befits our State of tomorrow:
So please now let me be alone,
And let the nurse sit with you tonight;
Because, I am sure, you all have your hands full,
In this sudden affair.

LADY CAPULET:
Good night:
Lie down and rest; because you need it.

JULIET:
Farewell! God knows when we will see each other again.
I have a slight cold fear running through my veins,
It almost freezes the warmth of life:
I will call them back to comfort me:
Nurse! What should she do here?
My gloomy scene that I need must act alone.
Come on, bottle.
What if this mixture doesn't work at all?
So should I get married tomorrow morning?
No, no: this forbids it: lie down there.
And if it was a poison that the brother
He subtly decided to make me die,
Lest in this marriage he be dishonored,
Because he already married me to Romeo?
I fear this is the case: and yet I think it should not be the case,
For he was again tested as a holy man.
And if, when I am laid in the tomb,
I wake up before the time Romeo
Come and redeem me? there is a scary point!
Shall I not then be suffocated in the vault,
In whose filthy mouth no healthy air breathes,
And die strangled before my Romeo arrives?
Or, if I live, isn't it very similar,
The horrible vanity of death and night,
With the terror of the place,...
As in a vault, an ancient receptacle,
Where, during these hundreds of years, the bones
Of all my buried ancestors are packed:
Where this damn Tybalt, although green on earth,
Lies festering in his shroud; where, as they say,
At certain times, in the night spirit station ;--
Alas, alas, isn't that how I,
Waking up so early, with disgusting smells,
And cries like mandrakes torn from the earth,
May living mortals go mad when they hear them:--
Oh, if I wake up, won't I be upset,
Surrounded by all these hideous fears?
And play madly with my ancestor's joints?
And tear the mutilated Tybalt from his shroud?
And, in this rage, with the bones of some great relative,
Like with a club, breaking my desperate brain?
Oh, look! it seems to me that i see the ghost of my cousin
In search of Romeo, who spat out his body
On the point of a rapier: stay, Tybalt, stay!
Romeo, I’m coming! This is what I drink to you.

LADY CAPULET:
Wait, take these keys and go get some more spices, nurse.

Nurse:
They ask for dates and quinces in the pastry.

CAPULET:
Come, stir, stir, stir! the second rooster crowed,
The curfew bell has rung, it’s three o’clock:
Look at the meats in the oven, good Angelique:
Don't spare the price.

Nurse:
Come on, you lit-quean, come on,
Get into bed; my goodness, you will be sick tomorrow
To watch this night.

CAPULET:
No, not at all: what! I looked before now
All night for the slightest reason, and I never got sick.

LADY CAPULET:
Yes, you have been a mouse chase in your time;
But I'm going to watch you this way now.

CAPULET:
A jealous hood, a jealous hood!
Now, my friend,
What's there?

First Servant:
Things for the cook, sir; but I don't know what.

CAPULET:
Hurry up, hurry up.
Sirrah, go get some drier logs:
Call Pierre, he will show you where they are.

Second servant:
I have a head, sir, who will find the newspapers,
And never bother Peter about it.

CAPULET:
Mass, and well said; a happy son of a bitch, ha!
You will be stupid. Good faith, it's day:
The county will be there with music directly,
For thus he said he would: I hear it near.
Nurse! Marry! What, ho! What, nurse, I say!
Go wake Juliette, go cut her;
I'll go chat with Paris: hello, hurry up,
Hurry up ; the groom has already come:
Hurry up, I said.

Nurse:
Mistress! what, mistress! Juliet! quickly, I guarantee, she:
Well, lamb! well, madam! fie, you bed-beater!
Well, my love, I say! Mrs! Dear! Well, married!
What, not a word? you take your money now;
Sleep for a week; for the next night, I guarantee it,
The County of Paris has arranged its rest,
That you will only rest a little. God forgive me,
Get married, and amen, how deeply she sleeps!
I have to wake her up. Madam, madame, madame!
Yes, let the county take you into your bed;
He's going to scare you, my word. Won't it be?
What, dressed! and in your clothes! and still down!
I have to wake you up; Lady! lady! lady!
Alas, alas! Help! my lady is dead!
Well, what a day I was born!
A little aqua vitae, ho! My lord! Mrs!

LADY CAPULET:
What noise is there here?

Nurse:
O lamentable day!

LADY CAPULET:
What is the problem?

Nurse:
Look look! O heavy day!

LADY CAPULET:
O me, oh me! My child, my only life,
Come back to life, look up, or I will die with you!
Help! Call for help.

CAPULET:
Out of shame, take Juliette out; his lord has come.

Nurse:
She died, died, she died; alas the day!

LADY CAPULET:
Alas, she is dead, she is dead, she is dead!

CAPULET:
Ha! let me see her: outside, alas! she is cold :
His blood is calm and his joints are stiff;
Life and these lips have long been separated:
Death spreads over her like an untimely frost
On the sweetest flower of all the fields.

Nurse:
O lamentable day!

LADY CAPULET:
O terrible time!

CAPULET:
Death, who took her from here to make me moan,
He ties my tongue and won't let me speak.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
Come, is the bride ready to go to church?

CAPULET:
Ready to leave, but never to return.
O son! the day before your wedding
Is death lying with your wife. There she rests,
Flower as she was, deflowered by him.
Death is my son-in-law, death is my heir;
He married my daughter: I will die,
And leave it all; life, life, everything belongs to Death.

PARIS:
Did I think long to see the face of this morning,
And does it give me such a spectacle?

LADY CAPULET:
Cursed, unhappy, miserable, odious day!
The most miserable hour I've ever seen
In the lasting work of his pilgrimage!
But one, poor, a poor and loving child,
But one thing to rejoice and comfort,
And cruel death snatched him from my eyes!

Nurse:
