Oh misfortune! O awful, awful, awful day!
The most lamentable day, the most dreadful day,
This, always, always, I have seen it again!
Oh day! Oh day! Oh day! O odious day!
We have never seen a day as dark as this:
O awful day, oh awful day!

PARIS:
Seduced, divorced, wronged, thwarted, killed!
The most detestable death, which you have seduced,
By cruel cruel, you are completely bowled over!
O love! O life! not life, but love in death!

CAPULET:
Despised, afflicted, hated, martyred, killed!
Uncomfortable moment, why did you come now
Murder, murder our solemnity?
O child! O child! my soul, and not my child!
You are dead ! A lack! my child is dead;
And with my child my joys are buried.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
Peace, ho, shame! The cure for confusion does not live
In these confusions. The sky and you
Had part in this beautiful young girl; now the sky has everything,
And so much the better for the maid:
Your role in her, you couldn't stop her from dying,
But heaven keeps its part in eternal life.
All you were looking for was his promotion;
For it was your paradise, it should be brought forward:
And cry now, seeing that she is advanced
Above the clouds, as high as the sky itself?
O, in this love, you love your child so badly,
That you are going crazy, seeing that she is fine:
She is not well married and lives married for a long time;
But it is better to marry when you die married young.
Dry your tears and stick your rosemary
On this beautiful body; and, as is usual,
In all her most beautiful outfit, wear her to church:
For although tender nature makes us lament,
Yet the tears of nature are the joy of reason.

CAPULET:
All the things we have ordained in celebration,
Turn away from their office for a black funeral;
Our instruments with melancholy bells,
Our wedding joy at a sad funeral feast,
Our solemn hymns with sullen songs change,
Our wedding flowers are used for a buried corpse,
And all things change them on the contrary.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
Sir, come in; and, madam, go with him;
And go, Sir Paris; everyone gets ready
To follow this beautiful corpse to its grave:
The heavens mourn over you because of some evil;
Do not move them anymore by crossing their high will.

First musician:
My goodness, we can put down our hoses and leave.

Nurse:
Honest friends, ah, bear with one another, bear with one another;
Because, you know, it's a pitiful case.

First musician:
Yes, my word, the matter can be amended.

ROCK :
Musicians, oh musicians, "Peace of the heart, peace of the heart
ease: 'Oh, and you'll make me play live' 'Heart's easy.'

First musician:
Why “tranquility of the heart?” »

ROCK :
O musicians, because my heart itself plays "My
the heart is full of woe: 'Oh, play me a merry dump,
to comfort me.

First musician:
We are not a dump; Now is not the time to play.

ROCK :
You won't do it, then?

First musician:
No.

ROCK :
I will then give it to you sincerely.

First musician:
What are you going to give us?

ROCK :
Not money, on my faith, but joy;
I'll give you the minstrel.

First musician:
Then I will give you the servant creature.

ROCK :
So will I lay the serving creature's dagger on
your pâté. I won't wear hooks: I will take care of you,
I will love you ; do you notice me?

First musician:
And you are us and we, you notice us.

Second musician:
Please raise your dagger and show your spirit.

ROCK :
So attack with my mind! I'm going to beat you dry
with a spirit of iron, and I brandished my iron dagger. Answer
me like men:
"When sorrow persists, the heart is wounded,
And mournful discharges oppress the spirit,
Then music with its silvery sound'--
why “silver sound”? why music with its money
her'? What do you say, Simon Catling?

Musician:
Get married, sir, for money has a sweet sound.

ROCK :
Pretty! What do you say, Hugh Rebeck?

Second musician:
I say “his money” because musicians play for money.

ROCK :
Pretty too! What do you say, James Soundpost?

Third musician:
Well, I don't know what to say.

ROCK :
Oh, I cry out to you for mercy; you are the singer: I will say
for you. It's "music with its silvery sound",
because musicians have no gold with which to sound:
'Then the music with its silvery sound
With quick help, I lend repair.

First musician:
What a pestilential rascal he is!

Second musician:
Hang him, Jack! Come, we will enter here; wait for it
mourners, and stay for dinner.

ROMEO:
If I can trust the flattering truth of sleep,
My dreams portend joyful news at hand:
The lord of my bosom sits lightly on his throne;
And all this day an unusual spirit
Lifts me above the ground with joyful thoughts.
I dreamed that my lady came and found me dead...
Strange dream, which gives leave to a dead person
think!--
And I breathed such life with kisses on my lips,
That I resurrected and was emperor.
Oh me! how sweet love itself is,
When the shadows of love are so rich in joy!
News from Verona!... Well, Balthasar!
Don't you bring me letters from my brother?
How is my lady? Is my father okay?
How is my Juliette doing? which I ask again;
Because nothing can be sick, if it is well.

BALTHASAR:
So she is fine, and nothing can be sick:
His body sleeps in the Capel monument,
And his immortal part with the angels lives.
I saw her lying in her relatives' vault,
And I took the post to tell you:
Oh, forgive me for bringing this bad news,
Since you left it for my office, sir.

ROMEO:
Is this still the case? so I challenge you, stars!
You know my accommodation: give me ink and paper,
And hire post horses; So I will do it this evening.

BALTHASAR:
I beg you, sir, to be patient:
Your looks are pale and wild, and matter
A mishap.

ROMEO:
Tush, you are wrong:
Leave me and do what I tell you.
Don't you have any letters for me from your brother?

BALTHASAR:
No, my good lord.

ROMEO:
It doesn't matter: go away,
And praise these horses; I will be with you directly.
Well, Juliette, I will sleep with you tonight.
Let us see the means: O mischief, you are quick
To enter the thoughts of desperate men!
I remember an apothecary,--
And that's pretty much where he lives, which I noticed late
In tattered grass, with crushing brows,
Elimination of simple ones; thin was his appearance,
Acute misery had exhausted him to the bones:
And in his needy shop a turtle hung,
An alligator thing and other skins
Malformed fish; and about its shelves
A miserable count of empty boxes,
Pots of green earth, bladders and moldy seeds,
Leftover yarn and old rose cakes,
Were scattered to make a spectacle.
Noticing this shortage, I said to myself
"And if a man needed a poison now,
Whose sale is present death in Mantua,
Here lives a wretch who would sell it to him.
Oh, that same thought only anticipated my need;
And this same needy man must sell it to me.
If I remember correctly, this should be the house.
On vacation, the beggar's shop is closed.
What, ho! apothecary!

Apothecary:
Who is calling so loudly?

ROMEO:
Come here, man. I see you are poor:
Here, there are forty ducats: give me
A glass of poison, such equipment that speeds up soon
As it will disperse in all the veins
So that the weary taker of life may drop dead
And that the trunk may be out of breath
As violently as rushing powder fired
Hurries to get out of the belly of the fatal cannon.

Apothecary:
I possess such deadly drugs; but the law of Mantua
It is death for anyone who says them.

ROMEO:
Are you so naked and full of misery,
And you're afraid of dying? the famine is on your cheeks,
Need and oppression starve in your eyes,
Contempt and begging weigh on your back;
The world is not your friend nor the law of the world;
The world offers no laws to make you rich;
So don't be poor, but break it and take this.

Apothecary:
My poverty, but not my will, consents.

ROMEO:
I pay for your poverty and not your will.

Apothecary:
Put that in any liquid you want,
And drink it; and if you had the strength
Out of twenty men, that would eliminate you directly.

ROMEO:
Here is your gold, the worst poison for the souls of men,
Make more killings in this loathsome world,
Than these poor compounds that you can't sell.
I sell you poison; you didn't sell me any.
Farewell: buy some food and put yourself in the flesh.
Come, cordial and not poison, come with me
At Juliet's grave; for that is where I must use you.

BROTHER JOHN:
Holy Franciscan Brother! brother, ho!

BROTHER LAURENCE:
This same voice should be that of Brother Jean.
Welcome from Mantua: what does Romeo say?
Or, if he thinks so, give me his letter.

BROTHER JOHN:
I'm going to find a barefoot brother
One of our orders, to associate me,
Here in this city, visiting the sick,
And finding him, the searchers of the city,
Suspecting we were both in a house
Where the contagious plague reigned,
He sealed the doors and would not let us out;
So that my route to Mantua was stopped.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
Who brought my letter to Romeo?

BROTHER JOHN:
I couldn't send it, here it is again,
And don't ask a messenger to bring it to you,
They were so afraid of infection.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
Unfortunate fortune! by my brotherhood,
The letter was not nice but full of charge
Of great importance, and neglect it
Can present a lot of danger. Brother Jean, go;
Give me an iron crow and bring it straight
In my cell.

BROTHER JOHN:
Brother, I'll bring it to you.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
Now I must go to the monument alone;
In three hours, the beautiful Juliette will wake up:
She's going to eat me much more than Romeo
He had no notification of these accidents;
But I will still write to Mantua,
And keep her in my cell until Romeo comes;
Poor living corpse, locked in a tomb of death!

PARIS:
Give me your torch, my boy: go then and stand aside:
Still, turn it off, because I won't be seen.
Under these yews you lay all the time,
Holding your ear close to the hollow ground;
So no foot will tread the cemetery,
To be cowardly, crippled, to have dug graves,
But you will hear it: whistle to me then,
As a signal that you hear something approaching.
Give me these flowers. Do what I tell you, leave.

PAGE:

PARIS:
Sweet flower, I adorn your wedding bed with flowers, -
Oh misfortune! your cover is dust and stones; -
That I dew every evening with sweet water,
Or, wanting this, with tears distilled by groans:
The funeral I will keep for you
Every night it will be to spread your grave and cry.
The boy warns that something is coming.
What cursed foot wanders here this night,
To get through my funeral and the rite of true love?
What with a torch! suffocate me, at night, for a moment.

ROMEO:
Give me this pickaxe and this tearing iron.
Wait, take this letter; early in the morning
Give it to my lord and father.
Give me light: over your life I charge you,
Whatever you hear or see, stay away,
And don't interrupt me in my lesson.
Why am I going down to this deathbed,
It is partly to see my lady's face;
But above all to remove some from his dead finger
A precious ring, a ring that I must use
In a dear job: therefore, go:
But if you, jealous, come back to search
In what I intend to do further,
By heaven I will tear you apart joint by joint
And dot this hungry cemetery with your members:
Time and my intentions are wild,
Fiercer and more inexorable away
Than empty tigers or a roaring sea.

BALTHASAR:
I will leave, sir, and I will not disturb you.

ROMEO:
Then you will show me friendship. Take this :
Live and be prosperous: and farewell, my good boy.

BALTHASAR:

ROMEO:
You, detestable face, belly of death,
Gorged with the dearest piece of earth,
So I force your rotten jaws to open,
And despite everything, I will stuff you with food!

PARIS:
It is this haughty and banished Montague,
Who murdered my love's cousin, with what sorrow,
It is assumed that the beautiful creature is dead;
And here comes to cause a villainous shame
To the corpses: I will apprehend him.
Stop your impious toil, vile Montague!
Can revenge go beyond death?
Wicked convict, I apprehend you:
Obey and come with me; because you must die.

ROMEO:
It is indeed necessary; that's why I came here.
Good and gentle young man, do not tempt a desperate man;
Flee from here and leave me: think of those who are gone;
Let them scare you. I beg you, youth,
Don't put another sin on my head,
Driving me to fury: O, go!
By heaven, I love you more than myself;
For I come here armed against myself:
Don't stay, go; live, and say below:
The mercy of a madman ordered you to flee.

PARIS:
I defy your conjurations,
And apprehend you here for a criminal.

ROMEO:
Do you want to provoke me? so go ahead, boy!

PAGE:
O Lord, they are fighting! I'll call the watch.

PARIS:
Oh, I'm killed!
If you are merciful,
Open the tomb, put me to bed with Juliette.

ROMEO:
In all faith, I will. Let me look over this face.
Kin of Mercutio, noble county of Paris!
What did my man say, when my tormented soul
Didn't you accompany him while we rode? I think
He told me that Paris should have married Juliette:
He said no? Or did I dream it like this?
Or am I crazy to hear him talk about Juliette,
To think that it was so? Oh, give me your hand,
A writing with me in the book of sour woe!
I will bury you in a triumphant tomb;
A grave? Oh no ! a lantern, a massacred youth,
For here lies Juliet, and her beauty makes
This vault has a festive presence full of light.
Death, lie there, near a buried dead.
How many times when men are about to die
How happy they were! that their guardians call
A flash before death: O, how can I
Would you call that lightning? O my love! my wife!
Death, which sucked the honey from your breath,
He has yet to have any power over your beauty:
You are not conquered; the beauty brand is still
Is crimson on your lips and on your cheeks,
And the pale flag of death is not raised there.
Tybalt, do you lie there in your bloody sheet?
Oh, what more favor can I do you,
That with this hand that cut your youth in two
To break the one who was your enemy?
Forgive me, cousin! Ah, dear Juliette,
Why are you so beautiful ? should I believe
This insignificant death is loving,
And that the thin and abhorred monster keeps
You here in the dark to be her lover?
For fear of this, I will always remain with you;
And never from this palace of the dark night
Leave again: here, here I will stay
With worms that are your maids; Oh, here
Will I establish my eternal rest,
And shake off the yoke of the ominous stars
Of this world-weary flesh. Eyes, look at your last one!
Arms, take your last embrace! and, lips, oh you
The doors of breath, seal them with a righteous kiss
An undated affair for a captivating death!
Come, bitter conduct, come, disreputable guide!
You, desperate pilot, run now immediately
The dashing one rocks your tired and seasick bark!
So much for my love!
O true apothecary!
Your medications are fast. So with a kiss I die.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
Saint Francis be my speed! how often tonight
My old feet have tripped over the graves! Who is here?

BALTHASAR:
Here is one, a friend and one who knows you well.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
Happiness be upon you! Tell me, good my friend,
What torch is there, which lends its light in vain
To larvae and eyeless skulls? as I discern,
It burns in the Capel monument.

BALTHASAR:
It is so, holy sir; and here is my master,
The one you love.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
Who is it?

BALTHASAR:
Romeo.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
How long has he been there?

BALTHASAR:
A full half hour.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
Come with me to the safe.

BALTHASAR:
I don't dare, sir
My master does not know it but I have left here;
And he terribly threatened to kill me,
If I stayed to see his intentions.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
So stay; I will go alone. Fear invades me:
Oh, I'm so afraid of something unlucky.

BALTHASAR:
As I slept here under this yew tree,
I dreamed that my master and another were fighting,
And my master killed him.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
Romeo!
Alas, alas, what blood is it, which stains
The stony entrance to this tomb?
What do these masterless and bloody swords mean
Remain discolored by this place of peace?
Romeo! O pale! Who else? what, Paris too?
And drenched in blood? Ah, what a wicked hour
Is guilty of this pitiful luck!
The lady moves.

JULIET:
O comfortable brother! where is my lord?
I remember well where I should be,
And here I am. Where is my Romeo?

BROTHER LAURENCE:
I hear a noise. Lady, come from this nest
Of death, contagion and unnatural sleep:
A power greater than we can contradict
Thwarted our intentions. Come come.
Your husband died in your womb;
And Paris too. Come on, I'll get rid of you
Among a brotherhood of holy nuns:
Don't ask questions, because the watch is coming;
Come, go ahead, good Juliette,
I don't dare to stay any longer.

JULIET:
Go, go, because I will not go.
What's here? a cup, closed in the hand of my true love?
The poison, I see, was its timeless end:
O idiot! I drank it all and left not a single friendly drop
To help me afterwards? I will kiss your lips;
Maybe a poison still weighs on them,
Make die with a repairman.
Your lips are warm.

First goalkeeper:

JULIET:
Yeah, noise? so I will be brief. O happy dagger!
This is your sheath;
there rust, and let me die.

PAGE:
It's the ideal place; where the torch burns.

First goalkeeper:
The ground is bloody; search in the cemetery:
Come on, some of you, whoever you find, tie them up.
Pitiful spectacle! here lies the slain county,
And Juliette bleeding, hot and newly dead,
Who has been buried here for two days?
Go, tell the prince: run to the Capulets:
Find the Montagues: others are looking for:
We see the ground on which these misfortunes rest;
But the real reason for all these pitiful misfortunes
We cannot detect it without circumstances.

Second goalkeeper:
Here is Romeo's man; we found it in the cemetery.

First goalkeeper:
Keep him safe until the prince comes here.

Third goalkeeper:
Here is a brother who trembles, sighs and cries:
We took this pickaxe and this spade from him,
As he was coming from this side of the cemetery.

First goalkeeper:
A big suspicion: stay the brother too.

PRINCE:
What misadventure is so early,
This calls our person from our morning rest?

CAPULET:
What makes them shout like this abroad?

LADY CAPULET:
People in the street shout Romeo,
A bit of Juliette and Paris; and everyone runs,
With an open cry towards our monument.

PRINCE:
What is this fear that surprises our ears?

First goalkeeper:
Sovereign, here rests the slain county of Paris;
And Romeo is dead; and Juliette, who died previously,
Hot and new killed.

PRINCE:
Search, search and know how this vile murder occurs.

First goalkeeper:
Here is a brother who massacred Romeo's man;
With instruments on it, fit to open
The graves of these dead.

CAPULET:
O heaven! O woman, look how our daughter is bleeding!
This dagger has mista'en - for, behold, his house
Is empty at the back of Montague,...
And it is poorly sheathed in my daughter's womb!

LADY CAPULET:
O me! this sight of death is like a bell,
This warns my old age of a grave.

PRINCE:
Come, Montague; because you are early,
To see your son and heir sooner.

ASSEMBLY :
Alas, my lord, my wife died last night;
The grief of my son's exile took his breath away:
What other misfortune conspires against my age?

PRINCE:
Look, and you will see.

ASSEMBLY :
O you uneducated! what manners are there in this?
To hurry past your father to the grave?

PRINCE:
Seal the mouth of indignation for a moment,
Until we can clear up these ambiguities,
And know their spring, their head, their
true descendants;
And then I will be general of your misfortunes,
And even leads you to death: in the meantime, refrain,
And let chance be the slave of patience.
Bring out suspicious parties.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
I am the greatest, capable of the least,
But this is what we suspect the most, because the time and place
He blames me for this terrible murder;
And here I am, both to impeach and purge
Myself condemned and myself excused.

PRINCE:
So tell me what you know about it right away.

BROTHER LAURENCE:
I will be brief, for my short meeting
It's not as long as a tedious story.
Romeo, who died there, was the husband of this Juliet;
And she, dead there, the faithful wife of Romeo:
I married them; and their wedding day stolen
It was the day of the end of Tybalt, whose untimely death
I banished the new husband from the city,
For whom, and not Tybalt, is Juliette pining?
You, to take away this seat of sorrow from him,
Engaged and allegedly married her by force
Towards the county of Paris: then she comes towards me,
And, with wild looks, tell me to invent a villain
To rid her of this second marriage,
Or, in my cell, she would commit suicide.
Then I gave him, so instructed by my art,
A sleeping potion; which thus took effect
As I expected, because it did
The shape of death: in the meantime I write to Romeo,
Let him come here on this terrible night,
To help bring her out of her borrowed grave,
This is the time when the strength of the potion should cease.
But the one who carried my letter, Brother Jean,
I was left by accident, and last night
I sent my letter back. Then all alone
At the predetermined time of his awakening,
I came to look for her in her relatives' vault;
That is to say, keep it near my cell,
Until I could easily send to Romeo:
But when I arrived, a few minutes before time
From his awakening, here lying prematurely
The noble Paris and the true Romeo are dead.
She wakes up ; and I begged her to come out,
And bear with patience this work of heaven:
But then a noise frightened me coming from the tomb;
And she, too desperate, didn't want to accompany me,
But, it seems, she did violence to herself.
All this I know; and at the wedding
His nurse knows: and, if there is something in all this
Miscarriage by my fault, leave my old life
To be sacrificed, a few hours before his time,
To the rigor of the most severe laws.

PRINCE:
We still know you as a holy man.
Where is Romeo's man? what can he say in that?

BALTHASAR:
I brought the news of Juliette's death to my master;
And then in office he came from Mantua
At this same place, at this same monument.
This letter he asked me to give to his father,
And threatened me with death, entering the vault,
I didn't walk away and leave it there.

PRINCE:
Give me the letter; I'll look into it.
Where is the county page that raised the watch?
Sirrah, what made your master this place?

PAGE:
He came with flowers to scatter his lady's grave;
And told me to stay away, and that's what I did:
Soon someone comes with light to open the tomb;
And little by little my master attracted him;
And then I ran off to call the watch.

PRINCE:
This letter confirms the brother's words,
Their journey of love, the news of his death:
And here he writes that he bought poison
From a poor 'pothecary, and with that
I came to this vault to die and sleep with Juliette.
Where are these enemies? Capulet! Montague!
See what scourge is imposed on your hatred,
May heaven find a way to kill your joys with love.
And me too for winking at your discords
I lost two parents: all are punished.

CAPULET:
O brother Montague, give me your hand:
It's my daughter's joint, for nothing more
May I demand.

ASSEMBLY :
But I can give you more:
For I will set up his image of pure gold;
Although Verona is known by this name,
No amount will be fixed at such a rate
Like that of the true and faithful Juliet.

CAPULET:
Romeo will also be rich thanks to his lady's lie;
Poor sacrifices of our enmity!

PRINCE:
It brings a dark peace this morning;
The sun, out of sorrow, will not show its head:
Go and talk more about these sad things;
Some will be forgiven and some will be punished:
Because never has a story been more unfortunate
Than that of Juliet and her Romeo.

WARWICK:
I wonder how the king escaped our hands.

YORK:
While we pursued the horsemen from the north,
He sneakily fled and left his men:
Then the great lord of Northumberland,
Whose warlike ears would never bear retreat,
Raised the morale of the weakened army; and himself,
Lord Clifford and Lord Stafford, all abreast,
We charged the front of our main battle and broke in
Were killed by the swords of common soldiers.

EDWARD:
The father of Lord Stafford, Duke of Buckingham,
Is either killed or dangerously injured;
I split his beaver with a clean blow:
It's true, my father, see his blood.

ASSEMBLY :
And, brother, here is the blood of the Earl of Wiltshire,
Which I encountered as the battles joined.

RICHARD:
Speak for me and tell them what I did.

YORK:
Richard deserved the best of all my sons.
But is your grace dead, my lord of Somerset?

NORFOLK:
What hope has the entire lineage of John of Gaunt!

RICHARD:
This is how I hope to shake King Henry's head.

WARWICK:
And me too. Victorious Prince of York,
Before I see you sitting on this throne
Which now the house of Lancaster usurps,
I swear by heaven these eyes will never close.
This is the palace of the fearful king,
And this is the royal seat: own it, York;
For this is yours and not that of King Henry's heirs.

YORK:
Help me then, sweet Warwick, and I will;
For here we have entered by force.

NORFOLK:
We will all help you; he who steals will die.

YORK:
Thank you, kind Norfolk: stay close to me, my lords;
And, soldiers, stay and spend the night near me.

WARWICK:
And when the king comes, offer no violence,
Unless he's trying to evict you by force.

YORK:
The queen holds her parliament here today,
But few people think that we will be of his advice:
By words or by blows, let us win our right here.

RICHARD:
Armed as we are, let's stay in this house.

WARWICK:
Will the bloody parliament be called,
Unless Plantagenet, Duke of York, is king,
And the timid Henry deposed, whose cowardice
He gave us words to our enemies.

YORK:
So leave me not, my lords; be resolute;
I want to take possession of my right.

WARWICK:
Neither the king, nor the one who loves him most,
The proudest is he who supports Lancaster,
Dare to move a wing, if Warwick shakes his bells.
I will plant Plantagenêt, uproot whoever dares:
Make up your mind, Richard; claim the English crown.

KING HENRY VI:
My lords, look where the strong rebel is,
Even at the presidency of the state: as he means,
Supported by the power of Warwick, this false peer,
Aspire to the crown and reign as king.
Earl of Northumberland, he killed your father.
And yours, Lord Clifford; and you both swore revenge
On him, his sons, his favorites and his friends.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
If I don't, may God take revenge on me!

CLIFFORD:
Hope makes Clifford cry in the steel.

WESTERN MORELAND:
What, are we going to put up with this? let's tear it off:
My heart burns with anger; I can not support it.

KING HENRY VI:
Be patient, gentle Earl of Westmoreland.

CLIFFORD:
Patience is for cowards, like him:
He wouldn't have dared to stay there if your father had lived.
My gracious lord, here in parliament
Let's attack York's family.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
You have spoken well, cousin: so be it.

KING HENRY VI:
Ah, you don't know that the city favors them,
And they have troops of soldiers at their service?

EXECUTE:
But when the duke is killed, they will quickly flee.

KING HENRY VI:
Far from Henry's heart this thought,
Make a disaster in Parliament!
Exeter's cousin, frowns, words and threats
This will be the war Henry intends to use.
You, factious Duke of York, come down to my throne,
and kneel for grace and mercy at my feet;
I am your sovereign.

YORK:
I'm yours.

EXECUTE:
For shame, come down: he made you Duke of York.

YORK:
It was my heritage, as was the county.

EXECUTE:
Your father was a traitor to the crown.

WARWICK:
Exeter, you are a traitor to the crown
By following this usurping Henry.

CLIFFORD:
Who should he follow but his natural king?

WARWICK:
It's true, Clifford; and this is Richard Duke of York.

KING HENRY VI:
And shall I arise, and you sit on my throne?

YORK:
It must be like this: be content with yourself.

WARWICK:
Be Duke of Lancaster; let him be king.

WESTERN MORELAND:
He is both king and duke of Lancaster;
And this the Lord of Westmoreland will maintain.

WARWICK:
And Warwick will refute it. You forget
That we are the ones who chased you from the field
And you killed your fathers, and with spilled colors
I walked through the city to the palace gates.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
Yes, Warwick, I remember it to my great regret;
And, by his soul, you and your house will miss him.

WESTERN MORELAND:
Plantagenet, of you and your sons,
Your relative and your friends, I will have more lives
That drops of blood flowed through my father's veins.

CLIFFORD:
Don't insist any more; lest instead of words,
I send you, Warwick, such a messenger
As I will avenge his death before I move.

WARWICK:
Poor Clifford! how I despise his useless threats!

YORK:
Will we show our title to the crown?
Otherwise, our swords will plead for him on the field.

KING HENRY VI:
What title do you have, traitor, to the crown?
Your father was, like you, Duke of York;
Your grandfather, Roger Mortimer, Earl of March:
I am the son of Henry V,
Who brought down the Dauphin and the French
And captured their cities and their provinces.

WARWICK:
Don't talk about France, since you have lost everything.

KING HENRY VI:
It was the lord protector who lost it, and not me:
When I was crowned, I was only nine months old.

RICHARD:
You are quite old now, and yet it seems to me that you are losing.
Father, tear the crown from the head of the usurper.

EDWARD:
Sweet father, do it; put it on your head.

ASSEMBLY :
Good brother, how you love and honor weapons,
Let's fight and not continue to quibble like this.

RICHARD:
Sound the drums and the trumpets, and the king will fly away.

YORK:
My sons, peace!

KING HENRY VI:
Peace, you! and give King Henry permission to speak.

WARWICK:
Plantagenet will speak first: listen to him, lords;
And be silent and attentive too,
For whoever interrupts it will not live.

KING HENRY VI:
Do you think I will leave my royal throne,
Where were my grandfather and father sitting?
No: first, war will be depopulated in my kingdom;
Yes, and their colors, often worn in France,
And now in England, to our great sorrow,
This will be my shroud. Why do you faint, lords?
My title is good, and far better than his.

WARWICK:
Prove it, Henry, and you will be king.

KING HENRY VI:
Henry IV obtained the crown by conquest.

YORK:
It was in rebellion against his king.

KING HENRY VI:

YORK:
So what ?

KING HENRY VI:
And if he can, then I am the rightful king;
For Richard, in the eyes of many lords,
Renounced the crown to Henry IV,
Of which my father was the heir, and I am his.

YORK:
He rose up against him, being his sovereign,
And made him forcibly give up his crown.

WARWICK:
Suppose, my lords, that he did it without constraint,
Do you think you have damaged his crown?

EXECUTE:
No; because he could not thus renounce his crown
But may the next heir succeed and reign.

KING HENRY VI:
Are you against us, Duke of Exeter?

EXECUTE:
He is right, and therefore, forgive me.

YORK:
Why whisper to you, my lords, and not answer?

EXECUTE:
My conscience tells me that he is the rightful king.

KING HENRY VI:

NORTHUMBERLAND:
Plantagenet, despite all your pretensions,
Do not think that Henry is thus deposed.

WARWICK:
It will be filed, regardless.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
You are deceived: it is not your southern power,
Of Essex, of Norfolk, of Suffolk, nor of Kent,
What makes you so presumptuous and proud,
I can trap the duke against my will.

CLIFFORD:
King Henry, whether your title is true or false,
Lord Clifford swears to fight in your defense:
May this ground gape and swallow me alive,
Where I will kneel before the one who killed my father!

KING HENRY VI:
O Clifford, how your words revive my heart!

YORK:
Henry of Lancaster, renounce your crown.
What do you whisper or plot, lords?

WARWICK:
Do good to this princely Duke of York,
Or I will fill the house with armed men,
And above the seat of state, where he now sits,
Write its title with usurping blood.

KING HENRY VI:
My Lord of Warwick, listen to me, but one word:
For this reason let me reign all my life as king.

YORK:
Confirm the crown to me and my heirs,
And you will reign in peace as long as you live.

KING HENRY VI:
I am happy: Richard Plantagenêt,
Enjoy the kingdom after I pass away.

CLIFFORD:
What harm does this do to the prince, your son!

WARWICK:
Of what use is this to England and himself!

WESTERN MORELAND:
Infamous, fearful and desperate Henry!

CLIFFORD:
How have you harmed yourself and us!

WESTERN MORELAND:
I can't stay to hear these articles.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
Nor me.

CLIFFORD:
Come, cousin, let us announce this news to the queen.

WESTERN MORELAND:
Farewell, pusillanimous and degenerate king,
In whose cold blood no spark of honor resides.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
Be a prey to the house of York,
And die as a group for this shameful act!

CLIFFORD:
In a terrible war may you be defeated,
Or live in peace, abandoned and despised!

WARWICK:
Turn around here, Henry, and don't look at them.

EXECUTE:
They seek revenge and therefore will not give in.

KING HENRY VI:
Ah, Exeter!

WARWICK:
Why should you sigh, my lord?

KING HENRY VI:
Not for me, Lord Warwick, but for my son,
That I will disinherit against nature.
But anyway: I hear here
The crown to you and your heirs forever;
On condition, that you take an oath here
To end this civil war, and, as long as I live,
To honor me as your king and sovereign,
And neither by betrayal nor by hostility
Seeking to bring me down and rule over you.

YORK:
I take this oath willingly and I will respect it.

WARWICK:
Long live King Henry! Plantagenet kisses him.

KING HENRY VI:
And long life to you and your avant-garde sons!

YORK:
Now York and Lancaster are reconciled.

EXECUTE:
Cursed be he who seeks to make enemies!

YORK:
Farewell, my gracious lord; I'm going to my castle.

WARWICK:
And I will guard London with my soldiers.

NORFOLK:
And me in Norfolk with my supporters.

ASSEMBLY :
And I towards the sea from which I came.

KING HENRY VI:
And I, with sorrow and sorrow, to court.

EXECUTE:
Here comes the queen, whose looks betray her anger:
I'm going to fly.

KING HENRY VI:
Exeter, me too.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
No, don't move away from me; I will follow you.

KING HENRY VI:
Be patient, sweet queen, and I will stay.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Who can be patient in such extremes?
Ah, wretch! I would have died a servant
And I never saw you, I never gave you a son,
Seeing that you turned out to be such an unnatural father
Did he thus deserve to lose his birthright?
If you had loved him half as well as I did,
Or felt that pain that I did to him once,
Or I fed him as I did with my blood,
You would have left your dearest heart blood there,
Rather than having this wild duke as his heir
And I have disinherited your only son.

PRINCE EDWARD:
Father, you cannot disinherit me:
If you are king, why should I not succeed?

KING HENRY VI:
Forgive me, Margaret; forgive me, my sweet son:
The Earl of Warwick and the Duke forced me.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
I forced you! art thou king, and wilt thou be forced?
I'm ashamed to hear you speak. Ah, fearful wretch!
You have undone yourself, your son and me;
And gave the house of York such a leader
As you will reign but through their suffering.
To involve him and his heirs in the crown,
What is it, if not making your sepulcher
And slip in well before your time?
Warwick is chancellor and lord of Calais;
Stern Falconbridge dominates the narrow seas;
The duke is named protector of the kingdom;
And yet, will you be safe? such security findings
The trembling lamb surrounded by wolves.
If I had been there, what a stupid woman I am,
The soldiers should have thrown me on their pikes
Before, I would have granted this act.
But you prefer your life to your honor:
And seeing that you do it, I divorce here
From your table, Henry, and from your bed,
Until this Act of Parliament is repealed
By which my son is disinherited.
The lords of the north who renounced your colors
Mine will follow, if once they see them spreading;
And they will spread, to your shameful shame
And the total ruin of the house of York.
So I'm leaving you. Come, my son, let us go;
Our army is ready; come, we will pursue them.

KING HENRY VI:
Stay, sweet Margaret, and listen to me speak.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
You've already talked too much: go away.

KING HENRY VI:
Sweet son Edward, will you stay with me?

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Yes, being murdered by your enemies.

PRINCE EDWARD:
When I return with victory on the field
I will see your grace: in the meantime, I will follow it.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Come, my son, go away; we cannot linger like this.

KING HENRY VI:
Poor queen! what love for me and for his son
This made him burst into rage!
May she be avenged by this odious duke,
Whose haughty spirit, winged with desire,
It will cost my crown, and like an empty eagle
Be weary of my flesh and that of my son!
The loss of these three lords torments my heart:
I will write to them and I will beg them fairly.
Come, cousin, you will be the messenger.

EXECUTE:
And I, I hope, will reconcile them all.
3KING HENRY VI

RICHARD:
Brother, even though I am the youngest, give me permission.

EDWARD:
No, I can play the speaker better.

ASSEMBLY :
But I have strong and compelling reasons.

YORK:
Well, how now, son and brother! during a conflict?
What is your quarrel? how did it start?

EDWARD:
No quarrel, but a slight argument.

YORK:
About what?

RICHARD:
Of what concerns your grace and us;
The crown of England, my father, which is yours.

YORK:
My boy ? not before the death of King Henry.

RICHARD:
Your right does not depend on his life or death.

EDWARD:
Now you are an heir, so take advantage now:
By letting the house of Lancaster breathe,
This will eventually overtake you, father.

YORK:
I took an oath that he would reign peacefully.

EDWARD:
But for a kingdom, any oath can be broken:
I would break a thousand oaths to reign for one year.

RICHARD:
No; God forbid that your grace be abandoned.

YORK:
I will be, if I claim by open war.

RICHARD:
I will prove otherwise, if you hear me speak.

YORK:
You cannot, my son; it's impossible.

RICHARD:
An oath has no importance if it is not taken
Before a true and legal magistrate,
Who has authority over him who swears:
Henry had none, but usurped the place;
Then, seeing that it was he who had you deposed,
Your oath, my lord, is vain and frivolous.
So, to arms! And, father, just think
How sweet it is to wear a crown!
In the circuit of which the Elysée is located
And all this, the poets feign happiness and joy.
Why do we finger like this? I can't rest
Until the white rose I wear is dyed
Even in the warm blood of Henry's heart.

YORK:
Richard, that's enough; I will be king, or I will die.
Brother, you are going to London soon,
And incite Warwick to this enterprise.
You, Richard, owe it to the Duke of Norfolk,
And tell him privately our intention.
You, Edward, owe to my lord Cobham,
With whom the Kentishmen will gladly rise:
I trust them; because they are soldiers,
Witty, courteous, liberal, witty.
While you are thus employed, what more remains,
But I am looking for an opportunity to elevate myself,
And yet the king is not aware of my excesses,
Nor any member of the House of Lancaster?
But let's stay: what news? Why do you come to such a position?

Messenger:
The Queen with all the earls and lords of the North
Hear you here besieged in your castle:
She is nearby with twenty thousand men;
And therefore fortify your position, my lord.

YORK:
Yes, with my sword. What! do you think we fear them?
Edward and Richard, you will stay with me;
My brother Montague will post in London:
May noble Warwick, Cobham and the rest,
Whom we left as protectors of the king,
With a powerful policy, strengthen itself,
And don't trust simple Henry or his oaths.

ASSEMBLY :
Brother, I'm going; I will win them, have no fear:
This is why I very humbly take my leave.
Sir John and Sir Hugh Mortimer, my uncles,
You arrive at Sandal in a happy hour;
The queen's army wants to besiege us.

JOHN MORTIMER:
She won't need it; we will meet her on the ground.

YORK:
What, with five thousand men?

RICHARD:
Yes, with five hundred, my father, for a need:
A female general; what should we fear?

EDWARD:
I hear their drums: let's put our men in order,
And come out and tell them to fight straight.

YORK:
Five men against twenty! even if the chances are great,
I have no doubt, uncle, of our victory.
I have won many battles in France,
When the enemy was ten to one:
Why wouldn't I have the same success now?
3KING HENRY VI

RUTLAND:
Ah, where must I fly to escape their hands?
Ah, guardian, look where the damn Clifford is coming from!

CLIFFORD:
Chaplain, go! your priesthood saves your life.
As for that damn duke's kid,
Whose father killed my father, he will die.

Tutor:
And I, my lord, will keep him company.

CLIFFORD:
Soldiers, far from him!

Tutor:
Ah, Clifford, don't kill this innocent child,
Lest you be hated both by God and man!

CLIFFORD:
How now! is he already dead? or is it fear
Does this make him close his eyes? I'll open them.

RUTLAND:
So looks the lion driven back on the wretched
Which trembles under its devouring paws;
And so he walks, insulting his prey,
And so he comes, to tear his members apart.
Ah, kind Clifford, kill me with your sword,
And not with such a cruel and menacing look.
Sweet Clifford, hear me speak before I die.
I am too wicked a subject for your anger:
Take revenge on men and let me live.

CLIFFORD:
It is in vain that you speak, poor boy; my father's blood
Closed the passage where your words were to enter.

RUTLAND:
As my father's blood opens it again:
He is a man and, Clifford, face him.

CLIFFORD:
If your brothers were here, their lives and yours
Was revenge not enough for me?
No, if I dug up the graves of your ancestors
And they hung their rotten coffins with chains,
It couldn’t quell my anger or calm my heart.
The view from any of York's house
It is like a fury to torment my soul;
And until I eradicate their cursed bloodline
And don't leave anyone alive, I live in hell.
SO--

RUTLAND:
Oh, let me pray before I die!
I beg you; sweet Clifford, pity me!

CLIFFORD:
What mercy the tip of my rapier offers.

RUTLAND:
I never hurt you: why will you kill me?

CLIFFORD:
Your father did it.

RUTLAND:
But that was before I was born.
You have a son ; for him, have pity on me,
Lest in vengeance, if God be just,
He will be killed as miserably as me.
Ah, let me live in prison all my days;
And when I give the opportunity to offend,
So let me die, because now you have no reason.

CLIFFORD:
No reason !
Your father killed my father; therefore, die.

RUTLAND:
Di faciant laudis summa sit ista tuae!

CLIFFORD:
Plantagenet! I'm coming, Plantagenêt!
And it's your son's blood that clings to my blade
Must rust on my weapon, until your blood,
Frozen with this, make me wipe both.
3KING HENRY VI

YORK:
The Queen's army is on the campaign:
My uncles were both killed while rescuing me;
And all my disciples to the bitter enemy
Turn around and fly, like ships into the wind
Or lambs chased by hungry wolves.
My sons, God knows what happened to them:
But that, I know, they humiliated themselves
Like men born for fame by life or death.
Three times, Richard walked towards me.
And three times he cried: “Courage, father! fight him! »
And, as often, Edward came to my side,
With purple falchion, painted to the hilt
In the blood of those who had met him:
And when the most valiant warriors withdrew,
Richard shouted, “Charge!” and don't give a single foot of land!
And he cried out: “A crown, or else a glorious tomb!”
A scepter or an earthly sepulchre!
With that, we charged again: but outside, alas!
We were wrong again; like I saw a swan
With useless work, swim against the tide
And expend his strength with overmatched waves.
Oh, listen! the fatal partisans actually pursue;
And I am weak and I cannot escape their fury:
And if I were strong, I would not avoid their fury:
The sands that make up my life are numbered;
Here I must stay, and here my life must end.
Come, damn Clifford, rough Northumberland,
I dare your inextinguishable fury to more rage:
I'm your ass and I'll take your shot.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
At our mercy, proud Plantagenet.

CLIFFORD:
Yes, to the mercy of his pitiless arm,
With direct payment, shown to my father.
Now Phaeton has fallen from his car,
And makes a midday evening sting.

YORK:
My ashes, like the phoenix, can give birth
A bird that will take revenge on you all:
And in this hope I cast my eyes to the sky,
Despising everything with which you can afflict me.
Why do not you come ? What! multitudes, and fear?

CLIFFORD:
So cowards fight when they can fly no further;
So the doves peck at the piercing claws of the hawk;
Thieves so desperate, all desperate for their lives,
Express invectives against officers.

YORK:
O Clifford, but think of you once more,
And in your thoughts you have passed my former time;
And if you can blush, look at this face,
And bite your tongue, which slanders him with cowardice
Whose frown made you faint and run away before that!

CLIFFORD:
I won't speak to you word for word,
But give in to your blows, twice two for one.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Here, valiant Clifford! for a thousand causes
I would prolong the traitor's life for a while.
Anger makes him deaf: speak, Northumberland.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
Wait, Clifford! don't honor him so much
To prick your finger, but to hurt his heart:
What value was it, when a priest smiled,
For someone to put their hand between their teeth,
When could he kick him away?
It is the price of war to take all the advantages;
And ten to one is not an indictment of courage.

CLIFFORD:
Yes, yes, this is how woodcock strives with gin.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
The same goes for the cony struggling in the net.

YORK:
Thus the thieves triumph over their conquered booty;
So true men give in, with thieves so outmatched.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
What would your grace have done to him now?

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Brave warriors, Clifford and Northumberland,
Come, make him stand on this here molehill,
Who attacks the mountains with outstretched arms,
Yet he only separated the shadow of his hand.
What! are you the one who would be the king of England?
Aren't you who feasted in our parliament,
And have you given a sermon on your high descent?
Where are your sons to support you now?
The wanton Edward and the lusty George?
And where is this valiant trickster prodigy,
Dicky your boy, that with his growling voice
Did he use to encourage his father during mutinies?
Or, with the rest, where is your darling Rutland?
Listen, York: I stained this napkin with blood
This valiant Clifford, with the point of his rapier,
Out of the boy's womb;
And if your eyes can cry for his death,
I give you this to dry your cheeks.
Alas, poor York! but I hate you mortally,
I should deplore your miserable state.
Please, sorrow, make me glad, York.
What, has your inflamed heart so dried up your insides
That not a tear can be shed for the death of Rutland?
Why are you patient, man? you should be crazy;
And I, to make you mad, I make fun of you like this.
Dab, rave and get excited, so I can sing and dance.
You would be paid, I see, for making me play:
York can't speak unless he's wearing a crown.
A crown for York! and, lords, bow down before him:
Hold his hands while I put him in place.
Yes, get married, sir, he looks like a king now!
Yes, it was he who took the chair of King Henry,
And here he was his adopted heir.
But how is it that this great Plantagenet
Is he crowned so soon and has he broken his solemn oath?
If I remember correctly, you shouldn't be king
Until our King Henry shook hands with death.
And will you fade your head in Henry's glory,
And strip her temples of the diadem,
Now in his life, against your holy oath?
Oh, this is also a mistake, too unforgivable!
Take off the crown, and with the crown his head;
And while we breathe, let's take the time to kill it.

CLIFFORD:
This is my office, for my father's sake.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
No, stay; let us listen to the prayers he makes.

YORK:
Wolf of France, but worse than the wolves of France,
Whose tongue is more venomous than the tooth of the viper!
How unpleasant it is in your sex
To triumph, like an Amazonian trull,
On their misfortunes that fortune captivates!
But your face is like that of a vizard, immutable,
Made impudent by the use of evil deeds,
I would try, proud queen, to make you blush.
To tell you where you come from, who you are descended from,
If you were ashamed enough to shame yourself, weren't you shameless.
Your father bears the type of the King of Naples,
From Sicilies and Jerusalem,
But not as rich as an English yeoman.
Did this poor monarch teach you to insult?
It's not necessary, and it doesn't bother you, proud queen,
Unless the adage needs to be verified,
These beggars on horseback race their horses to the death.
It is beauty that often makes women proud;
But, God knows, your part is small:
It is virtue that makes them most admired;
The opposite makes you think:
It is the government that makes them appear divine;
Lack makes you abominable:
You are the opposite of all good
As the Antipodes are to us,
Or like the south to the north.
O heart of a tiger wrapped in the skin of a woman!
How could you drain the child's blood,
To ask the father to wipe his eyes with it,
And yet be seen with a woman's face?
Women are gentle, gentle, pitiful and flexible;
You, stern, stubborn, hard, harsh, merciless.
Don't you tell me to get angry? well, now you have your wish:
Would I like to cry? well, now you have your will:
For the violent wind blows incessant showers,
And when the anger subsides, the rain begins.
These tears are the funeral of my sweet Rutland:
And every drop cries out for vengeance for his death,
"Against you," fell Clifford, "and you, false
French woman.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
Angers at me, but his passion moves me so much
I can barely hold back the tears from my eyes.

YORK:
This face of hungry cannibals
I would not have touched, I would not have stained blood:
But you are more inhuman, more inexorable,
O ten times more than the tigers of Hyrcania.
Look, merciless queen, at the tears of an unhappy father:
You dipped this cloth in my sweet boy's blood,
And I, with my tears, I wash away the blood.
Keep the towel, and go brag about this:
And if you tell the heavy story correctly,
On my soul, the listeners will shed tears;
Yes, even my enemies will shed tears that flow quickly,
And say: “Alas, it was a pitiful act!
There take the crown, and with the crown my curse;
And in your need, such comfort comes to you
How now I reap from your too cruel hand!
Hard-hearted Clifford, take me away from the world:
My soul to heaven, my blood on your heads!

NORTHUMBERLAND:
If he had been the man of massacre for all my loved ones,
I should not for my life but cry with him.
To see how sorrow grips his soul.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
What, in tears, my Lord Northumberland?
Think about it, but it's because of the wrong he did to us all,
And it will quickly dry your melting tears.

CLIFFORD:
So much for my oath, so much for my father's death.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
And here is to righting our gentle-hearted king.

YORK:
Open your door of mercy, merciful God!
My soul flies through these wounds to seek you.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Take off his head and lay it on the gates of York;
Thus, York risks neglecting the city of York.
3KING HENRY VI

EDWARD:
I wonder how our princely father escaped,
Or whether he ran away or not
From the pursuit of Clifford and Northumberland:
If he had been arrested, we should have heard the news;
If he had been killed, we should have heard the news;
Or if he had escaped, I think we should have heard
The happy news of his successful escape.
How is my brother? why is he so sad?

RICHARD:
I can't rejoice, until I'm resolved
Where did our valiant father become?
I saw him in the battlefield;
And I watched him how he chose Clifford.
I thought he wore it in the thickest troop
Like a lion in a herd of beasts;
Or like a bear surrounded by dogs,
Who pinched some and made them cry,
The others stand aside and bark at him.
So was our father with his enemies;
Thus my warrior father fled from his enemies:
It seems to me that this is reward enough for being his son.
See how the morning opens its golden doors,
And bid farewell to the glorious sun!
How it looks like the prime of life,
Trimm would like a younger one to prance in front of his love!

EDWARD:
Dazzle my eyes, or do I see three suns?

RICHARD:
Three glorious suns, each a perfect sun;
Not separated from the tearing clouds,
But separated in a pale, clear sky.
See see! they join, kiss and seem to kiss,
As if they were swearing to an inviolable league:
They are nothing more than a single lamp, a single light, a single sun.
In this, the sky represents an event.

EDWARD:
It's wonderfully strange, like nothing we've ever heard of.
I think that quotes us, brother, on the ground,
That we, the sons of the brave Plantagenet,
Everyone already flamboyant with our meals,
Should nevertheless join our lights together
And will illuminate the earth as well as the world.
Whatever it bodes, I will bear it from now on
On my target three bright suns.

RICHARD:
No, give birth to three daughters: with your permission, I say,
You like the breeder better than the male.
But what are you, whose heavy looks portend
A terrible story clinging to your tongue?

Messenger:
Ah, the one who was a horrible spectator
When the noble Duke of York was slain,
Your princely father and my beloved lord!

EDWARD:
Oh, don't talk anymore, because I've heard too much.

RICHARD:
Tell how he died, because I will hear everything.

Messenger:
Surrounded, he was with many enemies,
And stood against them, like the hope of Troy
Against the Greeks who entered Troy.
But Hercules himself must give in in the face of difficulties;
And many blows, but with a small axe,
Cut down and cut down the hardest-wooded oak.
By many hands your father was subdued;
But only slain by the wrathful arm
Of implacable Clifford and the Queen,
Who crowned the gracious duke despite everything,
He laughed in her face; and when he cried with sorrow,
The merciless queen gave him to dry his cheeks
A towel soaked with harmless blood
Of gentle young Rutland, killed by rough Clifford:
And after many contempts, many filthy taunts,
They took his head, and at the gates of York
They asked the same thing; and there it remains,
The saddest sight I have ever seen.

EDWARD:
Sweet Duke of York, our prop to lean on,
Now you're gone, we have no staff, no living quarters.
O Clifford, noisy Clifford! you killed
The flower of Europe for its chivalry;
And you defeated him through treachery,
In hand-to-hand combat, he would have defeated you.
Now the palace of my soul has become a prison:
Ah, would she break up with this, that it's my body
Could be locked in the ground at rest!
For from now on I will no longer rejoice,
Never, oh never will I see more joy!

RICHARD:
I can't cry; for all the moisture in my body
Rarely serves to quench my burning heart:
Neither can my tongue relieve the great burden of my heart;
For the same wind with which I should speak
They are lit coals that set my whole chest on fire,
And burns me with flames that tears would smother.
To cry is to reduce the depth of sorrow:
Tears therefore for babies; blows and revenge for me
Richard, I bear your name; I will avenge your death,
Or die of fame trying it.

EDWARD:
His name that this valiant duke left you;
His dukedom and his chair with me are left.

RICHARD:
No, if you are the bird of this princely eagle,
Show your descent looking against the sun:
For chair and duchy, throne and kingdom, say:
Either it is yours, or you were not his.

WARWICK:
Well, fair lords! What price? what news abroad?

RICHARD:
Great Lord of Warwick, if we were to tell
Our dire news, and to the deliverance of each word
Stab our daggers into our flesh until all the world is told,
Words would add more anguish than hurt.
O valiant lord, the Duke of York is slain!

EDWARD:
O Warwick, Warwick! that Plantagenet,
Who held three dear to his heart as the redemption of his soul,
Did the stern Lord Clifford put him to death.

WARWICK:
Ten days ago, I drowned this news in my tears;
And now, to add more measure to your misfortunes,
I'm here to tell you what happened then.
After the bloody fight at Wakefield,
Where your brave father breathed his last,
News, as quickly as messages could travel,
I heard of your loss and his departure.
I, then in London, guardian of the king,
I gathered my soldiers, I gathered flocks of friends,
And very well appointed, as I thought,
Marched towards Saint Alban to intercept the queen,
Taking the king in my favor;
Because my scouts told me
That she came with full intention
To destroy our late decree in parliament
Concerning King Henry's oath and your estate.
A little story to tell, we met in Saint Alban
Our battles joined, and both sides fought fiercely:
But if it was the king's coldness,
Who looked sweetly at her warrior queen,
This deprived my soldiers of their burning spleens;
Or if it was a report on his success;
Or more than the common fear of Clifford's rigor,
Who thunders blood and death to his captives,
I cannot judge: but to conclude with truth,
Their weapons came and went like lightning;
That of our soldiers, like the lazy flight of the night owl,
Or like an idle thresher with a flail,
They fell gently, as if hitting their friends.
I comforted them with the righteousness of our cause,
With the promise of high salary and great rewards:
But all in vain; they had no heart to fight,
And we have no hope of winning the situation;
As we fled; the king to the queen;
Lord George, your brother, Norfolk and myself,
In all haste, in all haste, come to join you:
For in the marches here we heard that you were,
Make another face to fight again.

EDWARD:
Where is the Duke of Norfolk, kind Warwick?
And when did George come to England from Burgundy?

WARWICK:
Six miles away, the duke is with the soldiers;
And for your brother, he was recently sent
From your kind aunt, Duchess of Burgundy,
With the help of soldiers in this necessary war.

RICHARD:
It was a safe bet that the valiant Warwick escaped:
I have often heard his praises in pursuit,
But never again his retirement scandal.

WARWICK:
And now you don't hear my scandal, Richard;
For you will know my strong right hand
Can tear the diadem from Henry's head, weak,
And snatches the horrible scepter from his fist,
Was he as famous and as daring in war
As he is renowned for his gentleness, peace and prayer.

RICHARD:
I know it well, Lord Warwick; don't blame me:
It is the love that I carry, your glories make me speak.
But in these troubled times, what to do?
Shall we throw away our coats of steel,
And wrap our bodies in black mourning robes,
Number our Hail Marys with our pearls?
Or should we wear the helmets of our enemies
Recount our devotion with vengeful weapons?
If it is for the end, say yes, and to that, lords.

WARWICK:
Well, that's why Warwick came for you;
And thus comes my brother Montague.
Assist me, lords. The proud insulting queen,
With Clifford and haughty Northumberland,
And from their feathers many other proud birds,
I shaped the king which melts easily like wax.
He has sworn to consent to your inheritance,
His oath was recorded in parliament;
And now in London the whole crew is gone,
To thwart both his oath and what else
Can do against the house of Lancaster.
Their power, I think, is thirty thousand strong:
Now, with the help of Norfolk and myself,
With all your friends, brave Earl of March,
Among the loving Welsh I can procure,
Will only amount to twenty-five thousand,
Why, via! towards London, shall we march again,
And let us ride our foaming steeds again,
And shout once again “Charge our enemies!” »
But never turn around and steal again.

RICHARD:
Yes, it seems to me now that I hear the great Warwick speaking:
He will never live long enough to see a sunny day,
This screams “Retire,” if Warwick asks him to stay.

EDWARD:
Lord Warwick, I will lean on your shoulder;
And when you fail, how God forbid at that hour!
Should Edward fall, what peril God preserve us!

WARWICK:
No longer Earl of March, but Duke of York:
The next degree is the royal throne of England;
For you will be proclaimed king of England
In each town we pass through;
And he who does not lift his cap for joy
Must, for the fault, have his head confiscated.
King Edward, Valiant Richard, Montague,
Let us no longer stay, dreaming of fame,
But sound the trumpets, and concerning our task.

RICHARD:
So, Clifford, was your heart as hard as steel,
As you showed flint by your deeds,
I'm coming to pierce it, or give you mine.

EDWARD:
So, bang the drum: God and Saint George for us!

WARWICK:
How now! What's new?

Messenger:
The Duke of Norfolk sends you a message through me,
The queen comes with a powerful army;
And needs your company for quick advice.

WARWICK:
Why then it's all right, brave warriors, let's go.
3KING HENRY VI

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Welcome, my lord, to this brave city of York.
There is the leader of this sworn enemy
Who sought to be surrounded by your crown:
Does not this object rejoice your heart, my lord?

KING HENRY VI:
Yes, as the rocks encourage those who fear their shipwreck:
Seeing this spectacle irritates my soul.
Restrain your vengeance, my God! it's not my fault,
Nor did I willfully violate my vow.

CLIFFORD:
My gracious liege, this is too much clemency
And harmful pity must be put aside.
To whom do the lions cast their gentle glances?
Not to the beast that would usurp their lair.
Whose hand does the forest bear lick?
He is not the one who spoils his youth in front of his face.
Who escapes the deadly sting of the lurking serpent?
Not the one who puts his foot on his back.
The smallest worm will become trampled,
And the doves will peck to protect their brood.
Ambitious York levels your crown,
You smiled while he frowned angrily:
He, if he were only a duke, would have his son king,
And raise his problem, like a loving father;
You, being a king, endowed with a good son,
Did you agree to disinherit him,
Which made you a very unloving father.
Unreasonable creatures feed their young;
And though the man's face is fearful in their eyes,
Yet, to protect their loved ones,
Who hasn't seen them, even with these wings
which they sometimes took advantage of with a frightening escape,
Make war on the one who climbed to their nest,
Offer their own lives in defense of their children?
For shame, my lord, make this your precedent!
Wasn't it a shame that this good boy
Should lose his birthright through his father's fault,
And long after, you will say to his child:
"What my great-grandfather and his grandfather had
My carefree father kindly confided it?
Ah, what a shame that was! Look at the boy;
And his virile face, which promises
Successful fortune, steel your melting heart
Hold his own and leave his own with him.

KING HENRY VI:
Clifford played the speaker very well,
Deduce arguments of great force.
But, Clifford, tell me, have you never heard
That things that went wrong never went wrong?
And it was always happy for this son
Because of his hoarding, what father went to hell?
I will leave my virtuous deeds behind to my son;
What if my father never left me again!
Because everything else is held at such a pace
As it brings a thousand times more care to keep
Only in possession and in joy.
Ah, cousin York! Did your best friends know
How it saddens me that your head is here!

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
My lord, cheer up: our enemies are close,
And this sweet courage makes your supporters faint.
You promised the title of knight to our fore-son:
Take out your sword and duplicate it immediately.
Edward, kneel down.

KING HENRY VI:
Edouard Plantagenêt, arise knight;
And learn this lesson, draw your sword correctly.

PRINCE:
My gracious father, with your royal permission,
I will draw it as apparent to the crown,
And in this quarrel, use him to the death.

CLIFFORD:
Well, it's addressed like a prince.

Messenger:
Royal commanders, be ready:
Because with a band of thirty thousand men
Comes Warwick, supported by the Duke of York;
And in the cities, as they walk,
Proclaims him king, and many fly to him:
Darraign your fight, for they are at hand.

CLIFFORD:
I would like Your Highness to leave the field:
The queen is more successful when you are away.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Yes, my lord, and leave us to our fortune.

KING HENRY VI:
Well, it's also my fortune; so I'm going to stay.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
Let it be with the resolution to fight.

PRINCE EDWARD:
My royal father, encourage these noble lords
And comfort those who fight in your defense:
Draw out your sword, good father; shout “Saint George!”

EDWARD:
Now Henry is perjuring! Will you kneel for grace,
And put your diadem on my head;
Or wait for the deadly fortune of the field?

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Come on, rate your servants, proud insulting boy!
It suits you to be so bold in terms
Before your sovereign and your lawful king?

EDWARD:
I am his king, and he must kneel;
I was adopted heir by his consent:
Since when has his oath been broken; because, as I understand it,
You who are king, even if he wears the crown,
Made him, by a new Act of Parliament,
To erase me and put his own son there.

CLIFFORD:
And the reason too:
Who should succeed the father if not the son?

RICHARD:
Are you there, butcher? Oh, I can't speak!

CLIFFORD:
Yes, crook, here I am to answer you,
Or anyone, he is the proudest of your kind.

RICHARD:
“You were the one who killed young Rutland, weren’t you?”

CLIFFORD:
Yes, and old York, and yet not satisfied.

RICHARD:
For the love of God, lords, give the signal to fight.

WARWICK:
What do you say, Henry, will you give up the crown?

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Well, how, long-tongued Warwick! do you dare to speak?
When you and I met for the last time in Saint Alban,
Your legs served better than your hands.

WARWICK:
Then it was my turn to steal, and now it's your turn.

CLIFFORD:
You said so much before, and yet you ran away.

WARWICK:
“It wasn't your courage, Clifford, that made me leave.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
No, nor your manhood which dared to make you stay.

RICHARD:
Northumberland, I hold you with respect.
Stop the talks; because I can barely refrain
Running my big swollen heart
About this Clifford, this cruel child killer.

CLIFFORD:
I killed your father, you call him a child?

RICHARD:
Yes, like a coward and a treacherous coward,
As you killed our tender brother Rutland;
But before sunset, I will make you curse this act.

KING HENRY VI:
Finish with the words, my lords, and hear me speak.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
So defy them, or close your lips.

KING HENRY VI:
Please give no limits to my tongue:
I am a king and I have the privilege of speaking.

CLIFFORD:
My lord, the wound that caused this meeting here
Cannot be healed by words; so stay calm.

RICHARD:
So, executioner, draw your sword:
By him who made us all, I am resolved
that Clifford's manhood rests on his tongue.

EDWARD:
Say, Henry, do I have my right or not?
A thousand men broke their fast today,
I will never dine unless you give up the crown.

WARWICK:
If you deny, their blood on your head;
For York, in justice, puts on his armor.

PRINCE EDWARD:
If what Warwick says is true,
There is no harm, but everything is good.

RICHARD:
The one who had you, your mother is there;
Because, I know, you have your mother's language.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
But you are neither like your father nor your mother;
But like a filthy and deformed stigma,
Marked by the fates to be avoided,
Like poisonous toads or terrible lizard bites.

RICHARD:
Naples iron hidden with English gilding,
Whose father bears the title of king,
As if a channel should be called the sea,
Are you not ashamed, knowing where you came from,
To let your tongue detect your vile heart?

EDWARD:
A blade of straw was worth a thousand crowns,
So that this shameless callet knows herself.
Helen of Greece was far more beautiful than you,
Although your husband is Menelaus;
And Agamemnon's brother was never wrong
By this false woman, like this king by you.
His father delighted in the heart of France,
And he tamed the king, and brought down the dolphin;
And if it had been matched according to its condition,
He could have retained this glory to this day;
But when he took a beggar to his bed,
And I honored your poor father on his wedding day,
Even then, this sun prepared a shower for him,
This took his father's fortune out of France,
And he caused sedition on his crown at home.
For what has broached this tumult but your pride?
If you had been gentle, our title would still have slept;
And we, for pity of the sweet king,
We had postponed our claim to another age.

GEORGE:
But when we saw our sun make your spring,
And your summer did not bring us growth,
We lay the ax on your usurping root;
And although something knocked us to the edge,
Yet, know this, since we began to strike,
We'll never leave until we take you down,
Or bathed your growth with our warm bloods.

EDWARD:
And, in this resolution, I challenge you;
Not wanting any more conferences,
Since you refuse the gentle king to speak.
Sound the trumpets! let our bloody colors float!
And either victory or death.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Stay, Edward.

EDWARD:
No, argumentative, we will no longer stay:
These words will cost ten thousand lives today.
3KING HENRY VI

WARWICK:
Spent by toil, like runners by a race,
I lie down for a little while to breathe;
For the blows received and the numerous blows reimbursed,
I deprived my strong tendons of their strength,
And despite my needs, I must rest for a while.

EDWARD:
Smile, sweet heaven! or strike, brutal death!
For this world frowns, and Edward's sun is darkened.

WARWICK:
Well, my lord! What happened ? what hope of good?

GEORGE:
Our misfortune is a loss, our hope is only a sad despair;
Our ranks are broken, and ruin follows us:
What advice do you give yourself? where are we going to fly?

EDWARD:
Without boots, it's flight, they follow us with wings;
And we are weak and cannot avoid pursuit.

RICHARD:
Ah, Warwick, why did you withdraw?
The thirsty earth has drunk your brother's blood,
Approached with the steel point of Clifford's spear;
And in the throes of death he cried:
Like a mournful noise heard from afar,
“Warwick, revenge!” brother, avenge my death!
So, under the bellies of their horses,
It stained their fetlocks in its steaming blood,
The noble gentleman has given up the ghost.

WARWICK:
So let the earth be drunk with our blood:
I will kill my horse, because I will not steal.
Why do we stay here like tender-hearted women,
We lament our losses, while the enemy rages;
And look, as if the tragedy
Were they played in jest by fake actors?
Here, on my knees, I make a vow to God above,
I'll never stop, I'll never stand still,
Until death closes my eyes
Or fortune gave me a measure of vengeance.

EDWARD:
O Warwick, I bend my knee with thine;
And with this vow, chain my soul to yours!
And before my knee rises from the cold face of the earth,
I cast my hands, my eyes, my heart towards you,
You who established and removed kings,
I beg you, if they want it, it works
That for my enemies this body must be prey,
Yet so that your bronze gates of heaven may be opened,
And give sweet passage to my sinful soul!
Now, lords, take your leave until we meet again,
Wherever it is, in heaven or on earth.

RICHARD:
Brother, give me your hand; and, kind Warwick,
Let me kiss you in my tired arms:
I who have never cried, I now melt with misfortune
This winter should thus cut off our spring.

WARWICK:
Far, far! Once again, sweet lords, farewell.

GEORGE:
But let's all rally to our troops,
And give them permission to fly who will not stay;
And call them pillars that will stand before us;
And if we prosper, promise them such rewards
How the winners wear the Olympic games:
This may give courage to their trembling breasts;
Because there is still hope of life and victory.
Don't delay any longer, make sure we stay.
3KING HENRY VI

RICHARD:
Now, Clifford, I have chosen you alone:
Suppose this arm is for the Duke of York,
And this for Rutland; both dedicated to revenge,
Would you be surrounded by a wall of bronze?

CLIFFORD:
Now, Richard, I am here alone with you:
This is the hand that stabbed your father York;
And this is the hand that killed your brother Rutland;
And here is the heart that triumphs in their death
And rejoice those hands that killed your father and your brother
To perform the same on yourself;
And then, be yours!

RICHARD:
No, Warwick, choose another pursuit;
For I myself will hunt this wolf to the death.
3KING HENRY VI

KING HENRY VI:
This battle is going on like the morning war,
When the dying clouds fight against the growing light,
At what time the shepherd, blowing his nails,
I can neither call it perfect day or night.
Now swing it this way, like a mighty sea
Forced by the tide to fight against the wind;
Now he swings it this way, like the same sea
Forced to give up by the fury of the wind:
Sometimes it is the flood that prevails, then the wind;
Now one is the best, then another is the best;
Both striving to be victorious, chest to chest,
Yet neither conqueror nor conquered:
The same goes for this fallen war.
Here, on this molehill, I will sit.
To whom God wills, there be victory!
For Margaret my queen, and Clifford too,
Scolded me during battle; both swearing
They thrive best when I'm there.
If I were dead! if the good will of God was;
For what is there in this world but sorrow and misfortune?
Oh my God! I think it was a happy life,
To be no better than a simple married man;
Sit on a hill, like I do now,
To carve dials in a picturesque way, point by point,
So to see the minutes how they unfold,
How many complete the hour;
How many hours are in the day;
How many days will the year end;
How many years can a mortal live.
When this is known, then divide the times:
So many hours must I tend my flock;
So many hours must I take my rest;
So many hours must I contemplate;
I need so many hours of sport;
So many days have my sheep been with their young;
So many weeks before the poor fools understood:
So many years before I sheared the fleece:
So minutes, hours, days, months and years,
Passed to the end, they were created,
Would bring gray hairs to a quiet grave.
Ah, what a life it was! how nice! so pretty!
Does not give hawthorn a softer shade
To the shepherds who look at their stupid sheep,
Than a rich embroidered canopy
To kings who fear betrayal from their subjects?
Oh, yes, that's true; It’s a thousand times more true.
And to conclude, the shepherd's curdled milk,
His cold, fine drink out of its leather bottle.
His usual sleep in the shade of a cool tree,
All he enjoys safely and sweetly,
Is far beyond the delicacies of a prince,
Its sparkling meats in a golden cup,
His body lying in a curious bed,
When worry, distrust and betrayal await him.

Son:
I will blow the wind that benefits no one.
This man I killed in hand-to-hand combat,
May be possessed of a hoard of crowns;
And I might take them away from him now,
May still before night deliver both my life and them
To another man, as this dead man does to me.
Who is it? Oh my God! it's my father's face,
Who, in this conflict, I killed without knowing it.
O heavy times, generating such events!
The king took me out of London;
My father, being the Earl of Warwick's man,
Came from York, urged by his master;
And I, who in his hands I received my life, he
I mourned him with my hands.
Forgive me, God, I didn't know what I had done!
And sorry, father, because I didn't know you!
My tears will erase these bloody marks;
And no more words until they are full.

KING HENRY VI:
O pitiful spectacle! O bloody times!
While the lions wage war and fight for their dens,
Poor, harmless lambs bear their enmity.
Cry, wretch, I will help you tear for tear;
And may our hearts and our eyes, like the civil war,
Be blind with tears and break down overwhelmed with sorrow.

Father:
You who resisted me so valiantly,
Give me your gold, if you have any:
Because I bought it at a hundred blows.
But let me see: is this the face of our enemy?
Ah, no, no, no, he's my only son!
Ah, my boy, if there is any life left in you,
Look up! see, see what showers come,
Blown by the windy storm of my heart,
On your words, which kill my eyes and my heart!
O pity, my God, this miserable century!
What stratagems, what fall, what butchery,
Wrong, mutinous and unnatural,
This deadly feud breeds every day!
O my boy, your father gave you life too soon,
And he deprived you of your life too late!

KING HENRY VI:
Woe above woe! sorrow is more than ordinary sorrow!
O may my death stop these merciless acts!
O pity, pity, sweet heaven, pity!
The red rose and the white one are on her face,
The fatal colors of our struggling houses:
The one to whom his purple blood closely resembles;
The other, his pale cheeks, it seems to me, presents:
Wither one rose and let the other bloom;
If you struggle, a thousand lives will disappear.

Son:
How is my mother doing for the death of a father
Face me and never be satisfied!

Father:
How is my wife for the massacre of my son
Shed seas of tears and never be satisfied!

KING HENRY VI:
How will the country face these terrible odds?
Think ill of the king and be dissatisfied!

Son:
Has a son ever regretted the death of a father so much?

Father:
Has there ever been a father who deplored his son so much?

KING HENRY VI:
Was a king ever so distressed by the misfortune of his subjects?
Your grief is great; mine ten times more.

Son:
I'll take you from here, where I can cry my heart out.

Father:
My weapons will be your shroud;
My heart, sweet boy, will be your sepulchre,
For your image will never leave my heart;
My sighing chest will be your funeral bell;
And your father will be so obsequious,
Even for your loss, having no more,
As Priam was to all his valiant sons.
I will carry you from here; and let them fight this will,
Because I killed where I should not have killed.

KING HENRY VI:
Men with sad hearts, overwhelmed with cares,
Here sits a king more terrible than you.

PRINCE EDWARD:
Fly, father, fly! because all your friends have fled,
And Warwick gets angry like an angry bull:
Far! because death pursues us.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Come up, my lord; to Berwick post tomorrow:
Edward and Richard, like two greyhounds
Having in sight the fearsome flying hare,
With fiery eyes sparkling with anger,
And bloody steel seized in their wrathful hands,
Are by our side; and therefore therefore a hand.

EXECUTE:
Far! because vengeance accompanies them:
No, don't reproach, do it quickly;
Or come later: I will leave before.

KING HENRY VI:
No, take me with you, my good and sweet Exeter:
Not that I'm afraid to stay, but I like to go
Where the queen wants. Before; far!
3KING HENRY VI

CLIFFORD:
Here my candle goes out; yeah, here he dies,
Which, while it lasted, enlightened King Henry.
O Lancaster, I fear your overthrow
More than my body separates from my soul!
My love and my fear have made many friends with you;
And now I'm falling, your hard mixture is melting.
Belittling Henry, strengthening the unfortunate York,
Ordinary people swarm like summer flies;
And where do the midges fly if not towards the sun?
And who shines now, if not Henry's enemies?
O Phoebus, have you never given your consent
So that Phaethon stops your fiery steeds,
Your burning car never burned the earth!
And, Henry, if you had influenced as kings should,
Or like your father and his father did,
Yielding no ground to the house of York,
Never then had they appeared like summer flies;
Me and ten thousand people in this unhappy kingdom
Had left no widow to mourn our death;
And you, that day, you kept your chair in peace.
For what do we cherish but the sweet air?
And what makes thieves bold, if not too lenient?
Complaints are useless, and my wounds are incurable;
No means to fly, nor strength to maintain flight:
The enemy is merciless and will have no mercy;
For from them I deserved no pity.
The air entered my mortal wounds,
And a lot of bloodshed makes me pass out.
Come, York and Richard, Warwick and the rest;
I stabbed your fathers' chests, I split my chest.

EDWARD:
Now let's breathe, lords: luck invites us to take a break,
