And soften the frowns of war with peaceful looks.
Some troops pursue the bloody queen,
This led Henry calm, although he was a king,
Like a sail, filled with an ominous gust,
Order an Argosy to stem the waves.
But do you think, lords, that Clifford ran away with them?

WARWICK:
No, it's impossible for him to escape,
Because, even if in front of his face I say the words
Your brother Richard marked it for the grave:
And wherever he is, he's probably dead.

EDWARD:
Whose soul is it that takes a heavy leave?

RICHARD:
A deathly moan, like the departure of life and death.

EDWARD:
See who it is: and now the battle is over,
Whether friend or foe, let him be used gently.

RICHARD:
Revoke this judgment of mercy, for it is Clifford;
Who is not happy to have cut the branch
By pruning Rutland when its leaves were growing,
But I put his murderous knife to the root
From which this tender jet gently springs,
I mean our princely father, the Duke of York.

WARWICK:
From the gates of York, collect your head,
Your father's head, which Clifford placed there;
Instead, let this populate the room:
We must respond measure by measure.

EDWARD:
Bring this deadly owl into our house,
That nothing sang but death for us and ours:
Now death will stop its mournful and menacing sound,
And his tongue of ill omen will speak no more.

WARWICK:
I think he doesn't quite understand.
Speak, Clifford, do you know who is speaking to you?
Dark and cloudy death eclipses its rays of life,
And he doesn't see us or hear what we say.

RICHARD:
Oh, would he! and maybe that's what he does:
It's just his policy of counterfeiting,
Because he would avoid such bitter taunts
Which he gave to our father at the time of his death.

GEORGE:
If you think so, antagonize him with hasty words.

RICHARD:
Clifford, ask for mercy and get no mercy.

EDWARD:
Clifford, repent in unnecessary penance.

WARWICK:
Clifford, make excuses for your mistakes.

GEORGE:
While we design terrible tortures for your sins.

RICHARD:
You loved York, and I am York's son.

EDWARD:
You took pity on Rutland; I will pity you.

GEORGE:
Where is Captain Margaret, for closure now?

WARWICK:
They're laughing at you, Clifford: swear like you used to.

RICHARD:
What, not an oath? no, then the world becomes harsh
When Clifford can't spare his friends an oath.
I know from this that he is dead; and, through my soul,
If this right hand could buy two hours of life,
That despite everything I could insult him,
This hand should cut it, and with the
give blood
Suffocate the wicked whose insatiable thirst
York and young Rutland could not satisfy.

WARWICK:
Yes, but he is dead: remove the traitor's head,
And raise him up in the place where your father is.
And now towards London with a triumphant march,
There to be crowned Royal King of England:
From where will Warwick cut the sea to France,
And ask Lady Bona your queen:
So you will divide these two lands together;
And having France as a friend, you will not fear
The scattered enemy who hopes to rise again;
For although they cannot sting greatly to hurt,
Yet, be careful that they buzz to offend your ears.
I will see the coronation first;
And then in Brittany I will cross the sea,
To carry out this marriage, may it please my lord.

EDWARD:
Even if you wish it, sweet Warwick, so be it;
For on your shoulder I build my seat,
And I will never undertake the thing
Where your advice and consent are lacking.
Richard, I will make you Duke of Gloucester,
And George, of Clarence: Warwick, like ourselves,
He will do and undo as he pleases.

RICHARD:
Let me be Duke of Clarence, George of Gloucester;
Because the Duchy of Gloucester is too worrying.

WARWICK:
But that's a stupid observation:
Richard, be Duke of Gloucester. Now in London,
To see these honors in possession.
3KING HENRY VI

First goalkeeper:
Under this thick brake, we will wrap ourselves;
For soon the deer will come across this plain;
And in this secret we will take our stand,
Shoot down the main of all the deer.

Second goalkeeper:
I'll stay over the hill so the two can shoot.

First goalkeeper:
This cannot be; the sound of your crossbow
This will scare the herd, and so my shoot is lost.
We are both here and aim for the best:
And, because time will not seem tedious,
I'll tell you what happened to me one day
In this place where we now intend to stand.

Second goalkeeper:
Here is a man; let's stay until it has passed.

KING HENRY VI:
From Scotland I am stolen, even for pure love,
To greet my own land with my pious gaze.
No, Harry, Harry, this is not your land;
Your place is filled, your scepter has been taken from you,
Your balm has been washed with which you have been anointed:
No bent knee will call you Caesar from now on,
No humble pretender presses forward to speak for good,
No, no one comes to ask you for compensation;
Because how can I help them, and not myself?

First goalkeeper:
Yes, here is a deer whose skin is a keeper's prize:
He is the former king; let's grab it.

KING HENRY VI:
Let me embrace you, bitter adversity,
Because the wise say that this is the wisest solution.

Second goalkeeper:
Why should we linger? let us lay our hands on him.

First goalkeeper:
Abstain for a moment; we'll hear a little more.

KING HENRY VI:
My queen and my son went to France to ask for help;
And, as I hear it, the great Commander Warwick
Left there, to implore the sister of the King of France
Marry Edward: if this news is true,
Poor queen and son, your work is only wasted;
For Warwick is a subtle speaker,
And Lewis, a prince, quickly won with moving words.
By this story, Margaret can then win him;
Because she is a woman to be pitied:
His sighs will make a drum in his chest;
Her tears will pierce a heart of marble;
The tiger will be gentle while he cries;
And Nero will be tainted with remorse,
To hear and see her complaints, her briny tears.
Yes, but she came to beg, Warwick to give;
She, on her left side, begging for help for Henry,
He, on his right, asks for a wife for Edward.
She cries and says her Henry is deposed;
He smiles and says his Edward is settled;
That she, the poor wretch, can no longer speak because of grief;
While Warwick tells his title, smoothes out the errors,
Deduce arguments of great force,
And in conclusion he wins the king from her,
With his sister's promise, and what else,
Strengthen and support King Edward Square.
O Marguerite, so it will be; and you, poor soul,
You are then abandoned, since you left alone!

Second goalkeeper:
Say, what are you to talk about kings and queens?

KING HENRY VI:
More than I seem, and less than I was born to do:
A man at least, because without that I would not be one;
And men can talk about kings, and why not me?

Second goalkeeper:
Yes, but you talk like you're a king.

KING HENRY VI:
Well, that's what I think; and that's enough.

Second goalkeeper:
But if you are king, where is your crown?

KING HENRY VI:
My crown is in my heart, not on my head;
Not adorned with diamonds and Indian stones,
Nor to see: my crown is called content:
A crown that kings rarely enjoy.

Second goalkeeper:
Well, if you are a king crowned with contentment,
Your crown is happy and you must be happy
To accompany us; because as we think,
You are the king that King Edward deposed;
And we, his subjects, took the oath of allegiance
Will apprehend you as his enemy.

KING HENRY VI:
But have you never sworn and broken an oath?

Second goalkeeper:
No, never such an oath; and won't do it now either.

KING HENRY VI:
Where did you live when I was king of England?

Second goalkeeper:
Here, in this country, where we stay now.

KING HENRY VI:
I was anointed king at the age of nine months;
My father and my grandfather were kings,
And you have been true sworn subjects for me:
And tell me, have you not broken your oaths?

First goalkeeper:
No;
For we were subjects, but while you were king.

KING HENRY VI:
Why am I dead? am I not breathing a man?
Ah! simple men, you don't know what you swear!
Listen, while I blow this feather from my face,
And as the air blows it to me again,
Obeying my wind when I blow,
And give in to another when he blows,
Always commanded by the greatest gust;
Such is the lightness of you, ordinary men.
But do not break your oaths; because of this sin
My sweet supplication will not make you guilty.
Go where you want, the king will be in charge;
And be kings, command, and I will obey.

First goalkeeper:
We are true subjects of the king, King Edward.

KING HENRY VI:
So would you be with Henry again,
If he sat like King Edward.

First goalkeeper:
We charge you, in the name of God and the king,
To accompany us to the officers.

KING HENRY VI:
In the name of God, lead; the name of your king be obeyed:
And what God wills, let your king execute it;
And what he wants, I humbly yield.
3KING HENRY VI

KING EDWARD IV:
Brother of Gloucester, in the field of Saint Alban
This lady's husband, Sir Richard Grey, was killed.
His lands then seized by the conqueror:
His goal now is to regain possession of these lands;
What we, in justice, cannot deny,
Because in the quarrel of the House of York
The worthy gentleman lost his life.

GLOCKESTER:
Your Highness will do well to grant his request;
It was a dishonor to refuse him.

KING EDWARD IV:
It was nothing less; but I'm still going to take a break.

GLOCKESTER:

CLARENCE:

GLOCKESTER:

KING EDWARD IV:
Widow, we will consider your request;
And come another time to know our spirit.

LADY GREY:
Most gracious lord, I cannot bear delay:
May it please Your Highness to resolve me now;
And what is your pleasure, will satisfy me.

GLOCKESTER:

CLARENCE:

GLOCKESTER:

KING EDWARD IV:
How many children do you have, widow? tell me.

CLARENCE:

GLOCKESTER:

LADY GRAY:
Third, my most gracious lord.

GLOCKESTER:

KING EDWARD IV:
“It would be a shame if they lost their father’s lands.

LADY GRAY:
Be pitiful, dreadful lord, and grant it then.

KING EDWARD IV:
Lords, give us leave: I will try the wit of this widow.

GLOCKESTER:

KING EDWARD IV:
Now tell me, lady, do you love your children?

LADY GRAY:
Yes, full as dear as I love myself.

KING EDWARD IV:
And wouldn't you do much to do them good?

LADY GRAY:
To do them good, I would suffer harm.

KING EDWARD IV:
So recover your husband's land, to do them good.

LADY GRAY:
This is why I came to Your Majesty.

KING EDWARD IV:
I will tell you how to get these lands.

LADY GREY:
So will you bind me to the service of Your Highness.

KING EDWARD IV:
What service will you do me if I do them?

LADY GRAY:
What you order is for me to do.

KING EDWARD IV:
But you will accept exceptions for my benefit.

LADY GRAY:
No, gracious lord, except I can't do it.

KING EDWARD IV:
Yes, but you can do what I want to ask you.

LADY GREY:
Well, then I will do as your grace commands.

GLOCKESTER:

CLARENCE:

LADY GRAY:
Why stop my lord, shall I not hear my task?

KING EDWARD IV:
An easy task; it is only to love a king.

LADY GREY:
It will soon be done, because I am a subject.

KING EDWARD IV:
Well, I'll give you your husband's land for free.

LADY GRAY:
I take my leave with a thousand thanks.

GLOCKESTER:

KING EDWARD IV:
But stay you, these are the fruits of love, I mean.

LADY GRAY:
I mean the fruits of love, my kind lord.

KING EDWARD IV:
Yes, but I fear myself, in another sense.
What love, do you think, am I so eager to obtain?

LADY GRAY:
My love unto death, my humble thanks, my prayers;
This love that virtue demands and grants.

KING EDWARD IV:
No, my word, I wasn't talking about such love.

LADY GREY:
Well, then you don't mean what I thought.

KING EDWARD IV:
But now you can partly perceive my mind.

LADY GRAY:
My mind will never grant what I perceive
Your Highness aims, if I aim well.

KING EDWARD IV:
To tell you clearly, I intend to sleep with you.

LADY GRAY:
To tell you clearly, I would rather stay in prison.

KING EDWARD IV:
Well, then you won't have your husband's land.

LADY GREY:
Well, then my honesty will be my dowry;
Because because of this loss, I will not buy them.

KING EDWARD IV:
This is where you are doing your children considerable harm.

LADY GRAY:
Here, Your Highness is wronging them and me.
But, mighty lord, this joyful inclination
This doesn't match the sadness of my costume:
Please return me with “yes” or “no”.

KING EDWARD IV:
Yes, if you want to answer “yes” to my request;
No, if you say “no” to my request.

LADY GRAY:
So no, my lord. My trial is over.

GLOCKESTER:

CLARENCE:

KING EDWARD IV:

LADY GRAY:
Better said than done, my gracious lord:
I'm a subject worthy of joking,
But far from being fit to be sovereign.

KING EDWARD IV:
Sweet widow, by my condition I swear to you
I only speak what my soul wants;
And that is to say, take advantage of you for my love.

LADY GRAY:
And that's more than I'll give in to:
I know I'm too bad to be your queen,
And yet too beautiful to be your concubine.

KING EDWARD IV:
You quibble, widow: I meant, my queen.

LADY GREY:
“It would upset your Grace, my sons should call you father.

KING EDWARD IV:
No more than when my daughters call you mother.
You are a widow and you have children;
And, by the mother of God, I, being only a bachelor,
Have others: well, it's a happy thing
Being the father of several sons.
Don't answer anymore, because you will be my queen.

GLOCKESTER:

CLARENCE:

KING EDWARD IV:
Brothers, think about the conversation we both had.

GLOCKESTER:
This does not please the widow, because she looks very sad.

KING EDWARD IV:
You will find it strange that I am marrying him.

CLARENCE:
To whom, my lord?

KING EDWARD IV:
Why, Clarence, for myself.

GLOCKESTER:
It would be at least a ten-day wonder.

CLARENCE:
It's one day longer than a wonder lasts.

GLOCKESTER:
The wonder is all the more extreme.

KING EDWARD IV:
Well, joke, my brothers: I can tell you both
Her request is granted for her husband's lands.

Noble:
My gracious lord, Henry, your enemy is taken,
And I have brought your prisoner to the gate of your palace.

KING EDWARD IV:
Make sure he gets transported to the Tower:
And let us go, brothers, to the man who took him away,
To the question of his apprehension.
Widow, go ahead. Lords, use it honorably.

GLOCKESTER:
Yes, Edward will use women honorably.
Would he be exhausted, marrow, bones and all,
So that from his loins no branch full of hope can spring,
To cross me from the golden time that I seek!
And yet, between the desire of my soul and me...
Lecherous Edward's Title Buried...
Clarence, Henry and his son young Edward,
And all the unexpected outcomes of their bodies,
To take their rooms, before I can take my place:
Cold premeditation for my words!
Well, then, I only dream of sovereignty;
Like one who stands on a promontory,
And sees a distant shore where he would walk,
Wishing his foot to be equal to his eye,
And from there he rebukes the sea that divides him,
Saying, he will load it dry to do what he wants:
So I wish for the crown, being so far away;
Then I rebuke the means that prevent me;
And so I say, I will cut the causes,
Flattering myself with impossibilities.
My eye is too keen, my heart races too much,
Unless my hand and strength can match them.
Well, let's say there is no kingdom for Richard then;
What other pleasure can the world offer itself?
I will make my paradise on the knees of a lady,
And decorate my body with cheerful ornaments,
And witch sweet ladies with my words and my looks.
O miserable thought! and more improbable
Than accomplish twenty golden crowns!
Well, love forgave me in my mother's womb:
And, for I should not mind her gentle laws,
She corrupted fragile nature with bribes,
To shrink my arm like a withered shrub;
To make an envious mountain on my back,
Where is the deformity to mock my body;
To shape my unevenly sized legs;
To disproportion myself in every way,
Like chaos, or a little unlicked bear
It doesn't feel like the dam.
And am I therefore a man to be loved?
O monstrous fault, to entertain such a thought!
So, since this land brings me no joy,
But order, check, bear such
As I am a better person than I am,
I will make my paradise a dream on the crown,
And while I live, to account for this world but hell,
Until my deformed trunk which carries this head
Be round impaled with a glorious crown.
And yet I don't know how to get the crown,
Many lives stand between me and home:
And I, like someone lost in a thorny wood,
Who tears thorns and is torn with thorns,
Seeking a path and turning away from it;
Not knowing how to find the outdoors,
But I'm working desperately to find out,--
Tormenting myself to catch the English crown:
And from this torment I will free myself,
Or cut my way with a damn axe.
Well I can smile and kill while I smile,
And shout “Glad” to what afflicts my heart,
And I wet my cheeks with artificial tears,
And frames my face on all occasions.
I will drown more sailors than the mermaid;
I will kill more spectators than the basilisk;
I will play the speaker as well as Nestor,
Deceive more slyly than Ulysses could,
And, like an Otherwise, take another Troy.
I can add colors to the chameleon,
Shapeshift with Proteus for benefits,
And put the murderer Machiavelli in school.
Can I do this without being able to get a crown?
But if it was any further, I would rip it out.
3KING HENRY VI

KING LEWIS XI:
Beautiful Queen of England, worthy Marguerite,
Sit down with us: this does not suit your state
And birth, so that you are standing while Lewis is sitting.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
No, powerful king of France: now Marguerite
I must raise the sail and learn to serve for a while
Where kings rule. I was, I must admit,
The Queen of the great Albion in the golden days of yesteryear:
But now chance has trodden my title,
And with dishonor I lay down on the ground;
Where I must take my place for my fortune,
And I conform to my humble seat.

KING LEWIS XI:
Why, let us say, fair queen, where does this deep despair come from?

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
For a cause that fills my eyes with tears
And shut my tongue, while my heart is drowned in worries.

KING LEWIS XI:
No matter what, always be like yourself,
And sit beside us:
Don't give your neck
To the yoke of fortune, but let your spirit be intrepid
Always ride in triumph over all misfortunes.
Be frank, Queen Margaret, and tell your sorrow;
It will be attenuated if France can give in.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
These gracious words revive my falling thoughts
And let my silent sorrows speak.
Now then, let the noble Lewis know,
This Henry, sole possessor of my love,
Is it from a king who became a banished man,
And forced to live in Scotland in abandonment;
While the proud and ambitious Edward Duke of York
Usurps royal title and seat
Of the true and rightful king of England.
That's why I, poor Margaret,
With this, my son, Prince Edward, Henry's heir,
I have come to implore your just and legitimate help;
And if you let us down, all our hope is lost:
Scotland is willing to help, but it cannot help;
Our people and our peers are both misled,
Our treasures seized, our soldiers put to flight,
And, as you see, we are in a difficult situation.

KING LEWIS XI:
Renowned queen, with patience calms the storm,
While we think of a way to end it.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
The longer we stay, the stronger our enemy becomes.

KING LEWIS XI:
The longer I stay, the more I will help you.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Oh, but impatience awaits true sorrow.
And see where the begetter of my sorrow comes from!

KING LEWIS XI:
Why is he boldly approaching our presence?

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Our Earl of Warwick, Edward's greatest friend.

KING LEWIS XI:
Welcome, brave Warwick! What brings you to France?

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Yes, now a second storm begins to arise;
For it is he who moves the wind and the tide.

WARWICK:
Of the worthy Edward, king of Albion,
My lord and sovereign, and your sworn friend,
I come, with kindness and sincere love,
First, salute your royal person;
And then want a friendship league;
And finally, to confirm this friendship
With a nuptial knot, if you deign to grant
This virtuous Lady Bona, your beautiful sister,
With the King of England in legal marriage.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:

WARWICK:

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
King Lewis and Lady Bona, hear me speak,
Before responding to Warwick. His request
Didn't come from Edward's honest, well-meaning love,
But by deception brought about by necessity;
For how can tyrants safely rule their house,
Unless abroad they buy a big wedding ring?
To prove him a tyrant, this reason may be enough,
That Henry still lives: but if he were dead,
Yet here is Prince Edward, the son of King Henry.
Listen then, Lewis, that by this league and this marriage
You do not take advantage of your danger and your dishonor;
For even if the usurpers dominate the rule for a while,
Yet the heavens are just, and time removes injustice.

WARWICK:
Insulting Marguerite!

PRINCE EDWARD:
And why not queen?

WARWICK:
Because your father Henri usurped;
And you are no more prince than she is queen.

OXFORD:
Then Warwick cancels the great John of Gaunt,
Which subjugated the greater part of Spain;
And, after John of Gaunt, Henry IV,
Whose wisdom was a mirror to the wisest;
And, after this wise prince Henry V,
Who by his prowess conquered all of France:
From these our Henry descends in a straight line.

WARWICK:
Oxford, how is it, in this sweet speech,
You haven't told how Henry the Sixth lost
Everything Henry the Fifth had gotten?
It seems to me that these French peers should smile.
But for the rest, you tell a pedigree
Sixty-two years old; a stupid time
To make a prescription for the value of a kingdom.

OXFORD:
Why, Warwick, can you speak against your liege,
Whom you obeyed for thirty-six years,
And not betray your treason by blushing?

WARWICK:
Can Oxford, which has already closed the right,
Now to close the lie with a pedigree?
Damage ! leave Henry and call Edward king.

OXFORD:
Call him my king by whose injurious destiny
My elder brother, Lord Aubrey Vere,
Was he killed? and more, my father,
Even in the fall of his sweet years,
When nature brought him to death's door?
No, Warwick, no; while life supports this arm,
This arm supports the House of Lancaster.

WARWICK:
And I the house of York.

KING LEWIS XI:
Queen Margaret, Prince Edward and Oxford,
Guarantee, at our request, to withdraw,
While I use another conference with Warwick.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
God grant that Warwick's words do not bewitch him!

KING LEWIS XI:
Now Warwick, tell me, even on your conscience,
Is Edward your true king? because I was disgusting
To bond with him who was not rightfully chosen.

WARWICK:
Thereupon I pledge my credit and my honor.

KING LEWIS XI:
But is he lovable in the eyes of the people?

WARWICK:
Especially since Henry was unhappy.

KING LEWIS XI:
Then further, all dissimulation aside,
Tell me in truth the measure of his love
To our sister Bona.

WARWICK:
Such it seems
How fitting for a monarch like him.
I myself have often heard him say and swear
That his love was an eternal plant,
Whose root was fixed in the soil of virtue,
The leaves and fruits maintained by the sun of beauty,
Free from envy, but not from disdain,
Unless Lady Bona abandons her pain.

KING LEWIS XI:
Now, my sister, let us listen to your firm determination.

BONA:
Your grant, or your refusal, will be mine:
Yet I admit that often before this day,
When I have heard of your king's desert,
My ear has tempted judgment toward desire.

KING LEWIS XI:
So, Warwick, thus: our sister will be Edward's;
And now the articles will immediately be drawn
Touching the joint that your king must make,
Which with its dowry will be in counterbalance.
Come closer, Queen Margaret, and witness
This Bona will be the wife of the King of England.

PRINCE EDWARD:
To Edward, but not to the King of England.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Deceptive Warwick! it was your device
By this alliance to annul my trial:
Before you arrived, Lewis was Henry's friend.

KING LEWIS XI:
And he is still friends with him and Margaret:
But if your title to the crown is weak,
As Edward's good success shows,
So that's just one reason for me to be released
Help I promised late.
Yet you will have all the kindness from me
That your heritage demands and that mine can yield.

WARWICK:
Henry now lives at ease in Scotland,
Where having nothing, he can lose nothing.
And as for yourself, our former queen,
You have a father capable of supporting you;
And it's better that you troubled him than France.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Peace, impudent and shameless Warwick, peace,
Proud smuggler and shooter of kings!
I will not leave until, with my words and my tears,
Both full of truth, I show King Lewis
Your devious means of transportation and the false love of your lord;
For you are both birds of the same feather.

KING LEWIS XI:
Warwick, this is a message for us or for you.

Job:

OXFORD:
I like that our beautiful queen and mistress
He smiles at her news, while Warwick frowns at his.

PRINCE EDWARD:
No, notice how Lewis stamps his feet, even though he was annoyed:
I hope everything goes well.

KING LEWIS XI:
Warwick, what's your news? and yours, beautiful queen?

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Mine, as they fill my heart with unexpected joys.

WARWICK:
Mine, full of sorrow and discontent of the heart.

KING LEWIS XI:
What! Did your king marry Lady Grey!
And now, to appease your falsehood and his,
Send me a paper to persuade me to be patient?
Is this the alliance he seeks with France?
Will he dare to look down on us like this?

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
I have already said this to Your Majesty:
This proves Edward's love and Warwick's honesty.

WARWICK:
King Lewis, I protest here, in view of heaven,
And by the hope I have of heavenly happiness,
That I am clear of this misdeed of Edward,
No longer my king, because he dishonors me,
But especially himself, if he could see his shame.
Did I forget that near York's house
My father died prematurely?
Did I let the abuse inflicted on my niece slide?
Did I impale him with the royal crown?
Did I put Henry from his native country, right?
And am I finally overcome with shame?
Shame on himself! because my merit is an honor:
And to repair my lost honor for him,
Here I give up on him and return to Henry.
My noble queen, let old grudges pass,
And now I am your true servant:
I will avenge his wrong with Lady Bona,
And replant Henry in his old state.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Warwick, these words transformed my hatred into love;
And I forgive and completely forget old faults,
And the joy that you become the friend of King Henry.

WARWICK:
So much his friend, yes, his sincere friend,
That, if King Lewis deigns to provide us
With a few bands of chosen soldiers,
I undertake to land them on our shores
And force the tyrant from his seat by war.
It is not his new wife who will help him:
And as for Clarence, as my letters tell me,
It is very likely that it will fall from him now,
To correspond more to wanton lust than to honor,
Or that for the strength and security of our country.

BONA:
Dear brother, how will Bona take revenge
But by your help to this queen in distress?

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Famous prince, how will poor Henri live,
Unless you save him from terrible despair?

BONA:
My quarrel and that of this Queen of England are one.

WARWICK:
And mine, fair lady Bona, joins yours.

KING LEWIS XI:
And mine with his, yours and Margaret's.
That's why I am finally firmly resolved
You will have help.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Let me humbly thank you for all of this at once.

KING LEWIS XI:
So, messenger of England, return to post,
And tell false Edward, your pretended king,
Let Lewis from France send maskers
To enjoy it with him and his new wife:
You see what has happened, go in fear of your king.

BONA:
Tell him, hoping that he will become a widower soon,
I will carry the willow garland for him.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Tell him my weeds of mourning are laid aside,
And I'm ready to put on some armor.

WARWICK:
Tell him for me that he hurt me,
That's why I'm going to remove him from his crown shortly.
Here's your reward: go.

KING LEWIS XI:
But, Warwick,
You and Oxford, with five thousand men,
Will cross the seas and propose a false battle to Edward;
And, depending on the occasion, this noble queen
And the prince will follow with a new supply.
Yet, before you go, but answer me one doubt,
What pledge do we have of your firm fidelity?

WARWICK:
This will ensure my constant loyalty,
That if our queen and this young prince agree,
I will join my eldest daughter and my joy
To him immediately in the holy covenants.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Yes, I agree and thank you for your motion.
Son Edward, she is just and virtuous,
So don't delay, give Warwick your hand;
And, from your hand, your irrevocable faith,
That only Warwick's daughter will be yours.

PRINCE EDWARD:
Yes, I accept it, because she deserves it;
And there, to pronounce my wish, I give my hand.

KING LEWIS XI:
Why do we stay now? These soldiers will be raised,
And you, Lord Bourbon, our great admiral,
I will bring them with our royal fleet.
I long for Edward to fall by chance from the war,
For a mocking marriage with a lady from France.

WARWICK:
I came from Edward as ambassador,
But I return his sworn and mortal enemy:
The question of marriage was the charge he entrusted to me,
But a terrible war will answer his request.
Didn't he have anyone but me to make a stale deal?
Then no one but me will turn his joke into sorrow.
I was the leader who raised him to the crown,
And I'll be the leader to bring him down again:
Not that I pity Henry's misery,
But seek revenge for Edward's mockery.
3KING HENRY VI

GLOCKESTER:
Now tell me, brother Clarence, what do you think
About this new marriage with Lady Grey?
Didn't our brother make a good choice?

CLARENCE:
Alas, you know, France is far from here;
How could he stay until Warwick returned?

SOMERSET:
Gentlemen, refrain from this speech; here is the king.

GLOCKESTER:
And his well-chosen wife.

CLARENCE:
I would like to tell him clearly what I think.

KING EDWARD IV:
Now, brother of Clarence, our choice is like you,
That you remain thoughtful, half displeased?

CLARENCE:
As well as Lewis of France, or the Earl of Warwick,
Who are so weak in courage and judgment
That they will not be offended by our abuse.

KING EDWARD IV:
Suppose they get offended for no reason,
It's just Lewis and Warwick: I'm Edward,
Your king and that of Warwick, and must have my will.

GLOCKESTER:
And you will have your will, because our king:
However, a hasty marriage rarely produces good results.

KING EDWARD IV:
Yes, Brother Richard, are you also offended?

GLOCKESTER:
Not me :
No, God forbid I wish they were apart
Which God has brought together; yes, and it was a shame
To break those who unite their yoke so well.

KING EDWARD IV:
Putting aside your contempt and your antipathies,
Tell me a reason why Lady Gray
I shouldn't become my wife and the Queen of England.
And you too, Somerset and Montague,
Say freely what you think.

CLARENCE:
So here is my opinion: that King Lewis
Becomes your enemy, to make fun of him
About Lady Bona's marriage.

GLOCKESTER:
And Warwick, doing as you entrusted him,
Is now disgraced by this new marriage.

KING EDWARD IV:
What if Lewis and Warwick were appeased
By an invention that I can conceive?

ASSEMBLY :
However, having joined France in such an alliance
Would it have strengthened our Commonwealth
“Against foreign storms more than any home-made marriage.”

HASTING:
Why, Montague doesn't know this about himself
Is England safe, if that is true in itself?

ASSEMBLY :
But it's all the safer when we're back with France.

HASTING:
It's better to use France than to trust France:
Let's be back with God and with the seas
Which he gave for impregnable enclosure,
And with their help, we only defend ourselves;
In them and in us lies our security.

CLARENCE:
For this speech alone, Lord Hastings deserves
Have Lord Hungerford's heir.

KING EDWARD IV:
Yes, what about that? it was my will and my concession;
And this time, my will will be law.

GLOCKESTER:
And yet it seems to me that your grace has not done well,
To give to the heiress and daughter of Lord Scales
To the brother of your beloved wife;
It would have suited me or Clarence better:
But in your wife, you bury fraternity.

CLARENCE:
Otherwise you would not have given the heir
From Lord Bonville on your new wife's son,
And let your brothers go elsewhere quickly.

KING EDWARD IV:
Alas, poor Clarence! is this for a woman
That you are unhappy? I will provide you.

CLARENCE:
By choosing for yourself, you have exercised your judgment,
Which being superficial, you give me permission
Play the role of broker on my own behalf;
And that's why I plan to leave you shortly.

KING EDWARD IV:
Leave me, or wait, Edward will be king,
And not be bound by his brother's will.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
My lords, before it pleases his majesty
To elevate my state to the title of queen,
Do me right, and you all must confess
That I was not of ignoble origin;
And those more wicked than me have had a fortune.
But as this title honors me and mine,
So your aversion, to whom I would please,
It obscures my joys with danger and sorrow.

KING EDWARD IV:
My love, don't make fun of their frowns:
What danger or sorrow can befall you,
As long as Edward is your constant friend,
And their true sovereign, whom they must obey?
No, who they will obey and love you too,
Unless they seek hatred from me;
And if they do, I'll keep you safe,
And they will feel the vengeance of my anger.

GLOCKESTER:

KING EDWARD IV:
Now, messenger, what letters or what news
Of France?

Job:
My sovereign liege, no letters; and a few words,
But like me, without your special forgiveness,
Don't you dare tell.

KING EDWARD IV:
Come on, we forgive you: so, in short,
Tell me their words as faithfully as you can guess them.
What response does King Lewis make to our letters?

Job:
When I left, these were his words:
"Go tell the false Edward, your supposed king,
Let Lewis from France send maskers
To enjoy it with him and his new wife.

KING EDWARD IV:
Is Lewis so brave? it's as if he thought of me as Henry.
But what did Lady Bona say about my marriage?

Job:
Here are his words, spoken with wild disdain:
"Tell him, hoping that he will soon become a widower,
I will carry the willow garland for him.

KING EDWARD IV:
I don't blame her, she could say a little less;
She was wrong. But what did the queen say about Henry?
Because I heard she was there, on site.

Job:
“Tell him,” she said, “my mourning weeds are over,
And I'm ready to put on some armor.

KING EDWARD IV:
As if she wanted to play the Amazon.
But what did Warwick say about these injuries?

Job:
He, more irritated with Your Majesty
All the rest dismissed me with these words:
"Tell him for me that he has hurt me,
And that's why I'm going to take him off his crown shortly.

KING EDWARD IV:
Ha! did the traitor dare to speak such proud words?
Well, I will arm myself, being thus warned:
They will have wars and pay for their presumption.
But let's say, is Warwick friends with Margaret?

Job:
Yes, gracious sovereign; they are so connected
friendship
This young Prince Edward marries Warwick's daughter.

CLARENCE:
Like the eldest; Clarence will have the youngest.
Now, brother king, farewell, and sit tight,
For now I go to Warwick's other daughter;
Even though I want a kingdom, I'm still married
I cannot be inferior to you.
You who love me and Warwick, follow me.

GLOCKESTER:

KING EDWARD IV:
Both Clarence and Somerset are off to Warwick!
However, I am armed against the worst that could happen;
And we must hurry in this desperate case.
Pembroke and Stafford, you on our behalf
Go raise men and prepare for war;
They are already, or will soon be disembarked:
I myself will follow you directly.
But before leaving, Hastings and Montague,
Solve my doubt. You two, of all others,
Related to Warwick by blood and marriage:
Tell me if you love Warwick more than me?
If so, then both go to him;
I wish you enemies rather than hollow friends:
But if you want to keep your true obedience,
Give me assurance with a friendly wish,
So that I can never suspect you.

ASSEMBLY :
So God help Montague to prove himself right!

HASTING:
And Hastings who favors Edward's cause!

KING EDWARD IV:
Now, Brother Richard, will you support us?

GLOCKESTER:
Yes, despite everything that will resist you.

KING EDWARD IV:
Well then! then I am sure of victory.
Now then, let us go; and don't waste any time,
Until we meet Warwick and his foreign power.
3KING HENRY VI

WARWICK:
Believe me, my lord, so far everything is going well;
Ordinary people, in numbers, rush towards us.
But look where Somerset and Clarence are coming from!
Speak suddenly, my lords, are we all friends?

CLARENCE:
Have no fear, my lord.

WARWICK:
So, kind Clarence, welcome to Warwick;
And welcome, Somerset: I consider it cowardice
Stay wary where a noble heart
Pawned an open hand as a sign of love;
Otherwise, I might think that Clarence, Edward's brother,
Were only a pretended friend of our efforts:
But welcome, sweet Clarence; my daughter will be yours.
And now what is left but, in the cover of night,
Your brother being carelessly camped,
His soldiers prowled the surrounding towns,
And but accompanied by a simple guardian,
Can we surprise him and take him as we please?
Our scouts found the adventure very simple:
It's like Ulysses and big Diomedes
With sleight and manhood I stole the tents of Rhesus,
And he brought from there the mortal steeds of the Thracians,
So we, well covered in the black mantle of night,
Out of the blue, he can shoot down Edward's guard
And grab hold; I say no, kill him,
Because my intention is only to surprise him.
You who will follow me until this attempt,
Clap Henry's name with your leader.
Well, let's continue our way in silence:
For Warwick and his friends, God and Saint George!
3KING HENRY VI

First goalkeeper:
Come on, my masters, everyone takes a stand:
The king puts him to sleep like this.

Second goalkeeper:
What, he's not going to bed?

First goalkeeper:
Why no ; because he made a solemn vow
Never lie and take your natural rest
Until Warwick or himself is completely suppressed.

Second goalkeeper:
Tomorrow will probably be the day,
If Warwick is as close as men claim.

Third goalkeeper:
But pray tell, which noble is it?
The one who rests here with the king in his tent?

First goalkeeper:
This is Lord Hastings, the king's greatest friend.

Third goalkeeper:
Oh, is that so? But why does the king command
Let his main supporters lodge in the towns around him,
While he himself remains in the cold field?

Second goalkeeper:
It is all the more honor because it is more dangerous.

Third goalkeeper:
Yes, but give me adoration and tranquility;
I prefer that to a dangerous honor.
If Warwick knew what state he was in,
It's unlikely he'll wake him up.

First goalkeeper:
Unless our halberds block his path.

Second goalkeeper:
Yes, why do we guard his royal tent,
But to defend oneself against the enemies of the night?

WARWICK:
This is his tent; and see where his guard stands.
Courage, my masters! honor now or never!
But follow me, and Edward will be ours.

First goalkeeper:
Who's there?

Second goalkeeper:
Stay, or you die!

SOMERSET:
Who are those who steal there?

WARWICK:
Richard and Hastings: let them go; here is the duke.

KING EDWARD IV:
The Duke! Why, Warwick, when we parted,
You call me king.

WARWICK:
Yes, but the case is different:
When you dishonored me in my embassy,
Then I degraded you from the rank of king,
And now come and create your Duke of York.
Alas! how should you rule a kingdom,
Who do not know how to use ambassadors,
Nor how to be satisfied with just one woman,
Nor how to use your brothers fraternally,
Nor how to study for the welfare of the people,
Or how to protect yourself from enemies?

KING EDWARD IV:
Yes, brother of Clarence, are you there too?
No, then I see Edward needs to come down.
Yet, Warwick, despite all misfortunes,
Of yourself and all your accomplices,
Edward will always behave like a king:
Even if the malice of fortune reverses my state,
My mind goes beyond the compass of its wheel.

WARWICK:
So, for his spirit, be Edward King of England:
But Henry will now wear the English crown,
And truly be a true king, you who are only the shadow.
My Lord of Somerset, at my request,
See that Duke Edward is transported immediately
To my brother, Archbishop of York.
When I fought with Pembroke and his comrades,
I'll follow you and tell you what the answer is
Lewis and Lady Bona send it to him.
Now, for a moment, farewell, good Duke of York.

KING EDWARD IV:
What destiny imposes, men must necessarily respect;
He boots not to resist the wind and tide.

OXFORD:
What remains for us now, my lords, to do?
But marching towards London with our soldiers?

WARWICK:
Yes, this is the first thing we must do;
To free King Henry from imprisonment
And see him sitting on the royal throne.
3KING HENRY VI

RIVERS:
Madam, what motivates you in this sudden change?

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Why Brother Rivers, you haven't learned yet
What late misfortune befell King Edward?

RIVERS:
What! the loss of a pitched battle against Warwick?

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
No, but the loss of one's own royal person.

RIVERS:
So is my sovereign killed?

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
Yes, almost killed, because he is taken prisoner,
Be betrayed by the lie of his guard
Or by his enemy surprised unexpectedly:
And, as I must further understand,
Is newly engaged with the Bishop of York,
Fell the brother of Warwick and thus our enemy.

RIVERS:
These news, I must admit, are full of pain;
Yet, gracious madam, bear it as best you can:
Warwick can lose, because he has now won.

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
In the meantime, right hope must prevent the decay of life.
And I prefer to wean myself from despair
For love of Edward's offspring in my womb:
That's what makes me curb my passion
And gently bear the cross of my misfortune;
Yes, yes, for that, I shed a lot of tears
And stop the rise of blood-sucking sighs,
Lest with my sighs or my tears I explode or drown
Fruit of King Edward, true heir to the English crown.

RIVERS:
But, madam, where has Warwick become?

QUEEN ELIZABETH:
I am informed that he is coming towards London,
To put the crown back on Henry's head:
Guess the rest; King Edward's friends must fall,
But to prevent the violence of the tyrant,
For do not trust him who once betrayed the faith,
So I go immediately to the sanctuary,
To save at least the heir of Edward's rights:
There I will be safe from force and fraud.
Come then, let us flee while we can fly:
If Warwick takes us, we will certainly die.
3KING HENRY VI

GLOCKESTER:
Now, my Lord Hastings and Sir William Stanley,
Stop wondering why I lured you here,
In this largest thicket in the park.
So it is: you know our king, my brother,
Is here a prisoner of the bishop, in whose hands
He has good use and great freedom,
And, often but accompanied by a weak guard,
He comes here to hunt for fun.
I announced it by secret means
That if towards this hour he was heading
Under the color of his usual game,
He will find his friends here with horses and men
To free him from his captivity.

Hunter:
This way, my lord; because that's how the game is played.

KING EDWARD IV:
No, over here, man: see where the hunters are at.
Now, brother of Gloucester, Lord Hastings and others,
Are you standing so close to steal the bishop's deer?

GLOCKESTER:
Brother, time and business require haste:
Your horse is ready at the corner of the park.

KING EDWARD IV:
But where are we going then?

HASTING:
To Lynn, my lord,
And ship from there to Flanders.

GLOCKESTER:
Well, I guessed it, believe me; because that's what I wanted to say.

KING EDWARD IV:
Stanley, I will reward your audacity.

GLOCKESTER:
But why do we stay? now is not the time to talk.

KING EDWARD IV:
Hunter, what do you say? Do you want to accompany me?

Hunter:
Better to do it than wait and be hanged.

GLOCKESTER:
Come then, go; let's not make any more noise.

KING EDWARD IV:
Bishop, farewell: protect yourself from Warwick's frown;
And pray that I may regain possession of the crown.
3KING HENRY VI

KING HENRY VI:
Master lieutenant, now that God and my friends
I shook Edward from the royal seat,
And I transformed my state of captivity into freedom,
My fear into hope, my sorrows into joy,
When we expand, what are your fees due?

Lieutenant:
Subjects cannot contest anything with their sovereigns;
But if humble prayer can prevail,
I then ask your Majesty for forgiveness.

KING HENRY VI:
For what, lieutenant? to use me well?
No, be sure that I will reward your kindness,
For this, my imprisonment was a pleasure;
Yes, such a pleasure as caged birds
Conceive after many brooding thoughts
Finally with notes of domestic harmony
They completely forget their loss of freedom.
But, Warwick, after God you set me free,
This is why I especially thank God and you;
He was the author, you the instrument.
Therefore, that I may overcome the spite of fortune
Living low, where fortune cannot harm me,
And may the inhabitants of this blessed land
I cannot be punished by my annoying stars,
Warwick, though my head still wears the crown,
I hand over my government to you here,
For you are happy in all your actions.

WARWICK:
Your grace is always known to be virtuous;
And now can appear as wise as virtuous,
By spying and avoiding the malice of fortune,
For few men rightly distrust the stars:
Yet on this point let me rebuke your grace,
For choosing me when Clarence is in place.

CLARENCE:
No, Warwick, you are worthy of the hold,
Whose heavens in your nativity
Awarded an olive branch and a laurel wreath,
Equally likely to be blessed in peace and in war;
And that is why I give you my free consent.

WARWICK:
And I choose Clarence only as a protector.

KING HENRY VI:
Warwick and Clarence give me both your hands:
Now join your hands, and with your hands your hearts,
Let no dissension prevent the government:
I make you two the protectors of this earth,
While I myself lead a private life
And I spend my last days in devotion,
To the rebuke of sin and the praise of my Creator.

WARWICK:
What responds to Clarence for the will of his sovereign?

CLARENCE:
Let him consent, if Warwick yields his consent;
For it is on your fortune that I rest.

WARWICK:
Why then, despite my repugnance, must I be content with:
We will cling together, like a double shadow
To Henry's body, and replace it;
I mean, carrying the weight of government,
While he enjoys honor and his ease.
And, Clarence, now it's more than necessary
Immediately let Edward be declared a traitor,
And all his lands and all his goods will be confiscated.

CLARENCE:
What else? and that the succession be determined.

WARWICK:
Yes, Clarence won't want his role.

KING HENRY VI:
But, to begin with your main business,
Let me beg you, for I no longer command,
May Margaret your queen and my son Edward
Be sent to return from France with all haste;
For until I see them here, out of dubious fear
My joy of freedom is half eclipsed.

CLARENCE:
This will be done, my sovereign, as quickly as possible.

KING HENRY VI:
My lord of Somerset, what a youth this is,
Who do you seem to care for so tenderly?

SOMERSET:
My lord is young Henry, Earl of Richmond.

KING HENRY VI:
Come here, England's hope.
If secret powers
Suggest only truth to my divine thoughts,
This pretty boy will prove the happiness of our country.
His looks are full of peaceful majesty,
His head is naturally framed to wear a crown,
His hand to wield a scepter, and himself
Probably in time to bless a royal throne.
Make much of him, my lords, for it is he
I have to help you more than I hurt you.

WARWICK:
What news, my friend?

Job:
That Edward escaped your brother,
And fled, as we have heard since, to Burgundy.

WARWICK:
Unsavory news! but how was he able to escape?

Job:
It was transmitted by Richard Duke of Gloucester
And Lord Hastings, who accompanied him
In secret ambush near the forest
And the bishop's hunters delivered him;
Because hunting was his daily exercise.

WARWICK:
My brother was too neglectful of his charge.
But let us, my sovereign, provide
A balm for any wound that may arise.

SOMERSET:
My lord, I do not like this flight of Edward;
Because without doubt Burgundy will bring him help,
And we will have other wars before long.
As Henry's final prophecy portends
I contented my heart with the hope of this young Richmond,
My heart also worries about these conflicts
What can happen to him, to his detriment and to ours:
Therefore, Lord Oxford, to avoid the worst,
We will send it immediately to Brittany,
Until the storms of civil enmity have passed.

OXFORD:
Yes, because if Edward regains possession of the crown,
It feels like Richmond and the others are going to fall.

SOMERSET:
It will be like this; he will go to Brittany.
Come on, let's go quickly.
3KING HENRY VI

KING EDWARD IV:
Now, Brother Richard, Lord Hastings and others,
Yet so far fortune has made us amends,
And said once again I'll trade
My state declined for Henry's royal crown.
Well we have crossed and now recrossed the seas
And brought the desired help from Burgundy:
What remains then, having thus happened to us
From the harbor of Ravenspurgh before the gates of York,
But for us to enter, as in our duchy?

GLOCKESTER:
Fast doors! Brother, I don't like it;
For many men who stumble at the threshold
Are well predicted that danger lurks within.

KING EDWARD IV:
Tush, man, homes need no longer frighten us:
By fair or foul means we must enter,
Because this is where our friends will come to visit us.

HASTING:
My lord, I will strike once more to summon them.

Mayor:
Gentlemen, we have been informed of your coming,
And close the doors for our safety;
For now, we owe our allegiance to Henry.

KING EDWARD IV:
But, master mayor, if Henry is your king,
However, Edward is at least Duke of York.

Mayor:
It is true, my good lord; I know you for nothing less.

KING EDWARD IV:
Well, and I dispute nothing but my duchy,
Like being quite happy with that alone.

GLOCKESTER:

HASTING:
Why, master mayor, why do you doubt?
Open the doors; we are the friends of King Henry.

Mayor:
Yes, you say so? the doors will then be opened.

GLOCKESTER:
A wise and robust captain, and soon to be convinced!

HASTING:
The good old man would like everything to go well,
So it wasn't long on his part; but having entered,
I don't doubt it, but we will soon persuade
He and all his brothers come to their senses.

KING EDWARD IV:
So, master mayor: these doors must not be closed
But at night or in times of war.
What! Fear not, man, but give me back the keys;
Because Edward will defend the city and you,
And all these friends who deign to follow me.

GLOCKESTER:
Brother, this is Sir John Montgomery,
Our faithful friend, unless I'm mistaken.

KING EDWARD IV:
Welcome, Sir John! But why do you come armed?

ASSEMBLY :
To help King Edward in this time of storm,
As any faithful subject should.

KING EDWARD IV:
Thank you, good Montgomery; but we forget now
Our title to the crown and our only claim
Our duchy until God pleases to send the rest.

ASSEMBLY :
So, good luck, because I repeat:
I came to serve a king and not a duke.
Drummer, strike and let's go.

KING EDWARD IV:
No, stay, Sir John, a moment, and we will debate
By what safe means can the crown be recovered?

ASSEMBLY :
What are you talking about debating? in a few words,
If you do not proclaim yourself our king here,
I'll leave you to your fortune and I'm leaving
To hold back those who come to your aid:
Why should we fight, if you claim to have no title?

GLOCKESTER:
Why, my brother, why do you insist on beautiful points?

KING EDWARD IV:
When we become stronger, then we will assert our claim:
In the meantime, it is wise to hide our intention.

HASTING:
No more scrupulous spirit! now weapons must reign.

GLOCKESTER:
And intrepid spirits ascend to crowns sooner.
Brother, we will proclaim to you from the outset:
Its sound will bring you many friends.

KING EDWARD IV:
So let it be as you wish; because it is my right,
And Henry usurps the tiara.

ASSEMBLY :
Yes, now my sovereign speaks like him;
And now I will be Edward's champion.

HASTING:
Sound the trumpet; Edward will here be proclaimed:
Come, comrade, make a proclamation.

Soldier:
Edward IV, by the grace of God, king of
England and France, and Lord of Ireland, etc.

ASSEMBLY :
And whoever disputes the right of King Edward,
By this I challenge him to a single combat.

All:
Long live Edward IV!

KING EDWARD IV:
Thank you, brave Montgomery; and thank you all:
If fortune serves me, I will reward this kindness.
Now, for this night, let us approach here to York;
And when the morning sun raises its car
Above the border of this horizon,
We will head towards Warwick and his companions;
Because I know very well that Henry is not a soldier.
Ah, sassy Clarence! how wrong it seems to you
To flatter Henry and abandon your brother!
However, if possible, we will meet you and Warwick.
Come on, brave soldiers: no doubt of the day,
And, once obtained, there is no doubt that the salary will be high.
3KING HENRY VI

WARWICK:
What advice, lords? Edward of Belgium,
With hasty Germans and brutal Dutch,
Safely crossed the narrow seas,
And with his troops marches towards London;
And many stunned people flock to him.

KING HENRY VI:
Let's raise men and push him back.

CLARENCE:
A small fire is quickly extinguished;
What the rivers, undergoing suffering, cannot extinguish.

WARWICK:
In Warwickshire I have true friends,
Not mutinous in peace, but bold in war;
I will gather them: and you, son Clarence,
I will stir in Suffolk, Norfolk and Kent,
The knights and gentlemen who will accompany you:
You, Brother Montague, at Buckingham,
Northampton and Leicestershire I will find
Men well inclined to hear what you command:
And you, brave Oxford, wonderful beloved,
In Oxfordshire you will gather your friends.
My sovereign, with loving citizens,
Like his island surrounded by the ocean,
Or the modest Dian surrounded by her nymphs,
We will rest in London until we come to him.
Beautiful lords, take your leave and do not answer.
Farewell, my sovereign.

KING HENRY VI:
Farewell, my Hector, and the true hope of my Troy.

CLARENCE:
As a sign of truth, I kiss the hand of Your Highness.

KING HENRY VI:
Clarence, self-righteous, be happy!

ASSEMBLY :
Comfort, my lord; and so I take my leave.

OXFORD:
And so I seal my truth and say goodbye.

KING HENRY VI:
Sweet Oxford, and my beloved Montague,
And suddenly, once again, a happy farewell.

WARWICK:
Farewell, sweet lords: let us meet again in Coventry.

KING HENRY VI:
Here, at the palace, I will rest for a while.
Cousin of Exeter, what does your lordship think?
I think of the power Edward has on the ground
I shouldn't be able to meet mine.

EXECUTE:
The doubt is that he will be able to seduce others.

KING HENRY VI:
This is not my fear; my meed brought me fame:
I did not cover my ears to their requests,
Nor did they drop off their suits with slow delays;
My pity was a balm to heal their wounds,
My gentleness has soothed their swollen sorrows,
My mercy has dried up their flowing tears;
I did not desire their wealth,
Nor much oppressed them with large subsidies.
Nor eager for revenge, although they were very wrong:
So why should they love Edward more than me?
No, Exeter, these graces defy grace:
And when the lion caresses the lamb,
The lamb will never stop following him.

EXECUTE:
Listen, listen, my lord! what cries are these?

KING EDWARD IV:
Seize the shame-faced Henry, take him hence;
And proclaims us once more king of England.
You are the source that makes the little streams flow:
Now stop your spring; my sea will suck them dry,
And swell all the higher by their reflux.
Therefore with him to the Tower; that he doesn't speak.
And, lords, towards Coventry we bend our course
Where now stands peremptory Warwick:
The sun is shining ; and, if we use the delay,
The cold and bitter winter spoils our hoped-for hay.

GLOCKESTER:
Early, before his forces rejoin,
And take the great traitor by surprise:
Brave warriors, march towards Coventry.
3KING HENRY VI

WARWICK:
Where did the message come from valiant Oxford?
Where is your lord, my honest man?

First messenger:
By this to Dunsmore, marching forward.

WARWICK:
How far away is our brother Montague?
Where is the message that comes from Montague?

Second messenger:
By this to Daintry, with a mighty troop.

WARWICK:
Say, Somerville, what does my beloved son say?
And how far away do you think Clarence is now?

SOMERSET:
At Southam I left him with his forces,
And expect him here in two hours.

WARWICK:
Then Clarence is close at hand, I hear his drum.

SOMERSET:
It is not his, my lord; here Southam lies:
The drum your honor hears comes from Warwick.

WARWICK:
Who should it be? for example, unexpected friends.

SOMERSET:
They are at your fingertips, and you will quickly know it.

KING EDWARD IV:
Go, trumpet, to the walls, and make people speak.

GLOCKESTER:
See how the surly Warwick holds the wall!

WARWICK:
O spontaneous wickedness! Did the sporty Edward come?
Where did our scouts sleep, or how are they seduced,
That we had no news of its repair?

KING EDWARD IV:
Now, Warwick, will you open the city gates,
Speak sweet words and humbly bend the knee,
Call Edward King and beg for mercy?
And he will forgive you these outrages.

WARWICK:
Nay, would you rather draw your strength from here,
Confess who established you and who tore you away,
Call Warwick's boss and do penance?
And you will always remain the Duke of York.

GLOCKESTER:
I thought at least he would have said the king;
Or did he make this joke against his will?

WARWICK:
A dukedom, sir, is it not a beautiful gift?

GLOCKESTER:
Yes, by my faith, for a poor count to give:
I will do you a favor for such a good gift.

WARWICK:
It was I who gave the kingdom to your brother.

KING EDWARD IV:
Why is he mine, if only because of Warwick's gift?

WARWICK:
You are not an Atlas for such a great weight:
And weak, Warwick takes back his gift;
And Henry is my king, Warwick his subject.

KING EDWARD IV:
But the King of Warwick is Edward's prisoner:
And, brave Warwick, just answer this:
What is the body when the head is cut off?

GLOCKESTER:
Alas, Warwick no longer had any predictions,
But, while he thought he was stealing the single ten,
The king was sneakily fingered from the bridge!
You left poor Henry at the bishopric,
And, ten to one, you will meet him at the Tower.

EDWARD:
This is still the case; yet you are still Warwick.

GLOCKESTER:
Come, Warwick, take your time; kneel down, kneel down:
No, when? strike now, otherwise the iron will cool.

WARWICK:
I would rather cut off this hand with one blow,
And with the other throw it in your face,
Than to carry such a low sail to hit you.

KING EDWARD IV:
Sail as best you can, have wind and tide your friend,
This hand, wrapped quickly around your coal black hair
Must, while your head is hot and freshly cut,
Write this sentence in the dust with your blood,
“Warwick, who changes the wind, can no longer change. »

WARWICK:
O cheerful colors! see where Oxford is coming!

OXFORD:
Oxford, Oxford, for Lancaster!

GLOCKESTER:
The doors are open, let's go in too.

KING EDWARD IV:
Thus, other enemies could fall on our backs.
Let us stand in good position; because they without a doubt
He will come out again and offer us battle:
Otherwise, the city being only a small defense,
We will quickly awaken the traitors in the same way.

WARWICK:
Oh, welcome, Oxford! because we want your help.

ASSEMBLY :
Montague, Montague, for Lancaster!

GLOCKESTER:
You and your brother will both buy this betrayal
Even with the most precious blood your bodies carry.

KING EDWARD IV:
The harder the match, the greater the victory:
My mind portends happy gain and conquest.

SOMERSET:
Somerset, Somerset, for Lancaster!

GLOCKESTER:
Two of your name, both Dukes of Somerset,
Have sold their lives to the house of York;
And you will be the third if this sword holds.

WARWICK:
And there you have it, where George de Clarence rushes in,
Strong enough to ask his brother to fight;
Among whom an honest zeal for good prevails
More than the nature of a brother's love!
Come, Clarence, come; you will, if Warwick calls.

CLARENCE:
Father of Warwick, do you know what that means?
Look here, I throw my infamy at you
I will not ruin my father's house,
Who gave his blood to cement the stones,
And I installed Lancaster. Well, it's true, Warwick,
That Clarence is so harsh, so direct, unnatural,
To bend the deadly instruments of war
Against his brother and his rightful king?
Perhaps you will object to my holy oath:
Keeping this oath was even more impious
Than that of Jephthah, when he sacrificed his daughter.
I am truly sorry for my intrusion
That, to deserve well from my brother's hands,
I here proclaim myself your mortal enemy,
With resolution, wherever I meet you...
As I will meet you, if you move abroad...
To torment you because of your mistake in misleading me.
And so, proud-hearted Warwick, I challenge you,
And towards my brother I turn my blushing cheeks.
Forgive me, Edward, I will make amends:
And, Richard, do not disapprove of my faults,
Because I will no longer be fickle.

KING EDWARD IV:
Now welcome more, and ten times more loved,
As if you had never deserved our hatred.

GLOCKESTER:
Welcome, good Clarence; it’s fraternal.

WARWICK:
O traitorous passenger, perjured and unjust!

KING EDWARD IV:
What, Warwick, are you going to leave town and fight?
Or should we strike the stones around your ears?

WARWICK:
Alas, I am not locked here to defend myself!
I'm going to Barnet straight away,
And offer to fight, Edward, if you dare.

KING EDWARD IV:
Yes, Warwick, Edward dares and leads the way.
Lords, on the ground; Saint George and victory!
3KING HENRY VI

KING EDWARD IV:
So lie there: die, and die of our fear;
Because Warwick was an insect that we all feared.
Now, Montague, sit tight; I'm looking for you,
So that Warwick's bones can keep you company.

WARWICK:
Oh, who is there? come to me, friend or foe,
And tell me who is the winner, York or Warwick?
Why am I asking this? my mutilated body shows,
My blood, my lack of strength, my sick heart manifest themselves.
That I must abandon my body to the earth
And, by my fall, conquest to my enemy.
Thus yields the cedar to the edge of the axe,
Whose arms sheltered the princely eagle,
Under whose shadow the lion rampant slept,
Whose upper branch surpassed the spreading tree of Jupiter
And protected the low shrubs from the powerful winter wind.
These eyes, now obscured by the black veil of death,
Were as piercing as the midday sun,
To search for the secret betrayals of the world:
The wrinkles in my eyebrows, now filled with blood,
They were often compared to royal sepulchres;
For who lived as a king without me being able to dig his grave?
And who dared mine when Warwick bowed his brow?
Behold, now my glory is stained with dust and blood!
My parks, my walks, my mansions that I had.
Even now, abandon me and all my lands
I only have the length of my body left.
Why, what is the pomp, the rule, the reign, if not earth and dust?
And we live as best we can, but we must die.

SOMERSET:
Ah, Warwick, Warwick! were you like us.
We could recoup all our losses again;
The Queen of France brought powerful power:
Even now we were hearing the news: Ah, could you fly!

WARWICK:
Well, then I wouldn't steal. Ah, Montague,
If you are there, my sweet brother, take my hand.
And with your lips keep a moment in my soul!
You do not love me ; because, brother, if you did,
Your tears would wash away this cold and frozen blood
It sticks to my lips and won't let me speak.
Come quickly, Montague, or I'm dead.

SOMERSET:
Ah, Warwick! Montague breathed his last;
And to my last breath I cried out for Warwick,
And he said: “Commend me to my valiant brother. »
And he would have said more, and he would have spoken more,
Which sounded like a clamor in a vault,
This should not be distinguished; but finally
I could well hear, delivered with a moan,
“Oh, farewell, Warwick!

WARWICK:
Sweet rest his soul! Flee, lords, and save yourselves;
For Warwick bids you all farewell and will meet you in heaven.

OXFORD:
Go, go, to meet the great power of the queen!
3KING HENRY VI

KING EDWARD IV:
Until now our fortune continues to progress,
And we are adorned with crowns of victory.
But, in the middle of this radiant day,
I see a black cloud, suspicious and threatening,
Who will meet our glorious sun,
Before reaching his comfortable Western bed:
I mean, my lords, these powers that the queen
The people of Gallia have arrived on our shores
And, as we will, march to fight with us.

CLARENCE:
A little gust of wind will soon disperse this cloud
And blow it to the source where it came from:
The very beams will dry these vapors,
Because not every cloud creates a storm.

GLOCKESTER:
The queen is estimated at thirty thousand people,
And Somerset, with Oxford, fled to her:
If she has time to breathe, rest assured
His faction will be as strong as ours.

KING EDWARD IV:
We are heralded by our loving friends
Let them stay on course towards Tewksbury:
We, now having the best on Barnet's field,
I will go straight, because good will clears the way;
And, as we walk, our strength will be increased
In each county as we go.
Throw the drum; shout “Courage!” » and far.
3KING HENRY VI

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
The great lords, the wise never sit down and mourn their loss,
But joyfully seek how to right their wrongs.
And if the mast were now blown overboard,
The cable broke, the holding anchor was lost,
And half of our sailors were swallowed up in the flood?
Yet our pilot still lives. It is not appropriate that he
Should leave the bar and like a fearful boy
Eyes full of tears, add water to the sea
And give more strength to those who have too much,
While, in its complaint, the ship splits on the rock,
What industry and what courage could have saved?
Ah, what a shame! ah, what a mistake it was!
Let’s say Warwick was our anchor; what about that?
And Montague our summit; and him ?
Our friends massacred the tackles; what about these?
Why isn't Oxford another anchor point here?
And Somerset, another beautiful mast?
Friends of France, our shrouds and plating?
And, even if it's not clever, why not Ned and I
For once, is the charge of the skilled pilot authorized?
We will not sit and cry from the rudder,
But keep our course, even if the strong wind says no,
Shelves and rocks that threaten us with shipwreck.
As good to rebuke the waves as to speak them fairly.
And what is Edward but a merciless sea?
What Clarence but quicksand of deception?
And Richard, but a fatal and tattered rock?
All these enemies of our poor crust.
Say you know how to swim; alas, it's only for a moment!
Walk on the sand; why, there you sink quickly:
Straddle the rock; the tide will carry you away,
Or you are hungry; it’s a triple death.
This is what I say, lords, to make you understand,
If one of you ran away from us,
That there's no mercy expected with brothers
More than with merciless waves, with sand and rocks.
Well, courage then! which cannot be avoided
“It was childish weakness to complain or fear.

PRINCE EDWARD:
I think that a woman of this valiant spirit
If a coward heard him say these words,
Infuse his chest with magnanimity
And make him, naked, outwit a man-at-arms.
I'm not talking about this to doubt it here
For did I suspect a fearful man
He should be allowed to leave from time to time,
Lest in our need he may infect another
And restore to him a spirit like himself.
If there are any here, God forbid!
Let him go before we need his help.

OXFORD:
Women and children of such great courage,
And the warriors faint! well, it was a perpetual shame.
O brave young prince! your famous grandfather
Living again in you: may you live long
To carry his image and renew his glories!

SOMERSET:
And he will not fight for such hope.
Go home, lie down, and like the owl in the daytime,
If he stands up, people will laugh and wonder at him.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Thank you, kind Somerset; sweet Oxford, thank you.

PRINCE EDWARD:
And accept his thanks which have nothing else.

Messenger:
Prepare yourselves, lords, for Edward is near.
Ready to fight; therefore be resolute.

OXFORD:
I didn't think any less: it's his policy
Rushing so quickly, only to find ourselves without provisions.

SOMERSET:
But he is deceived; we are ready.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
It gladdens my heart to see your audacity.

OXFORD:
Here begin our battle; that is why we will not move.

KING EDWARD IV:
Courageous disciples, there stands the thorny wood,
Who, with the help of heaven and your strength,
The roots must be cut before nightfall.
I don't need to add more fuel to your fire,
Because I know that you are flaming to burn them
Give the signal to battle, and to him, lords!

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
Lords, knights and gentlemen, what shall I say
My tears contradict; for every word I speak,
You see, I drink the water out of my eyes.
So, nothing more than this: Henry, your sovereign,
Is a prisoner of the enemy; its usurped state,
His kingdom is a slaughterhouse, his subjects killed,
His statutes canceled and his treasure spent;
And over there, it's the wolf who makes all this mess.
You fight in justice: then, in the name of God, lords,
Be brave and give the signal to fight.
3KING HENRY VI

KING EDWARD IV:
Now comes a period of tumultuous turbulence.
Go from Oxford to Hames Castle directly:
For Somerset, get rid of his guilty head.
Come on, carry them from here; I won't hear them speak.

OXFORD:
For my part, I will not bother you with words.

SOMERSET:
Me neither, but I look patiently at my fortune.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:
So we part sadly in this troubled world,
To find ourselves with joy in sweet Jerusalem.

Is the proclamation made, he who finds Edward

It is: and there comes young Edward!

What! can a thorn so young start to sting?
Edward, what satisfaction can you give

Speak like a subject, proud and ambitious York!

Ah, that your father was so resolute!

The Tower, the Tower.

QUEEN MARGUERITE:

Can't you speak? O traitors! murderers!
Those who stabbed Caesar shed no blood,
Did not offend and was not worthy of blame,
If this vile act were to equal it:
He was a man; this, with regard to a child:

What's worse than a murderer, so to speak?
No, no, my heart will burst, and if I speak:

3KING HENRY VI

GLOCKESTER:
Hello, my lord. What, your book is so hard?

Yes, my good lord: my lord, I should rather say;
It is a sin to flatter; “good” wasn’t much better:
“Good Gloucester” and “good devil” were alike,
And both absurd; therefore not “good God”.

GLOCKESTER:
Sirrah, leave us alone: we must confer.

KING HENRY VI:
Thus flees the reckless shepherd before the wolf;
So first the harmless sheep sheds its fleece
And then down his throat to the butcher knife.
What death scene should Roscius now perform?

GLOCKESTER:
Suspicion always haunts the guilty mind;
The thief fears every bush of an officer.

KING HENRY VI:
The bird that was limed into a bush,
With trembling wings he doubts every bush;
And I, the unfortunate male of a sweet bird,
I now have the fatal object in my eyes
Where my poor child was kicked, caught and killed.

GLOCKESTER:
Well, what a sullen fool Crete was,
This taught his son the poultry trade!
And yet, despite all his wings, the fool drowned.

KING HENRY VI:
I, Daedalus; my poor boy, Icarus;
Your father, Minos, who denied our way;
The sun that burned my sweet boy's wings
Your brother Edward, and you the sea
Whose envious abyss has swallowed up his life.
Ah, kill me with your gun, not with words!
My chest can better support the point of your dagger
That my ears can hear this tragic story.
But why are you coming? is it not for my life?

GLOCKESTER:
Do you think I'm an executioner?

KING HENRY VI:
You are a persecutor, I am sure:
If killing innocent people is execution,
Well, then you are an executioner.

GLOCKESTER:
I killed your son because of his presumption.

KING HENRY VI:
Would you have been killed when you first presumed,
You didn't live to kill one of my sons.
And so I prophesy that many thousands,
Who is no longer suspicious of my fear,
And the sighing of many old men and many widows,
And many stagnant orphan eyes...
Men for their sons, women for their husbands,
And the orphans of the timeless death of their parents...
I will miss the time you were born.
The owl cried at your birth, a bad sign;
The nocturnal crow cried out, remaining unhappy for a moment;
The dogs howled and a hideous storm shook the trees;
The crow threw it to the top of the chimney,
And chattering pies in lugubrious discords sung.
Your mother felt more than a mother's pain,
And yet he produced less than a mother's hope,
Namely an indigested and deformed mass,
It's not like the fruit of such a beautiful tree.
You had teeth in your head when you were born,
To signify that you have come to bite the world:
And if the rest of what I've heard is true,
You came...

GLOCKESTER:
I will no longer hear: die, prophet in your speech:
This, among other things, is why I was ordained.

KING HENRY VI:
Yes, and many more massacres after that.
God forgives my sins and forgives you!

GLOCKESTER:
What, the sucking blood of Lancaster
Sinking into the ground? I thought it would be up.
See how my sword mourns the death of the poor king!
O, may such purple tears ever be shed
Of those who wish for the fall of our house!
If there is still a spark of life left,
Below, in hell; and say that I sent you there:
I who have neither pity, nor love, nor fear.
Indeed, it’s true what Henry told me about;
Because I often heard my mother say
I came into the world with my legs first:
If I wasn't right, you think, to hurry up,
And seek their ruin which has usurped our right?
The midwife wondered and the women cried
“Oh, Jesus, bless us, he was born with teeth!”
And that's what I was; which clearly meant
That I should growl and bite and play dog.
Then, since the heavens have thus fashioned my body,
Hell make me feel like I answered it.
I don't have a brother, I don't look like any brother;
And this word “love”, which gray beards call divine,
Being a resident among men like others
And not in me: I am myself alone.
Clarence, be careful; you keep me from the light:
But I will sort out a difficult day for you;
For I will broadcast abroad such prophecies
That Edward will fear for his life,
And then, to purge his fear, I will be your death.
King Henry and the prince his son have left:
Clarence, your turn is next, and then the rest,
Count me but bad until I'm better.
I'll throw your body in another room
And triumph, Henry, on your day of misfortune.
3KING HENRY VI

KING EDWARD IV:
Once more we sit on the royal throne of England,
Redeemed with the blood of enemies.
What valiant enemies, like the autumn wheat,
Did we break down, to the height of their pride!
Three Dukes of Somerset, Thrice Renowned
For robust and indisputable champions;
Two Cliffords, like father and son,
And two Northumberlands; two braver men
They never spurred their steeds to the sound of the trumpet;
With them, the two brave bears, Warwick and Montague,
who, in their chains, chained the royal lion
And made the forest tremble when they roared.
So we swept suspicion from our seat
And makes our safety step.
Come here, Bess, and let me kiss my boy.
Young Ned, for you, your uncles and me
We watched the winter night in our armor,
I walked in the scorching summer heat,
So that you can regain possession of the crown in peace;
And from our labors you will reap the gain.

For here, I hope, begins our lasting joy.
