LEONTES:
Is whispering nothing?
Is leaning cheek to cheek? is meeting noses?
Kissing with the inner lip? stop career
To laugh with a sigh? – an infallible note
To break honesty, to ride a horse toe to toe?
Hiding in corners? Want faster clocks?
Hours, minutes? midday midnight? and all eyes
Blind with the pin and the web but to them, to them only,
Would that be mean? is it nothing?
Well, then the world and everything in it is nothing;
The sky that covers us is nothing; Bohemia, nothing;
My wife is nothing; nor anything has these nothings,
If it's nothing.

CAMILLO:
Good my lord, be healed
Of this sick opinion, and early;
Because it is the most dangerous.

LEONTES:
Say it, it's true.

CAMILLO:
No, no, my lord.

LEONTES:
It is; you lie, you lie:
I say you lie, Camillo, and I hate you,
Declare yourself a big thug, a stupid slave,
Or a hovering timer, that
Can your eyes see both good and evil,
Tilting towards both: was my wife's liver
Infected like her life, she would not live
How a glass works.

CAMILLO:
Who infects it?

LEONTES:
Well, he who wears it like a medal, hanged
On his neck, Bohemia: who, if I
I had true servants about me, those naked eyes
To see my honor as their profits,
Their own savings, they would do that
Which should undo more things: yes, and you,
His cupbearer, of which I am in a more wicked form
I sat down and lifted myself up to worship, who can see
As the sky sees the earth and the earth sees the sky,
How irritated I am, I could annoy a cup,
To give a lasting wink to my enemy;
Which draft was cordial to me.

CAMILLO:
Sir, my lord,
I could do this and that without a rash potion,
But with persistent drama, it shouldn't work
Maliciously like poison: but I can't
Believe that this crack is in my formidable mistress,
So supremely honorable.
I loved you,--

LEONTES:
Make that your question, and go rot!
I think I'm so muddy, so unstable,
To name me in this vexation, Sully
The purity and whiteness of my sheets,
What must be preserved is sleep, which is identified
They are stingers, thorns, nettles, wasp tails,
Make scandalous the blood of the prince my son,
Who I think is mine and I love him as my own,
Without maturing to go there? Would I do this?
Could the man turn so pale?

CAMILLO:
I must believe you, sir:
I do; and he will come and seek Bohemia for that;
Provided that, when he is returned, Your Highness
Take back your queen as yours first,
Even for the sake of your son; and thus to seal
The wound of tongues in courts and kingdoms
Known and allied to yours.

LEONTES:
You advise me
Even so, as I myself established:
I will not fault his honor, none.

CAMILLO:
My lord,
Go ahead; and with such a clear face
As friendship wears out at parties, stay with Bohemia
And with your queen. I am his cupbearer:
If he receives a healthy drink from me,
Do not count me as your servant.

LEONTES:
That's all:
Do it and you have half my heart;
Don't do it, you're sharing yours.

CAMILLO:
I will not, my lord.

LEONTES:
I will appear friendly, as you advised me.

CAMILLO:
O miserable lady! But for me,
What situation do I find myself in? I must be the poisoner
Good Polixenes; and my reason for not doing it
Is obedience to a master a
Who in rebellion against himself will have
All this belongs to him too. To accomplish this act,
Promotion follows. If I could find an example
Thousands who had smitten the anointed kings
And having prospered, I would not; but since
Neither brass, nor stone, nor parchment bears one,
Let not even wickedness renounce it. I have to
Abandoning court: to do or not to do so, that's for sure
For me, a daredevil. Lucky star, reign now!
This is Bohemia.

POLIXENES:
It's strange: I think
My favor here is starting to shift. Do not speak?
Hello, Camillo.

CAMILLO:
Hello, very royal sir!

POLIXENES:
What's the news at court?

CAMILLO:
Nothing rare, my lord.

POLIXENES:
The king has such a face on him
As he had lost a province and a region
Loved as he loves himself: even now I have met him
With the usual compliment; when he,
Waving his eyes away and falling
A lip full of contempt moves away from me and
So this leaves me thinking about what reproduction is
This changes his ways.

CAMILLO:
I dare not know, my lord.

POLIXENES:
How! don't dare! not. Do you know it and do you not dare?
Be smart with me: that's pretty much it;
For to yourself, what you know, you owe.
And I can't say, don't you dare. Good Camillo,
Your changed complexion is a mirror for me
Which shows me that mine has changed too; because I have to be
One party in this modification, finding
Myself so modified with this.

CAMILLO:
There is a disease
Which confuses some of us, but
I cannot name the illness; and it's caught
Of you who are doing well.

POLIXENES:
How! caught from me!
Don't make me look like the basil:
I observed thousands of them, which accelerated better
In my opinion, but I didn't kill anyone that way. Camille,...
As you are certainly a gentleman,
Experienced clerk, who no less adorns
Our nobility than the noble names of our parents,
In whose success we are sweet, I beseech you,
If you know anything that is within my knowledge
We must be informed, not imprisoned
In ignorant dissimulation.

CAMILLO:
I can not answer.

POLIXENES:
An illness has caught me, and yet I am doing well!
I need an answer. Do you hear, Camillo,
I conjure you, through every part of man
What honor recognizes, the least of which
Is it not my trial that you declare
What incidence do you guess of evil
Heads towards me; how far, how far;
How to be prevented, if at all;
Otherwise, how best to bear it.

CAMILLO:
Sir, I will tell you;
Since I am charged in honor and by him
This seems honorable to me: therefore heed my advice,
What must be followed as quickly as
I want to say it, or you and me
Cry lost, and then good night!

POLIXENES:
Come on, good Camillo.

CAMILLO:
I appointed him to assassinate you.

POLIXENES:
By whom, Camillo?

CAMILLO:
By the king.

POLIXENES:
For what?

CAMILLO:
He thinks, and even swears with complete confidence,
Like he didn't see it or wasn't an instrument
To stop you from doing it, that you touched his queen
Forbidden.

POLIXENES:
O, then my best blood turns
To an infected jelly and my name
Be under the yoke of the one who betrayed the best!
Then turn my freshest reputation towards
A flavor that can hit the dullest nostrils
Where I arrive, and my approach be avoided,
No, hated too, worse than the biggest infection
It has been heard or read!

CAMILLO:
Swears his thought is over
By each particular star in the sky and
Through all their influences, as much
Ban the sea to obey the moon
As or by oath, withdraw or advise shake
The fabric of his madness, whose foundation
Is stacked on his faith and will continue
The position of his body.

POLIXENES:
How should this grow?

CAMILLO:
I don't know: but I'm sure it's safer to
Avoid what grew up rather than wondering how it came to be.
So if you dare to trust my honesty,
Who is locked in this chest that you
I'll continue, unawn'd, away tonight!
Your subscribers, I will whisper to the company,
And will do it in twos or threes with several posterns
Eliminate them from the city. For my part, I will put
My fortunes at your service, which are here
By this lost discovery. Don't be uncertain;
Because, by the honor of my parents, I
I have spoken the truth: and if you seek to prove it,
I do not dare to sit idly by; and you won't be any safer
Let him who was condemned by the king's own mouth, thereupon
His sworn execution.

POLIXENES:
I believe you :
I saw his heart in the face. Give me your hand :
Be my pilot and your seats will be
Always my neighbor. My ships are ready and
My people expected me to leave
Two days ago. This jealousy
Is for a precious creature: as it is rare,
Should he be great, and as his person is powerful,
It must be violent, and as he sees it
He is dishonored by any man
He was told, well, his vengeance must
It will be made more bitter. Fear darkens me:
Good expedition be my friend and comfort
The gracious queen, part of her theme, but nothing
Of his unhealthy suspicions! Come, Camillo;
I will respect you as a father if
So you give me life: let's avoid it.

CAMILLO:
It is within my authority to command
The keys to all posterns: please Your Highness
Take urgent time. Come, sir, go.

HERMIONE:
Take the boy home: he bothers me so much,
It's unbearable.

First lady:
Come, my gracious lord,
Should I be your playmate?

MAMILLIUS:
No, I won't do that to any of you.

First lady:
Why, my sweet lord?

MAMILLIUS:
You will kiss me hard and you will talk to me as if
I was still a baby. I like you better.

Second lady:
And why, my lord?

MAMILLIUS:
Not for because
Your eyebrows are blacker; but black eyebrows, they say,
Become the best woman, so that there is no
Too much hair there, but in a semi-circle
Or even a half-moon made with a pen.

Second lady:
Who taught you that?

MAMILLIUS:
I learned it from the women's faces. Pray now
What color are your eyebrows?

First lady:
Blue, my lord.

MAMILLIUS:
No, it's a mockery: I saw a lady's nose
It was blue, but not his eyebrows.

First lady:
Listen ;
The queen, your mother, keeps pace: we are going
Introduce our services to a new prince
One of these days; and then you will go wild with us,
If only we had you.

Second lady:
It has spread recently
In large volume: good time meeting him!

HERMIONE:
What wisdom awakens among you? Come, sir, now
I am still for you: please sit next to us,
And tell a story.

MAMILLIUS:
Happy or sad, won't it be?

HERMIONE:
As happy as you want.

MAMILLIUS:
The best sad tale for winter: I have one
Sprites and goblins.

HERMIONE:
Let's go, good sir.
Come on, sit down: go on, and do your best
To scare me with your sprites; you are powerful in this area.

MAMILLIUS:
There was a man--

HERMIONE:
No, come, sit down; then continue.

MAMILLIUS:
Lived near a cemetery: I will say it gently;
There, the crickets won't hear it.

HERMIONE:
Come then,
And give me to my ear.

LEONTES:
Was he met there? his train? Camillo with him?

First Lord:
Behind the clump of pines I met them; Never
I saw the men walking along it: I watched them
Even to their ships.

LEONTES:
How blessed I am
In my just censure, in my true opinion!
Alas, for less knowledge! how cursed it is
To be so happy! There might be some in the cup
A spider soaked, and we can drink, go away,
And yet he consumes no venom, as far as he knows
Not infected: but if present
The abhorred ingredient in his eyes, make it known
As he has drunk, he splits his throat, his sides,
With violent weights. I drank,
and I saw the spider.
Camillo was his help, his accomplice:
There is a plot against my life, my crown;
Everything we are suspicious of is true: this false villain
The one I used was pre-employed by him:
He discovered my project, and I
Stay a pinched thing; yes, a very tip
So that they play at will. How did the posterns arrive?
So easy to open?

First Lord:
By his great authority;
Which has often prevailed no less than that
On your order.

LEONTES:
I do not know very well.
Give me the boy: I'm glad you didn't breastfeed him:
Although it bears some signs of me, yet you
He has too much blood in him.

HERMIONE:
What is this? sport?

LEONTES:
Take the boy from here; he will not come around her;
Far from him ! and let her play sports
With that, she is big; because it is Polixenes
It made you swell like this.

HERMIONE:
But I would say no,
And I will swear that you will believe what I say,
But you lean on the negative side.

LEONTES:
You, my lords,
Look at it, notice it carefully; be but about
To say "she's a good lady", and
The righteousness of your hearts will add to it
“It’s a shame she’s not honest, honorable:”
Praise her but for this form without a door,
Which, in my opinion, deserves a lofty and direct speech
The shrug, the hum or ha, those little marks
This slander uses... Oh, I'm out...
This mercy does, for slander will burn
Virtue itself: these shrugs, these hums and ha's,
When you said 'she's nice', put yourself in between
Before you can say "she's honest:" but don't be known,
Of the one who has the most reason to grieve, it should be,
She is an adulterous woman.

HERMIONE:
If a bad man says it,
The most regenerated villain in the world,
He was just as much more wicked: you, my lord,
Just fool yourself.

LEONTES:
You were wrong, my lady,
Polixenes for Leontes: O you, thing!
That I will not call a creature from your home,
Lest barbarity, making me a precedent,
Should similar language be used across the board
And the polite distinction is left aside
Between the prince and the beggar: I said
She is an adulterous woman; I said with whom:
Plus, she's a traitor and Camillo is
A federal with her, and the one who knows
What she should be ashamed to know herself
But with her most vile director, that she is
A bed diverter, even as bad as these
Let the vulgar give the most daring titles, yes, and private
To this their late escape.

HERMIONE:
No, by my life.
Aware of none of this. How will this upset you?
When you come to clearer knowledge,
So you published me! Sweet my lord,
You can barely straighten me out completely by saying
You made a mistake.

LEONTES:
No; if I am wrong
In these foundations on which I build,
The center is not big enough to support
A school top. Far from her! in prison!
Whoever speaks for her is guilty by far
But that's what he's talking about.

HERMIONE:
There is a sick planet that reigns:
I must be patient until the sky looks
With a more favorable appearance. Good my lords,
I don't tend to cry, like our sex
Are usually ; the need for what vain dew
Perhaps it will dry up your pity: but I have
This honorable sorrow lodged here that burns
Worse than tears drown: I beseech you all, my lords,
With thoughts as qualified as your charities
I will instruct you as best I can, measure me; and so
The king's will be executed!

LEONTES:
Should I be heard?

HERMIONE:
Who is accompanying me? Implore your Highness,
My wives can be with me; because you see
My fate demands it. Don't cry, good fools;
There is no cause: when you know your mistress
Deserved prison, then burst into tears
When leaving: this action, I continue now
It is for my best grace. Farewell, my lord:
I never wanted to see you sorry; NOW
I hope I will. My women, come; you have leave.

LEONTES:
Come on, do what we want; Thus!

First Lord:
Implore Your Highness, call the Queen again.

ANTIGONE :
Be sure of what you do, sir, lest your justice
Prove violence; in which three great ones suffer,
Yourself, your queen, your son.

First Lord:
For her, my lord,
I dare to risk my life and I will not do it, sir,
Please accept it, that the queen is impeccable
I have eyes from heaven and towards you; I mean,
In what you accuse him of.

ANTIGONE :
If it proves
It is otherwise, I will keep my stables where
I accommodate my wife; I will go as a couple with her;
That when I feel it and see it, I no longer trust it;
For every square inch of woman in the world,
Yes, every piece of woman's flesh is fake, if it exists.

LEONTES:
Keep your peace.

First Lord:
Well my lord,--

ANTIGONE :
We speak for you, not for ourselves:
You are abused and by a putter
It will be damned for that; had I known the wicked,
I would land, damn it. That she has a lack of honor,
I have three daughters; the eldest is eleven years old
The second and the third, nine and about five;
If this turns out to be true, they will pay for it:
by my honor,
I will gel them all; fourteen they will not see,
Bringing false generations: they are joint heirs;
And I would have preferred to be casual rather than them
Shouldn't produce a fair issue.

LEONTES:
Cease; no more.
You feel this matter with such a cold sensation
Like a dead man's nose: but I see it and I feel it
As you feel while doing so; and see with
Instruments that feel.

ANTIGONE :
If this is so,
We don't need a grave to bury honesty:
There is not a grain of the face to soften
Of all the filthy earth.

LEONTES:
What! am I short of credit?

First Lord:
I would have preferred you to miss rather than me, my lord,
On this ground; and what's more it would please me
So that his honor is truer than your suspicions,
Take the blame however you may.

LEONTES:
Why, what do we need
Communicate with you about this, but instead follow
Our energetic instigation? Our prerogative
Call not your advice, but our natural goodness
Give this; and if you are amazed
Or who seems so competent, can't or won't
Savor a truth like us, get informed
We no longer need your advice: the matter,
The loss, the gain, the order, that's it
Properly ours.

ANTIGONE :
And I wish, my liege,
You had only tried it in your silent judgment,
Without more openness.

LEONTES:
How could this be?
Either you are the most ignorant by age,
Or you were born a fool. Camillo's escape,
Added to their familiarity,
Which was as crude as ever a touched conjecture,
He only lacked sight, nothing for approval
But only seeing, all other circumstances
Made in accordance with the act, he pushes this procedure:
Yet, for further confirmation,
Because in an act of this importance, there was
It's very pitiful to be wild, I mailed it
At sacred Delphos, at the temple of Apollo,
Cleomenes and Dion, whom you know
Sufficient things: now from the oracle
They will bring everything; whose spiritual counsels had,
Must stop me or stimulate me. Did I do well?

First Lord:
Well done, my lord.

LEONTES:
Even though I'm satisfied and don't need more
That what I know, the oracle will do
Give rest to the minds of others, like him
Whose ignorant credulity
Come to the truth. So did we think it was good
Of our free person she should be confined,
Lest the betrayal of the two flee from here
Let her play. Come, follow us;
We must speak in public; for this matter
Will uplift us all.

ANTIGONE :

PAULINE:
The prison guard, call him;
let him know who I am.
Good lady,
No court in Europe is too good for you;
So what are you doing in prison?
Now, good sir,
You know me, don't you?

Gaoler:
For a worthy lady
And someone I honor very much.

PAULINE:
Please then,
Take me to the queen.

Gaoler:
I can't, ma'am:
On the contrary, I have an express command.

PAULINE:
So,
To lock up the honesty and honor of
Access for sweet visitors!
This is not legal, please,
To see his wives? any of them? Emily?

Gaoler:
So please, ma'am,
To set apart your servants, I
I will give birth to Emilia.

PAULINE:
I pray now, call her.
Withdraw.

Gaoler:
And, Madam,
I have to be at your conference.

PAULINE:
Well, don't be so, please.
Here is such noise to make no stain a stain
As the coloring progresses.
Dear lady,
How is our gracious lady?

EMILIE:
As one so great and so desperate
May they hold together: over their fears and their sorrows,
What ever tender lady was born greater,
It is something delivered before its time.

PAULINE:
A boy?

EMILIE:
A girl and a pretty baby,
Vigorous and loving to live: the queen receives
Lots of comfort in that; said "My poor prisoner,
I'm innocent like you.

PAULINE:
I dare to take an oath
These dangerous and dangerous moons for the king,
devour them!
You have to tell him, and he will: the office
Becomes a better woman; I will take care of it:
If I prove my honey mouth would let my tongue blister
And never in my red gaze will anger be
The trumpet, no more. I pray to you, Émilie,
Recommend my best obedience to the queen:
If she dares to entrust her little baby to me,
I will show it to the king and promise to be
His lawyer at his strongest. We do not know
How he can soften at the sight of the child:
The silence often of pure innocence
Convinces when words fail.

EMILIE:
Very worthy madam,
Your honor and goodness are so evident
That your free commitment cannot be lacking
A growing problem: there are no women alive
So get together for this big race. Please, Your Lady
To visit the next room, I will immediately
Inform the Queen of your noblest offer;
Who has not hammered home this design today,
But I didn't dare tempt an honorary minister,
Lest it be refused.

PAULINE:
Tell him, Emilia.
I will use this language of mine: if the mind arises from it
Like the boldness of my breast, let there be no doubt
I will do good.

EMILIE:
Now be happy about it!
I'm going to the queen: please,
approach something.

Gaoler:
Madam, please the queen to send the baby,
I don't know what I would incur to adopt him,
Having no mandate.

PAULINE:
You need not fear him, sir:
This child was trapped in the womb and is
By law and by a process of great nature
Freed and freed, not party to
The anger of the king nor guilty,
If there is, the queen's intrusion.

Gaoler:
I believe him.

PAULINE:
Do not fear: on my honor,
I will stand between you and danger.

LEONTES:
Neither night nor day, no rest: it is only weakness
Bear the matter thus; simple weakness. If
The cause was not existence, part of the cause,
She is the adulterous woman; for the harlot king
Is quite beyond my arm, out of nowhere
And at the level of my brain, proof of intrigue; but she
I can hold on: say she was gone,
Given to the fire, half of my rest
I might come back to me. Who is here?

First Servant:
My lord?

LEONTES:
How is the boy?

First Servant:
He rested well last night;
I hope his illness will be cured.

LEONTES:
To see its nobility!
Conceiving his mother's dishonor,
He directly refused, sank down, took it deep,
Tied up and repaired the shame in himself,
He lost his mind, his appetite, his sleep,
And downright languishing. Leave me alone: go,
See how he does.
Fi, fi! I didn't think about him:
The thought of my revenges this way
Stand back on me: in itself too powerful,
And in his parties, his alliance; let it be
Until a time has come: for present vengeance,
Take it out on her. Camillo and Polixenes
Laugh at me, make my sorrow their pastime:
They shouldn't laugh if I could reach them, nor
Is it in my power?

First Lord:
You must not enter.

PAULINE:
No, my good lords, be my second:
Do you fear his tyrannical passion more, alas,
What about the queen's life? a gracious and innocent soul,
More free than jealous.

ANTIGONE :
That's enough.

Second servant:
Madam, he did not sleep last night; order
No one should pick on him.

PAULINE:
Not so hot, good sir:
I'm coming to put him to sleep. It's like you,
who crawl like shadows near him and sigh
Everyone has their own useless gasps, like you
Nourish the cause of his awakening: I
Come with words as medicinal as they are true,
Honest too, to purge him of this humor
This wakes him up from sleep.

LEONTES:
What noise there, ho?

PAULINE:
No noise, my lord; but conference necessary
About some gossip about Your Highness.

LEONTES:
How!
Far from this daring lady! Antigone,
I charged you not to let her come to me:
I knew she would.

ANTIGONE :
I told him, my lord,
At my own risk,
She shouldn't visit you.

LEONTES:
What, you can't rule her?

PAULINE:
With all dishonesty, he can: in this,
Unless he takes the course you took,
Hire me for committing honor, trust him,
He will not rule me.

ANTIGONE :
Now you hear:
When she takes the reins, I'll let her run;
But she won't stumble.

PAULINE:
Well my lord, I am coming;
And, I beg you, listen to me, who professes
Myself, your faithful servant, your doctor,
Your most obedient advisor, but who dares
The less he will appear thus to console your ills,
That those who seem to be yours: I say, I come
Of your good queen.

LEONTES:
Good Queen !

PAULINE:
Good queen, my lord,
Good Queen ; I say good queen;
And the fight would make her good, me too
A man, the worst thing about you.

LEONTES:
Force her to leave.

PAULINE:
Than the one who only does trifles with his eyes
Give me first: of my own free will I go;
But first I'm going to run my errand. The good queen,
For she is good, she has given you a daughter;
So ; commend him to your blessing.

LEONTES:
Out!
A witch of humanity! So with her, outside:
One of the smartest whores!

PAULINE:
This is not the case :
I'm as ignorant as you on the subject
By allowing myself thus, and no less honest
Then you are crazy; which is enough, I guarantee,
In the world, pass as honest.

LEONTES:
Traitors!
Won't you push her away? Give him that bastard.
You idiot ! you are a tired woman, without rest
By your Lady Partlet here. Take this bastard;
Hurry up, I said; give it to your old wife.

PAULINE:
Forever
Invenerable are your hands, if you
Takes the princess by this forced baseness
Which he put on it!

LEONTES:
He fears his wife.

PAULINE:
So I would; then there was no longer any doubt
You would call your children your own.

LEONTES:
A nest of traitors!

ANTIGONE :
I am nothing, on this good day.

PAULINE:
Neither me nor anyone
But he who is here, and it is himself, for he
The sacred honor of himself, that of his queen,
Her hopeful son, her baby, betrays the slander,
Whose sting is sharper than that of the sword;
and I won't...
Because, as things stand, it's a curse
You can't force it...once it's removed
The root of his opinion, which is rotten
As always, the oak or stone was sound.

LEONTES:
A call
Of a limitless tongue, which belatedly beat her husband
And now it tempts me! This kid is none of mine;
This is the issue of the Polixenes:
So with him, and with the dam
Send them to the fire!

PAULINE:
It's yours;
And might we blame you for the old proverb:
So like you, it's the worst. Behold, my lords,
Even though the print is small, the whole deal
And copy of the father, eye, nose, lip,
The thing of the frown, of his brow, no, of the valley,
The pretty dimples of his chin and his cheek,
His smiles,
The mold and the very structure of the hand, the nail, the finger:
And you, good goddess Nature, who made
So love the one who got it, if you got it

A rude witch

Hang all the husbands

Unable to produce more charges

Yes, it's scandalous for the world.

On your allegiance,

Jupiter sends it
A better guiding spirit! What do these hands need?

LEONTES:
You, traitor, decided to do this with your wife.

And see him instantly consumed by fire;
Even you and no one but you. Take it straight:
In this hour, bring me a word, it's done,

With what you call yours. If you refuse
And if you meet my anger, say so;
These bastard brains with my own hands
Should I rush. Go, take it to the fire;
Because you are attacking your wife.

ANTIGONE :
I didn't do it, sir:

Lords:

Time:
Me, it pleases some people, I try everything, both joy and terror
Of good and evil, it makes and unfolds error,
Now take upon me, in the name of Time,
To use my wings. To impute is not a crime
Towards me or my rapid passage, that I slide
O'er sixteen years and let growth without trial
From this wide gap, since it is in my power
To overthrow the law and in a single hour
Planting and submerging custom. Let me pass
The same as I am, before the order of elders was created
Or what is now received: I testify of
The moments that led to them; then I will do

It seems now. Your patience allowing,

AUTOLYCUS:
When the daffodils begin to peer,
With height! the doxy on the valley,
Well, then comes the sweet year;
For red blood reigns in the paleness of winter.
The white sheet whitening on the hedge,
With height! the sweet birds, oh how they sing!
It puts a strain on my tooth;
Because a liter of beer is a dish for a king.
The lark, this tirra-lyra sings,
With height! with height! the thrush and the jay,
These are summer songs for me and my aunts,
While we fall in the hay.
I served Prince Florizel and, in my time
wore three hairs; but now I'm out of service:

and would you like to have an adventure

Make the climate here! You have a holy father,

As sacred as it is, I have committed the sin:
Which the heavens, angrily taking note of,
Left me without problem; and your father is blessed,
As he deserves it from heaven, with you
Worthy of his goodness. What could I have been,
May I, a son and a daughter, look upon them now,
Such beautiful things as you!

Lord:
Very noble sir,
What I report will carry no credit,
Wasn't the proof so close. Please, great sir,
Bohemia greets you on its behalf through me;
Wants you to tie up his son, who has...
Both his dignity and his duty have been abandoned...
Running away from his father, his hopes and with
A shepherd's daughter.

LEONTES:
Where is Bohemia? talk.

Lord:
Here in your city; I now come from him:
I speak with astonishment; and it becomes
My wonder and my message. At your court
As he hurried on, seemingly in pursuit,
Of this beautiful couple, he meets him on the way
The father of this apparent lady and
His brother, having both left their country
With this young prince.

FLORISEL:
Camillo betrayed me;
Whose honor and honesty so far
Endured all the weather.

Lord:
Put him in charge:
He is with the king your father.

LEONTES:
WHO? Camille?

Lord:
Camillo, sir; I talked to him; who now
Are these poor men in question? I've never seen
The wretched thus tremble: they kneel, they kiss the earth;
Refrain as often as they speak:
Bohemia covers their ears and threatens them
With various deaths within death.

PERDITA:
O my poor father!
The sky is spying on us, it won't have it
Our contract celebrated.

LEONTES:
You are married?

FLORISEL:
We are not, sir, and we do not intend to be;
The stars, I see, will first embrace the valleys:
The probabilities are the same for highs and lows.

LEONTES:
My lord,
Is she the daughter of a king?

FLORISEL:
She is,
When once, she is my wife.

LEONTES:
This "once" I see it at the speed of your good father
It will come very slowly. I'm sorry,
Sorry you broke up with his taste
Where you were bound by duty, and as sorry
Your choice is not as rich in value as beauty,
So that you can appreciate it well.

FLORISEL:
Dear, looking for:
Even if Fortune, visible enemy,
I should chase me and my father away, power is useless
Will it change our loves? I beg you, sir,
Remember since you no longer owed anything to time
That I do now: thinking of such affections,

As she lived without equal,

His natural posture!

As she could have done now,

My pains evoked in memory and

And give me leave,

Expertly done:

LEONTES:
O sweet Pauline,

Do it, Pauline;

Well my lord, refrain:
The reddish color of her lip is moist;

No, not these twenty years.

I could so long

No more escape:
We have with a choice of sourdough and prepared

ANGELO:

CLAUDIO:

Take me to prison, where I am incarcerated.

Provost:

But from Lord Angelo by special charge.

CLAUDIO:
Thus can the Authority of the demigod
Make us pay for our offense by weight
The words of heaven; on whom it will be done, it will be the case;
On whom this will not be the case, then; and yet, it is right.

LUCIO:
Well, how now, Claudio! where does this restraint come from?

CLAUDIO:
Too much freedom, my Lucio, freedom:
As excess is the father of many fasts,
So each worn by immoderate use
Turns to restraint. Our natures pursue,
Like rats ravaging their own plague,
A thirsty evil; and when we drink, we die.

LUCIO:
If I could speak so wisely while under arrest, I would
bring in some of my creditors: and yet, to say
the truth, I aimed to have the happiness of freedom
like the morality of imprisonment. What is your
Offense, Claudio?

CLAUDIO:
Anything other than talking would be offensive again.

LUCIO:
What, it's not murder?

No.

Lust?

Call it that.

A hundred, if that's useful to you.

The too rude character is written on Juliette.

Or if the public body is
A horse on which the governor rides,
Who, newly seated, so that he knows
He can command, it allows him to feel the spur directly;
Let tyranny be in its place,
Or in his seed which fills him,
I'm staggering: but this new governor
Wakes up all the penalties listed
Which, like unscrubbed armor, hang on the wall
So long that nineteen zodiacs have gone around
And none of them were worn; and, for a name,
Now put on the sleepy and slovenly act
Fresh on me: it's probably for a name.

To the strict deputy; ordered himself to analyze it:
I have a lot of hope in this; because in his youth

DUKE VINCENTIO:
No, holy father; throw away this thought;
Don't believe the dribble of love
Can pierce a full chest. Why do I want you
Giving me a secret port has a purpose
More serious and wrinkled than goals and ends
Burning youth.

BROTHER THOMAS:
Can your Grace speak to this?

DUKE VINCENTIO:
My holy sir, no one knows it better than you
How I always loved the suppressed life
And held in slow motion to haunt the assemblies
Where youth, price and insane bravery are kept.
I delivered it to Lord Angelo,
A man of rigor and firm abstinence,
My absolute power and my place here in Vienna,
And he supposes that I have traveled to Poland;
For thus I have poured it out into the common ear,
And so he is received. Now, pious sir,
You will ask me why I do this?

BROTHER THOMAS:
With pleasure, my lord.

DUKE VINCENTIO:
We have strict statutes and very severe laws.
The necessary pieces and brakes for stubborn weeds,
What we let slip away for nineteen years;
Even like an overgrown lion in a cave,
This is not prey. Now, as loving fathers,
Having bound the threatening branches of the birch,
Only to put it in front of their children
For terror, do not use, over time the rod
Becomes more mocked than feared; therefore our decrees,
Dead to the infliction, they are dead to themselves;
And freedom cuts justice by the nose;
The baby beats the nurse, and completely wrong
Everything is fine.

BROTHER THOMAS:
He rested in your grace
To resolve this obstructed justice whenever you want:
And it would have seemed more terrible in you
Than in Lord Angelo.

DUKE VINCENTIO:
I'm afraid, it's too terrible:
If it was my fault for giving people room to act,
"It would be my tyranny to strike them and exasperate them
For what I have asked them to do: for we ask that this be done,
When bad actions have their permissiveness
And not the punishment. This is why, in fact, my father,
I imposed the position on Angelo;
Who can, in the ambush of my name, strike at home,
And yet my nature is never in the fight
To be slandered. And to see its influence,
I will do it, as if it were a brother of your order,
Visit the prince and the people: therefore, I pray you,
Give me the habit and teach me
How can I officially support myself in person
Like a real brother. More reasons for this action
At our greatest leisure, I will return you;
Only this one: Lord Angelo is precise;
Stands to guard with envy; barely admit
Let his blood flow, or his appetite
It is more bread than stone: that is why we will see,
If power changes its objective, what will our appearances be?

Of its true conception. In its place,
And with all the line of his authority,
Rules Lord Angelo; a man whose blood

ISABELLE:
Should he die?

ANGELO:
Girl, no cure.

ISABELLE:
Yes; I think you could forgive him,
And neither heaven nor man grieves because of this mercy.

ANGELO:
I will not do it.

ISABELLE:
But can you, if you want?

ANGELO:
Look, what I don't want, I can't do.

ISABELLE:
But could you do it and not harm the world,
If so, your heart has been touched by this remorse
Like mine is for him?

ANGELO:
He is condemned; it's too late.

LUCIO:

ISABELLE:
Too late? why no ; Me, who says a word.
Maybe call him back. Well, believe it,
No ceremony awaiting the grown-ups,
Neither the king's crown nor the deputy's sword,
The marshal's baton, nor the judge's robe,
Become them with half so good grace
As does mercy.
If he had been like you and you like him,
You would have slipped like him; but he, like you,
It wouldn't have been as severe.

ANGELO:
Please leave.

ISABELLE:
I wish in heaven I had your power,
And you were Isabel! should it be like this?
No; I would say what it is like to be a judge,
And what a prisoner.

LUCIO:

ANGELO:
Your brother is a crime against the law,
And you're just wasting your words.

ISABELLE:
Alas, alas!
Well, all the souls that were were lost once;
And the one who could have taken the best position
I discovered the cure. How would you be,
If He, who is the summit of judgment, were to
But judging you as you are? Oh, think about it;
And then mercy will breathe on your lips,
Like a newly created man.

ANGELO:
Be content, beautiful young girl;
It's the law, I don't condemn your brother:
Was he my parent, my brother or my son,
It should be like this: he must die tomorrow.

ISABELLE:
Tomorrow! Oh, it's sudden! Spare him, spare him!
He is not prepared for death. Even for our kitchens
We kill the seasonal birds: will we serve the sky
With less respect than us, minister
To our gross selves? Well, good monsignor, think about it;
Who is the one who died for this crime?
Many people have committed it.

LUCIO:

ANGELO:
The law is not dead, even if it slept:
Many had not dared to do this evil,
If the first who made the edict broke
Had answered for his act: now he is awake
Take note of what is done; and, like a prophet,
Look into a glass, which shows what future evils,
Either new or new designed by negligence,
And so in the process of hatching and birth,
No longer must have successive diplomas,
But before they live, it's over.

ISABELLE:
But show a little mercy.

ANGELO:
I show it especially when I show justice;
For then I pity those whom I do not know,
Which would be an offense rejected after the gall;
And do him well, responding to a fault,
He does not live to act on others. To be satisfied;
Your brother dies tomorrow; be happy.

ISABELLE:
So you must be the first to say this sentence,
And he suffers. Oh, it's excellent
Have the strength of a giant; but it's tyrannical
To use it like a giant.

LUCIO:

ISABELLE:
Could great men thunder
Like Jupiter himself, Jupiter would never be silent,
For every skinning, master
Would use his sky for thunder;
Nothing but thunder! Merciful Heaven,
You rather, with your sharp and sulphurous lightning
Split'st the non-stuck and knotty oak
Than the sweet myrtle: but man, proud man,
Dress yourself with a little brief authority,
The most ignorant of what he is most assured of,
Its glassy essence, like an angry monkey,
Play such fantastic tricks before the sky
Like making angels cry; who, with our spleen,
They would all laugh to death.

LUCIO:

Provost:

ISABELLE:
We cannot weigh our brother with ourselves:
Great men can joke with saints; it's spirit in them,
But in the least ignoble desecration.

LUCIO:
You are right, my daughter; more o, that.

ISABELLE:
That in the captain's word it was only an angry word,
Which for the soldier is pure blasphemy.

LUCIO:

ANGELO:
Why do you impose these words on me?

ISABELLE:
Because authority, even if it makes mistakes like the others,
Still has some kind of medicine in itself,
This scratches the vice at the top. Go to your bosom;
Knock there and ask your heart what it knows
It's like my brother's fault: if he confesses
A natural guilt like his,
Don't let a thought pass on your tongue
Against my brother's life.

ANGELO:

Sweet my lord, come back.

ISABELLE:

ANGELO:
How! bribe me?

ISABELLE:
Yes, with such gifts that heaven will share with you.

LUCIO:

ISABELLE:
Not with precious shekels of tested gold,

It will be in heaven and will enter there
Before sunrise, prayers of preserved souls,
Fasting maids whose spirits are devoted
Nothing temporal.

ANGELO:
GOOD; come see me tomorrow.

LUCIO:

ISABELLE:
Heaven keep your honor safe!

ANGELO:

At what time tomorrow

ANGELO:
Any time before noon.

ISABELLE:
“Save your honor!”

ANGELO:
Of you, even of your virtue!
What is it, what is it? Is it his fault or mine?
The tempter or the tempted, who sins more?
Ha!
Not her: she doesn't try either: but it's me
That, lying near the violet in the sun,
Be like the carrion, not like the flower,
Corrupted with a virtuous season. Can it be
This modesty can further betray our feeling
Than the lightness of woman? Having enough vacant land,
Should we desire to raze the sanctuary
And plant our evils there? Oh, fi, fi, fi!
What are you doing, or what are you, Angelo?
Do you desire her grossly for these things
Does that make it good? Oh, let his brother live!
Thieves for their theft have authority
When judges steal from themselves. What, do I love him,
How I long to hear him speak again,
And feast on his eyes? What am I dreaming of?
O cunning enemy, who, to catch a saint,
With the saints, bait your hook! The most dangerous
Is it temptation that pushes us
Sin while loving virtue: the trumpet could never,
With all its double vigor, art and nature,
Once, stir my mood; but this virtuous servant
It completely subdues me. Even until now,
When men were affectionate, I smiled and wondered how.

DUKE VINCENTIO:
Hello, Provost! so I think so.

Provost:
I am the provost. What is your will, my good brother?

DUKE VINCENTIO:
Bound by my charity and my blessed order,
I come to visit the afflicted spirits
Here in the prison. Give me common law
To let me see them and let me know
The nature of their crimes, so that I can exercise
To them accordingly.

Provost:
I would do more than that, if more was needed.
Look, here's one: one of my ladies,
Who, falling into the failings of his own youth,
He put a blister in his report: she is pregnant;
And he who had it was condemned; a young man
More likely to commit another offense of this type
Than die for it.

DUKE VINCENTIO:
When should he die?

Provost:
As I think, tomorrow.
I have provided for you: stay a little,
And you will be led.

DUKE VINCENTIO:
Repent, beautiful, of the sin you bear?

JULIET:
I do; and bears shame with great patience.

DUKE VINCENTIO:
I will teach you how to bring your conscience to justice,
And test your penance, if it is healthy,
Or hollowed out.

JULIET:
I will learn with pleasure.

DUKE VINCENTIO:
Do you love the man who wronged you?

JULIET:
Yes, how I love the woman who wronged him.

DUKE VINCENTIO:
So it seems your most offensive act
Was he mutually committed?

JULIET:
Mutually.

DUKE VINCENTIO:
Your sin was then more serious than his.

JULIET:
I admit it and I repent of it, father.

DUKE VINCENTIO:
It is so, my daughter; but lest you repent,
As sin brought you to this shame,
What sadness is always towards ourselves and not towards heaven,
Showing that we would not spare the sky as we love it,
But since we are afraid,...

JULIET:
I repent, because it is evil,
And take the shame with joy.

DUKE VINCENTIO:
He's staying.
Your partner, I hear, is due to die tomorrow,
And I will give him instructions.
Grace accompanies you, Bénédicte!

JULIET:
I must die tomorrow! O harmful love,
This leaves me with a life whose very comfort
It's still a dying horror!

Provost:
It's a shame for him.

ANGELO:
When I prayed and thought, I thought and prayed
On several subjects. Heaven has my empty words;
While my invention, not hearing my language,
Anchors on Isabel: paradise in my mouth,
As if I were just chewing his name;
And in my heart the strong and growing evil
Of my design. The state I studied in
It's like a good thing to be read often,
Became fearful and annoying; yes, my gravity,
Hence, let no one hear me, I am proud,
Can I change startup for an inactive plume,
Let the air beat in vain. O place, o form,
How often do you deal with your case, your habit,
Remove the fear of fools and bind the wisest souls
At your false appearance! Blood, you are blood:
Let's write good angel on the devil's horn:
It's not the devil's crest.
How now! Who is here?

Servant:
A certain Isabel, a sister, wishes to have access to you.

ANGELO:
Teach him the way.
O heaven!
Why does my blood gather like this to my heart,
Making him incapable of being self-sufficient,
And dispossess all my other parts
Necessary physical condition?
So play foolish crowds with him who faints;
Everyone come and help him, and thus stop the air

The general, subject to a welcome king,
Leaving their own role, and in obsequious tenderness
Crowd in his presence, where their uncultivated love
It has to appear offensive.
And now, beautiful girl?

ISABELLE:
I have just heard of your pleasure.

Just so you know, you better please me

Under your sentence?

Yeah.

ANGELO:
Ha! fi, these dirty vices! It was also good

Their impertinent sweetness which marks the image of the sky
In banned stamps: it's just as simple
Falsely to take away a life truly made

It is so in heaven, but not on earth.

How do you say ?

I, now the voice of the law recorded,
Say a sentence about your brother's life:
Could there be no charity in sin?
To save this brother's life?

ISABELLE:
Please don't do it,
I will take it as a peril for my soul,

ANGELO:
I pleased you not to do it at the risk of your soul,

ISABELLE:
That I ask for his life, if it is a sin,
Heaven, let me bear it! you grant my trial,
If it's a sin, I'll make it my morning prayer
To add to my faults,
And nothing from your response.

ANGELO:
No, but listen to me.
Your sense does not follow mine: either you are ignorant,
Or appear so artfully; and that's not good.

ISABELLE:
Let me be ignorant and no good,
But fortunately to know that I'm not getting better.

ANGELO:
Thus wisdom wishes to appear the brightest
When he imposes himself; like these black masks
Proclaim protected beauty ten times louder
That beauty could be exposed. But notice me;
To be received clearly, I will speak more crudely:
Your brother must die.

ISABELLE:
SO.

ANGELO:
And his offense is such, it seems,
Accountant with the law on this pain.

ISABELLE:
TRUE.

ANGELO:
Admit no other means of saving his life,--
As I do not subscribe to this or any other,
But in the loss of the question, that you, his sister,
Finding yourself desired by such a person,
Whose credit with the judge, or his own great place,
I could get your brother back from the handcuffs
Of the law of all buildings; and that there was
No earthly means to save him, but that neither
You must lay down the treasures of your body
At this supposed, or else let him suffer;
What would you do?

ISABELLE:
As much for my poor brother as for me:
In other words, if I were under the influence of death,
The impression of sharp whips that I would carry like rubies,
And undress me to death, like for a bed
This desire made me sick before it gave in
My body is ashamed.

ANGELO:
So your brother must die.

ISABELLE:
And it was the cheapest way:
Better for a brother to die instantly,
That a sister, by redeeming him,
Should die forever.

ANGELO:
Were you not then as cruel as the sentence
Whom have you thus slandered?

ISABELLE:
Ignomy as a ransom and free forgiveness
Are of two houses: legitimate mercy
This has nothing to do with filthy redemption.

ANGELO:
Lately you seemed to be making a tyrant of the law;
And rather proved your brother's slippage
A cheerfulness rather than a vice.

ISABELLE:
Oh, forgive me, my lord; it often falls,
To have what we would have, we don't say what we want to say:
I excuse something the thing I hate,
For its advantage that I really like.

ANGELO:
We are all fragile.

ISABELLE:
Otherwise, let my brother die,
If it is not a feudal, but only him

ANGELO:
No, women are fragile too.

ISABELLE:
Yes, like the glasses where they see themselves;
Which are as easy to break as they are to create shapes.
Women! Help Heaven! men their creation mar
By taking advantage of it. No, call us fragile ten times;
For we are as gentle as our complexion,
And gullible to false fingerprints.

ANGELO:
I think so:
And according to this testimony from your own sex,...
Since I guess we're made not to be stronger
That faults may shake our bodies, let me be bold;
I stop your words. Be what you are,
That is to say a woman; if you are more, you are nothing;
If you are one, as you put it well
By all external mandates, show it now,
By donning the planned livery.

ISABELLE:
I have only one tongue: sweet my lord,
Let me beg you to speak the ancient language.

ANGELO:
Conceive clearly, I love you.

ISABELLE:
My brother loved Juliette,
And you tell me he will die for it.

ANGELO:
He won't, Isabel, if you give me love.

ISABELLE:
I know your virtue has license,
Which sounds a little more disgusting than it is,
To snatch others.

ANGELO:
Believe me, on my honor,
My words express my purpose.

ISABELLE:
Ha! little honor to be much believed,
And the most pernicious goal! Apparently, apparently!
I will proclaim you, Angelo; look for it:
Sign me a present pardon for my brother,
Or with a tight throat I'll tell the world out loud
What a man you are.

ANGELO:
Who will believe you, Isabel?
My name intact, the austerity of my life,
I vouch against you, and my place in the state,
Will your accusation weigh like this,
That you will suffocate in your own report
And it smacks of slander. I started,
And now I give free rein to my sensual course:
Adapt your consent to my keen appetite;
Lay by all the delicacy and prolix blushes,
This banishes what they are pursuing; redeem your brother
By abandoning your body to my will;
Or else he must not only die a death,
But your wickedness will lead to his death
To persistent suffering. Answer me tomorrow,
Or, by the affection that guides me most now,
I'm going to prove him a tyrant. As for you,
Say what you can, my fake outweighs your real one.

ISABELLE:
Who should I complain to? Did I say that,
Who would believe me? O perilous mouths,
Who carry within them one and the same language,
Either of condemnation or of approval;
By ordering the law to do court to their will:
Hanging on good and evil to the appetite,
To be continued as the draw progresses! I go to my brother:
Although he fell because of blood,
Yet he has such a spirit of honor within him.
This, did he have twenty heads to offer
On twenty bloody blocks he would return them,
In front of his sister, should his body lower himself
To such abhorred pollution.
So, Isabelle, live chastely, and, brother, die:
More than our brother is our chastity.
I'll tell him about Angelo's request,
And adapt his mind to death, for the rest of his soul.

DUKE VINCENTIO:
So you hope for forgiveness from Lord Angelo?

CLAUDIO:
The miserable have no other medicine
But only hope:
I have hope of living and I am ready to die.

DUKE VINCENTIO:
Be absolute for death; either death or life
This will be the sweetest. So let's reason with life:
If I lose you, I lose something
That only fools would keep: you are a breath,
Servile to all celestial influences,
That's what this dwelling does, where you stand,
Hourly Affliction: Simply, you are a fool of death;
For him you work by your escape to avoid
And yet, I still run towards him. You are not noble;
For all the accommodations you put up with
Are nourished by baseness. You are by no means valiant;
Because you fear the soft and tender fork
From a poor worm. Your best rest is sleep,
And you often provoke this; but I'm terribly afraid
Your death, which is no more. You are not yourself;
Because you exist on several thousand grains
This problem has risen from the dust. You are not happy;
Because what you don't have, you always strive to get,
And what you have, forget it. You're not sure;
Because your complexion takes on strange effects,
After the moon. If you are rich, you are poor;
For, like a donkey whose back bows with ingots,
You only carry your heavy riches for a journey,
And death discharges you. You have no friend;
For your own insides, which call you father,
The simple effusion of your own kidneys,
Curse gout, serpigo and colds,
For killing you immediately. You are neither young nor old,
But, so to speak, a sleep after dinner,
Dreaming of both; for all your blessed youth
Becomes old and asks for alms
From paralyzed field; and when you are old and rich,
You have neither warmth, nor affection, nor limb, nor beauty,
To make your riches pleasant. What's still in there?
Who is named after life? Yet in this life
He has hidden a thousand deaths: yet we fear death,
This makes these chances equal.

CLAUDIO:
I humbly thank you.
In an attempt to live, I find that I seek to die;
And, in seeking death, find life: let it come.

ISABELLE:

Provost:

For what,

Lord Angelo, having adventures with heaven,

Tomorrow you leave.

None, but such a remedy as, to save a head,

I think I can find a resolution

The prenzie Angelo!

Oh, it's hell's cunning livery,

Imagine yourself screaming: it’s so horrible!

In delayed death.

Provost:

The content of this is the return of the Duke: you

This is something Angelo doesn't know; for him that

I know myself as well here as at home

persuasion.

Isabel's language. She got to know

Mark what I say, you will find it

Who prepares to meet him at the gates,

Grace of the Duke, vengeance to your heart,

ISABELLE:

Command these agonizing waters from your eyes

This act completely distorts me, makes me not pregnant

For my authority carries great credibility,
That no particular scandal can touch
But this confuses the prompter. He should have lived,

Perhaps in times to come we could have taken revenge,
By thus receiving a dishonored life
With a ransom of such shame. Would he still have lived!
A lack, when once our grace we have forgotten,
Nothing is right: we would, and we wouldn't.

DUKE VINCENTIO:
These timely letters deliver me
The provost knows our goal and our plot.

She was my suitor for her brother
Cut off by justice,

Through justice!

This Angelo bet; isn't that strange?

DUKE VINCENTIO:
No, it's ten times strange.

ISABELLE:
It's not true anymore, it's Angelo
So all this is as true as it is strange:
No, it's ten times true; because the truth is the truth

DUKE VINCENTIO:
Far from her! Poor soul,
She speaks thus in the infirmity of sense.

ISABELLE:
O prince, I conjure you, as you believe
There is another comfort than this world,
That you do not neglect me, with this opinion
How touched I am with madness! Don't make it impossible
What seems different: it's not impossible
But one, the baddest boss in the world,
Can appear as timid, as serious, as fair, as absolute
Like Angelo; even if Angelo can,
In all its dressings, characters, titles, forms,
Be a big bad guy; believe it, royal prince:
If it is less, it is nothing; but it is more,
If I had more name for evil.

DUKE VINCENTIO:
By my honesty,
If she is crazy, like no other I believe,
His madness has the strangest meaning,
Such dependence from thing to thing,
As always I heard it in madness.

ISABELLE:
O gracious duke,
Don't dwell on it, and don't banish reason

To reveal the truth where it seems hidden,
And hiding the fake seems true.

DUKE VINCENTIO:
Many are not crazy

In short, to define the unnecessary process,

DUKE VINCENTIO:

ISABELLE:

Carnally, she said.

Partly for this, its promised proportions
Lack of composition, but in chief
For this, his reputation was devalued
In lightness: for what period of five years
I never spoke to her, I never saw her, nor heard of her,
On my faith and my honor.

MARIANNE:
Noble prince,
As light comes from heaven and words from breath,
As there is meaning in truth and truth in virtue,
I am also heavily engaged to this man's wife

But on Tuesday evening I entered the garden house
He knew me as a wife. How true it is,
Let me rise safely from my knees
Or be forever confined here,
A marble monument!

ANGELO:

These poor informal women are no longer

DUKE VINCENTIO:
Yes, with my heart

When they pay homage to this simple peasant.

Could well soothe the overly happy spleen
Which would otherwise turn into extremes.

LUCENTIO:
Tranio, because for the great desire that I had
To see Padua fair, incubator of the arts,
I have arrived for fruitful Lombardy,
The pleasant garden of great Italy;
And by my father's love and departure, I am armed
With his good will and your good company,
My faithful servant, well approved in all,
Here, let's breathe and perhaps establish ourselves
A journey of learning and ingenious study.
Pisa is renowned for its serious citizens
Gave me my being and my father first,
A merchant with large traffic across the world,
Vincetino comes from Bentivolii.
Vincetino's son grew up in Florence
He will become at the service of all the hopes conceived,
To adorn his fortune with his virtuous acts:
And so, Tranio, during the time I study,
Virtue and this part of philosophy
Will I apply this treat of happiness
Under specially to achieve.
Tell me what you think; because I still have Pisa
And I come to Padua, like one who leaves
A little push to plunge him into the depths
And with satiety seeks to quench his thirst.

TRANIO:
Mi perdonato, sweet master of mine,
I am affected in everything like you;
Glad you maintain your determination
To suck the sweets of sweet philosophy.
Only, good master, while we admire
This virtue and this moral discipline,
Let us neither be stoic nor stock up, I pray;
Or devote yourself to Aristotle's checks
As Ovid was a completely abjured pariah:
Refuse logic with knowledge you have
And practice rhetoric in your common speech;
Music and poetry are used to invigorate you;
Mathematics and metaphysics,
Fall towards them when you find that your stomach serves you;
No profit grows where there is no pleasure:
In short, sir, study what affects you most.

LUCENTIO:
Thank you, Tranio, you advise me well.
If, Biondello, you came ashore,
We could immediately prepare,
And take accommodation worthy of receiving
Such friends as time spent in Padua will engender.
But wait a minute: what company is this?

TRANIO:
Master, a show to welcome us to town.

BAPTIST:
Gentlemen, don't bother me any further,

What I know she is aware of:
Accept it, otherwise you are doing me wrong:
His name is Licio, born in Mantua.

BAPTIST:
You're welcome sir; and him, for your good.
But for my daughter Katharina, I know,
She is not for your turn, all the more my sorrow.

PETRUCHIO:
I see that you don't want to part with her,
Or you don't like my company.

BAPTIST:
Do not mistake yourself ; I speak but as I find.
Where are you from, sir? what can I call your name?

PETRUCHIO:
Petruchio is my name; Antonio's son,
A man well known throughout Italy.

BAPTIST:
I know him well: you are welcome for him.

GRÉMIO:
Save your story, Petruchio, I pray,
Let us also speak, we who are poor petitioners:
Baccaré! you are wonderful forward.

PETRUCHIO:
Oh, forgive me, Signor Gremio; I would gladly do it.

GRÉMIO:
I have no doubt of it, sir; but you will curse your
woo. Neighbor, this is a very grateful gift, I am
sure of that. To express the same kindness, myself,
who were kinder to you than
anyone, give you this young scholar for free,
who studied for a long time in Reims; so cunning
in Greek, Latin and other languages, like the others

accept his service.

BAPTIST:
Many thanks, Signor Gremio.
Welcome, good Cambio.
But, kind sir, it seems to me that you walk like a stranger:
may I have the audacity to know the cause of your coming?

TRANIO:
Forgive me, sir, the audacity is mine,
That, being a stranger in this city,
Make me a suitor for your daughter,
To Bianca, beautiful and virtuous.
And your firm resolve is not unknown to me,
In older sister's preference.
This freedom is all I ask for,
That, knowing my parentage,
I may have welcomed among the others who court
And free access and favor like the rest:
And, for the education of your daughters,
I tune here a simple instrument,
And this little package of Greek and Latin books:
If you accept them, then their value is great.

BAPTIST:
Lucentio is your name; where do I pray from?

TRANIO:
From Pisa, sir; son of Vincentio.

BAPTIST:
A powerful man from Pisa; compared with
I know him well: you’re welcome, sir,
Take the lute, and you the books;
You will go see your students later.
Holla, inside!
Sirrah, lead these gentlemen
To my daughters; and tell them both,
They are their tutors: tell them to make good use of them.
We will go for a little walk in the orchard,
And then dinner. You are welcome to pass through,
And so I beg you all to think for yourselves.

PETRUCHIO:
Lord Baptista, my affairs require haste,
And every day I can't come courting.
You knew my father well, and in him I,
Remained sole heir of all his lands and property,
What I improved rather than reduced:
So tell me, if I receive your daughter's love,
What dowry will I have with her as my wife?

BAPTIST:
After my death, half of my lands,
And in possession of twenty thousand crowns.

PETRUCHIO:
And, against this dowry, I will assure him
Her widowhood, whether she survives me,
In all my land and leases whatever they may be:
Let specialties emerge between us,
These alliances can be respected by one side or the other.

BAPTIST:
Yes, when the special thing is well obtained,
That is to say his love; because it is everything in everything.

PETRUCHIO:
Well, it's nothing: for I tell you, father,
I am as peremptory as she is proud of spirit;
And where two raging fires meet
They consume the thing that fuels their fury:
Even if the small fire grows with little wind,
However, extreme gusts put out the fire and everything:
Thus I am towards her and thus she yields to me;
Because I'm tough and I don't court like a baby.

BAPTIST:
Well, may you court, and blessed be your speed!
But be prepared for a few unfortunate words.

PETRUCHIO:
Yes, to the proof; as the mountains are for the winds,
It doesn't shake, even though they blow perpetually.

BAPTIST:
Well, my friend! why are you so pale?

HORTENSIO:
Out of fear, I promise, if I look pale.

BAPTIST:
What, will my daughter turn out to be a good musician?

HORTENSIO:
I think she will become a soldier sooner
Iron can hold with her, but never the lute.

BAPTIST:
Why, then you can't make her play the lute?

HORTENSIO:
Why no ; because she broke my lute.
I did it but I told her she had the wrong frets,
And she bowed her hand to teach him to play with her fingers;
When, with a most impatient diabolical spirit,
“Frets, what do you call that?” " she says ; 'I'm going to fume
with them:'
And, with this word, she hit me on the head,
And through the instrument my dough made its way;
And there I stood amazed for a moment,
As on a pillory, looking through the lute;
While she called me a naughty fiddler
And Jack trembling; with twenty such vile terms,
Just like she had studied to abuse me.

PETRUCHIO:
Now, in the world, she is a vigorous girl;
I love him ten times more than ever:
Oh, how I want to chat with her!

BAPTIST:
Well, come with me and don't be so taken aback:
Carry out the practice with my youngest daughter;
She is willing to learn and grateful for good luck.
Signor Petruchio, will you accompany us,
Where should I send you my daughter Kate?

PETRUCHIO:
I pray that you do.
I will assist him here,
And court her with a little enthusiasm when she comes.
Say she moans; why then I will tell him clearly
She sings as sweetly as a nightingale:
Say she frowns, I'll say she looks as fair
Like morning roses newly washed by dew:
Say that she is mute and will not say a word;
Then I will salute his volubility,
And say she utters piercing eloquence:
If she asks me to pack, I'll thank her,
As if she asked me to stay with her for a week:
If she refuses to marry, I will long for this day
When will I apply for banns and when will I get married?
But here she comes; and now, Petruchio, speaks.
Hello, Kate; for that is your name, I hear.

CATHERINE:
Well, you heard, but something hard to hear:
They call me Katharina and talk about me.

PETRUCHIO:
You lie with faith; because your name is simply Kate,
And the beautiful Kate and sometimes the cursed Kate;
But Kate, the prettiest Kate in Christendom
Kate from Kate Hall, my super-delicate Kate,
For the treats are all Kates, and so, Kate,
Take this from me, Kate, my consolation;
Hearing your sweetness praised in every city,
Your virtues spoke and your beauty resonated,
Yet not so deeply that it belongs to you,
I myself am moved to court you for my wife.

CATHERINE:
Moved! in time: leave the one who brought you here
Get away from here: I knew you at the beginning
You were mobile.

PETRUCHIO:
Why, what is furniture?

CATHERINE:
A common stool.

PETRUCHIO:
You touched him: come and sit on me.

CATHERINE:
Asses are made to endure, and so are you.

PETRUCHIO:
Women are made to endure, and so are you.

CATHERINE:
There's no jade like you, if you mean me.

PETRUCHIO:
Alas! good Kate, I will not burden you;
Because, knowing you are young and light...

CATHERINE:
Too light for a man like you to catch;
And yet as heavy as my weight should be.

PETRUCHIO:
Should be! should--buzz!

CATHERINE:
Well ta'en, and like a buzzard.

PETRUCHIO:
O slow-winged turtle! will a buzzard take you away?

CATHERINE:
Yes, for a turtle, like he takes a buzzard.

PETRUCHIO:
Come, come, wasp; My goodness, you are too angry.

CATHERINE:
If I am naughty, beware of my sting.

PETRUCHIO:
My remedy then is to tear it out.

CATHERINE:
Yes, if that fool could find him where he is,

PETRUCHIO:
Who doesn't know where a wasp goes
carry your sting? In his tail.

CATHERINE:
In his language.

PETRUCHIO:
Which language ?

CATHERINE:
To you, if you talk about tails: and then goodbye.

PETRUCHIO:
What, with my tongue in your cock? no, come back,
Good Kate; I am a gentleman.

CATHERINE:
That, I'm going to try.

PETRUCHIO:
I swear I'll handcuff you if you hit again.

CATHERINE:
So may you lose your arms:
If you hit me, you are not a gentleman;
And if there is no gentleman, why then no weapons.

PETRUCHIO:
A herald, Kate? Oh, put me in your books!

CATHERINE:
What is your badge? a strong one?

PETRUCHIO:
A rooster without a comb, so Kate will be my hen.

CATHERINE:
No cock of mine; you too sing like a chicken.

PETRUCHIO:
No, come, Kate, come; you must not look so sour.

CATHERINE:
It's my fashion when I see a crab.

PETRUCHIO:
Well, there's no crab here; and therefore does not look sour.

CATHERINE:
There are, there are.

PETRUCHIO:
So show it to me.

CATHERINE:
If I had a drink, I would.

PETRUCHIO:
What, you mean my face?

CATHERINE:
Well intended for one so young.

PETRUCHIO:
Now, by Saint George, I'm too young for you.

CATHERINE:
And yet you are withered.

PETRUCHIO:
It's with concern.

CATHERINE:
I do not care.

PETRUCHIO:
No, listen to yourself, Kate: the truth is, you don't get away with it.

CATHERINE:
I irritate you, if I delay: let me go.

PETRUCHIO:
No, not at all: I find you rather gentle.
I was told that you were rough, shy and sullen,

Because you are pleasant, playful, temporarily courteous,
But slow to speak, but sweet as spring flowers:
You can't frown, you can't look askance,
Nor bite my lip, like angry girls would,
Nor do you enjoy being angry while speaking,
But you gently entertain your suitors,
With a gentle, gentle and affable lecture.
Why is the world reporting that Kate has a limp?
O slanderous world! Kate likes the hazel twig
Is straight and thin and also brown in color
Like hazelnuts and sweeter than the stones.
Oh, let me see you walk: you don't stop.

CATHERINE:
Go, fool, and whoever you obey.

PETRUCHIO:
Has Dian become a grove

Oh, be Dian, and let her be Kate;
And then let Kate be chaste and Dian sporty!

CATHERINE:
Where did you study all this beautiful speech?

PETRUCHIO:
It's improvised, from my maternal spirit.

CATHERINE:
A witty mother! without other his son.

PETRUCHIO:
Am I not wise?

CATHERINE:
Yes; keep you warm.

PETRUCHIO:
Get married, so I mean, sweet Katharina, in your bed:

Now, Kate, I am a husband to you;

Your beauty, which makes me love you,
You must not be married to any other man than me;

Here is your father: never deny;
I must and will have Katharina for my wife.

How, but well, sir? how but good?
There was no way I could accelerate badly.

Call me my daughter? now I promise you

A crazy thug and a swearing Jack,
This thinks with oath to face the matter.

Father, so it is: you yourself and the whole world,

Sunday is the wedding day.

CATHERINE:
I'll see you hanged on Sunday first.

Listen, Petruchio; she says she will see you

TRANIO:
Is it your speeding ticket? no, then, good night, our part!

PETRUCHIO:
Be patient, gentlemen; I choose it for myself:

It's a deal between the two of us, being alone,

I tell you, it's incredible to believe

She clung to my neck; and kiss after kiss

In the blink of an eye, she won me over to her love.
O you are novices! it's a world to see,
How tame it is, when men and women are alone,

To buy clothes for the wedding day.
Prepare the feast, father, and invite the guests;
I will be sure that my Katharina will be fine.

BAPTIST:
I don't know what to say: but give me your hands;

GRÉMIO:
Amen, we say: we will be witnesses.

Father, wife and gentlemen, farewell;

GRÉMIO:
Has a match ever been applauded so suddenly?

“It was a commodity you were worried about:

The gain I am looking for is calm in the match.

Without a doubt, he had a quiet take.

And I'm one of those who love Bianca more

Young, you can't love as dearly as I do.

Graybeard, your love is frozen.

GRÉMIO:

Boss, step back: it’s age that feeds.

TRANIO:
But youth in the eyes of women who flourishes.

First, as you know, my house in the city

TRANIO:
This “only” is welcome. Sir, list me:
I am the heir and only son of my father:
If I can have your daughter as my wife,

What, did I pinch you, Signor Gremio?

Two thousand ducats per year of land!
My land doesn't represent much in total:

What, did I choke you with an argosy?

TRANIO:
Gremio, we know that my father is no less

GRÉMIO:
No, I offered everything, I have no more;

Well, then the servant is mine from the whole world,

BAPTIST:

TRANIO:
It's just a refrain: he's old, I'm young.

GRÉMIO:
And can't young men die as well as old men?

BAPTIST:
Well, gentlemen,
I am thus resolved: next Sunday you know

Now, next Sunday, Bianca
Be your wife, if you have this assurance;
Otherwise, Signor Gremio:

GRÉMIO:
Farewell, good neighbor.
Now I no longer fear you:
Sirrah young player, your father was a fool

An old Italian fox isn't so nice, boy.

TRANIO:
Revenge on your withered and artful skin!
Yet I faced him with a ten card.

And it's a wonder: fathers generally

Where did we last go?

'Hic ibat Simois; hic is Sigeia tellus;

Build them.

wearing my port, "celsa senis", so that we can
trick the old pants.

Madam, my instrument is in tune.

Spit in the hole, man, and tune again.

Servant:

BAPTIST:

Morning dawns, it's time for us to be at church.

Trembled and shaken; why, he knocked and swore,

Having no other reason
But his beard has become thin and hungry

Listen, listen! I hear the minstrels playing.

As with meat, an undeserved fault

This is one way to kill a woman with kindness;
And so I will repress his crazy and stubborn humor.
He who knows best how to tame a shrew,

The foulest fortune belongs to me, and that is an end.

BAPTIST:
Now, on my vacation, here is Katharina!

CATHERINE:
What is your will, sir, that you send for me?

PETRUCHIO:
Where is your sister and Hortensio's wife?

CATHERINE:
They sit and talk by the fire in the living room.

PETRUCHIO:
Go get them here: if they refuse to come.
Throw them all the way to their husbands:
Go away, I say, and bring them straight here.

LUCENTIO:
That's a marvel, if you're talking about a marvel.

HORTENSIO:
And so it is: I wonder what this portends.

PETRUCHIO:
Getting married bodes well for peace and love and a quiet life,
And a terrible rule and a just supremacy;
And to make a long story short, what's more, it's sweet and joyful?

BAPTIST:
Now good for you, good Petruchio!
The bet you won; and I will add
For their losses, twenty thousand crowns;
Another dowry to another girl,
Because she is changed, as she had never been.

PETRUCHIO:
No, I will win my bet even better
And shows more signs of his obedience,
His newly constructed virtue and obedience.
See where she comes from and brings your rebellious women
As prisoners of her feminine persuasion.
Katharina, your cap doesn't suit you:
Take off this bauble, throw it under your feet.

Widow:
Lord, let me never have reason to sigh,
Until I was brought into such a stupid situation!

BIANCA:
Fi! what senseless duty calls you thus?

LUCENTIO:
I wish your duty were as senseless:
The wisdom of your duty, beautiful Bianca,
It has cost me a hundred crowns since dinner time.

BIANCA:
You will be even more fooled for having failed in my duty.

PETRUCHIO:
Katharina, I charge you, tell these stubborn women
What duty they have to their lords and their husbands.

Widow:
Come on, come on, you're kidding: we won't know anything about it.

PETRUCHIO:
Come on, I said; and start with her.

Widow:
She won't.

PETRUCHIO:
I say she will: and start with her first.

CATHERINE:
Fi, fi! untie this wicked and threatening front,
And do not cast contemptuous glances with these eyes,
To hurt your lord, your king, your governor:
It erases your beauty like frost bites the meadows,
Confound your fame as whirlwinds shake beautiful buds,
And in no way is he sympathetic or kind.
A troubled woman is like a troubled fountain,
Muddy, ugly, thick, devoid of beauty;
And while it is so, no one is so dry or thirsty
Will deign to sip or touch a drop.
Your husband is your lord, your life, your guardian,
Your head, your sovereign; the one who takes care of you,
And for your interview engages his body
To hard work at sea and on land,
To watch the night in the storms, the day in the cold,
While you stay warm, safe and secure at home;
And demand no other tribute from you
But love, beauty and true obedience;
Too little payment for such a large debt.
The duty that the subject owes to the prince
Even such a woman owes to her husband;
And when she is rebellious, sullen, sullen, sour,
And not obeying his honest will,
What is she, if not a dirty rebel
And a traitor without grace to his loving lord?
I'm ashamed that women are so simple
Propose war where they should kneel for peace;
Or seek rule, supremacy and influence,
When they are required to serve, love and obey.
Why are our bodies soft, weak and smooth,
Unfit for work and trouble in the world,
But let our sweet conditions and our hearts
Do we have to agree with our external parties?
Come, come, rebellious and incapable people!
My mind is as big as one of yours,
My heart as big, my reason perhaps more,
Exchanging word for word and frowning for frowning;
But now I see that our spears are only straws,
Our strength is weak, our weakness is incomparable,
It seems like the most we actually are the least.
So inflate your stomach, because it's not a boot,
And place your hands under your husband's foot:
As a sign of what duty, if he wishes,
My hand is ready; may it do him good.

PETRUCHIO:
Well, there is a girl! Come and kiss me, Kate.

LUCENTIO:
Well, go your way, old man; because you will.

VINCENTIO:
It's good hearing when the kids are around.

LUCENTIO:
But an audition is hard when women are rebellious.

PETRUCHIO:
Come on, Kate, we're going to bed.
All three of us are married, but you two are in a hurry.
It's because I won the bet, even if you hit white;
And, being a winner, may God wish you a good night!

HORTENSIO:
Now go your way; you tamed a damn shrew.

LUCENTIO:
It's amazing that, with your permission, she is tamed like this.

Boatswain:

Boatswain:

Sailors:

The king and the prince in prayer! let's help them,

SEBASTIAN:
I'm running out of patience.

GONZALO:
He will still be hanged,
Even if every drop of water swears against her

ANTONIO:
Let's all go down with the king.

Now I would give a thousand sea stadia for one

MIRANDA:
If through your art, my dear father, you have
Put the wild waters into this roar, still them.
The sky, it seems, would pour with stinking pitch,

Extinguish the fire. O, I suffered
With those I saw suffer: a brave ship,

If I was a god of power, I would
Having sunk the sea into the land or before
The good ship would have to have swallowed it and
The heavy souls in her.

PROSPERO:
To be collected:
No more astonishment: tell it to your pitiful heart
There is no harm.

MIRANDA:
Oh, woe to this day!

PROSPERO:
No problem.
I did nothing but take care of you,
Of you, my beloved, you, my daughter, who
You don't know what you are, you don't know anything
Where I come from, nor that I'm any better
That Prospero, master of a cell full of poor people,
And your father is not taller.

More to know

It's time

I have such a disposition in my art

You often

Your mother was a virtue, and

Both, both, my daughter:

MIRANDA:

PROSPERO:
My brother and your uncle, called Antonio...
Please notice me: that a brother should

Of everyone I've loved and put to him
Managing my condition; like at that time
Across all the lordships it was the first
And Prospero, the first duke, being so renowned
In dignity and for the liberal arts
Without parallel; these being all my study,
The government that I imposed on my brother
And my state became foreign, being transported
And fascinated by his secret studies. Your fake uncle...
Are you accompanying me?

MIRANDA:
Sir, with great attention.

PROSPERO:
Being once perfected how to grant suits,
How to refuse them, who to advance and who
Discard for overrun, new created
The creatures that were mine, I say, or that changed them,
Or else, they would have taken them in a new form; have both the key
Of officer and office, put all hearts in the State
What air pleased his ear; that now he was
The ivy that hid my princely trunk,
And I sucked my greenery on that. You don't participate in it.

MIRANDA:
Oh, good sir, I do.

PROSPERO:
Please notice me.
I, thus neglecting the ends of the world, all consecrated
To the closeness and improvement of my mind
With what, but being so withdrawn,
Popular overrated fare, at my fake brother
Has awakened an evil nature; and my confidence,
Like a good parent, I fathered him
A lie in its opposite as big
As my confidence was; which indeed had no limits,
Limitless confidence. He being thus lord,
Not only with what my income brought in,
But what my power might otherwise demand, as a
Who has entered into the truth, by telling it,
Made his memory such a sinner,
To credit his own lie, he believed
He was indeed the duke; out of substitution
And performing the outward face of royalty,
With all the prerogatives: hence its growing ambition...
Do you hear ?

MIRANDA:
Your story, sir, would cure deafness.

PROSPERO:
To have no screen between this role he played

Absolute Milan. Me, the poor thing, my library

He now believes me incapable; Confederates--
So dry he was for influence - with the king of Naples

Submit his crown to his crown and bend it

To the most ignoble leaning.

MIRANDA:
O heavens!

PROSPERO:
Mark its state and the event; so tell me

MIRANDA:
I should sin

Now the state.
The King of Naples, being an enemy

That is, he, instead of premises

A treacherous army raised, at midnight

Me and you crying.

MIRANDA:
Alas, for pity’s sake!

Listen a little further

MIRANDA:
Why didn't they
Does this hour destroy us?

PROSPERO:
Well asked, girl:
My story raises this question. Dear, they did not dare,
So dear the love that my people bore me, nor put up
Such a bloody mark on the company, but
With fairer colors they painted their fetid extremities.
In a few moments, they took us aboard a boat,
Take us a few leagues offshore; where they prepared
A rotten hulk of a boat, unrigged,

Instinctively, we abandoned it: there, we are hoisted,
Shout to the sea that roared towards us, sigh

We did but I didn't like it.

MIRANDA:
Alas, what a problem
Was I then for you!

PROSPERO:
Oh, a cherub
It is you who preserved me. You smiled.
Imbued with a force from heaven,
When I have covered the sea with drops full of salt,
Under my burden I groaned; who raised in me
A stomach in pain, to bear
Against what should result from it.

MIRANDA:
How did we get to land?

PROSPERO:
By divine Providence.
A little food that we had and some fresh water that
A Neapolitan nobleman, Gonzalo,
By his charity, being then named
Master of this design, gave us, with
Rich clothes, linens, fabrics and necessities,
Since then, they have resisted a lot; then, with its sweetness,
Knowing that I loved my books, he provided me
From my own library with volumes that
I hold above my duchy.

MIRANDA:
Could I

PROSPERO:
Now I get up:
Sit quietly and listen to the last of our sea sorrows.
Here, on this island, we have arrived; and here

That the other princesses can have more time
For wasted hours and not-so-careful guardians.

MIRANDA:
Thanks my God ! And now, I pray you, sir,

PROSPERO:
Know so far.
By chance, the strangest and most generous Fortune,
Now my dear lady, have my enemies
